text:
This is an awesome way to team build or hang out with friends and family. The instructors make you look like a rock star even if you have zero talent. The paintings are simple and easily customizable. 

I love that you can bring snacks and drinks for your private classes. I will definitely do this again!

I've been here for a few times, and I'm in love with this place. The menu is quite impressive, and it will seriously take more than a few minutes to read through the choices.  (The huge star in the middle of the menu can be quite distracting!). If you need a good sushi lunch place, then get the lunch special. They have an awesome deal at 3 rolls for $12, which includes either soup or salad. Guess how many choices of rolls you get to choose from? 43!!! Lots of choices to choose from, and I really digged the Pepper Tuna roll and the Alaskan roll. I had the crabmeat apple roll, but didn't care much for it.

More reasons to love this place: Service is fast and friendly, and they have LOW-sodium soy sauce. 

My challenge is to try different rolls/dishes each time I go there, except the California roll. :)

I actually had to come here twice in order to their delicious shrimp poboys. The first time was around 11:30pm on a Saturday night, but they had ran out of bread for the night. We decided to try again the next day for lunch and was able to order a shrimp poboy.

It took them about 20-30 minutes to make 10 orders of shrimp poboys, but that meant it was a perfect time to grab a frozen irish coffee from the bar. 

The shrimp poboys reminded me of vietnamese sandwiches. Same type of bread with lots of veggies, but the key ingredient is the fresh shrimp. Every time I've had shrimp poboys, the shrimp has always been fried, but this time I was pleasantly surprised to see the shrimp without batter. 

The sandwich was quite delicious although quite expensive at $14.

This is like a Denny's, in that they offer a huge variety of foods, but in no other way - it is one hundred times better than a Denny's. When you walk in you see a wall of cheesecake and you pretty much know it is going to be a fun experience. We were fortunately seated near the HDTV at the back of the restaurant as we watched the Jets fail their faces off against the Steelers - that part sucked, but even that sucking moment was still fun since we were hanging out at the diner. We were in a big group and we also were sitting right next to another big group, the Duke University fencing team. This place draws big groups in because it has a legit reputation among everyone, locals and those from far away who had a great meal here once a long long time ago.

The big guy (4u) waiter right off the bat was friendly, gracious, and funny - top notch staff here for sure. The water was not exactly refilled at a regular pace but I guess it was pretty busy. It was really hard to choose a dinner since everything sounded so good. I finally settled on the open faced Monte Cristo, longing for 'ye olden days when that deliciousness of the Monte Cristo used to be available at Bennigan's before their shenanigans shuttered their doors across the country. Penrose does not make 'yo daddy's Monte Cristo and that is not an entirely bad thing.

This is french toast as the base, two pieces and very moist and eggy. Not fried like Bennigan's. Just french toast that is AWESOME. Then meat piled on top of the french toast. Then some cheese on top of that. And a big helping of fries. The fries were solid, the good diner kind, not the shoe string or crinkle cut or that other junk places try to pass off.

I will be back for more Penrose.

I dislike the Winn Dixie chain as a whole. I think the products are overpriced and their food selection tends to focus on highly processed foods. That being said, this is probably one of the nicest Winn Dixies I've ever been to. It's always clean, it's a large store, it's right next to a basketball court and art studio, and it's down the street from my gym. The parking lot is also more shaded than most are due to the trees. So I guess if you're going to get ripped off at a Winn Dixie, get ripped off at this one.

OK I don't understand why the star ratings so far are so bad if everyone is saying they really liked the food. Maybe the ratings are from competitors?

So here is the REAL blow-by-blow breakdown of this place.

YES it is mobbed. That's because there is a HUGE HUGE HUGE pent-up demand for fast casual Mexican in Tampa, and people are flocking there. After all, let us review our options for fast Mexican food in Tampa Bay: 

1. Chipotle = Sodium-filled food, pre-cooked and later boiled in plastic bags. A digestive nightmare.

2. Tijuana Flats/Moe's = Can't really tell the difference between these crapholes; 
both are substandard Mex joints that would go out of business in California, Texas, etc.

3. Taco Bus = Tasteless food served in cardboard tortillas in a dirty restaurant.YUM!


But back to Lime Fresh:

Do not just show up. Place your order online before you head over there. When you get there, go to the back of the restaurant where the takeout cashier is. Pay for your food there, take it to a table, and eat. This took me 5 minutes. And watch everyone else wait in line for 30 minutes. I had the chicken soft tacos and my friend had the chicken cobb salad. Both were good. Both tasted fresher than any food at the above-mentioned places.
 
Lime Fresh is not the same as Moe's, Tijuana Flats or Chipotle. It is much much better. Is it the best Mexican food you have ever had? NO. Is it authentic Mexican, Cal-Mex, Tex-Mex, etc.? NO. Is it better than the fast food Mexican food in Texas, Arizona, California, etc.? NO. But is it better than Chipotle, Tijuana Flats, etc.?
YES!!!!!!!

The ingredients here are much fresher than at Chipotle and Tijuana Flats, you can taste it. (Well, let's face it, the food from Chipotle comes already cooked in plastic bags, which they later boil.) The execution with some of the meats at Lime Fresh is not there yet, but I am hopeful they will get better with that.

This place is automatically better than the above mentioned places JUST for the extensive salsa bar, which is standard in Cali, Ariz, Texas, etc. but most no one else in Tampa has. And the pico de gallo is pretty decent, as are the other salsas. The menu is extensive, the dining space is nice and huge, the online order process was seamless.

I would def. go back when it's off-peak hours.

This is not my regular Schnucks. However, whenever I am heading home from Costco and cutting down Loughborough to Hampton, I stop by for items I just cannot buy in bulk at the warehouse store for a single man. 

In my original review, which is now several years old, I complained about the produce department. Wow, things have really changed. I will now say this is one of the better produce departments in STL. It's always fresh, organized and well stocked.

I've also gotten use to the lay-out and can shop the aisles with ease. Another area that is pretty good, is the butcher counter. Give me those pork steaks for that backyard grilling. 

The staff has done a full Three-Sixty on their attitudes. Even during this pandemic when everyone seems to be on the edge, they were upbeat and positive.

While shopping during the COVID pandemic, I felt safe with all the safety precautions this store had in place. 

Will I return? - For, sure. 

When: June 4, 2020
Why: Grocery items I cannot buy in bulk.

Swamp Tour! Great driver that picked us up on-time from our hotel. Then drove us around to some parts of NOLA since we were all on time, so had some extra time. She showed us some parts of New Orleans destroyed by Hurricane Katrina. Gave us her perspective of what life was like before and after the disaster. Learned a lot from here.

The tour was great. Our swamp boat driver was great. Saw many alligators, and he got them to come really close too, enough for one to jump and ram its body into the side of our boat to reach the sausage/chicken he was feeding them. He was also interacting with the people on the boat, trying to get to know us, too!

Driver back was good, too,

Definitely a great tour. I highly recommend!

I love all my Philly Ritzes. I can always count on at least one of them to be showing a film that I want to see. More often than not Ritz East, Ritz at the Bourse and Ritz 5 are ALL featuring films on my "wanna see" list.

I love independent films the most. I love foreign films and art joints. Here's where you find em in Filmadelphia (I'm the worst). Ritz East is well-maintained, clean and comfortable. I am a fan.

 I love going to see films and then being able to ramble incessantly with friends willing or otherwise about what we've seen. Judging by the thin-lipped smiles and glazed over expressions on their faces, I'm sure that I take it to an insufferable level; as is my way. Maybe it's just that I keep repeating the word, "film," over and over. I really geek over this stuff. 

One of my favorite things in Philly life is to hatch a plan where we go catch what's playing at one of the Ritzes, then go for a drink/meal/bite along our walking way to another nearby Ritz, another movie. 

How bout a movie-meal crawl? For when you're feelin like you deserve some fun and special treatment. It's a nice little movie-meal-movie-meal cycle. Double double feature, get me?

I do love all my Ritzes, and this one is a beaute.

If you are in the French Quarter and you have had your fill of Po Boy's and Gumbo and you are just craving some fresh fruit Rouses is your place. It was refreshing to come here and see such a selection of fresh fruit and other healthy items. Of course, they have a great selection of beers, so either way your bases are covered.  Rouses is centrally located and is walking distance to any French Market hotel or B&B.

As a fro-yo fan, I wanted to try this place for a long time. Finally, I stopped in here for dessert. The selection of yogurt flavours was decent, and I combined plain with chocolate and raspberry. The chocolate was not all that rich, but the other two flavours were good. I think the selection of toppings is the biggest of all of the different fro-yo places I have tried. They even line the wall. Most of the cereals are in hanging containers that you have to release with a lever, and the stuff comes out FAST! I would prefer everything just be in bins to scoop out, because I ended up with far more Lucky Charms than I intended. The fruit looked fresh, and there was lots of candies and nuts. I only wish everything was labelled. Price-wise Twisted Yogurt is comparable with other fro-yo chains, and I wish it was not so out of my way to visit more often.

Nice diner. I was at a conference in Philly this pas weekend, by the airport, and there's no good food immediately near the hotel row. A group of us decided to drive out to the Penrose diner so we could all get what we wanted. 

I had a cheesesteak, a solid choice. One friend had a Chicken Caesar salad, one had a pasta dish,  one had a Turkey Club, and one had eggs benedict. Everyone was happy with their choices. Those of us who had fries had to put up with our friends swiping them off of our plates because they were delicious.

Service was excellent. The waitress went out of her way to accommodate everyone, and she was busy with many tables, so she's a real professional. Going here was a much better choice than the places near our hotel and was worth the drive.

Any time I bring someone to STL I bring them to this Ted Drewes.  It is by far the best custard EVER!!!!  It's the thickest, richest, best custard  known to man kind!

I don't think I can add anything that anyone else hasn't already said!
But I am glad I don't live in the area I would be huge!
My first Yogurtland and I liked it better than all the other Yogurt places out there.  Great flavors, toppings, and creamy yummy yogurt!
Umm, cashiers are NOT nice, I retract!  Zero stars for you, Kmart.

kickass ice cream that all tastes home-made.  In a MMMMMMMGOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOD way.

no sissy flavors- everything is spiced full force.

the chocolate cherry cordial icecream burned and iced my throat and tummy all the way down.  I always tip the kids behind the counter 100 percent of my total, if only so they dont notice my flavor erection as i giggle out the door.

Maybe this is going to sound mean, but I don't care: The South is not ready for a place like Charcoals. 

Places like this are everywhere in California. If this place was by my house, I would eat there every week. $20 for a burger with chips is not outrageous. I got a bison burger with 2 kinds of cheese, 2 kinds of bacon & basil & that's what it came to. Yeah, it took a little while to come out. That's what happens when food is cooked to order. I did not mind the wait. Our food was delicious. I have absolutely zero complaints. Neither did the rest of our party. I only wish this place was not 1800 miles from my home.

This was my first visit to the French Quarter and it was nice to have a market close by. The prices are a little high, but it is the only full size market in the quarter.  My first stop in, I was able to find everything I needed for breakfast in the morning.  The cashier was really sweet!  I wish I remembered her name.  However, on my second visit, just to pick up a gallon of water, something shady happened...

Now, maybe it was an honest mistake, but I had been drinking and was feeling pretty good.  The cashier was friendly.  My water was under $2 and I gave her a twenty.  I watched her grab my change, but when she handed it to me, she just said "thank you."  Luckily I took a look and counted, because $10 was missing.  I hadn't left the lane and just turned to her and said "I gave you a twenty" (it was even on the receipt).  She apologized and said she thought she gave the correct change.  She couldn't open her drawer because she rang the next person up.  

But funny thing, when she handed me my ten, she wouldn't look me in the eye....

So I'm just going to say, BEWARE...count your change if you pay cash or use a credit card!

As soon as we checked into our hotel across the street, we came here to unwind, listen to live music, and then to cafe beignet for snacks, which is located in the back of Musical Legends Park
Live music was great! 
Beignets were good and also the iced cafe they have an assortment of sandwiches, appetizers...
This place has a line at night (closed Tues and Wed) 
Nice place to geta quick bite or order and hang out to listen to music

What a huge improvement over the previous incarnation. 

AND: Bathrooms! New, clean bathrooms! 

The terraced seating is well done, the patio that overlooks the park and river nicely designed and proportioned. There is a dog park that seems quite popular, although it seems to be where the Museum folks told me they would be expanding at some point in the future. (The museum is still way to freaking small to be useful, honestly)

The viewshed from Ashley is far improved as well. So many wins.

Now: If they'll finally restore Kiley Park with its crepe myrtles back to what its supposed to be, it will be complete.

BONUS: Read the rules for the play fountain - HILARIOUS

I've only had lunch here, but each time the food has been really good.  The manager is also a really nice guy, we talk every time I stop by. The restaurant is a decent size with booths lined up along the walls and some tables in the middle. I've eaten in the dining room a couple of times, but I usually just get a falafel to-go.

One of the better Mexican inspired restaurants in the city. The portions were very big and the veggies were very fresh. The house margarita was also very delicious. I'm usually afraid of those house, well liquor, mixed drinks but this one didn't leave me disappointed. I also appreciated them allowing me to create my own burrito since I have a restricted diet.

I am pizza... Pizza is me!!!! That being said, this place gets it all the way right. $7.95 plus tax gets you a whole pizza pie, all to yourself. The menu calls for the standard for $5 & some change; or $7.95 to build your own. 

I crafted my own with Garlic Basil as the base, ALLLLLLLLLL the cheeses in the building, add in a few jalapenos & HAPPY HAPPY AM I!!!! Then to top it off, literally and figuratively, at the end, I added oil and balsamic vinaigrette drizzle to my pizza once it edited the oven... OMG!!!! Sheesh!!! My only disappointment was that I couldn't eat it all in one setting.  

For my beverage of choice, I opted against the water, soda, coconut water, juices options... Bring on the NOLA Beer on tap. It was my first time trying it annnnnnnnnnd I was pleased. 

Start to finish, this process took about 12 minutes. That's novel for pizza making. What's the secret? Is it the massive fire oven? Or the thin, flaky, buttery crust? Or the super efficient restaurant workers? Idk, whatever the reason, it happened and that made the difference. 

The only draw back for THIS location, is the lack of parking. Truly this location caters to the CBD/downtown crowd and that's super cool. And since I know parking is the challenge I will face, I'll be prepared for it HEAD FIRST. And speaking about head first... Did I mention there's an option to call ahead??? I saw it, it happens and then so now BLAZE has been added to my list of places for one of my infamous #stickandmovecapers!!!! Great, Great, Great!!!!

Admittedly not the best first impression. I walked in to find a harried scene: tables were littered with plates, napkins and other debris; tables were out of sort; and the staff behind the counter were excitedly talking at one another (I'm neglecting to call it 'shouting'). In the midst of all of this, the manager/owner/woman in charge, took a deep breath, smiled, welcomed me in Spanish and English, and asked if I was eating in or needed to take my order to go.

'To go.'

I'd studied the menu online (well, pictures of) but it looks like those menus may be out of date. The menu I looked at was smaller and had been edited down. No matter, I had an idea of what I wanted: tacos and a papusa. There was a 3 for $4 taco deal* I was going to take advantage of and papusas are always a good idea. I ordered... and waited. In the time I waited, the tables weren't bused, a woman came in with a slightly unruly child to pick up a take out order, the TV showed various barely clothed men and women writhing about Miami Beach, and an older man entered sat down, got annoyed at the wait time, waved his hands, banged on the table and shouted 'Estoy aqui!' I just sat there. After more waiting (and more TV jiggling) my order was finally ready. When I got up to pay for it, the woman put her hands together and thanked me for my patience. My annoyance melted away then and there. Chismes is a small space, packed with seating. She was, obviously, in the weeds and doing several jobs at once. Sometimes all the mierda hits the fan at once. She acknowledged it and thanked me. Done. I wasn't going to belabor her agony. Besides, my food smelled great.

I got home and tore into my tacos. Ridiculous. So so good. Seasoned, shredded meat, cilantro and onion never tasted so good. Add in fresh lime and Chismes' thick, green hot sauce and you have a party. The papusa came with curtido (good). The texture/consistency of the papusa was a bit tough and off-putting but I don't know if that's because I ordered a Salvadoran dish at a Mexican place. It wasn't terrible but didn't top the papusas at my local fave Salvadoran spot. The curtido didn't have the vinegar-y kick I was looking for, so I just added some green sauce and kept it moving. For as tough as the papusa was, the inner beans and cheese were very good. I'd return to Chismes but I am sticking to getting my food to go. 

*Seriously: why do you pay so much for tacos. You know you're ripping yourself off, right?

mmmm...a choc-work orange, so good.  Flavors to please everyone in the family from the gourmand to the 6 year old.  

This ice cream parlor does traditional bar service in the location of the original McKenzie's Bakery location (and they've left the old neon sign earning eternal love from many New Orleanians).

Solid standard Chinese. And they deliver. I ordered chicken and broccoli one weekend when I had the craving but didn't want to eat anything too heavy. Lots of tasty white meat (nothing scary), and lots of slightly crunchy broccoli (just the way I like it). The sauce wasn't too heavy and the rice was perfectly cooked. I also liked the wonton soup. Definitely interested in giving this place another shot sometime soon!

I visited this location when it was "Liberities" and I wasn't impressed.  When Bourbon & Branch arrived - stopped in for Happy Hour and I liked the vibe.  I cam back recently to try the food and was impressed.  I had the Asian Wings,  Beer mac and cheese and friends had burgers.  We all were pleased with the quality of food and beer selection.  After speaking with the bartender, looks like they have a comedy night and it's getting popular nice venue for local acts.  

Politeness/Professionalism=Great
Food=Good
Service=Wait time on food could improve.
Drinks=Consistently Good

It's not everyday you find yourself in New Orleans on a bayou tour. But when you do, make sure it's Cajun Encounters Tour Company. 

There's something to be said for the brave folks that tour the bayou in early August. When humidity and the ambient temperature are about the same there's only so much you can do. But making the most of the experience with a smile and good attitude will never do you wrong. 

I spent a good month researching all the things to do on our NOLA bday trip. Every day we filled it with things to do, places to be, and foods to eat. After much research I found Cajun Encounters was an absolute necessity. 

First, know that the bayou isn't anywhere near NOLA. You'll board a nice bus that will transport you about 40 minutes north/north-east of NOLA to the bayou. From there you'll wait some more. By the time you return to your hotel it will be well into the late afternoon. So expect that this will take a good chunk of your day. 

With that said, make time for this experience. I can't guarantee you'll have a similar experience to ours as every guide is unique in their presentation. But it'll be fun for sure. 

I was super pleased with our tour guide (his name escapes me) but he was a retired conservation officer. His tour was fantastic - we learned about the flora, fauna and all kinds of conservation efforts. No cheap photo ops with hot dogs on a stick here. I appreciated his natural approach to the tour! We saw plenty of gators in their natural habitat which (trust me) was more than enjoyable. 

The only thing that could have made this experience even better was if they didn't cram so many folks into the boats. We had several large people and packing 20-something guests into these tin cans (shoulder-to-shoulder) meant very little air-flow. And of course, very little opportunity to social distance. I would have paid double for half the number of people. 

Definitely take the weather into account. Bring your camera. And enjoy!

For some reason, people love this little Italian eatery.

It is wicked small, and can get loud. But such makes a great Italian BYOB eatery's atmosphere.

The reason it gets 3 stars from me was the food. It wasn't spectacular Italian at all. Actually there is another reason: service. The wait is usually ridiculous (make reservations) and the servers are kinda cold and unfriendly. And if you are in an aisle seat, prepared to get bumped by the servers going in and out of the kitchen!

Fried green tomato and shrimp.

It was a deliscious dish to say the least. The service was quite nice and prompt. I came here with my neighbor and we sat at the bar. The experience was nothing special, but that should take nothing away from your decision on stopping on in for a meal.

The ambiance is very chill, fitting for its location just off of City Park's entrance. There's outdoor seating for nicer days, i believe there are heaters as well. The place was bubbling with business the entire time and rightfully so, everything I saw coming out of the kitchen looked like something to mark down to try later.

This little section of Esplanade is one that I don't frequent, but i need to change that. There are too many places to grub around here, plus I dig the vibe of the area.

We spent last evening in Hyde Park, including a visit to Goody's.  It's a beautiful shop in a great location, and it smells fantastic.  It's also very roomy with outdoor seating.

My husband got a cup of chocolate ice cream to share with our sons and I tried a caramel shake.  Upon his first bite, my husband was amazed at how chocolate-y his chocolate ice cream tasted.  It was very rich and creamy. My shake was a little too rich, not that it's a bad thing.  I was just full from dinner.  It could have used a little more caramel in it because it was mixed with vanilla bean ice cream that was as vanilla bean-y as my husband's chocolate ice cream was chocolate-y and overwhelmed the caramel.  

I find it sadly amusing that another reviewer said the flavors were off.  It's made from natural ingredients. Some people are so used to the synthetic stuff, they don't know what real food tastes like.The ice cream is higher in price due to the quality of ingredients but on par with chains like Ben & Jerry's.  It's very rich and filling so you definitely get your money's worth.

I also took some gourmet chocolate home: a Bailey's Irish cream truffle, a Kahlua and cream truffle, a French chocolate velvet, a butterscotch velvet and a salted milk chocolate caramel. Everything was great.

The shop also carries Ty's line of beanie boos and plush animals to peruse while you wait for your order.

Let's me start by saying, I love ice cream.   Love, love, love ice cream. 

So it's after 10pm and I'm in town just for a few hours. I had a great dinner now I need dessert. So YELP has a few suggestions but this one was nearby.

It's a local hangout which gets pretty crowded. It's late but this little place is packed. I'm talking at least 30 people hanging out.  

I tried a couple of samples before deciding on the Cream Cheese and Mexican hot chocolate ice cream in my sundae with butterfinger and was ready!!  The cashier warned me to the Mexican Hot had Cayenne pepper in it and I said "I hope so"!! 

Best sundae ever!! It was creamy, the scoops were big and I tried, really I did but I couldn't finish all of it. So I owe it to myself to go back again for more ice cream from this little gem.

Palace of Asia has been my favorite place for Indian food since my mother discovered it about six years ago. I live in Phoenix now and the choices for good Indian food are very limited, so whenever I'm back in town I make sure my mom and I go for a dinner. We went on a Wednesday and it turned out to be buffet night, which is perfect since we can get to try out new dishes. 

Chicken Tikka Masala: excellent, one of the best I've had
Lamb Kadhai: very good, tender juicy lamb
Vegetable and Potli Samosas: awesome
Navratan Korma: a new vegetable dish for me. loved it, blown away by it even.
Kashmiri Dum Aloo: potatoes filled with cheese in a cream sauce. You don't even have to ask if  these are amazing. you already know they are.
Mutter Panir: really good
Daal Makhani: black beans and lentils in cream, I recommend if eating from buffet.

Delicious, served hot Garlic Naan.

This tip may make you feel like an old person, but go a little early, like around 5:30-6pm.  The first round of buffet items are brought out around then for dinner, so you know they are fresh and untouched. 

I don't typically get dessert at an Indian restaurant, but since they offer it in the buffet I figured I'd give it a shot. I liked the Gulab Jaman (milk and cheese balls dipped in syrup), but not a must have next time. The rice pudding was ok, a little too runny for my liking.  

Overall, one of my all time favorite Indian restaurants and one of my all time favorite south NJ restaurants.

Whoever let this baby grace the streets of Philadelphia deserves a hand job, and a good one. It really has kicked everything else out of the water (where the hell did I get that expression). In any case, I ordered the Sagg Paneer which featured a smooth densely flavorful spinach curry and buttery paneer. My friend got a chickpea dish which wasn't quite as good, but it's hard to beat Sagg Paneer. The atmosphere was also nice, not a hole in the wall feel, the nann was floury, and the service was attentive.

So hopefully that person has gotten a hand job by now because I certainly got enough foodgasms while eating at his/her restaurant. Congrats!

FINALLY I can say I've been to Nada.  It took me long enough!

I echo many other reviews in saying that the space is beautiful.  It's so swanky and vibrant inside in both parts of the restaurant.  As for the food, I think you could have quite the taco party with all of the options Nada has.  I've had bites of the Hongos and Senor Mu Shu, and I'd recommend both to anyone.  There's also the lunchtime Taco Lunch Box, which includes a side and a doughnut.  I say include the Santa Fe cowboy beans if you're going to go that route.

My experience revealed that I need to return to Nada with an army of friends because I have a feeling it will be nada problem to handle a large group.

I ordered what almost seemed like a big ok sampler plate. Got to try a little bit of everything and I definitely wasn't disappointed. I like having variety so I was happy to know I got to order a little bit of everything I wanted all in one plate. It came with a taco, an enchilada, chile relleno, rice and beans. I didn't finish everything but the food was good. I don't have any complaints about it. My friend ordered the torta and swore it was like the best he's ever had. 

Would I return? I probably would, if I had the hankering for Mexican food.

Good affordable eat in Chinatown. Food is delicious. Somewhat smaller portion compared to other restaurants but it's okay. Lots of good food to order. I recommend trying Fook's noodles to start. The stir fry water spinach in fermented tofu is one of the best I've had. Highly recommend coming here.

For nearly a year, I've avoided sweets but knew that one day I will have a craving that will need to be satisfied. I'm glad when that time came, I've already done my research and read so much great things about Mr. Wizard's that the choice was obvious.

My first of a few visits (~4 this year so far since I really don't want to overdo it), I tried their Hawaiian concrete with yogurt. I did get brave and tried their custard but quickly regretted the sinful decision. I do have to say that their custard was really creamy, thick, and delicious. But nowadays, I am happy and satisfied with my occasional visit to pick up some yogurt concrete with coconut flakes, pecans, bananas and pineapple chunks.

Service has always been quick and the staff have always been friendly. I have noticed though when I've passed by several times that the place does get extremely busy and there is barely enough parking for everyone! It's that good.

I am required by law to state that, even living in Chicago, where our pizza is better than your pizza, I still crave Pizza Hut once in a while. So I'm equal opportunity, if not the shame of my city. 

Black Thorn was advertised to me as "the best pizza in St. Louis," and while it's a whole lot better than Imo's (Good lord, is anything worse than Imo's?) I think there's still room for something better. No, I don't know what it is? But I don't think Black Thorn is unimpeachable at the top. 

Yes, the place is a dive - as a friend said, there might be some "deferred maintenance." But it didn't reek of smoke too badly, so I have no problem with it. Our pizza was a green pepper and mushroom, with a side of garlic bread - absolutely plenty to serve three people, probably could have served 5, really. The pizza itself isn't as much thick crust as it is stuffed - the pie was ordered on my behalf by the friends I was with, so maybe I missed something, but I wouldn't consider this to be exactly like the Malnati's/Giordano's/Gino's East thick crust pizza, but more like thin crusts with cheese and toppings in between, then more cheese and toppings on top. Not a lot of sauce - we got a "side" of sauce, which was literally just cold red sauce, and awfully sweet red sauce at that. Might have been better warm, but it didn't add much. The pizza was solid. Nothing bad here, worth going back. But maybe over-hyped for me. 

Worth mentioning that we went on a Saturday, and it was not that packed...there was easy nearby street parking, and we got a table within minutes, but I believe the order was called in about 45 minutes before we arrived, and we waited for maybe 15-20 minutes after we showed up before our order came out. If you're interested in trying, I would definitely call ahead, especially if you think it might be busy.

They have amazing wings here! They're pretty big in size and always delicious. I also love the chips they serve with a ranch sauce on the side. Those are the bomb! Once I stopped eating chicken though, I sadly, had no reason to return. I'm just not a huge fan of their salads. I recall thinking they were bland and "nothing special". I'd say Eats American Grill is a great place to go for a low- key dinner or place to watch sports. The waitresses are nice here as well! It's a small restaurant but I've never had to wait to sit and the parking lot is also small, but I've never had a problem finding a spot. enjoy! xo

Every once in awhile, the stars align perfectly and the ideal dining experience is delivered. Such was my recent experience at The Prime Rib.

I have struggled a bit in coming up with an adjective to describe the ambience. I've settled on "cool elegance" based on the combination of soft piano music (the grand piano has a clear cover - really cool), dark woods, mirrors, leopard print carpet, large floral booths, and huge floral displays in beautiful large vases. I felt in a way like I was stepping back in time, wondering if Bing Crosby or Frank Sinatra ever dined in an atmosphere like this. Table settings were simple - white tablecloths, small plate, appropriate crystal - very nice.

Service was impeccable as well, as servers were attentive but not hovering. They know their menu and offer great insight into the wine selections as well. There were four of us, and I was the only red wine drinker of the group so I opted for a Malbec by the glass. I was pleased with the "by the glass" selection, by the way - something that many restaurants seem to ignore.

My fare for the evening began with escargots - tender and tasty snails with mushroom caps in a wonderful garlic butter - easily some of the best I've ever enjoyed. My signature cut Prime Rib was a perfect medium rare and was accompanied by freshly grated horseradish. Sides for our table included steak fries, brussels sprouts, and sautéed spinach with garlic. All were delicious (I'm taking my boss's word on the brussels sprouts - I just can't go there).

Succinctly stated, this is why I so enjoy fine dining. And I can't wait to return.

I have had the displeasure of eating here twice and was disappointed both times.  The pompous asswipe attitude of the staff which I thought was just an abnormal thing is clearly the norm.  The food was border line Uneatable the last time I Ed there.

You don't have to mess with food that much. Just give me a frickin monk fish dude. Your poached egg gave me awful diarrhea.  Your rigatoni wasn't bad.  But I had to let my wife eat it.  So I had to order the crappy egg and it gave me diarrhea.  

Any way, they change the dishes daily which means the staff still sucks and they serve different dishes.  

I would go to a different BYOB in Philadelphia.

I do most of my shopping at Costco, but occasionally I go to Kmart for that one thing, and every single time I leave feeling exasperated.  It is not at all surprising that Sears/Kmart are in big trouble financially.  The shopping center is confusing and could really use a few stop signs here and there to improve traffic flows and safety.  The store is disorganized and not well lit.  You often find an item with no price tag anywhere.  Was it suppose to be here or was this lonely object randomly placed here by employees or shoppers?  Who knows?  There are a lot of stuff on shelves/racks in the middle of the aisles. There is no logic in how the items are organized.   Its like a thrift shop, the dollar store, or a garage sale.   The lines are long and the cashiers move like molasses.  Just think of the efficiency you see at Costco, and now picture the exact opposite happening at Kmart.  

The so call shop your way reward system is just more trouble than it is worth.  If you have credit in the account, It is not automatically credited toward your purchase.  You have to ask everytime and you have to input a pin number just to use it.  Anyone remember that?  I don't think so since no sane individual would regularly subject herself to the Kmart shopping experience.  

Once, I even had a cashier who specifically ask me if I want to know how much is in my rewards account.  She then looked it up and told me the number, something like 15 cents.  When I looked at my receipt later, the credit was not applied to my purchase.  Well, why the hell did you go through all that trouble if it is not going toward my purchase?  Oh yeah, she would need the stupid pin number to use it.  Along with the question of "would you like me to see how much is in your account?", this particularly friendly cashier also had a repertoire of other questionnaires.  "Would you like the receipt printed or emailed?", "Would you like just the receipt or the receipt with all the coupons?", "Would you like to donate to St. Jude?", "Would you like to apply for a credit card?", "Would you like this in a bag?"...Gahh, maybe that's why the line moves like molasses.
Great ShopRite. It's smaller than the others in the area, but has the same great choices. Deli is fast, and fresh. Great produce section as well.

During a recent trip to Louisiana, my son and I visited this Fleming's location.  We shared the fixed price menu of Filet with Lobster Tail.  It was served with a grilled scallop small appetizer as well as a salad.  The price was $50 and it was definitely enough for my son and me to share.  The bread was fresh and accompanied by a delicious butter as well as crab spread.  This location does offer Happy Hour, but only for patrons that sit in the bar.  If I return to this city, I'd love to visit this Fleming's location again.  Great job, Fleming's!

After hearing about the newest ice cream shop in our area, Lickety Splitz, I couldn't wait to give it a try. My first time here (definitely not my last) was on a Wednesday night around 8 PM. Lickety Splitz is connected to Laurel Lanes Bowling. 

Lickety Splitz offers a variety of flavors - both sweet and sinful. The difference? Sinful is alcohol infused. Who knew  you could make ice cream even MORE fun? All the ice cream is handcrafted and totally delicious. A full flavor list is displayed on site and online. 

By checking out their website, you can also see the current specials they're running - in June they ran half off ice cream flights. 

Speaking of ice cream flights - they're awesome! You get the option to try 4 flavors in 2 ounce cups. Of course, this is what I opted for. I tried the red velvet, chocolate, birthday cake and smores. Each thick and creamy, but smores was my favorite. The Smores was filled with crushed gram-crackers and stuffed with mini marshmallows. 

There is a small seating section in front of the ordering window, and additional seating at the Splitz Bar & Grill which you're welcome to sit at. 

The staff all wore masks and gloves, and wiped down tables and high touch points when tables turned over. The staff was friendly. 

If you're craving ice cream, give Lickety Splitz a try!

I can only vouch for the breakfast here, however I do intend to return for dinner. Breakfast on the weekends is possibly one of the best deals in the city, a simple breakfast buffet with coffee or iced tea is only 6.95! You can get biscuits and gravy, bacon, sausage, French toast sticks, build your own omelet, etc pretty simple however its a great value. Service is quick and the staff is friendly.

I come here for the chicken. 
It's tasty and it's cheap. 
I sometimes get the mojo pork 
I love the rice and black beans. 
 
I've never been inside 
So I can't comment on the decor. 
But the cheap and tasty chicken
Is what I come back for.

Meh.
You get what you pay for and they do go crazy with the Kewpie Mayo here - so either avoid rolls with mayo or ask for sauces on the side.

I had seen the place (walked by) and read the other yelp reviews - but for $8 (2 maki - you can get 3 for $12) I figured I'd give it a shot.

Service was icy-cold at first (one lady was kinda mean - she was prepping a table for a large party that was not there yet and clearly did not want to stop to help another table) but then my "real" server showed up and was very sweet. Vibe is kinda icy too - with colored LEDlights that change color and rock-hard banquettes that are straight up & down and not that comfortable to sit at.  Water was brought instantly (YAY!) and green tea (which I had to ask for) was free.

I ordered a yellowtail scallion roll (had decent yellowtail but hardly any scallion in it) and a roll with salmon and grilled onions (loaded with mayo blobs on top which I scraped off - seriously, at least 3-4 tsp. of mayo.  Eew).  It was also supposed to have masago but there was NOE in there - and when I asked the (sweet) girl about it she said they don;t include masago on the lunch special.

These people are certainly cost consious - as the lettuce & dressing salad indicated (no tomato, no nothin').

I am in absolutely NO HURRY to come back here - yet - oddly enough - I ran into a friend here with another aquaintance and the LOVE it here.

Meh. Meh. Meeeeeeh.

Sorry.

Doma and Vics cost more - but are sooooo much better.

Nope.
Good old boys drinking Pabst, unaware hipsters everywhere want to be just like 'em. Except for the part about playing video golf.
Good Maplewood spot to get good custard in the summer months!!

I've been seeing ads on ABC for weeks on the west coast for Ruby Tuesday even though there aren't any RTs on the west coast. Well tonight I was finally able to satisfy my need for the shrimp po'boy flatbread! It was everything I'd hoped for and more. Service was great and my friend and baby were accommodated with the stroller etc. The food came out fresh and hot and beforehand we were served cheesy herb biscuits - yum!

Delivery through multiple online platforms.    There was a mixup on my order, and they called me right away to clear everything up.   The hostess was very pleasant on the phones as well.     

The salad actually had decent ginger dressing & the sushi was really fresh.   Although I ordered veggie rolls, all the ingredients were top notch.   I also appreciated the interesting and different makis like eggplant tempura roll...yum!    

All told a good new rotation for my work lunch splurge days.    And the delivery was on time or even a bit early.

3.5 stars

The service was spectacular. Upon arrival, the girl at the counter was very nice and asked if it was my first time. When I replied yes, she asked if she could tell me what the have to offer. Why of course!

So they offer pretzel crusted chicken tenders, dark meat and white meat, spicy vs mild. They also have some sweets that I didn't indulge in (but baked on premises!) I also got their mac and cheese, and jalapeno corn bread. 
So the way they price things here is based on weight. And if i remember correctly it's either $7.50 or $8.95/pound I can't remember.. I'll update when I check! 
But as you can see, it's kind of pricey. For my chicken,  cornbread and mac n cheese it came to $15.46 (and I got 5 pieces of chicken tenders). 

I'll give it to them for the mac n cheese. It was awesome flavorful, with a good crust on the top!  The chicken was A-OK. It was decently juicy, but not very flavorful! Kind of bland.  But the crust was nice and crispy! They also have a handful of dipping flavors for 50 cents a piece. I opted for the pesto parmasean which was super awesome. 
The cornbread was pretty good. A ltitle on the dry side, but I really appreciated the amount of jalapenos in there! I love jalapenos :)

I'm not sure I'd be back just due to the pricey-ness and OK value of food. Maybe if I'm in the area :)

St. Louis Frozen Custard Factory is a decent frozen custard and frozen treat restaurant. The frozen custard is not bad. The prices could be a tad bit cheaper but the prices aren't bad. The biggest plus about this place is the drive-thru! It's nice to get custard on the go any day! They have a large menu with much more ice cream desserts than frozen custard, featuring customizable options, as well as pre-set menu items. Whatever your heart's desire, STLFCF is sure to please.

Lunch yesterday at Boil was magnificent.  The food and the service were first class. 

Outside seating is available also.  My wife an dis hated the tray of crawfish and shrimp and it was plenty for us. 

The spices were to die for...I asked for a loaf of bread at the end just to soak the juice. So so good. 

Enjoy.

Not a fan!  Apparently I'm not into eating with my hands and getting messy.  We went on a double date to check out this new place and I don't think we'll be back.  They were packed as it had just recently opened.  We grabbed cocktails at the bar while we waited about 20 min for our table.  Apparently they had just gotten their liquor license that day so the bar wasn't fully set up and it was rather chaotic.  This is very much a chain restaurant trying to set a vibe with their kitschy decor.

We ordered hush puppies and fried calamari right away.  The food came out quickly and the hush puppies were delicious but we would not order the calamari again.  Half of our table ordered their food cajun style while the other half opted for butter & garlic.  I will definitely say that the cajun fans enjoyed their food a lot more.  My husband ordered the Reel's Catch ($46) with lobster tails, crawfish, and clams.  I ordered the make your own combo ($27) and got 1 lb of snow crab legs.  We shared our food and both agreed that we would never order the crawfish again.  The food was okay but everything tastes the same and it is very messy.  We may go back down the road to see if it has improved but I'd rather spend my money elsewhere.

We were EXTREMELY excited to join the Plantation and Swamp Tours. We chose Cajun Encounters because of the raving reviews as well as the lowest price for a combo tour 2 Plantation + swamp tour and we could do the tours in different days.

We took the Plantation Tour first.. it was fun and low key.. Stacey, our driver, was a local NOLA and she seemed to LOVE her job. She was really informative.. she kept us entertained during our 50 minutes bus ride to Laura Plantation. I will review the plantations separately.

We did feel a bit ripped off realizing that each plantation actually only charges $18/person ..so the $70 price tag for the 2 plantation tours + pick up service.. seemed a bit overpriced.

However, Stacey was GREAT, we requested her to drop us of at Central Grocery after the tour instead of our hotel and she oblige. She even showed us Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie's house at the French Quarter.

The next day... we took the Swamp tour.. and our driver (he didn't introduce himself, don't know his name) WAS HORRIBLE! He was on the phone constantly and he didn't navigate or give us any story about NOLA at all.. the 50 minutes bus ride was so boring!

Then, we went on the swamp tour.... our tour guide was friendly and nice HOWEVER he obviously didn't have enough experience to be a swamp tour guide! He's just a local young man who is likes to talk and talk and talk. When I joined a swamp tour..I wanted to see and know about the swamp. I don't care about American Idol or any hollywood actors and actresses and I can watch E! or ET to get updated of how screw up they could be. I don't need my swamp tour guide to ramble about hollywood all trip long!

It was not the season.. we didn't see lots of gators like what people claimed. We only saw one tiny gator and the tour guide failed to entertain the gator with marshmallow and he also didn't stay long enough to allow us to watch the gator. Then he enjoyed talking about hollywood so much that the boat got stuck between the trees.

The only thing I enjoyed from the swamp tour was feeling the breeze when the tour guide speed up the boat! Also.. our boat didn't have a cover and hello it was 12PM, 90 degrees and on an open swamp and we were there for about 2 hours!

After the boring tour.. we were all hungry and tired and HOT... but we had to wait for 45 minutes because the bus was LATE. The bus was FULL and the only empty seats were at the back of the bus..that's ok EXCEPT..,the A/C was LEAKING to the BACK SEATS so the seats were all drenched and my bf and another tourist had to experience water dripping to their shoulders during the trip back to our hotel.

For about $50/person... the swamp tour certainly failed to impress ..what a rip off!

Great place to come to kill some time.  They have a driving range, a mini golf course and a pitch and putt course. 

The driving range has some heated and covered stalls so you can come all year round.  They have clubs you can borrow or you can bring your own.  A large bucket of balls is only $12 and there's usually always a coupon you can get from the mail!

so far, this is the best place for sushi in tampa in my opinion. i came here for lunch and ordered 2 types of rolls. i forgot the names of the rolls, but both were good. i had eel in one and grouper in the other (i think it was tempura fried). add a little sriracha and you're good to go! will definitely be coming back again!

The menu here is a bit limited, but I liked it anyway, which says a lot. The choices were healthy and the portions were hearty. That being said, I came here for a quick dinner by myself without having made a reservation (something I don't recommend, as there were several groups waiting). The hostess took me upstairs, where I sat at the bar and was haphazardly served by the bartender up there. 

I got a cup of Mexican chicken tortilla soup and the Moroccan salmon salad and it was all delicious! The salad had a nice sized cut of salmon, cranberries, couscous, spinach and a light dressing. 

I don't recommend sitting at the bar otherwise, as I have a pretty high tolerance for bad service and this one was about to break me. Maybe their computers were down or maybe this is the way the servers order drinks, but every five minutes there was a server barking out their drink orders to a frazzled bartender who never got around to filling up my water or even checking on me for that matter. 

Obviously, I could have spoken up if I was dying of thirst, but that's not the point. There were couples flanking me who waited 30 minutes just to put their food order in because she was too busy to take their drink AND food orders? Either get a server there or don't sit people there to eat. Period.

Seafood boil!! We got the shrimp & crawfish mix that came with potatoes, sausage, and corn. It was delicious!! The flavor tasted authentic and the seafood was fresh. We split it between 2 of us and it was a good portion! For those who know the chain boiling crab in CA, this is def better! 

Minus stars only because their fryer was broken and we weren't able to try a lot of other things including the crawfish beignets we came for

Since moving from Korean food heaven (aka. Los Angeles) to Philly a few months ago, I've tried over a few dozen Korean restaurants and I've been fairly disappointed in every single one of them. All of them had ok to terrible tasting Korean food and they were all overpriced for the quality that they served. I was about to give up on all Korean food in the East Coast and write it up as a hopeless endeavor.

And that all changed when I came here.

I was told about Jong Ka Jib by a friend who knew I was looking for good soon doo bu and how I'd been so disappointed in all of the Korean places around the area. I honestly didn't think this place would be any different but I was thinking, "Hey, at this point, I might as well start conditioning my mind into thinking this is good Korean food." and I went.

I was blown away. Not only is Jong Ka Jib the best Korean food I've had at a restaurant since moving out from LA, but I would definitely consider it one of the top ten soon doo bu places I've ever been to in my life. Granted, it's not in the top 3 in my opinion but it's definitely up there. I had the pork soon doo bu extra spicy and ordered a side of kalbi ($15). The soup base was very tasty and it wasn't too watery or thick. And the tofu was cooked to perfection. They give out perfect portions too so after you finish eating, you should be pretty full.

Don't be surprised or put-off when you come in and see a ton of non-Koreans eating here (white and Chinese) if you're not used to that. I myself, coming from LA, if I went to a Korean place and saw the customer base were mostly non-Koreans, I walked out because from experience, the food did not taste like Korean food but very Americanized. This place doesn't follow that trend.

The service here is just ok, or maybe even below ok but that's what I've come to expect and experience when I was in LA going to good Korean restaurants. It's rare to find a Korean place that has great service and great food. The galbi was terrible though. Don't get it. First off, it's not marinated very well and the flavors come across a bit funky. Second, it is way overpriced for the amount and quality of the meat. I shared the kalbi with two other people and we didn't even finish the galbi. That's how bad it was. As long as you stick with the soondoobu, and the occasional pajun (Korean pancake), you'll be very happy.

After my oh so amazing experience here, I came here two more time thinking maybe it was a fluke. And no, it wasn't. I think I've found my home here.

Parking: Limited lot or street
Price: $10 per person
Wait: 10 mins after order (during rush hour you will wait an hour to be seated so beware)

Awesome burgers and fries with a Wisconsin twist at this new fast-food drive through cum sit-down restaurant in north Tampa.
The ButterBurgers are hearty and have a great char and texture, plus the buns are actually toasted, which is a huge plus, in my book. I had the signature Culver's Deluxe, which features two patties, cheese and lettuce and tomato.
The crinkle fries are large and fried and salted just right. My friend had a kids' meal that was actually just right-sized for any normal adult. In fact, the only real qualm here is the portion size and calorie count, both of which are really too much for regularly consuming, unless, I guess, you live in Wisconsin and need to stay warm.
Some of the desserts look mighty tempting, such as something they call a Concrete Mixer, which is a takeoff on the Dairy Queen Blizzard, featuring a ton of mix-ins.
The kids' meal even came with a scoop of the signature frozen custard, a creamy treat somewhere between gelato and soft serve.

Sand, Waves, Shade Trees, Bikini Clad Bartenders, Cold Drinks all under one of the best sunsets in the world... 

The only downside is limited parking. But show me a place with an empty parking lot, and I'll find somewhere else to drink.

Not too much more I can add about this quaint custard shop! It does what it does and it does it well. 

I ordered up a News 11 concrete which had their Scotch Oatmeal cookie and Reese's peanut butter cups blended in. My brother got the Apple Pie concrete which was delicious and my grandma got an apple cobbler drenched in caramel and custard. My grandpa went with his favorite dessert- a banana split and although it was huge, I'm pretty sure his empty container suggests it was tasty! 

We got here right when it opened and got our dessert right away to enjoy on the benches. It'd be nice if they had some tables set up but the absence kind of adds to the novelty of the place. Like many others, this will definitely be a go-to whenever I am back in St. Louis.

It's Steak 'n' Shake. If you haven't tried their food, then let me halps you from that rock you's living under.

So I'm not gonna review the food like I would every other restaurant.

I had to wait a little longer ("Just pull over to that big shake sign and it will be out nice and fresh for you in about four and a half minutes!") but I didn't even care that it was actually more than four and a half minutes because it was certainly fresh, and delicious. And the kid at the window was super bubbly. I like bubbly at 3 in the morning. It just makes me enjoy life. It's like, why NOT be friendly and corny just because it's at an incredibly strange and somewhat dangerous hour here at Kingshighway and Chippewa? Life's too short to be crabby!

I don't even really like Steak 'n' Shake....I only went here because McDonalds pissed me off a lotta bit....but I'll probably be back when I need my occasional dose of night shifter weight gain.

Zeppoli is definitely my favorite place for dinner in Collingswood. This is a small intimate place for a quality dinner.... and it's BYOB. Major downer for myself it's not on the main Haddon strip and it's hard to get an earlier reservation.

Anyways foods amazing, definitely a place we're you want to get a 4 course meal, which is probably about $40-$65 per person if you like to eat. My favorite pasta is the limone pasta, which is citrusically unique. For my entree, everything is great, swordfish, rabbit... but I usually go with the steak $30. It's a very fatty, large  portion which is served medium. 

Zeppoli is definitely a great place for a special occasion or a special lady.

Run of the mill yogurt place, really. No special flavors in particular, but the toppings are great and you can have basically whatever kind of toppings you want on your yogurt. The service isn't necessarily exceptional since it's a basic froyo place, but I don't really expect a lot if I'm pouring my own yogurt and putting on my own toppings.

I can't speak to the smoothies, but they've got a wide variety of options for smoothie lovers. They just seemed a little expensive to me.

I don't feel any shame in admitting that this was my first experience with this chain. That is not to say that I was unfamiliar with it, but opted for more "authentic" spots when burrito etc. needs arose. After dining here I can better understand their popularity though.

Trish's steak burrito was huge and like everything else here, made to order. I found the beef to be a bit tough and am always turned off when protein is cubed into such consistent pieces. My chicken bowl was perhaps better. The poultry was tender and nicely seasoned with a Tex/ Mex blend. Again another great portion and more suited to a dinner than a lunch. A side of guac was ok, definitely not on par with most Mexican spots.

I would be all in favor of returning if convenience and serving size was my main concern. C's is definitely a good option in comparison with chains that serve similar grub. Maybe even the best option. I prefer to seek out more independent establishments where this type of food is not part of a business plan, but instead the backbone of their food culture. 3.25 still thinking about that whole cilantro fiasco Yelps

This warm and inviting space was exactly what we needed before starting our day each morning at the Don Cesar. Located on the ground level of the beautiful Don Cesar Hotel, this oasis of goodies and coffee is exactly what we needed and when we needed it. When you walk by Uncle Andy's Ice Cream Parlor, you can't help but feel pulled in by the sights of the brightly highlighted coffee and ice cream bar.

Once inside the shop, you're immediately surrounded by shelves and tables of snacks and goodies. They have just about everything you would need in one spot from breakfast and lunch sandwiches, which they heat up for you upon request, to chocolates, liquor, and snacks. There's definitely something for everyone at Uncle Andy's! 

The folks there are so helpful and accomodating, as they even offer to allow you to place your order with the restaurant next door and take it to go from Uncle Andy's! Right outside the doors of this amazing coffee shop is the courtyard leading to the beach. We carried our breakfast and coffee out toward the beach to the couches, where we enjoyed the sunrise and breakfast with a view. 

I highly recommend the Don Cesar, and frequent Andy's Ice Cream Parlor while you're there!

Shots! Shots! Shots! For free!! That is one thing to draw you in at this small local distillery. My friend wanted to do something different and signed us up for their free tour on Sunday. They had two times, 2 pm and 4 pm. The man working that day stated 4pm is usually a slower time, so we could enjoy more.

What I liked about this, was they didn't limit the tastings. He literally said "you can taste through our whole product line if you can handle it" well I attempted to do so (but didn't)

Let me start off my saying vodka is NOT my drink of choice, but I can get into their vodka! It was really smooth in my opinion, and the flavor wasn't overpowering. Some flavored vodkas taste so syrupy I hate it. This is very clean tasting with a hint of flavor. They also have whisky, gin and moonshine! 

My favorite was the sunrise moonshine. It has a toffee flavor that reminded me of coffee. I bought some!! It's 109 proof :-) I tasted three of their moonshines! Sunset, sunrise, and high noon. 

For Vodka they had candy cane ready to go for the holidays and it was pretty good! Very dangerous as well lol 

Others I tasted were: Miami mango, key west lemon and lime, Orlando orange, Florida fire ant (wait that's almost all hehe). 

As a grand finally, they said they had moonshine infused ice cream!! They top it off with a moonshine shot as you eat it. You can't beat the prices either for the quality and proof.

Vodka bottle: $25 moonshine: $30 two coop ice cream: $7 and pint: $14 they also have plane sized bottles for $5!

I will be back!

It's not just dinner, it's an intimate meal and BYOB setting that isn't only for romantics. I would definitely say this is a place to bring your inner circle for great food and conversation. The lighting is dim, the room is small and a reservation is a must. The tea light lit tables aren't fancy and it has plain wooden tables that are generic but done on purpose. Servers (2-3) understand their menu and since they aren't overworked as you would see in a crowded noisy place they are much more in tune with patrons.  

For starters the complimentary bread is every bit of delicious. The focaccia has a contradictory texture of crispness on top but moist the on the bottom. It is served with olives and an olive oil. Our special appetizer was one of the anchovy starters that was served with roasted red peppers. My husband was a bigger fan of this dish than I was but still, it met my expectations. 

Drinks can be BYOB but since it skipped our minds to bring wine we ordered the lemon aid that is for 2 people. It was served in a pitcher and was tangy and less sour than I would have expected. It was refreshing and a pitcher carried us on throughout the course of our meal.

The salad we had was light: giant juicy red tomatoes, a bread that was soaked with flavor-fulness and cucumber on top of arugula. It was our pre-game before the entree. For our next course, I had the fusilli pasta in a pesto pistachio sauce. My husband had the rabbit with rosemary oven roasted potatoes. The rabbit was moist and it fell off like silk away from the bone. Dessert was three Zeppoli doughnuts and a rich milk chocolate sauce. The inner dough wasn't too dense and had outside crust that was cinnamon-sugary and sweet.

Why 5 stars? Because it's a shame it took me so long to come here.

   ---   ---   ---

After restaurants reopened, I've made a concentrated effort to visit places that I've had bookmarked for years and just never went to for some reason. 1200 Chophouse was the final local bucket list spot to check off. Don't get me wrong, there are still places I want to visit, but I'm talking about only the top, top tier of restaurants that I've really always wanted to check off. Other new places will open, but as of now, I feel like I've pretty much been everywhere. And I saved a good one for "last".

This time around, Anna M made sure to set her alarm properly, so we arrived a few minutes before 5pm on a Saturday when doors open. We were the 2nd people in line, but by 5:00 on the dot, there were several other customers ready to enter. After only a few minutes of being seated, pretty much every table was occupied. We arrived at 5p because I have a young child at home and I wanted to help with bedtime, but I'm glad we came when we did, because otherwise we would have been in quite the wait. When we walked out around 6:30p, there were many people waiting - some sitting on the couches outside near the road.

This part of my review is not an indictment of 1200 Chophouse - they are simply following the rules. The rules are 10/10 silly. You must have a mask on inside, unless you're seated at the table. The dining room is not large at all - it was about 8-12 feet from the doorway to our table and another 8-12 feet from our table to the bathroom. So we put on our masks, took about 6 steps, sat down at our table and talked/ate/drank for 90 minutes with no mask on - like every other patron. When I got up to the bathroom, I had my mask on for the 6 steps in route to the single person toilet room. Again, mask on for the 6 steps back to the table. And finally, mask on for the 6 steps out the door. At one point, a server asked a man to put his mask on. The man said, "what about all of these people?" The server said, "they are seated and dining. So he literally grabbed the bar chair that was within arms reach and sat down. Standing? Mask needed. Sitting down, 10 inches to the left? No mask necessary. Again - nothing against 1200 Chophouse, they don't want to get shut down. But the rules themselves? It's just good science.

Onto the food...

We started off with steak frites and bacon wrapped scallops. The scallops were the highlight of the evening. The smokiness of the bacon complemented the bacon perfectly - I wish I could eat these every day. The streak frites were delicious and the sauce was ideal, but the bacon wrapped scallops stole the show.

Anna and I shared the prime bone-in ribeye special and upgraded to oscar style. This worked out well, as they evenly split the plate for us and removed the bone, but still brought it out for us. We both enjoyed the steak very much. The only gripe I had is that oscar style kind of overwhelmed the flavor of each bite and took away from the natural steak flavor. If I were to return, I'd maybe do a traditional surf and turf where the seafood is separated from the steak.

The bread and honey butter that came with it was amazing and the salads were great too. I opted for a loaded baked potato as my side dish, which came with big clumps of butter and sour cream to add at my leisure. I added. A lot.

I'd definitely love to come back again, especially for future special occasions. This was definitely one of my favorite dining experiences in the St. Pete Beach area!

This place was fantastic.

We went because my husband was craving a burger, and I wanted to try a local, non-chain restaurant.  What a wonderful surprise!

The best part of the place was the amazing service we received.  Our waiter was constantly checking on us (in a non-obnoxious way) and refilling drinks.  More impressively, the owner came to our table multiple times, remembered our names, and even comped us dessert.

I had the fried pork chop sandwich, and it was wonderful.  I went with the super spicy sauce, which had the right amount of kick for me.  Apparently most people find it too spicy, so even after the waiter insisted that I order the sauce on the side, the owner came out to make sure that I didn't want to switch to the normal spicy sauce.  Whatever.  Oh, the fries were perfectly crisp, and I loved the spices.

My husband had his cheeseburger, and he enjoyed it.  He had a cup of chili instead of fries, and he said that he'd happily order it again.

As I mentioned above, dessert was on the house.  The owner insisted that we try the orangesicle cheesecake, which tasted very orange-y and rich.  It was great (if you love oranges -- and I do), but next time, I want to try the neapolitan cheesecake.

The homemade chips and ranch dip were phenomenally simple yet tasty.  I'd go back to EATS again just for the chips and a beer.  But, of course, then I'd want the cheesecake.  And a fried pork sandwich.  

Oh, be forewarned: on Tuesdays, kids eat free, so Tuesdays are crowded with kids.  That might or might not be a positive in your book.

This was my first time at the Tap Room ... never quite noticed it before.  Anyway, it's a small area at the front of the store, small but adequate lunch menu.  I didn't want to have a beer or wine, so I went out into the store and picked up a lemonade and they just rang it up with my lunch order which I chose to sit at the bar to eat.  There are some counters and tables if you prefer.

Chose to have a Rueben ... OMG it was one of the best I ever had.  Came with way too many fries.  Almost finished the sandwich.  

I understand they have a Happy Hour .. great place to stop and have a snack before doing the rest of your shopping.

Would definitely go again.

Checked this place out because they were located on the st pete pier dock and have a beautiful view. Very casual restaurant with friendly staff. 

I ordered the crab cakes and they tasted like balls of stuffing with a hint of crab. I was very disappointed because the description on the menu sounded wonderful. 

Also ordered some cheese bread situation, I forget what it was called, but you can see the photo. It was very doughy and chewy. Nothing that I ordered was seasoned well so that sucks.

Me and my companion ordered back to back pina colada drinks. They were absolutely delicious. The bartender was experimenting and gave us some coconut concoction. I added coconut rum and that set it off! It was a good spot to have conversation and meet new people, but I wouldn't suggest coming on an empty stomach.

Umami is a newly opened pan-Asian restaurant serving authentic Japanese, Korean and Thai food. I live in Chicago, but I go to Nashville often to visit family and friends (I stayed in Brentwood area), so it was nice timing for me to try out this new restaurant and I got to try a lot of their menu items with our group. They've got a great variety of dishes on their menu, and everything we had was delicious. You can tell that everything is made from scratch here, as well as using fresh, authentic ingredients. Here's my review on each item, in no particular order:

Kimchi fries: This is a fun take using a Korean classic (the kimchi) and an American snack (cheese fries). I loved all the flavors and textures on this dish: crispy hot french fries topped with ooey, gooey nacho cheese, sauteed kimchi, scallions, and a white sauce that I can only guess is mayo (or sour cream?). I will try to update this when I find out. 

Korean Fried Chicken: One of their more popular items (according to our server). You can select the soy garlic or the spicy sauce, or go half and half with your order (6 pcs, 10 pcs, 20 pcs, 30 pcs). I wanted my son to be able to try it, so I opted for the soy garlic. That did NOT disappoint! It's the perfect blend of that umami flavor that comes from soy sauce paired with the garlic flavor. It comes with a side of pickled radishes that is the perfect complementary crunch with your chicken. This is actually how fried chicken is served in Korea, and it's excellent. No need to travel all the way to Seoul!

Tuna poke: this is your classic tuna poke (pronouned poh-kae), which is a salad of raw tuna, cucumber and avocados. There were large chunks of fresh tuna, marinated and seasoned well (not overpowering the tuna or anything). 

Speaking of fresh...can't get any fresher with the sashimi plate! We got a variety of sashimi to share, and I seriously loved every type of fish! If you're adventurous, you can try the freshly fried shrimp head if you order the sweet shrimp sashimi. The kitchen basically deep-fries the actual shrimp head that's taken off the body of the raw shrimp. For some of you, that sounds like something that could be shown on Andrew Zimmern's show, Bizarre Foods. But like he says on his show...if it looks good, eat it!!!!!!! Ahng!!!!! 

Mango Tango Maki Roll: one of the recommendations from our server -- did not disappoint! I asked for this roll without cream cheese (I just do not prefer to have any cream cheese in any of my rolls) and it was not even an issue (I mention this, because some restaurants don't like to customize the maki roll orders -- "no substitutes" policy at those places). I don't think I've ever had a "sweet" maki roll before, and I was pleasantly surprised with the flavors of this roll. The spicy crab and mango/strawberry actually went really well together. I'm glad that they can be inventive with their maki rolls, as well as serve the usual crowd favorites. 
Side note: I love the fun names of the maki rolls -- ranging from "Pokemon Go", "Music City", and "the "OMG Roll" (I imagine this one will make you say OMG haha)

Korean Chicken Tacos: You can choose from beef, chicken or pork for the Korean tacos. My son loves chicken, so we just went with the safer option (still delicious). I guess we could have tried the combo, I think that comes with one of each taco, maybe? This is also a very fun take on some classic Korean flavors with a little Mexican twist: the chicken has a Korean marinade, topped with Asian pickled radishes and cilantro, served in a warm corn tortilla.

Seafood Ramen: If you're familiar with and (like me) LOVE the Chinese-Korean noodle dish called "Jjam-bbong", then you will equally fall in love with this dish! The noodles are obviously the ramen noodles, but in the spicy seafood broth that is used for the "jjam-bbong" dish. I can tell that they use fresh seafood for the broth, because it's spicy and refreshing, not fishy at all! I was actually thinking about this bowl the next day...and how much I wanted to eat it again. The next time I'm in town, I will definitely be coming back to get this dish again!

Beer Selection: They have an AWESOME beer selection, with some local and international beers. I love checking out local beers wherever I go, and the ones I tried were awesome. They also have some great ones on tap. 
Fun tip: Order a large pitcher of beer, and it comes out in this REALLY fun pitcher that has dry ice and flashing lights -- so flashing smoke from your pitcher. It's not just for funsies, though...it keeps your beer nice and cold so that every pour is just as refreshing as the first.

I saw a lot of people coming in for pick-up orders, so if you don't have time to sit down in the restaurant, you could always call ahead and pick up on your way home (or wherever you're headed).

Overall, a wonderful meal and experience at Umami. Keep it up, guys! I'll be coming back soon.

After hearing good things from my coworkers and reading some recent Yelp reviews about how pleased the Yelpers were coming to Bareburger, I decided to come here for lunch today with my coworker. We were mostly pleased.

The first thought upon entry was the bright colors and spaciousness of the place with the booths on one side and tables on the other. The sign directed people to sit where they wanted. After a walk down the movie theatre somewhat sticky floor, we sat near the front of the restaurant. A short wait for our friendly waitress and we got our paper menus. I was very happy to see that a lot of the foods here are organic.  

The appetizer of the crispy Brussels sprouts was excellent. Perfectly fried with no grease and the Asiago cheese with scallions and lemon wedges really upped the anti. I had to save room so I took half home with me as my coworker is not a foodie like me and also not adventurous to even try except for the piece of cheese that was calling her name. She liked it!

For my burger, I chose to go the "build your own" route but they do have plenty of other options. Bison burger on lettuce with crisped onions, sweet pickles, tomato, spinach, pepper jack cheese, and sriracha sauce. Medium rare. My coworker went with the beef on Brioche and organic cheddar, with a spicy chipotle Mayo  sauce. Well done but not burnt.

My burger was perfectly made and very flavorful. My coworker knew there would be a problem with hers once she saw a bit of blood on the plate. She did try it, but it was not to her liking and had to send it back. The Manager eventually came back with the burger after it was refired and it was better, but not great. We did get an apology and he said he'd speak with the grill chef. We also got and shared some excellent crispy fries and the organic ketchup was better than most other ketchups you'll find. Definitely better than the popular brands. For drinks, I had a strawberry hibiscus tea, and my coworker had the cucumber blueberry lemonade. Both were good, but the lemonade was that perfect Country Time saying Not Too Tart, Not Too Sweet, and especially the cucumber taste pulled through. It was so good, I got myself one. 

The restaurant was advertising they needed staff and this unfortunately was quite apparent. In a relatively crowded restaurant that more were showing up and others coming for takeout, the staff at the time we were there on a Friday just after opening (12pm) was only a waitress, Manager, and I think a single chef. They certainly did their best to get orders out, but people who came after us were served their food before ours. I can imagine how there could be severe issues during rush times. 

Overall, a very pleasant experience in a new lunch place. Friendly staff, and I'd come back.

I should mention that the back of the menu has a bucketload of beer, cider, and mixed drinks available. When I ordered one, I was told something about the liquor license, so no alcohol was available. Turned out ok because of that awesome lemonade and maybe in the future we could get some of that mixed with some vodka or something!

$65 including tax and tip for two build your own burgers, two drinks, appetizer Brussels sprouts, and side of fries.

A nostalgia-laced icon,  this branch of Ted Drewes is my favorite. It's located on Route 66 in a very pretty neighborhood and part of the experience is enjoying the ambiance as you stand outside waiting to order.

This is the first place I ever had frozen custard, that luscious concoction that is richer than ice cream and usually prepared soft serve style to lend itself to all sorts of invention.   The richness is due to high butterfat and egg content and minimal air.

Important term:  "concrete" - the frozen custard equivalent of a Dairy Queen Blizzard, you pick your mix-ins and they blend it up into decadent goodness.

One of my favorite items at Ted Drewes is the Christie, which is actually a sundae:  a brownie, frozen custard, hot fudge, and caramel ($5).  Great diet food!
