Highly recommended to any frozen confection lover visiting St. Louis!!

This was an experience.  I'll start by saying our waitress was fantastic.  She was attentive, consistent, and by far the best thing about the place.  There were large groups of people in there with kids everywhere.  I mean the kids were just running loose and sticking their hands and faces all over the buffets.  It was just chaotic, and I was stressed, so I was stress eating at a buffet.  The guy fixing the steak didn't seem to understand the definitions of cooking temps.  I mean I told him medium, and I got a piece that was well done.  So, then I tried to compensate and told him medium rare.  I got rare.  Very rare.  The thing mooed at me and then got up and walked off the plate.  Both pieces had gristle through them.  Honestly, the food is what you would expect at a buffet and/or a GC, but I've seen them in a better state than this one.  I kept looking around for the hidden cameras because I thought I was on Punked.

We love this park! Discovered it when I met a moms group here and there is so much to it. They have areas where you can plan soccer or basketball or so many other sports. 

There are roads where you can basically go for a walk and circle the entire park. There's a section where there are benches and it's covered so there is plenty of shade and restrooms! It gets REALLY windy though so be warned.  The kids playground has a variety of things to play with for the younger and older kids. The downfall is that it is not covered.  The bigger issue I have are the large ant piles (most likely fire ants) which I am deathly allergic to. What if one of the kids walk through it by accident? One of my bigger fears.....

Recently stayed here for a kayaking/surfing trip. The group I was with rented the whole place out. The entire place was just adorable. Each room is slightly different. My room was one of the smaller ones but the shower had twin heads! That was so much fun. I also took a bath in one of the casitas (they decorated it with rose petals, so cute!). There is a Lush a couple blocks on State Street and I highly recommend going there before using the jets! 

Breakfast was made to order and delicious!

I'm 1000% coming back on a romantic weekend get away or with some girlfriends!

This shop rite is always clean and the environment is always welcoming. The hot food stations are okay. The Chinese Buffett area is subpar however as you can notice right away the processed taste in the sweet chicken that they save. The grill however is another story. The jerk chicken which is very popular is generally good. Some hit and miss days, but I would say 90% of the time is has very good flavor. The staff are friendly and although it's generally packed, everything is organized and smooth flowing. I just say the sweet potato pie in the bakery section *not the regular one, the Eickhoffs Bakery Swet Potato pie is the BEST pie I have ever tasted. I brought it to work and all my co workers say the same thing. I kid you not, if you like sweets, try it...you won't ever regret it!

My friends and I got the rice combinations and while the meat was tasty, the rice was an odd cheddar yellow color that (surprisingly due to it's outstanding color) tasted like normal white rice. So odd.

I love, love, loveeee their soon dubu. I don't get it anywhere else because it just doesn't compare!

If you aren't a big fan of spice, you can get your tofu non-spicy but if you're like me and can't live without the kick in your mouth, you can get your tofu very spicy (or something in between) and trust me, it burns...oh-so-good!

Each soon dubu arrives boiling and with a generous portion of rice. Before the tofu gets to your table, you're served with an array of side dishes which are quite delectable. 

The last time my friend & I ate here, we ordered a side of BBQ Squid along with our tofu. The squid was pretty massive & had to be cut with a pair of scissors the waiter provided- once we cut it into chunks, it was easily devoured!

The staff is always courteous and very friendly, the menu prices are superb and their food is absolutely delicious. I can't say enough good things about this place!

Dear Plain Jane,
I found you here. You were encased as a hard shell taco with chicken and ground beef. You screamed my name out and said you were $2 each on wed thru Fridays from 4-7. I said hell yeah, what a bargain.
You tricked me, though. You enticed me by showing me pineapple salsa and sweet black bean corn salsa and limes to fancy you up.
You simply were even over priced bc you didn't show your taste and your finesse.
You were not plain, just bleh. Sorry. Hope you have better days!

This review was for their Sunday brunch. I took a few days to mull over why I couldn't justify giving this place a 4 regardless of the great service, great view and nice ambiance.

Service was great. Sandy took great care of our table making sure to get whatever we wanted from the menu as well as accommodate special requests. One thing to note is that there was no clear beverage menu so we weren't sure what drinks, alcoholic or non-alcoholic, they had for us. 

That being said, I would give this place 3.5 stars. 

When I go to the a buffet especially at at this price point, I'm already going in with the idea I'm going to indulge, indulge and indulge some more. Sadly, the Rusty Pelican's offerings didn't leave me feeling indulgent. 

The set-up here is a separate room with seafood, omelette station, carving station (ham), bacon, potatoes, sausages and two types of pasta salad. It would have been nice to see a nice cheese selection and some great breads.

The seafood had ahi tuna slices, crab legs, oysters, and not deveined shrimp. Our table was a fan of the cocktail sauce though.

There was one attendant for the omelette station so the wait could get long (and others might poach your omelette...true story). ALL the omelettes that came out of the station were overdone and brown - definitely not my idea of a nice fluffy omelette. 

Besides this, there is a menu with items that the server will bring out for you as many times as you want. The favorite of the table seemed to be the mojo pork with garlicky mashed potatoes. The chicken was dry and the "risotto" was more like a pilaf which had an odd taste to me. I wasn't a fan of the salmon seasoning either. The quiche was delicious though (it came as a tiny sliver but you could probably ask for more servings).

The fresh fruit with coconut yogurt that came wasn't exactly like it was described on the menu. It was missing both blueberries and strawberries. It only had pineapples, cantaloupe and honeydew.

Belgian waffle was great. My brother was a fan of the whiskey butter. 

The bread basket came with sad looking "croissants" and uninspired muffins. Our table didn't touch them at all.

There is a dessert table that had different things like a chocolate chip coconut bar, eclairs, coconut mousse, creme brulee and chocolate chip cookies. Nothing particularly was amazing.

For drinks, our table (8 people) stuck with mimosas the entire time we were there being unsure what else we could order. The servers promptly refilled our glasses with premixed mimosas from a pitcher on the side. 

The view was nice but I wouldn't rush back any time soon ($30+ pp) unless I was in the mood to eat piles and piles of crab legs, which I was not.

The atmosphere is gargantuan but very artistically and aesthetically interesting, but even better, the seafood here is surprisingly great for Reno and a casino. I enjoyed freshly dipped corn meal calamari that was addictive, and a delicious sole in brown butter sauce and delicious veggies. The service was timely and helpful. Kudos.

UBER EATS REVIEW:

i had such a craving for mapo tofu on a cold night i decided to place a delivery here since i had a good dine in review! i was so disappointed...

the mapo tofu was like an orange color, nowhere near the vibrant red and spice that i wanted. the tofu wasnt't even the soft kind that's usually used, it was hard and not what i wanted at all. no flavor, didn't taste good. i was so disappointed. 

spicy schezuan chicken was also disappointing. the chicken pieces were so tiny and not crispy at all. i put them in my air fryer hoping to get it crispy which it did but it also shrunk down the size of them even more

shrimp crispy pan noodles was OK. needed more flavor and seasoning.

all in all, this was such a disappointing order i wanted a refund so badly but nothing was missing but deliciousness.

I'm not really a Big Lots person but decided to come in just to check the place out since I'm the same plaza as Best Buy. Didn't know that they sell furniture for the home and patio! Prices seemed reasonable too but they weren't very comfy when we sat on them. But hey, if you're looking for a cheap deal on furniture you may wanna give this place a try. Close out prices on food and home items, pet items, personal care etc.  Store was relatively clean and not too many people in there. Prices seemed reasonable although all we purchased was some candy.

Looks can be deceiving when it comes to this place. I was a little apprehensive about coming in, but I'm glad I trusted my instincts. 
Upon walking in we were politely greeted by our server and immediately seated in a booth. She helped me situate my sleeping infant in his car seat before she left to get the chips and salsa. She promptly returned with our water. 
I ordered the pork wet burrito. I was very full after finishing my meal and I enjoyed it very much. My girl friend ordered something off of the dinner menu. It looked like beef tacos of some sort. She complained that the beef tasted a little greasy, but other than that she said she liked her food. My son orederd the child's grilled cheese and french fries. He liked it, but I noticed that the cheese looked like the sliced fake cheese singles that you get at the store. For the price I would have expected it to be fresh shredded cheese. 
An employee had brought her daughter to work with her (the cook I assume) while I am a single mom and I understand that plans fall through with babysitters,  the little girl kept coming up to our table. She wasn't a nuisance, I just felt bad because she looked hungry. 
Our service was on point. Our drinks were never empty and she brought our checks in a timely manner. I definitely feel she deserved the tip I left for her. I would recommend this place for any of my family or friends in need of a mexican food fix and if I'm in the mood and in the area, I would return.

As Andrew J. mentioned, the sweet aroma of boil drifts down the street like a heavenly feather, tickling your nostrils coquettishly.  I immediately went on high alert, sniffing for the source.  Two blocks later, I found myself heading into French Market Restaurant.

In line with our general theme of gorging on some of the best food on earth in New Orleans and no longer quite as full after a charming 3 hour bike tour, we sat down at the bar and ordered the "small" seafood platter (~$24).  Michael, who tends bar, was kind enough to help me decide on the size, and boy was I grateful.  The "small" platter was HUGE!  We got a ton of perfectly plump oysters, huge and spicy boiled shrimp, 2 crabs and some corn and potatoes.  All of this was complemented by some excellent homemade cocktail sauce and some sinus clearing horseradish!  The restaurant has the largest boil(er?) in New Orleans and they have a pulleyed contraption just to get the seafood in and out.

It's not a fancy pants joint, but for me it was laid back and felt genuine.  People were extremely friendly, the food was extremely tasty and the prices were extremely reasonable.  What more do you really want?

PARTING THOUGHT: I can't stop thinking about the oysters!

Still one of my favorite places, I pop in once a month to use my wine club credits. I use the fishers the location, it's close to my house and I love the set up and just relaxing inside.
Right now, they have stopped tastings, but it is still enjoyable to go in a glass or a flight.
For those who don't know, this is an Indiana family that makes wine from California, and it's tasty stuff. 
The variety has something for everyone, and they can always answer questions you might have about what you are drinking.
Ensure you check out the charity wall since the workers don't get tips; when you tip, it goes towards a local charity, which I think is an excellent feature that you don't see in many places. 
They have a Carmel and mass ave location. Make sure you check them out!

This place is a dark hole of despair! It gets worse every time. It smells really weird. About a minute after I walked in most recently, they starting playing Ben Folds Five's "Brick" over the intercom. I can credit that song for teaching me what abortion was in elementary school. Kinda depressing for K-Mart but then again it's a really depressing place.

Why 4 stars?  Because it was a solid experience.

   ---   ---   ---

I knew that the fried pork sandwich was the main event, but I was too tempted by the Philly Cheesesteak with the picture of Geno's in Philadelphia on the menu next to it.  Luckily, my friend got the fried pork sandwich, so I was able to try both.

Both items were really great.  The cheesesteak did not taste like Geno's, but it was really good.  I expected it to be closer to the original cheeseteak king because the menu mentioned that included cheese whiz, but it seemed to be much greasier than Geno's. 

The fried pork sandwich was really good and definitely unique.  It came with a spicy sauce, that apparently had an even spicier version as an option.  We were told by our server that the fried pork sandwich was going to be on some kind of food network show for spicy foods.  My friend got the more mild version though, and it was delicious.

I will definitely go back to EATS!

I recently stopped in New Aston Palace for lunch. Chinese and Japanese food is served here, and the food is pretty good. I stopped in mainly for their sushi lunch. The interior won't overwhelm you, and I'd personally don't think that anyone is coming here to dine in unless they're having lunch while working. Even under those conditions I'd say order your food to go. It was down right cold inside when I decided to eat in. There are only a few small two seat tables there, which would be more convenient for the workers there than the customers...
On to the food. The spicy salmon roll was good as well as he sashimi lunch that I ordered. The sashimi was sliced on the thin side if you ask me, but it satisfied my craving. 
A decent local takeout sushi option that many small town don't have.

I've been here about 3 or 4 times and I've liked everything that I've had everytime. I really love their guacamole it's so fresh and delicious! The last time we were here I actually got the Guacamole as my meal and we also ordered the Taco Truck taco plate. The Taco Truck taco plate came with 3 delicious tacos, rice and black beans. The steak in the tacos was really well seasoned and I loved the little bit of Cotija cheese that they put on top. The only thing that I wasn't too crazy about were the black beans, they were just missing something. I was hoping that they would be really good but they lacked flavor. They could've used some onions, cilantro, garlic or pepper I don't know some kind of something in them but no biggie I just mixed in a little salsa in with them and it did the trick. The service is always on point and all of the employees are always really nice so I always end up here.

I give it to Ninki for being wise about their marketing strategy. Our recent Yelp's Cravin' For Asian Weekly Yelp (http://www.yelp.com/weekly?edition_id=wONFT-H307gq1Weu0g6nIg) informed me that Ninki offers 50% off an alluring assortment of sushi at all times. No kidding! Sounds too good to be true, right? 

This is precisely why I had to venture out to Belle Meade for my veg sushi fix... well that is until I saw the fantastic lunch bento box deal at $6.95. Everything from the 4 pieces of sushi to the salad, miso soup, tempura, and rice were excellent. The portions were just right but the standout was the miso soup! You may not think that miso is very exciting but I appreciated the big chunks of shitake mushrooms and robust flavor. Yum in the tum. 

Don't judge this book by it's cover either. From the exterior, Ninki is nestled inside a dated strip mall but when you walk through the doors, it is a spacious and dark place to relax and enjoy tasty but affordable Asian cuisine. 
If you're planning a dinner for a large group or a dinner party, the space has a couple of private areas that accommodate and there appears to be some flexibility in the layout of the space. 

I will definitely come back to Ninki but on my next trip, I will try the deeply discounted rolls instead. Definitely consider this spot for lunch or even a date too!

So many incredible flavors!! I love ice cream, and the choices here always make it so hard for me to decide. I typically get two flavors no matter what size I get. They let you try samples. There is always a line, but it moves fast. 

My favorites are the cookies and cream, black and gold, and christmas flavors. Can't go wrong here!
Great brunch with all you can drink mimosas and buffet that includes stone crab claws shrimp oysters desserts fajitas and much more .

there are some harsh reviews for this location on yelp - i don't think it is any different or any more or less expensive than any other whole foods.  the people who work at this location are nice and they validate parking in the lot for you at any register. 

people complaining about the price just do NOT know how to shop.  there are bargains hidden in the bulk bins, the 365 brand products, and frozen organic veggies and berries.

the bulk selection here is good. the snack food selection is also top notch. 

things i wouldn't buy here are vitamins (cheaper at vitamin shoppe) most produce  (cheaper at sook hee's or sue's produce) except fair trade bananas which are very competitively priced, and pre packaged or pre made microwave meals - just because i don't eat that anyway. 

pro tip:  check the whole deal either online or in the store for coupons.  often times things go on sale in the store while there is a coupon available.  for example yesterday i got a coupon in the "whole deal" for $1 off vegan mayo - AND the brand was also on sale 2/$6 - therefore what would have cost me $8 for two containers, cost me $5. 

also they price match trader joes now.  check out the 365 tofu for under $2 a package.

love that this is only 10 minutes from my house.  We try to go on a Sunday right before / after sunset, to avoid the long lines. They do offer a fast pass for an additional cost  ($15 I believe) but it's not really worth it, unless you are going right before Halloween. They also offer discount coupons locally or online.  Parking is usually $5.00. 

They offer a few attractions with your combo ticket, which is worth it. The hayride could be a little longer, but the scenes and actors are amazing. They have a few haunted houses/ walk thru's even a "Forrest" it's always a great time. 

I love that they offer snacks and drinks for sale, so you can sit and enjoy the live music and huge bonfire. They even offer a photo with a zombie and Valley of Fear as a backdrop. I usually think it's too much for one photo but we had a decent size group and I'm happy we got it!

If you go at lunch and see the line out the door, no problem as the line moves quickly - speedy service here.   I had fish & beef tacos with crispy shell.  The filling was skimpy, covering only about a third of the shell.  "Where's the beef?" 

The ice tea is really good (3 options) and you get a large slice of lime for it, not a tiny sliver like many places.  The salsa bar has 8 or so choices and the pineapple salsa very good.   The cups for the salsa are tiny, but it is a free add -on, not a menu option.   Very nice decor and I will return.

such a sweet place! you'd never guess such charm and tastiness are tucked away in this mini mall, but once you're in yah mon, you know you're in for a truly wonderful experience. 

upon entering, you're greeted by the lovely couple behind the establishment, and it's clear from the start that they care deeply about food and its presentation. this is not a place where you rush through your meal. items are brought out slowly, fresh from the kitchen, where they were lovingly coaxed from various ingredients into a beautifully presented supper.

my curried tofu with veggies was stellar, and the portion was enormous, serving me well as a second lunch the next day. super flavorful, and the veggies were perfectly done-just crisp enough but without a raw crunch. my dining compadres enjoyed their fish and steaks, and the bread pudding and coconut cake two of them took to go were reportedly stupendous.

i unequivocally recommend yah mon for anyone's dining needs!

Pretty Americanized and didn't see any other Asian patrons there besides us, but happy with the meal overall. Deducted one star because the meal was a bit oily and I asked for pork belly specifically in Chinese (I didn't read it on the menu but asked if they had it, to which they said yes), but they gave me another pork dish instead.

For the seven year anniversary of when we met, we decided to try somewhere we hadn't yet. 
When I need to find a new place to try I look on Yelp. The pictures, menu and reviews for M3 reeled me in...but the reason we chose M3 was for their Stroganoff. My husband LOVES stroganoff and I hardly make it at home. You should've seen the look of excitement he got when I mentioned it! And that was that. 
The entrance is clearly stated in previous reviews and someone we still managed to get a little lost looking! Inside is warm woods and deep booths. The dining room was separate from the bar which makes it a bit more private. The two TVs add a pub feel. 
First I ordered a Moscow mule, and while it wasn't bad it wasn't special like some I've had...the menu is simple yet inspired. The Grilled Artichokes and the Brie cheese skillet caught our eyes. The artichoke was tender and flavorful grilled and the curry mango Brie bruschetta skillet was decadent and delicious!! My husbands not a big fan of Brie so I got ...all... of it HA! 
Next I ordered the creamy mushroom soup. The soup was earthy, and super creamy with huge slices of fresh mushrooms. Everything you would want in a creamy mushroom soup, it was the best! Finally my hubby got his stroganoff and I got the lamb. He says the meat in the stroganoff was very tender and the whole dish was perfect. 
The lamb was perfectly cooked with a sweet yet tangy fig balsamic reduction. Out of this world. And the Marscapone polenta was very creamy (The consistency of mashed potatoes) and very very good. Finally the veggies were fresh, crisp and garlicky. A perfect addiction. 
By the end I was stuffed to perfection! The waiter was on top of things, perfectly timing our entrees to come out right after our appetizer. He was great, and so was his bus boy, who was definitely on top of dirty dishes. 
Five stars. We will definitely be coming back!

I never thought I would be a fan of a Chicago style pizza since my heart belongs to New York style; however, Black Thorn has swayed my decision. 

The first thing you need to know about Black Thorn is that you will wait at least 45 minutes to an hour before your pizza is ready! The second thing you need to know is that the pizza is worth the wait! Black Thorn is in fact the only pizza place in the city I will order a Chicago Style pizza-it is that good. The sauce has a bit of a "kick" to it which means I usually only eat 1 piece, but the slices are so thick and filled with so many toppings it doesn't even matter because I get full from just 1 slice! 

The atmosphere is definitely as others have mentioned; kind of a "hole in the wall" restaurant, but aren't those typically the best? The service has been okay each time I've gone in for a visit. I can't complain. 

Overall, I think you have to experience this place for yourself and then let me know what you think!

My boyfriend and I went on a self guided beignet tour and this place was the worst by far! We were surprised that they let these beignets leave the kitchen as they were clearly burnt. Even the mound of powdered sugar couldn't hide that. Not only that, they were tiny (see pics) and super hard/not doughy or light at all. We took a few bites and just threw out the rest - something we NEVER usually do because we are huge. Do yourself a huge favor and get Café Du Monde where the beignets are not only tastier but cheaper too!

The quality of the donuts are what you would expect. Very sugary taste but that is the brand. Donuts are served hot and baked just shortly before. The drive thru could use some love. The ordering board has an annoying welcome to Krispy Kreme how many dozen can I get for you today. This is a recorded message that is not only insincere but very rude to the staff to have machine answer when the motion detector shows you pulled up. Krispy Kreme- value your staff more then trying to sell more the one dozen at a time and the service will be better in the end....

The 5-star reviews say it all! What a unique experience and enjoyable way to tour downtown Indy. The best part: burning the calories you are in-taking instantaneously! 

BYOB, pedal your legs off, and get ready to have a blast. One word of advice, invite enough friends to fill everyone slot... you're gonna need the pedal-power.!

This was a great experience from start to finish.

Our server was so friendly and welcoming that we felt comfortable immediately despite being tired, stiff, and cold from our 10 hour drive from DC. We lucked out and got seated in the back of the restaurant in a space that could double as a private room. No other tables in the room were occupied for the entirety of our meal.

The bread and olive oil they brought out first was amazing - soft, still-warm fresh bread and quality oil for dipping. We started with the Cheese Fritters and Calamari Fritti, both of which were delicious. The Fritters were especially great - crunchy perfection on the outside and melty, stringy cheese on the inside. Dipping them in both the honey mustard and the marinara sauce they come with is a must.

The Calamari Fritti had a great crunch and wasn't over- or undercooked; there was enough chew to be comfortable but not so much that you began to worry about the health of your jaw. Eating at least half of it with the caper pesto sauce ensured I was happy throughout the appetizer course.

For dinner we had the seasonal pork special, the Chicken Margarite, and the Smoked Chicken Ravioli between the four of us. (One of us was so stressed out after our drive that he just wanted wine.) Each dish was rich, filling, and so satisfying on a cold night. The portions were also huge; we all had leftovers at the end despite the three of us sampling a little of each other's dishes.

I wish we had had room for dessert but we were all so full that it wasn't an option. Next time I'm in Nashville I plan to return just to try the Chocolate Bread Pudding with rye whiskey caramel sauce. If it's as good as everything we had that night, I'm sure it'll be worth the trip.

No complaints but pricier than expected and probably not worth the overall value.  Friendly service at the bar and an interesting group of patrons (as with most places in the Quarter) including a magician who was doing tricks at the bar.

We went to this Pizza Factory with a bunch of friends the other day and my son enjoyed the pizza buffet while I ordered a medium gluten free pizza. 

The only size pizza they have gluten free is medium, so I had some yummy leftovers that night! Their crust is better than several of the gf crusts in the area while their prices are about in the mid-range. I really appreciate their proximity to my home, since it is the closest gluten free pizza to me at about 4 minutes drive.   ;)  

I enjoyed their Western BBQ Chicken pizza minus the green peppers and added an extra helping of onions in their place. Yummo!

By the way, there is definitely a chance of cross-contamination, but I was not personally glutenned and neither were a few friends of mine who are also gluten-intolerant.

Took advantage of the free doughnut coupon from Krispy Kreme ...so with all the signage and hype for the pumpkin flavored fall doughnuts.. I chose the Pumpkin Cheesecake... and it was very very good.... especially the FREE part

I adore this market! As soon as you walk in, the bakery case is right there. It is bright and beautiful, and everything looks delicious. In addition to regular cakes, desserts and breads they have Latin ones which look amazing. There is tons of choice. As you keep walking, there is a hot food bar that looks and smells amazing. It is a bit overwhelming because the menu is set over the middle of the food, but if you just stand back and look for a minute you should be good to go. The produce section is next and it is beautiful. They have everything you find in a regular grocery, plus things I've only seen there. I love it! The isles are fun- again a mix of the usual and the imported/unusual. But my absolute favorite part is the meat counter. The meats are gorgeous and the prices are great. This is definitely a place to at least check out once if you have never been!

We enjoyed the foods here! Their spicy is actually pretty spicy - I got medium and it had a good kick. I love eating spicy foods so was pleasantly surprised that a medium would actually burn my mouth a bit. I ordered a pound of head on shrimp in the boil house sauce which is essentially all the seasonings/sauces, medium spicy. We also shared half a dozen of the char grilled oysters. Others had the mussels + shrimp no spice, shrimp po boy sandwich, salad, fettuccine noodles, fire brussels sprouts. Our waitress was friendly and attentive. The restaurant was empty when we arrived on a Sunday lunch but slowly started to fill up closer to 1pm. Still plenty of tables available. 

We got our foods within a decent amount of time. My pound of shrimp was pretty small - a pound of shrimp in the bay comes with much more shrimp... fortunately I wasn't too hungry and it was enough to fill me up. I think others would need double the portion to get full. The char grilled oysters came with cheesy/garlic toppings! It was really good and had the right amount of flavors. The shrimp seasoning was salty and tasty - I enjoyed the spice and sauces... especially the chunks of garlic. The fire brussels sprouts were crispy and delicious. It had a tiny kick of spice to it. Overall I enjoyed the seafood boil here and would definitely be back here if I'm in the area.

I was shocked to discover that this location no longer caries my person favorite Krispy Kreme donut the "Glazed Chocolate Cake". Not that I need it, but it was a bit of a disappointment. 

The staff here is always friendly, and was happy to answer our questions about the Cheerwine Donut, so I won't remove a star for their discontinuing my favorite donut. 

Probably not as many varieties at Fox's Donut Den or Shipley's Do-Nuts but if you are looking for a Krispy Kreme fix, you'll do just fine here

I usually eat at the one on Girard Ave.  This was perfectly acceptable. But nothing special. Dinner for 4 was $60 so it's reasonable. Tiffin brings Indian to the masses. I guess that's a good idea. Right?

The Quick: Go for the view alone. You are right on the water with gorgeous view of Palm trees, blue waves, and even actual pelicans! 

The details: In terms of food, the lobster mango salad was great, I would highly recommend. I also had a side of brussel sprouts which was prepared with a generous amount of bacon and olive oil (just the way I like it). My co-worker ordered the grouper and wasn't overly thrilled by his meal. 

The Rusty Pelican was very good. There are better seafood restaurants in Tampa, however the tropical view and friendly staff are worth many repeat visits.

Interesting location considering Chipotle and Moe's are so close by.

I walked in and didn't really know what to do. No one yelled "WELCOME to The Lime!" and there was no one else jn line in front of me for me to follow their lead and eavesdrop on their order. 

Why was  I a little flustered upon walking in? Their menu is not very user friendly. My main issue was the disturbingly low occurrence of guacamole on it. I scanned the menu for something with guacamole on it, as I wanted whatever that would be (avocados being present on a menu item is usually how I decide what I'm going to pick). Nothing seemed to come with guac. Could I add guac to my meal? I had no idea how much it would cost since there was no mention of add ons, so I refrained. Perhaps it would have given my naked beef burrito (everything but the tortilla) some more flair. 

Another gripe about the menu: be clear if "beef" means ground beef or steak. They had delicious looking steak cooking on the grill which is why I chose beef for my meal. I was pretty disappointed it ended up being ground beef.

They DO get major points for their salsa bar, which in addition to about 8 different salsas includes fresh cilantro. I'm a huge salsa verde fan, and theirs was pretty on point. 

Overall, this is a middle-of-the-road casual Mexican joint on par with Tijuana Flats or Moe's. I will give it another try but I'll probably go for a quesadilla or tacos since my burrito bowl didn't leave much of an impression.

I guess i'll write a separate review for Cafe Beignet then i did for the Music Legends Park. Came back the next morning here since they were closed when we came for Jazz the night before. We got beignets and coffee. They were super fresh and delicious. A little different than dumonde. I wouldn't say better or worse. Just different but equally delicious. I will say this. Cafe Beignet has the live jazz in the park, which gives it a favorable advantage. Come try and ENJOY!

What a great little neighborhood hangout! Smack dab in the middle of Maryland Farms, it's not an incredibly visible location. But they do steady business with an extensive menu of American classics, way better than your typical sports bar!

I'm a sucker for fried pickles and these pass the test! The fried oysters are also fantastic and extraordinarily fresh! The wings are pretty good, but I felt like the lemon pepper flavor was a bit overwhelming and salty. Good quality chicken though. The fries are nearly perfect!

The house-made ranch and bleu cheese dressings that accompanied the wings, fried pickles, and chicken strips were very, very, very good!!! I love it when a restaurant offers a great house-made ranch (shout out to McDougal's in Hillsboro Village) and Jefferson's does it very well!

The only thing I would change is the batter for the fried pickles and the oysters. I love the fact that it's light rather than heavy, but it wasn't quite crispy enough. Almost soggy but not quite. Otherwise, Jefferson's is definitely a place that has earned my business.

This sweets shop will bring out the kid in you and if it doesn't then you are definitely a grouch!  Candy, chocolate, ice cream, what is not to like?  The quality is pretty darn good, even if it is a little on the expensive side.  Nice olde-timey feel to this shoppe since it's in an older house.  It's kind of like grandmas in that it is crammed full of EVERYTHING sweet, including the stuffed animals.  The floors creak authentically and they have a counter with stools - very charming indeed.  

Only gripe: it feels very local and the location is in the best neighborhood in Boise, but alas it is a franchise of a chain out of Bend.  It may be locally run, but still not a one of a kind.

Lord, this review is overdue - this is what happens when you plan your own wedding :( Anyway, thankfully I always take notes (dork), so despite the fact that my review is from warmer times I can say that Kermit's Bakeshop produces tasty treats that are primarily fun, and all in a very surprising location on Washington Ave. I live about 15 minutes away and not long after they opened I walked over with the explicit purpose of picking up a bunch of goods for us to try together. The place is really just take-out, although there is a small bar on the side. The one staffer at the counter was super nice and patient, and amused when I told him our plan to 'taste test' their baked goods that evening. He answered the few questions I had as I went along both cases, and packaged up everything in boxes so that nothing would get accidentally destroyed. I lugged my big order back to our apartment and later on we all had fun taking bites and commenting on each:

Hamburglar (no longer on the menu?): a soft vanilla cake bun with sesame seeds, creamy "patty" that tasted like thick fudgy milk chocolate with chocolate sauce and coconut flakes "lettuce", and raspberry sauce "ketchup" - its like getting a vanilla cupcake with chocolate fudge frosting,  sweetened coconut flakes and a raspberry jelly filling. Mostly just fun, but pretty tasty too.
Ballpark Frank (not sure if also still available): my husband's favorite treat, its a red velvet hotdog with I believe a white chocolate cream, pistachio "relish" all in a choux pastry bun. The pink frosting was off putting at first, but the first bite revealed the yummy, sweet flavors for a slight variation on the classic red velvet cake
Banana Bread: this slice of quick bread was solid overall - moist, not too dense, a good banana flavor, and a sweet basic icing glaze on top with chopped walnuts
Chocolate chip cookie: large chunks of semisweet chocolate in a shortbread like cookie base, this cookie was kind of dry and compact, not a hit with anyone
Oreo Marshmallow: this was a damn fine glob of homemade fluff about the size of my palm - it was a special treat that day
Kermit Hole: this cookie was simple and therefore perfect - thin shortbread cookies sandwiched a thin nutella layer with a cocoa-sugar dusting. The light nutella flavor with the buttery shortbread was the perfect amount for balanced flavors
Pistachio tea cake: Delicious! Moist and sweet, though the pistachio flavor was subtle, with the top crust dusted with confectioner's sugar
Finger 32 (again, no longer on the menu): this pastry was a roll with sweet, thin, moist cake layers with a cream filling, white chocolate ganache frosting, mini marshmallows and gold painted walnut pieces, and a thin shortbread-biscuit vanilla cookie bottom. The guy had said the words 'sweet potato,' which may have been in the filling. This was my favorite, and very pretty
Smores: their version was rectangular with a thin marshmallow bottom dipped in chocolate with graham cracker crumbs dusted on top, and a graham cracker piece stabbing center. Good, but truth be told, homemade smores are the best 
Chocolate Marshmallow Pop Tart: chocolate filling inside a flaky pop tart pastry dough and a basic chocolate icing glaze topped with a cookie crumble and mini marshmallows that were lightly torched. It was good not great, but if you like pop tarts then this is probably your type of treat - I actually didn't grow up with pop tarts, freak that I am
Hippie dippie whoo-pie: I wanted to like this, but it needed improvement. The cake was thin but dense, and moist like pound cake. The cream filling was a sweet cream with fruity pebbles within it. 
There's something about the fruity pebbles flavor, and I realized that you have to love the cereal to like this whoopie pie. 

All in all, it was a super fun, sugar-filled evening that we all greatly enjoyed. I would go back, and actually would like to try their savory items, but it's kind of out of my way to get to...and one reason why I haven't had a chance to go back. Once I get a free day on the weekend, though, all bets are off - or perhaps I should get delivery since they oh so conveniently offer it...

I go here so often and after work this week was just another trip. But THIS week, Dierberg's has specific meats on special for $5 a package (you have to buy at least 3), no matter what the label says.

So, I set about finding the heaviest packages of ground round, chicken thighs, beef stew meat and boneless pork chops. I saved $31.

The bagging gentleman mentioned that a previous shopper that day got a pork roast for $5 that was labeled $18. Bargains galore!

I must return before this sale is over!

I went to Shanghai 1 with a group of 8 yesterday. We were craving soup dumplings and one of the guys in the group wanted to try out a new place (as opposed to the usual 'dim sum garden'). 

My sister and I ordered steamed soup dumplings, cold cucumber, and a beef with chili pepper soup. Some of our friends got the Dan Dan noodles, the Taiwanese beef noodle soup, and the sweet and sour soup. 

The soup dumplings were good (not much different from Sakura or dim sum garden), but unfortunately nothing else was. 

The beef w/chili pepper tasted not like a soup, but like sautéed beef thrown into a bowl of noodles and hot water. The broth tasted more like oil residue than anything else. 

The Dan Dan noodles were bland. More reminiscent of spaghetti you'd get from your school cafeteria than Dan Dan. 

I tried the other soups as well and wasn't a fan of either. 

The worst part was that once we left, one of our friends let us know that they'd once found a cooked cockroach in one of their soup dumplings -_-. This was apparently a few years back, but it still made me feel super uneasy. Given everything, I definitely don't think it's worthwhile coming.

Centrally-located, large, lots of staff, good selection - now that the Jasper Avenue location of Sobey's is closed, this is probably your best bet if you want to go grocery shopping in the downtown area. Lots of parking too.

Not my usual Dierbergs Market, but I wish it were. I stopped in with a friend who was doing some serious grocery shopping. I was amazed at how much nicer this location is compared to the one closer to my house. It's true when they say in retail, "Location, Location, Location." It does make a difference. 

What impressed me, was the produce and meat departments. WOW! very impressive. I'm not even Jewish and I was also impressed with the Kosher section. So impressed, that I grabbed a few items that were on sale.

One section that was sort of a disappointment was their discount section. I guess everything really gets bought up here, because the variety of items was not as impressive as at my regular market and I do love a bargain. 

When checking out, I had to change lanes. The cashier was so rude and mean to the two people ahead of me, I was afraid of what I would say, if he crossed me. So I politely went to the next lane and waited my turn there. Some folks are not made for customer service, especially old curmudgeons. 

Will I return? - I would if I still lived in STL, but I've moved. 

When: September 17, 2020
Why: Power Grocery Shopping with a friend.

I'm accustomed to Ted Drewes and thick custard that is essentially immobile until it thaws. So I thought their custard was a little watery. Maybe it's low fat or something like that. I tried the yellow cake batter and cookie dough on the recommendation of Stephen. It was delicious, but missing a little something. It wasn't as sweet as what I'm used to, and also it was not as thick. The flavors were good.

Unanimously, a drop dead gorgeous park.

Located in what seems to be the heart of in Downtown Tampa (I'm not too familiar with the area) you'll find a park for all seasons here. By the looks of other reviews, everything from festivals and concerts take place at Curtis Hixon throughout the year. 

There are vast patches of fresh-cut green grass, playgrounds for the young ones, and a brick-lined waterfront walkway by the river. The views are remarkable. You can tell a lot of time and effort went into the construction (and a hefty chunk of change). 

Without a doubt, as good as it gets!

I wanted to grab a quick coffee and a bite to eat after leaving my friends place one morning. This was near by so I drove on over! I ordered a cappuccino and a chocolate croissant to go. I couldn't pass up the huge macaroons so I got a chocolate one. I also gave in and got the strawberry cake as well. 
Chocolate croissant is prob one of the best I've had in a very long time. Crispy outside and chocolately goodness inside! The cake was so delicious and the macaroon omggg worth the almost four dollars I paid. Cappuccino was nothing to write about. Cute place! Will def. Be back next time I'm in the area :)

I ate here this past Saturday for lunch with 4 dining companions.  We decided upon Drago's after reading about it in an airplane magazine on a previous vacation.  Upon arriving there was a half an hour wait and you are rightfully not able to be seated without your full party present.  The entrance to the restaurant does not look like much more than a bar but once you make it through past the hostess area you are able to see that it is an absolutely cavernous space.  There were 2 interesting bars that I took note of with the first being beautiful up high in the middle of the dining room with the second one being in front of chefs cooking food.  Both were very cool and impressive.

For lunch we decided to start out with the Crabmeat Au Gratin Dip.  The dip was presented nicely and had large chunks of crab which tasted good.  I decided upon the Shrimp and Grits with Tasso for my entree and I was also able to have a decent amount of the seafood pasta that another dining companion had ordered.  All of the dishes ordered by our group came out plated nicely with vivid colors when able.  The Tasso of my Shrimp and Grits had a nice and spicy flavor as promised by my waiter and the shrimp tasted nice as well.  The only thing that I will complain about it is that I wish that I had some more grits to accompany it.  The seafood pasta also tasted good although there was not part of it that stuck out for me.  While I decided to pass on dessert, the rest of my dining companions did not.  They decided to split both the brownie and the bread pudding.  The brownie that came out was colossal and I believe could have fed the four itself.  Overall, everyone agreed that they really the desserts.  My only complaint with the lunch as a whole was the leisurely pace and which we went through our meals.  While for some a 2 hour 3 course lunch may be nice, I do not count myself among them.

The bottom line for me is that I would head back here in the food.  Although the service was slow, the food was top notch and easily outweighed any other concerns I would have.

I only had the char broiled oysters so that is all I am basing this review off of!

So the locals that I was working with recommended this place and that the only thing I need to order were the Charbroiled Oysters. They were AWESOME!  I generally don't like my oysters cooked....but these Charbroiled ones were excellent!

The menu has many options for oysters, and you can order them in various sizes.  I will have to come back and try the other ones.

I started with their house made Spiced Orange Daiquiri, which was sweet, tangy & delicious! Who knew that a Chinese restaurant would make daiquiris?! So glad they broke the mold. Plus, it was a perfect complement to the spicy General's Chicken that I ordered. To round out my meal, I added the small order of Egg Rolls (2). 

They serve food "family style" meaning that they bring food out when it is ready (vice waiting for all items to be ready before serving). 

This place is on the bottom story of a 2-story house and it is a long, narrow set-up. It's dimly lit  a bit of a "grungy" feel. Yet, it smells like fresh, delicious food and the wait staff and kitchen crew all greeted me upon arrival. The music is a mix of R&B and 80's hits. The menu is much smaller than most other Chinese restaurants and carry-outs too. However, that means that they do a few things VERY well.

Yummy small town chocolate ship that serves chocolates, ice cream and homemade Carmel corn. The Carmel corn is delicious. Ice cream is served up at an old fashioned bar and the place is well air conditioned. I loved the small town, olde time feel of this shop!

I've been here a few times. The food is good. I can recommend it to others. The service is excellent. But I have never found anything on the menu that they do better than anyone else.
For my last visit I got the spicy lunch burrito with beef. It had some nice tang. The best touch were the grilled onions. But it wasn't an especially good burrito. The chips and salsa were average. 
The other menu choices were limited. You can't order just a taco on the side, for instance. And they don't offer tamales. No jamaica either.

While it was unfortunate that Marko was not able to make my tight time frame for work fit his schedule (I needed help asap; he's booked out 2-3 weeks), he was very pleasant, prompt and courteous in our communications. That impressed me quite a bit and he is now on my speed dial for any upcoming project that isn't urgent. I told him I was glad that he's busy. Always a good sign. 

A little courtesy goes a long way. Five stars for his!

Came here for Happy Hour oysters. Between me and three others, we shared two dozen fresh oysters and two side order of fried calamari. The tables for the HH section is puny. we had to squeeze the table together to create a semi larger table to hold up the oyster trays. 

The oysters were chilled and fresh, it came with a meshed covered lemon and a sauce platter. I dug for the calamari first and tried the marinara sauce, the horse radish, and a vinaigrette dip. All were tasty, but the spicy marinara was my favorite. For the oysters, I did a simple squeeze of lemon and a dab of sriracha. I wish they had some ponzu sauce which would have given it a nice citrus/soy sauce taste. 

Our server often checked on how we were doing. We teased him to just take a seat and grab a few oysters when we overheard how he has been working long hours. :P The ambiance here is relaxing. There are hanging artificial fish and in the center is a real aquarium with live fish swimming about. Sadly we were too full to try the buffet here, so I'll write about that on my update once I give them a try.

3.5 stars
I've been here several times. My goto is the Pacifica sandwich or fish and chips. The soup is pretty good too. I've had the lobster bisque and clam chowder. Both good. I have had the ayce sushi before and will probably never order it again. It was ok, but just ok and the sushi service is sometimes very slow. Service is hit or miss.

Oh that tasty goodness of the peartini at the end of the work day! Thanks to the excellent bartender, Paul B. for sponsoring my mini-vacay!

One bad thing... And it's REALLY bad... They don't have happy hour prices at the bar. Uh, hello... This is New Orleans, right?!

The location just opened about a week ago at the corner of Lindbergh (North 67) and Washington/Charbonier near Dierbergs.  There is a drive-thru and plenty of parking.  Cashier was on top of their game since they tried upselling all over the place: Want to add avocado to your sandwich?  Want to add a cookie or pickle?  Ordered at the drive-thru, paid, and picked up my food at the window in less than 2 minutes.  They really are freaky fast!  Sandwich was perfectly prepared, soda was full, and chips were not smooshed.  5 stars.

This pains me to write this because I desperately wanted a restaurant to do well in this location. But, I simply didn't care for Las Fuentas' food. The salsa is very bland, chips are just store bought and the rest of the food was just fair. Yes, it was edible but again bland. 

The decor is really nice, lots of Mexican tile and stone. Very pretty without being gaudy. The server was nice but they over charged us for a couple of items. I ordered water but was charged for iced tea. My hubby and I ordered fajitas for 2 and we were charged extra for sour cream even though it came on the plate without us asking for it. The server did remove both items when we asked but I thought it was a little strange. 

They've only been open for a few weeks so I'm hoping things will improve, drastically. I will give it another try. I want to see how the margaritas taste and I'd like to try other menu items. Hopefully I can improve my review next time.

Coming from San Jose land of amazing Pho, my expectations are pretty high but I am fully aware Im in Reno.  When that Pho craving calls you must answer the call! 
Not too bad for Reno pho.  But they lost big time on the honey walnut prawns.  Worst I've ever had.  

Ambiance was decent, China feel to it with the chair design and tables.  
Could be a little bit cleaner as far as utensils, chop sticks looked kinda gross had to go though a few to get clean ones.  

Honey walnut prawns were TERRIBLE TERRIBLE TERRIBLE.       WARNING DO NOT ORDER THIS!!!
I've never had any shrimp this bad.  How the hell could they serve that to us?  Shame  shame shame 

Pho : took a long time like 20+ minutes, which tells me they probably used a powder or premix or it was old and they reheated it.  However it was pleasantly decent haha I was surprised.   It wasn't as Hot as I would like it, I like my pho HOT!!!  Meat was tender and tasty, veggies were good.  Would have liked a little bit more flank but it's reno so not bad.  

Service was ok more lackadaisical 

When you need that pho fix I'd consider coming back but I'd want to venture to find better first.

Like a lot of people, I have a love/hate relationship with Whole Foods.

I love their selection of specialty foods, I have been able to expand my cooking repertoire because of them. I love the cheese bin that Meredith also mentioned. I scored a little nub of Idiazábal on Sunday that I am way too excited about. You can make a great cheese plate for two or three people with these little pieces. I also enjoy their sales, especially on produce. They some times have ridiculously low prices on grapes, mangoes and avocados. The employees are generally nice, I think I've only met one disgruntled cashier ever. 

On the other hand, I hate their high prices, especially when it is an emergency item so I can't shop around. I am not a fan of the clientele, but at least there aren't a million babies like at suburban grocery stores. The salad bar and hot food bar are sooooo expensive. Only made that mistake once. Meat is really pricey, even when it is on sale. And, finally, I hate, hate, hate the hot dog & hamburger buns they carry.

This review comes from someone that despises oysters. First night in NOLA and we are told by a staff member at our hotel that Drago's has some of the best oysters we will ever eat. I'm a bit skeptical but as soon as I hear that they are grilled and are cooked with garlic and parmesan, I am sold. We walk over from our hotel and are seated almost immediately. Our waiter was incredibly friendly and attentive and quickly took our drink order and put in our app request. 

We started off with their crabmeat au gratin, which came served with Zapp's potato chips and then split a dozen of their charbroiled oysters. This meal was a great foreshadowing of the food to come in New Orleans. Not only were these the best oysters I've ever had, but they are the only oysters I've ever liked and one of the best meals I had on my unconventional road trip from New Jersey to Colorado. 

Drago's wasn't incredibly busy on the night we visited, but it seems like the kinda place that can definitely fill up quick on a busy night. As others have mentioned, the only thing you should be getting from here are their oysters. The crab meat was certainly tasty but didn't match the $16 price tag. Also be prepared to spend some dough here as a dozen oysters will run you $20. Still not bad for some of the best you will ever have.

I lost my beignet virginity to Café Beignet. And they set the bar high. 

Before my trip to NOLA, I heard that Café Beignet was better than Café du Monde. Luckily on my first morning in town, I walked past this location and got to discover this myself. Also luckily, there was no line at the time of my visit; we were able to walk right up and order. 

Despite the lack of crowd, it still took a little while to receive our beignets. I'm mentioning this as a positive! Boy did they taste fresh. There was a light crisp to the outside and they were filled with heaven on the inside. I can see why they are referred to as heaven's pillows. 

The small coffee was still a fairly decent size and it was strong. If you like strong coffee, this coffee is good. 

It had been raining a little earlier so my friend and I ate at the bar. The bartender was very friendly and chatted with us most of the time. 

This café was set back in an adorable courtyard. There was even a live musician. 

I did go to Café du Monde later in my trip, however I know that Café Beignet will be my beignet headquarters for all future trips to New Orleans.

When you know a place is great, explore. I've had gallons of Ted Drewes over the years, but the best thing I have ever done is to try new things. And I've never been disappointed. Often, I ignore the menu and just look for the decorated notecards in the windows. These are the new or different selections.

Tonight I ordered "the Christy," an iced brownie sundae with caramel and hot fudge. I added some marshmallow cream for good measure. It was rich and creamy, with a little salty kick from the caramel.

Whenever I'm in St. Louis, I always pay a visit to Ted Drewes. Sometimes two visits.

the Kamehameha nachos are possibly the best nachos I've ever had.

dear lord.

can be a bit of wait with a group but WELL worth it.

i don't know anyone in our group who didn't walk away stuffed.

Found CDMI thanks to fellow yelpers. Thank you for not letting me down! We would definitely stay here again. The property is so cute - looks like a Spanish villa. Loved chatting with Yun, the Innkeeper. He was very friendly and helpful with restaurant recommendations.  The wine & cheese hour and continental breakfast were a little meager, but I knew that going in so I wasn't too disappointed. A couple blocks off State St., it's in a great location away from the hustle and bustle. The beach is practically across the street and Stearns Wharf is a 5 minute walk.

For the value, location, and warm Customer Service, we would definitely stay here again if we found ourselves in Santa Barbara.

I came here for breakfast because of the "look" of it.  Aside of the cool jazz band that was there at 10 in the morning, it was cold and rainy outside.  They do provide heaters that only work for the couple tables that are sitting in front of them.  You have to walk to get your food all the way in the back.  They have a bar area and a restaurant area (which you can only order at).  They do bring you your food while your sitting which is nice.

The food was TINY for what I paid.  I was so mad.  They charged me 50 cents for a cup of hot water.  I was pissed about that, too.  The food wasn't even that good.  Right after we were done, we immediately left and got breakfast at a better place.  Don't even waste your money or time eating here.  They even wanted tips at the counter?  Tip for what!??  Here's a tip, lower your prices and hire a chef to change your menu.

Is it the best diner in New Jersey, Land of Diner Enchantment?
Maybe not, but it certainly has history and local color going for it.
Oh, and a great breakfast if you fancy overflowing plates, unlimited coffee, and a Greek Omelet that is a wonder of the world.  
What is it about feta cheese and eggs that moves me so?  Don't know, but when mixed with sausage, potato, onion, peppers, all wrapped up in an fresh egg case, they become an amazing sensory explosion.  
Trenton may have seen better days (we have been waiting for its resurgence since it was "Americas Town" in the 60's), but Pat's carries on.
Diners are only partially about the food, and the rest about the concept, design, and lustful loyalty they inspire. 
Pat's is a worthy contender for the Urban Diner List on Yelp* (If there is one). 
Give it a try. 
Sit at the counter and watch professionals do their thing. Sit at a window and see a worldview that captures the past-its-prime city, the capital of the Garden State, remind you that... We Are Still Here.

Mmmmm.  Mexican.  Lots of it, in different ways, shapes and forms.  Fresh, comforting, delicious.  So good!  Everyone's order was tasty, and I know, I had a bite of everything.

Service not so much.  There isn't anything I can't tell you to order, my only advice is to have your ENTIRE order ready to go, drinks and all, at once.  Good luck getting a refill or another beer in a timely fashion.  Don't let it be a deterrent though...come eat here anyways.  But, maybe...order yourself say, 2 or 3 beers and 2 waters with your food.  When the waitresses look at you like you're insane, just smile like Mona Lisa because you already know what they would do before they DON'T do it.  

PS--bring a hearty appetite for the burritos.  None of us could finish ours, and we were hungry...

What a terrific new addition to Chinatown.  This new restaurant is nice on the eyes and great on the tongue.  The food is Shanghai and Taiwanese cuisines .... and a good idea is probably to order something from both of these Chinese culinary traditions.  The one appetizer you must try without a doubt are the incredible beef scallion pancakes from Taiwan.  With beef, scallions, and an oyster sauce inside - you will not want to share them with anyone else at your table.  You want to eat them all yourself! 
And to add to the great dining experience at this restaurant, the service was extremely attentive and friendly.

With the current Korean chicken craze in full flame, I'm planning on coming back to Shanghai 1 to try their Taiwanese lightly salted chicken.  Everyone tells me it is really tasty.  Judging by what I've already eaten at this restaurant, I believe it!

A couple of friends of mine ate here and we enjoyed what basically was a shrimp bahn mi and the roast beef poboy. Both were great particularly the shrimp poboy. Combined with a great frozen irish coffee for dessert you have one of the best combos you can get in New Orleans.

2.85 stars.
I see something good there, but it's not there, yet.
The seeds are sown, but the way they're fertilizing, could be their demise.

I felt like I was in a catering hall, for a wedding and the rush was on to feed everyone at once.

No, no, no, no! NO!

Each server needs someone behind them to bus the tables, clean off the used dishes, fill the water glasses.  This way, each server can concentrate on each person at the table, who is going to tip them based on how well the server performs.  And that server depends on those tips, so she is going to work her best, to make sure you have a good experience.
Someone needs to be behind them, to make them perform, top notch and that isn't happening and everyone is complaining about service.
Food is good. Some creative dishes, good variety, ample servings.. I see nothing wrong with the menu.  A little something for everyone.  We enjoyed fondue between the two of us and our meals and our dessert.  It was wonderful as far as flavor, the way each dish was prepared, the ample serving so that some could go home with us..  Dessert was delicious, although our first choice was already sold out.  I think dessert is as big a profit maker as alcohol, no?  Why wouldn't you have more desserts prepared?  Hmmm..
Dessert was large enough for both of us to enjoy.  Main dishes were very large portions. Food was cooked to desired request.
It was a good experience, except for watching the waitstaff speed run past our table every 20 seconds with a look of anguish on her face, never thinking to stop and ask us if we would like a drink.. Or a menu.. Or a glass of water.  We were completely ignored  for a good 10 minutes, while they bussed their own table, poured their own water at their tables, took drink orders..  Someone could have come and given us a drink menu, filled our glass.. while our server finished up with someone else.  Right?
So simple.  So easy to achieve, and yet, so frugal.

It could very well be your demise --- if you're reading this.

For some reason I am able to come out of Whole Foods with lots of groceries having only spent like 80 bucks.  I can't do this in any other supermarket.  Theoretically, Whole Foods is expensive.  It an establishment that sells high-end organic produce and grain fed meats, yet I can rock and roll the joint with less than a bill.  

What Whole Foods is really great for is freaks like me who are allergic to things.  For instance, I am allergic to cow dairy.  I still like cheese and yogurt but it has to come from a goat or a sheep or something like that, which Whole Foods has and most large chain grocery stores do not.  What I don't like about Whole Foods is that being a large chain grocery store they run independent organic markets out of business like crazy.  And it's a dilemma.  For me to get the same amount of food at Essene that I get at Whole Foods, it would cost me around 30% more, which I can't afford, so often I end up at the big store.
Concretes here are quite fun, but not one of the great ice cream places I have been to.

I think that coming here during lunch and parking in the Del La Guerra area, right in front of the SB Newspress building (parking is 15 min so you have got to be "to-go") is a perfect lunch idea. I did this yesterday with a co-worker and we had a buy one get one free coupon from a mailer so totally good deal. We went here, and although it was packed, the line was moving very fast, which I can appreciate especially in a lunch crowd. The staff was friendly and fast, and I did not get jipped on the amount of meat (I hate going places and they truly measure the damn food). I thought the service was fast and their burrito bowls are delicious!

I believe this spot has been open for about a week now without advertising. And at 5 pm was filling up pretty good. 

Note the entrance is on the Lakeside of the building so you don't have to walk around the entire building to find the right door- like me. The interior is very nice- rustic painted cement floor and walls that look like various reclaimed boards. I like the over all appearance. 

Being the first time there, the only server I can comment on was Charlotte. Damn that girl is a perfect server. Subtle  suggestions - a drink from the bar, "we have a great bartender."  Or an appetizer or two while looking the menu over. She saw my indecision and said take your time, I'll bring the drinks. For a new restaurant she seemed to know the menu pretty good and made a couple of suggestions. One two sided menu has sandwich, burger $10-14, salad $9-15 and small plate choices $9-14. The second menu had more of a dinner selection - ribeye $20, pasta $13, and lamb chop $18. The food arrived on, my personal favorite, HOT plates. My three tacos were so stuffed you couldn't fold them in half and tender beef, fresh crisp cabbage and a creamy cool cilantro sauce. Hubby enjoyed the rigatoni with mushrooms and chicken in a cream sauce.  

A nice variety of wines from $5 to $11 a glass and also available by the bottle. Also a reasonable beer list. 

Of coarse Charlotte returns with a final suggestion and tease of some decadent sounding desserts. Next time, we were just too full. 

Will  absolutely be returning there were several other items we really wanted to try.

After seeing Mark P's picture & review of the spicy tom yum noodle soup w/ seafood, I knew I had to get me some of that ASAFP.

Well I can say it lived up to the hype, and thensome! It came in huge pho-sized bowl, steaming with an amazing aroma with lots of shrimp peeking out.  Along with the generous amount nice-sized shrimps, there were also mussels, scallops, and squid, about 4-5 pieces of each.  And then the broth, oh my god, this broth.  Perfectly spiced, tangy, savory...just freaking amazing.  Best $12 I've ever spent.

I'd suggest you go alone when you get this, so you can just focus on the flavors and moan with pleasure without judgment or distraction.  This soup commands your full undivided attention.

Mark P, I owe ya one!

To kick of Philly's first Restaurant Week of 2013, I felt like indulging my primal urges and quite simply ... felt like digging into a prime rib. So when I saw that The Prime Rib on the list for Restaurant Week, I couldn't help but head over for their eponymous dish.

Entering into the Philly outpost of The Prime Rib, the atmosphere felt slightly stuffy, as if I was coming in for a power lunch/dinner. Happy Hour was in full effect (I hear it's great actually according to Yelp), and all the patrons were easily twice my age. The latter is understandable due to the high price point for the majority of the dishes at The Prime Rib. Still, we're talking about a prime rib joint and not reinventing cuisine. And that's ok! Sometimes all we need is a nice slab of meat, great service, and a pianist riffing on a clear-top grand piano. Nothing else.

Bread Service

The bread was served warm, which I appreciated, along with the spreadable room-temp butter. Decent variety, but pretty standard.

Roasted Tomato Soup

The tomato soup came out hot with a sweet, tangy undertone from the roasted tomatoes. Delicious and a nice way to whet my carnivorous appetite.

House Salad

The GF opted for the house salad, which was a bit over-dressed with ranch. However, there was a nice mix of chopped egg whites, fresh cucumbers, tomatoes, and mixed greens. The pepperoncini offered some bite to the dish.

Famous Potato Skins ($10 supplemental)

I can't resist anything advertised as 'famous.' So I obviously went for the potato skins, which did not disappoint. They were unadorned with anything fancy like bacon bits or cheese, but that's ok when we're talking about something that is so simple that's done so right.

The innards were scooped out, resulting in skins that were crispy on both sides. Perfect vessels for the accompanying horseradish and sour cream, which worked well to bring some fresh flavors to the dish.

Grilled Atlantic Salmon

The salmon had nice seasoning and a decent crust from the grill. However, the GF wasn't the biggest fan since it didn;t taste particularly fresh and was frankly, a bit dry.

Roast Prime Rib of Beef

This 12 ounce slab of beef was well-roasted and seasoned. However, there were portions of the beef that were whole unappetizing chunks of fat. The accompanying grated horseradish was frankly chewy and didn't taste that fresh.

The outer crust that I typically enjoy on prime rib was also quite dry and inedible in some parts. Still, the parts of the beef that were edible were enjoyable and exactly what I was looking for in a good prime rib. I'll chalk the rest up to Restaurant Week demands. 

Creamed Spinach

The Restaurant Week menu advertised roasted vegetables, which was actually a duo of dishes that are typical of any steak or prime rib joint. The first was the creamed spinach, which unfortunately was a weak iteration of this standard dish. This was a soupy mess - indicative of what may have been frozen spinach. Butter shone through rather than the essence of spinach.

Mashed Potatoes

 The mashed potatoes were sufficiently smooth but were fairly standard. It would have been nice to seen these spruced up.

Key Lime Pie

The key lime pie was perfectly smooth and tangy with a nicely light, thin graham cracker crust. A nice way to cleanse the palate, especially after a heavy meal.

Creme Brulee

The creme brulee had a perfect sugar crust and the custard was creamy and redolent with vanilla essence.

Overall, if you're in the mood for prime rib and have deep pockets, I would suggest giving The Prime Rib a try. Regardless of whether it was Restaurant Week or not, we came for an early dinner and the restaurant was not close to being packed by the time we paid the bill. I can't see myself coming back anytime soon as this dining experience was rather lackluster. However, I may just have to stop by for a drink and some of their potato skins.

The vegan chicken and waffles are so insanely good! I came here for a private event and loved it! Their space upstairs is very open and cozy. 

The amount of vegan options on their menu was also astounding! It was so difficult to pick out what I wanted to eat. I finally settled on the vegan chicken and waffles, thank god I did. The waffle is vanilla-y and sweet while the vegan chicken is salty, savory, and comforting! I loved the blueberry syrup served with it too. I will definitely order it again!

Okay so my first time here wasnt so great but I will give it another try because my friend said its a great place to eat. I came here with my boyfriend on a Wednesday and the WHOLE reason we came was to get the Steak Sammy we asked our waitress if that was on the menu and she said NO, I will give her the benefit .. she was new and did not know the specials. I asked her twice thought about the specials and she said there was only a drink special. She did suggest an awesome sandwich so that is why I am giving it a 3 star rating rather that a 4 or 5 star. My boyfriend loved his burger and we loved the pickles and the dipping sauce. We will be back, and hopefully will get the steak sammy. I did talk to the manager and he apologized and he said next time it wont happen and to make sure I see him next time I come in and he would make arrangements. That is great customer service and that is why I will be back and get the steak sammy everyone has been talking about LOL

Came with a friend who had been here before and wanted to take me out to celebrate a successful first day at my new job, and Crazy Sushi was the perfect place! Great service, great ambiance, and more importantly, great sushi! We got a few rolls to share between the two of us (all vegetarian rolls- fried banana, pumpkin, and sweet potato) and I got a bagel roll (salmon and cream cheese, lightly fried on the outside) for myself.  The way they plate and present their sushi is the most elaborate and creative I've ever seen anywhere! Looking forward to my next visit!

What do you go to TCBY for? Yogurt... delicious, moderately healthy, tasty yogurt at an affordable price. And for that they absolutely deliver! I give them 4-stars. Also, it's SO CRAZY AFFORDABLE compared to some of the self-serve yogurt places in the valley. Trust me, you get more bang for your buck at TCBY. With daily specials, you just can't go wrong.

Food: They have hand-scooped yogurt and sorbets, soft serve yogurt and sorbets, tons of toppings to pile on top, and cartons of yogurt as well as yogurt cakes. You just can't beat it! The cake batter soft serve is great. Pralines and Cream and Strawberries and Cream hand scooped flavors don't even taste like yogurt. They'd totally fool me! They're SO GOOD and creamy. 

Drinks: n/a

Atmosphere: It's very start and simple, but hey, it's a yogurt shop. They do have benches outside and a drive-thru. I feel like they cover all the bases.

Service: Super sweet and friendly. It's not a 5-star restaurant... it's almost always kids who work there who are earning a couple extra bucks. This is most likely their first job. Give them credit, they do a great and superb job!

Happy Hour Offerings: While they don't have happy hour, they do have daily specials! Make sure to check the sign posted out front for the deal of the day!

Healthy Hack: Wanting a little bit of a treat? Try a dairy-free sorbet to cut calories or go for a kid's size. 

Tips: n/a

Eating outside Santa Fe on a nice summer night with my boyfriend reminds me of a great R&B video. A love story, with a couple sitting outside wooing each other. The candles are dimly lit, but the mere sight of them makes you melt. The salsa dip is..NO WORDS..that great. I like cilantro. No, I love cilantro. Santa Fe does a great job of preparing the salsa dip with just enough cilantro. Careful with the chips & salsa, the 2nd round is on you ha!ha!

I am a margarita, mojito, lemondrop diva! The margarita was so refreshing. I can't think of any other adjective to describe it. The drink did not disappoint Elle. Eating outside around people from all over the world makes me feel good. My boyfriend swears by the softshell crab taco. It lit him up. I did enjoy it as well. There are so many obvious choices when viewing the menu. I would challenge you to try something new. I love trying new stuff at magnificent restaurants like Santa Fe. If you don't like what you order, SWALLOW it..LOL no seriously, you will definitely enjoy it.

Drago's Seafood Restaurant at Hilton Riverside is not so great. We were forced to eat here for lunch as we had meetings at the Hilton all day. 

I tried the spring salad with assorted greens, cranberries, walnuts and blue cheese. The lettuce was wilting and the cranberries tasted stale. The blue cheese dressing was very peppery. 

I also tried the eggplant romano which was okay. The eggplant was so heavily breaded that you could barely taste it. 

The shrimp linguini which was a lunch special was too rich. There was an abundance of think and creamy sauce are barely any pasta. 

Overall, I would try to avoid eating here. If you have meetings or conferences in this hotel, try to eat elsewhere before you head over here because Drago's is the only option for dining in the Hilton Riverside.

It was our server's first day.

Should I continue?

A group of friends decided to meet here for a Phillies game- there's a $3 draft special during all games, and I wanted to go somewhere I could actually get a decent meal. 

Though the TV was relatively large, the room was quiet. We were sitting next to the fine diners, silently sipping on bottles of Miller Lite. Bottles of Miller Lite? What about that $3 draft special?

Our server told us they were tapped out of the $3 drafts (Lionshead and Dogfish Head Pumpkin), and wouldn't be replacing them for awhile, she didn't know with what. Great.

Poor girl didn't know the happy hour specials either. We ordered our food and waited.

Menu was surprisingly interesting. Chef salad was good, nothing to scream about. I believe the other eaters at my table felt the same way. While I wouldn't be opposed to eat at Marathon again, I'm sure I'll end up at one of their many locations one way or another.

Comfortable little restaurant in a convenient location. Easy parking and great service. 

The food though is out of control. Stop reading and get  over here to try it. 

Oxtail - A+
Sides - delicious
Prices - just right

Another mom and pop restaurant I had the pleasure of eating at during my trip, I'll definitely be back when I'm in Tampa.

I really don't like the ambiance here. It's neither swanky nor endearingly run down. If I had to compare it to anything, it would be to the back room of a synagogue where they do the kiddush. But they have the best dumplings I've ever had, hands down. What I've had of their entrees hasn't been memorable, which isn't a bad thing. Service is prompt and friendly, and the complimentary tea is just perfect.

An interesting tour of New Orleans with a great guide. We did the afternoon tour of four neighborhoods, a cemetery, and a distillery. 

We booked through one of the tourist spots in the French Quarter. The woman there was able to give us availability, book, and give us meet up information. Since our tour was on a holiday and the parade closed many downtown roads our meet up spot was an arbitrary intersection. Normally the bus can pick up and drop off at hotels.
