The tour was about two and a half hours with a stop for bathroom breaks in the middle.

The driving portion of the tour was great, especially since it was very cold the day we did our tour. Our guide was Rene and he gave us city information the entire time we were driving around the city. Some of the information was historical and some was interest like pointing out homes of famous residents. He kept the tour interesting.

The cemetery portion of the tour was interesting as well. It seems odd to go to a cemetery, but it is an important part of learning about the city. We were given about 10 minutes to walk around after Rene gave us information about the cemetery. 

The last part of the tour was a stop at Seven Three Distillery. The distillery gave us a quick tour of the facility as well as a taste of their vodka or gin which in total lasted about 30 minutes. It was a nice distillery and a nice enough tour, but it didn't seem to fit in with the rest of the tour. It would definitely be fun as part of a separate drinking themed tour. Maybe a new tour option idea that goes to local distilleries and breweries? 

Overall, a great way to see and learn about the city on a day too old to walk!

The ice cream was OK. My visit here solidified that I'm not as big of a Coldstone fan as other ice cream places. For one, after they've mashed it altogether it loses the shape and texture of just regular old ice cream that I like. 

At this particular location, I stood waiting behind the glass awkwardly for a few minutes before even being helped. I was hoping someone might greet me and ask what I wanted. 

A-OK, but I'm not rushing back to this Coldstone or any of them, really.

Honestly....I don't see how its any better than a Wendy's burger. HOWEVER, the fries alone get all three stars. I love fresh cut fries and you can order them extra crispy and they will fry them twice to make sure you have a heart attack. You would think the cajun seasoning would be a big win for me, but I like them with just the sea salt they use. Sometimes simple is better.
Huge supermarket that is close to Metrolink. It has everything a supermarket can offer.  No gluten free bread but does have a gluten free isle.  It is near Trader Joes and Whole Foods.

Visited last night for restaurant week. As it's aptly named, they are known for their prime rib and wow it was melt in your mouth delicious! 

Aside from the ignorant hostess (short blond hair, older woman) and the lack of appropriate # of servers for the amount of people, we thoroughly enjoyed our dinner with family and a friend (party of 5).

Our waiter Vinny was fantastic and very social BUT spread way too thin which meant longer wait times on drinks, no serving spoons for the family style served mashed potatoes and string beans for the table and forever to get coffee to go with our desserts (coffee arrived after everyone was done). Our tip appropriately complimented Vinny as a great server, it isn't his fault they don't have enough wait staff. Monday (the following day) they had over 500 people coming with only 8 servers staffed. Think about that. Last night there were approximately 350 diners, and it showed in attentiveness of the wait staff. Again, NOT the servers fault at all, Vinny was great. 

They have a full service bar and extensive wine list but it is also BYOB so we enjoyed our favorite wines. 

Parking is ugh... it is Center City, so parking garages are expensive and street meter parking is an adventure to find. However I am in love with the new meterup app the city of Philadelphia has instituted and it's only $3 an hour for meter parking that you can add time to from your smartphone. We also found out that handicap tagged cars get an hour free parking on Sundays in the city! 

Restaurant is beautiful, well laid out, has a nice ambiance with a piano player (who takes tips), upper scale normal pricing approx $60 per person, dressier than a casual place so dress up and go have an amazing night out in the city starting with a wonderful prime rib dinner.

Yes.  It really is that good.  Everything you've heard is likely true.  There's a soft serve ice cream place in Lynden, Washington I couldn't imagine being superseded by anyone, but truly, Ted Drewes did circles around my previous number one.

What is so special about their frozen custard?  For me, it's the right balance of creaminess, flavor, and lightness.  It's not heavy feeling as you eat it and sits in your stomach.  The custard makes it taste like a proper vanilla flavor.  Not too sweet either.  It's not icy or watery, but a very creamy consistency.  It really is wonderful.

We were in St. Louis on a hot summer night so the line was long, orderly, yet fast moving.  We ordered our treats and enjoyed them in the parking lot.  So good.  

If I make subsequent trips to St. Louis, I will make time in my calendar to come here for a soft serve.

Stopped by this place to grab a quick slice of pizza while running errands. My spinach pizza with tomato was delicious! Loved the crust, and it was just enough pizza for me. You can orde take out, but they had a few tables for patrons to sit at. Spices and napkins were at each table which I thought was very convenient.

$3 for the slice means cheap lunch for me!

Great location with lots of parking. Love coming here with friends and even for a quick meeting. I'm not much of a beer person but I really like the fact that they offer a cider option and wine. Great decor and large seating area. Th summer here is great but it is often very chilly inside in the winter.

I came in to try to exchange some slippers that I got for Christmas that were the wrong size. The selection of slippers was almost non existent! I really needed new slippers so I really did not look at anything else. 

When I went to return them since they had been bought with a charge card I had to either take a store credit or put it on my card. I would have rather had cash but oh well.

The employees that I dealt with were nice and the store was clean. This store has always felt like a thrift store to me.

I usually go to the TBBC in YBor but I was meeting a friend who lived in the area and this one was closer. When I first arrived, I noticed the parking lot was packed! People parking on the street etc...

The outdoor section had a bar and live music playing. 

When I walked inside, I noticed it was smaller than the other location. Tables were packed as well. Looks like there are more younger kids here with their parents as well. 

Luckily it was just two of us and the wait wasn't too long. We secured a booth. Our server was great and helped me select flights. I told him I am not a beer drinker but was trying some because my friend liked beer. He selected the fruity cider style beers for me to try. They weren't bad!

We got the pretzel appetizer and it came with two pretzels so we didn't have to share :-) I of course ordered the bomb burger with a black bean burger instead of beef. I love how you can swap out the patty. 

The menu here is the same and the service is good too. I will come to this one more often.

Wonderful experience:  gorgeous setting, great food, excellent service and well-managed. 

Food: I had the local, whole red snapper and it was superb.  It is a whole fish (see my pic) fried and with a light batter. The meat is just succulent and tender. Amazing. Others had the swordfish and stuffed grouper which were also great. The salads are OK but iceberg was brown. The filet mignon came out a bit too cooked. 

Service: Owen waited on our table of ten, which was NOT an easy table to wait on. We had special requests, discombobulation, children, split bills, people leaving early and coming late. Owen was just awesome. 

Drinks:  The drinks are excellent, and they have a great wine list. They have Copain's pinot noir, which is excellent. The mojito was fantastic with lots of mint and lime.  The strawberry mule was also reportedly fantastic. 

Setting: the interior is beautiful and the setting is amazing. Come here to see a beautiful sunset. 

Management, you have AWESOME people and you are doing a great job managing them. Congrats on a job well done to all. And thank you.

I'm such a fan of Chipotle, like seriously.

I think it's because my friend likes it. Or maybe because my parents like it. No, somehow, even if you get short-changed on your ingredients in the place, your burrito or burrito bol will still taste pretty damn good. The ingredients are pretty addicting. Though I think I must give a warning in that I think the tomatillo-green chili salsa is pretty damn spicy. This is coming from an Indian girl, so mind you, I can handle most of the spicy stuff I am given. Perhaps I'll give it another shot before I REALLY warn you about this ;)

And nothing says accomplishment better than eating an entire Chipotle burrito. Until Center City has a location, I suppose I must frequent this location more often.

It was cold, wet, and a windy night in Chinatown Philadelphia. We were all hungry after visiting the Christmas Village for the holidays and with several restaurants across from us, we decided to choose this place for their decent reviews.

I ordered the Taiwanese beef noodle soup and beef scallion pancake for appetizer. I am fortunate enough to be living in Las Vegas for nine years where Asian soup from different parts of the world is not hard to find. I would have to say that the beef soup here was less than satisfaction. I prefer my meat cut smaller rather than large chunks, but the meat was very tender. The broth overall was good, but I prefer the Taiwanese  beef noodle soup at Noodle Pot in Vegas.

As for the beef scallion pancakes that seems to be very popular here, is not so popular with me. The sauce was too sweet for me and the pancake was a little bit chewy. The temperature was almost at room temperature that may had contributed for being a little bit chewy. Liang's Kitchen in Vegas has awesome beef scallion pancakes served warm and is seasoned well.

The ladies were great and service was super quick. However, when in Chinatown, I would try other places before coming back here again.

There were so many people in line when we first drove up that I thought they were giving out money. On a visit to my wonderful friend in St. Louis, we all got a sudden Jones for some Ice Cream. My friend Jan knew the perfect place. Other than the mass of humanity we witnessed waiting in line, our visit to Ted Drewes was nothing short of wonderful. The staff did a wonderful job moving the line along and I had my Chocolate concrete in no time. 
 The Custard has a wonderful, buttery flavor that is quite unique and delicious. It was the perfect treat for a hot summer night.  
 The next time that I'm in St. Louis and have Jones for some great Custard, I will head back down to Ted Drewes. The Custard was awesome, and so was the people watching.

This is a great grocery store for tourists, smack in the middle of the CBD/FQ area.  Skip the souvenir shops and come here for all your local spices and food.  Louisiana Gumbo packets were half the prices I saw at some of the shops, so were the pralines, hot sauces, etc.   Variety galore.  If you are flying domestic, it may even make sense to buy some of their freeze dried alligator meat/crawfish tails and check it into baggage.

It was worth the trek out here to get a burrito! Even though it's a tourist trap, the burritos are very large and very good made with the freshest ingredients. 

This is not a large establishment, so not ideal for a large group.  You might have quite a wait and if I remember correctly, the don't usually do reservations.  

If you are into interesting light fixtures while you dine, this is the place for you.  I often wondered if any of them are for sale, they could probably make a killing in selling art as well as burritos.

5 stars for the chargrilled oysters! 

3 stars for all of the rest of the food. I'm lucky in that I got to eat off 7 other girls' plates, however none of them were outstanding except the chargrilled oysters. I tried everything from gumbo, to lobster, to pasta, to barbecue shrimp. Next time I come back, I'm order 2 dozen of these guys for my meal, and I'm not sharing! They give you bread to dip into that buttery delicious sauce that the oysters are floating in. Drago's oysters DOMINATES Acme's oysters.

The restaurant itself is old NOLA classy, and it's huge. It's got plenty of TVs and if you time yourself correctly when you walk by the kitchen, you can see the huge flames from the grill where they prep those mouth-watering oysters.

I'd had this spot bookmarked since it opened and figured I'd better check it out. 
First impression was that the place needed an identity. The interior was very bizarre and the restaurant had an odd layout. It seemed like it wanted to be high end, but they ran out of money and went in a different direction. 
That being said, the server was amazing. Extremely attentive and genuine. 
The menu was also a bit odd, but we asked for suggestions. 
We ordered the hot chicken wings which had a dry rub on them. I'm pretty sure they were the best wings I've ever eaten. I don't know how they make them but I'd highly recommend trying them. I had the meatball ragout and the BF has some sort of sandwich that he enjoyed. 
The food was delicious and service was good. The price and ambiance didn't seem to match. 
But I'll definitely be back.

Looking for something different for a date night or girls night out?  Check out Mimosa & A Masterpiece!!   Get online, go to the website, click on the calendar, pick a painting that strikes your fancy, sign up, and GO!  I believe they also offer private events for bigger groups.  SO FUN!   Located in the heart of the arts district off Mass Ave, enter through the door by the Stamp Shop on the corner to get here!


What makes it fun:
Twana -- AKA "the Hostess with the mostest" was awesome!  So friendly!   Our glasses were never empty nor did we have to ask for anything.  She was hilarious, personable, and anticipated our needs.  Sweet.  

Alan -- our instructor for the evening.  Provided great guidance while encouraging individual creativity.  He was very willing to hop in and help where needed and was funny to boot.  He even did a great job of diffusing the awkwardness of some "difficult" painters and made us laugh in the process.

$5 "liquid courage" -- Red and white wines, mimosas... very generous pours and quality product for just $5 a glass.


What sets them apart:
They let you customize your color palate so your painting can complement your decor -- which was really nice.  Other similar places already have your stuff set up and colors are predetermined when you arrive.  Not at Mimosa & a Masterpiece.  They will even give you a quick overview of which colors look good together to ensure you are on the right track.

You are encouraged to "make it your own" -- meaning they will provide a loose guide and framework, but not a step-by-step on how to make your painting look EXACTLY like theirs.  This is great for the creative or rebel painter...and it's all in fun anyway, right?  

So yes.  We will return to Mimosa & a Masterpiece again.  SO. MUCH. FUN.

These charbroiled oysters could easily be my last meal request. Unreal how tasty they are. Cannot get enough. I had a cup of the seafood gumbo which was good but not $8 good. Overall service was very good, not busy at all on a Thursday afternoon. Will always find a Drago's when working in NOLA.

Came here because of the highway signs.
Good food, good price. The guys working back there perhaps seemed a tad nicer than other places that I've been to in Northern Virginia , but maybe it's the water in Delaware that makes people nicer.

Nice big parking space!

I've stopped by this location a few times because it's right near the highway. It's a chain, so the food won't be any different from any other Jimmy John's in America. The thing that's disappointing about this is how slow service is. 
When you think Jimmy John's, you think, "Freaky Fast, Freaky Good." My experience with this sight has been "Freaky Slow". On my last trip, I ordered two sandwiches, two bags of chips. I hung out in the drive-thru, watched the gentleman that took order restock chips and replenish cups... still no sandwiches. I saw him take an order over the phone, speak to a delivery person as they returned... still no sandwich. Then, after some more hanging out in the drive thru, I got my sandwiches. Sadly, in the time between me ordering my food and actually getting it, he'd forgotten my order. I had to remind him that I ordered chips. He hands me one bag. I reminded him there were two, he handed me another. My hope is that the experiences I've had are isolated instances. We shall see.

This is a great place for a girls night out or a big birthday dinner. BYOB so thats always a plus. i came here with about 11 girls and we all got about 2 rolls and ended up each paying 22 including tip which is amazing. The presentation of the sushi here is always beautifullllll. Each one is different and the sushi is always freshly made. I'm a huge fan of the yakitori and sashimi salad here, very fresh and delicious. I have no complaints except that they need to BLAST THE AC, it gets so hot so fast.

Elk, wild boar, goat burger? All in one place and conveniently located just 5mins from home? Sweet. 

Our waiter Tony was pretty awesome. Normally I wouldn't remember our servers name. But he repeated it enough for it to stick in my head. Being our first time at Bareburger, he explained the items on the menu and told us which stood out the most. 

We got the Bison and Elk... They were definitely a different texture from the normal cheeseburgers you get. The meat was very soft and tender. We also got the fries and rings with the sauce. If you want the one with the sauce, make sure you order that one. Because there's a regular fries/rings and fries/rings with sauce (i saw a snobby woman at the table next to me pretty much demanding for her sauce. I say., she prolly ordered the wrong one). Anyways, they have four types of sauce., which i forgot and too lazy to google it back up.. But you'll see it on the menu. We also got the ginger green tea. The ginger was very powerful. Enough for me to forget that it was tea that i ordered and not ginger ice water. 

Why three stars? The portions quite small. And the prices are a little bit on the higher side. 2 burgers, fries/rings, and 2 green tea for a little over $40. 

The experience is worth it if you want to try Elk or even goat =)

It's been quite a while since I was last at Brio, and not a lot has changed since the last time.

Brio's always had a nice location at the corner of the Plaza Frontenac parking lot overlooking Manchester Road, with a large outdoor patio for diners. The other week, the weather turned nice enough that we decided to try dining outside for a change and Brio sounded good.

What I always forget about Brio is that even at lunch time nothing is under $10 on the menu. At least they've started adding some healthier options to the menu in addition to the pastas, flatbreads, soups and entrees. And although the menu seems large, it's actually a bit sparse in options (and my mom asked for the gluten free menu and was given a list as small as the little special card - not very accommodating, in my opinion).

I ended up ordering a quinoa chicken salad, my mom had the strawberry fields salad with chicken and my dad got the lobster bisque and salad. Everything was fine, but I wasn't overly impressed, especially since everything was $12 or more. It just seems expensive for what it is.

Luckily, we went on a weekday, but on the weekend, trying to get in for lunch is nearly impossible without a reservation. Brio's is very popular even though it's just average as far as food goes. But I guess if you want to see and be seen in Frontenac, it's a safe bet.

Not a lot of selection to be honest, but it's nice to have a corner market in the neighborhood for basic items. Stopped by here to get a few snacks and toothpaste. They have a deli in the back of the store and a soup bar. It would be a nice if they'd run a meal deal like the ones in England or Ireland. Mark & Spencers, Sainsbury, Tesco, Lidl, Dunnes....They all offer some sort of meal deal which includes drink, sandwich, and chips! This store is very basic. I didn't see anything good on sale either.

Best Thai restaurant on the loop! In case you didn't know, ALL the thai places on delmar are owned by the same people, but for some reason this one is the best. 

They serve reliably delicious thai food with fast service, making Thai Country a great place to come with a group. Portions are large and usually involve yummy leftovers the next day. My recent favorites include the panang curry and crab rangoons. The noodles and rice dishes are also a safe bet. Just make sure to be clear on what level spice you want!
Over rated.... the broiled oysters are just OK.  Shrimp and grits were just OK....everything else also just OK...

Hands down in the future when aging 21st century New Orleanians wonder how and why the Warehouse District became one of the beacon neighborhoods to the Crescent City, look no further than this site once a successful Cadillac dealership.  My dad used to sell Caddies here, and his desk was where the wine is now.  Rouses deserves amazing amounts of credit and respect for this successful transformation of use of space and reinvention, not too mention the balls to take the risk.  Hats off!

At the core it remains what all other Rouses are: local, fresh, and customer focused.

Came here during a recent trip home from FL.  Parking is off street or you can take your chance in the private lot across the street.  The shop was busy with tourists and students but that is to be expected since it was featured on Diners, Drive Ins and Dives.  

There is no "line begins here" sign. You just push in wherever there is space, get someone's attention and place your order. I noticed they had unique flavors like Mexican hot chocolate and lavender honey. After requesting a few samples, I went with a scoop of salted caramel. Creamy and good.  The service wasn't exactly warm and friendly . More like blunt with no personality. The girl hurriedly took our orders and directed us to the cash register. Not exactly tip worthy.  

Overall, a cute little spot to stop in for a snack if you're in the area.


WARNING:
Make sure you bring cash as they do not accept debit and/or credit cards.

Came here with the family. As a Filipino-American, especially being a first born in America, my lens for things is different. And needless to stay, I've noticed that there are not many Asian people walking around Tuscon or going into Mexican restaurants in Tucson (or even AZ as a whole). That being said, when we first walked in with a group of 7 of us, we got strange looks from the wait staff and kitchen peaking at us!  And after a couple of minutes and big smiles from our group, the wait staff ladies eventually warmed up to us and showed us their smiles. I have to admit that was a tense 3 minutes! 

Came here after reading on the "visit Tucson" website that this place was on the famed 12-miles of authentic mexican food, and they served a proprietary dish called chicharon camarones...basically fried shrimp balls. Hmmm I was intrigued! Overall I agree with some that this wasn't the "best" mexican food I've had. It was pretty standard tasting really. Maybe my taste buds are biased because I'm a San Diego born Mexican food lover. California does it's Mexican Food different than Arizona! However this restaurant does have some stand out dishes that aren't found at every Mexican joint. I wish I would have ordered more of the seafood items here. Here's the quick and skinny on the rest of the food/place:

Pros:
-Large portions, freshly prepared food
-Quick service
-Cheese Crisps! I actually think this was my favorite item of food I ordered. It's huge, tasty and really satisfying. Don't call it a mexican pizza, tho it looks like it. It's way better, less "doughy". 
-Chicharon camerones, yes this is different. It's not flavored a whole lot which is good because you can taste the shrimp and they served it with sauce. This is different, I haven't seen this item at any other mexican/latin restaurants I've been to. 
-Service was quick, but it wasn't a busy evening either. 

Being that there are so many other Mexican restaurants in Tuscon and Tuscon is a "gastronomic city" I'd have to try other restaurants in town to really know what the food scene is about in this town.

I was in the area with my sister, my bro-in-law and the bf to look at marble for a kitchen island.  Unfortunately, everything was closed on Sundays.  So when I saw Kermit's, we decided to check it out so our trip wasn't completely wasted.   

I got an everything bagel with plain cream cheese and my sister got the plain bagel with scallion cream cheese.  The bf got some coffee and a slice of cheese pizza.   While the bagels were just okay (NY bagels are incomparable!), the scallion cream cheese was very flavorful.  The pizza was delicious!  I can see why people are raving about Kermit's pizza.  That's the only reason to come here.

We also got the yo shorty cake, which was some almond cake with a weirddddddd raspberry cream in the middle and mousse and a strawberry glaze.  It was beyond gross!  No one could eat it at my house.  The raspberry in the inside of the cake was rotten or something.  We also got a vanilla cream puff for my mother.  She hated it.  The texture of the cream was super thick and sticky.

Pizza, yes!
Desserts, no..

Two stars for the gross aftertaste that cake left in my mouth

This is a review for all my vegetarian friends. 
I came here early on a thursday before the dinner rush. The place was already full, so we managed to squeeze in some seats by the bar. This small, cozy restaurant was the perfect place to quickly grab a bite on a rainy day. 
We ordered their spicy fat noodles and coconut curry noodles. The spicy fat noodles are different, not in a broth, and have a spicy sesame flavor to them. The cocunut curry reminds me a vegetarian version of ramen. I personally like the coconut curry noodles wayyy more than the fat noodles. 
Side note: apparently the garlicwings are amazing, every table had them. 
Regardless of what you order, you MUST get a thai iced tea. Its one of the best in the city!

We came on a Sunday night and the place was packed.  The service was great though. We had many different people talking to us and serving us. We loved it!

We ordered the seared tuna salad, cream shrimp pasta penne and
corn and cheese grits.  The tuna salad was very good. The shrimp pasta was creamy and delicious.  The corn and cheese grits actually tasted really good.  I usually dont like grits so I was surprised I enjoyed this dish. It must have been all the butter in the food. Yum!

I think the rating would scare people off but I'm glad I came here. The food is not exactly the American-Chinese food you'd expect for Isla Vista. It's very asian here, that's probably part of the issue people have with the service. My expectations weren't high but honestly there isn't good service in Isla Vista anywhere.

Chongqing Beef Noodles were very good. I don't normally order off of pictures but I went with it this time. 

Not a bad place to eat. It's not the greatest though, but more deserving than its current rating.

Alert! If you have not been enjoying the deliciousness that is Food + Drink then you really need to take advantage ASAP! Because... the owner announced this week that the restaurant will only be open through June 27, 2021. Oh my...

If you need a reason to try out this pizza then please continue reading my review. Through the pandemic my husband and I tried to enjoy the fact that we suddenly had weekends together--like every weekend--so we created our Friday night ritual, Pizza Friday. We stumbled upon Food+ Drink during our Reno pizza tour and immediately were in love! The pizzas paired well with our "to-go cocktails" from other local joints. However, the pizza was truly delicious, especially the Kendy! All the ingredients were fresh and made from scratch. The difference was noticed from the very first bite of pizza all the way to the last bite of their Magic Cookie. Oh, yes! I loved that cookie. We first had it because the owners' mom gave us a complimentary one with our pizza. So sweet! After that we were hooked!

The owner, Aaron, spent most of the pandemic working with his parents and keeping their bubble safe and healthy while still serving up some great pizza. Now he has some friends on his crew who were moving to Reno and getting settled. Food + Drink was a safe place for his family and friends as well as a safe place for my family. 

Today (and for the next week) the restaurant will be open for pick-up, outdoor dining, and indoor dining. If you want to dine indoors be sure to bring proof that everyone in your party is vaccinated. Still important to be safe y'all. Anyways, if you haven't been yet I would highly encourage anyone to check it out before the doors close forever. I went tonight and will miss their delicious food.

I went in to Big Lots real quick to pick up some laundry detergent because Big Lots usually has  competitive prices on laundry detergent and other household items. The store was very clean an organized. Every employee had masks on.  All of the staff, from the people stocking the shelves to the cashier, were friendly and professional.  As I walked around the store, I was asked several times if I needed assistance. They had markers on the floor indicating  where 6 feet apart would be and had signs all around the store on the shelves with friendly reminders that we should socially distance to keep ourselves and others safe. You can buy online and pickup curbside and that's really helpful since we're going through this pandemic. The one thing I would say is you should bring your own sanitary wipes because they don't wipe down the carts or the little carriers so you can social distance all you want but if you touch that surface where somebody else was sick then those germs now belong to you too :-) So just give yourself some added protection, keep those wipes on hand. Which by the way,  you can buy at Big Lots! Big Lots has everything. I even picked me up some more Cafe Bustelo, cereal, and sarsaparilla :-)

Note:  No credit cards.  Also they close at 10 or 10:30 on weekdays.

I stopped in after the place I wanted to go to was closing at 8 PM.  It was 7:40 PM and I needed dinner and a quiet place to take a 1 hour conference call.

The young peppy (gorgeous) server was attentive and kind.
I did not get the $3.89 breakfast (served all day) deal - but that is alot of food and I will consider it when I want breakfast.

Mashed potatoes are from a box (so the server said) so I got a baked potato, ffrozen green beans and a surprisingly OK steak dinner.  Plus a large diet coke with Vanilla syrup in it.  (They can also put cherries in your soda).

Very reasonable CASH only prices.
Dated decor - but I bet it's fun when you are wasted on a Friday or Saturday night.

It's been here for YEARS.

They have amazing handmade pasta. Please do yourself a huge favor and go here. They are a byob spot however they do have a bar so it's ok if you didn't bring anything. The Cacio e Pepe and bolognese were AMAZING. Phenomenal!

With 6 burger joints opening in the next year, I feel it is my duty to get this review in the books. I'm excited about the new burger offerings but they will have their work cut out for them. Burger Republic is top notch. You have high hopes for a place that specializes in three distinct things; burgers, beers, and milkshakes. After surveying the menu I chose the west coast burger. It consists of two thinly pressed patties mustard steamed with american cheese, BR sauce, lettuce, tomato, and onions. It was perfection! I actually likened it to the Husk burger. I was equally as stuffed after this burger too. I paired my patty with tator tots. They were classic, nothing crazy, but if you like truffle tots this is where you need to be! We also split the Philly egg rolls which were good, but next time I may only get a burger, mostly because of its size. The manpanion was equally as impressed with his burger, as was the rest of the table. As for the milkshakes, they were super rad! They have spiked milkshakes and regular milkshakes. I went with the Chocolate Peanut Butter and the honeybee went spiked with the Maple Bourbon. They were both crazy good! They were thick, they had a ton of whipped cream, and they were flavorful. I was slurping the bottom trying to get every last drop. Finally the beer, they have the usual Nashville suspects. It's hard when our distribution is so limited.

As for the ambiance it's cool and casual. They have large booths, large TVs, garage doors, and a large patio. Everything you would want when slurping down a milkshake or indulging on a giant burger. The service was fantastic and our food came out in a timely manner. Actually a little faster than timely. They were on the ball! Burger Republic has officially moved into my top 5 burger joints in the Nash.

When the plate was laid out before me the first words I uttered were, "Now that's what chile rellenos are supposed to look like." 

And they were good. Could have used more cheese, but good nonetheless. 

Beans and rice were good. Chips and salsa were good too. It's all good. 

Except for the fresh flour tortilla they gave me. That was GREAT. Especially when tearing it up and sopping up the sauces.

I absolutely love Ted Drews! It's one of the best frozen custard in STL! I've tried almost everything there! To name a few must have is orange slush, Carmel apple sundae, strawberry shortcake, all shook up, and their pumpkin  yumm . I would highly recommend everyone trying out Ted Drews at least once in their life time! In the summer it can get extremely busy so now is a good time to go!

Finally tried Ted Drewes! This place is one of the things St. Louis is known for so I was so pumped to finally try this place out. Came at around 2 on a weekday and was surprised that there was actually a line?

I will not lie, I have no idea what is the difference between frozen custard and ice cream, but whatever I ate, it was good!
- Cardinal Sin - So so YUMMY! I never had hot fudge on ice cream before and this was the perfect combination. The berry syrup with the rich chocolate contrasted perfectly with the ice cream and I really appreciate the whole chunks of cherry they had in there.
- Peach - I didn't like this one as much, I thought it would be peach flavored rather than mixed in peaches, but once again, I appreciate the whole fruit they put into the custard.

To be honest, I think I like ice cream a little bit more (it wasn't mindblowing), but not mad about this place at all! Will definitely come back because of its prices... it's so cheap!

Desi Chaat is one of those places that I have enjoyed time and time again over the years. But with the larger spot that Mood Cafe offers, Hassan and his crew have really managed to kick things up a notch and do some of the traditional and innovative recipes that their previous area couldn't maintain.

Mood does have a lot of the same menu offerings as Desi. But the larger food prep space does allow them to engage the customer with a lot more presentation when they put together the many ingredients that goes into their chaat recipes. This can make for a good interactive show of sorts that caters to your customization; especially when you factor in the number of spices, nuts, fruits, and other ingredients that you can add. Add in some chaat recipes variations that take on influences from other cultures, and things really start to get interesting.

Another plus to Mood is that its menu puts much more emphasis into the lassi, ice cream, and hot beverage side of the menu, making it a great spot to go to please your sweet tooth and grab a beverage on the go. Namaste!

This is the best custard I have ever tasted! I was expecting it to be really heavy and too sweet, but it was lighter and the perfect consistency- I could actually eat the entire thing. Also, you can hold it upside down for a couple seconds, and it won't all out. There are so many flavors and special combinations that they offer. I got the Hawaiin one (macadamia nuts, pineapple, and coconut), but I would recommend the "Blues" custard- it's lemon blueberry and is sooo amazing. It was pretty crowded at 9PM at night, but the service was quick. Definitely coming back here the next time I'm in St. Louis.

We had such a FUN Digital Date Night with a Free Online Class offered by Picasso & Wine.  We found the painting class via Social Media for a Friday date night option with all of the instructions posted.  You had the option to order painting kits from them with or without brushes (here's a link:  https://squareup.com/store/picasso-and-wine/item/complete-art-kit) or you could even paint along with your own supplies, talk about easy - now that's AWESOME!  There was a deadline to order the kits from them as their hours are limited, understandable with everything happening currently and they even offered delivery for the area around the studio.  With us living in Carson City we were limited on time with our work schedule for pickup but not to worry Picasso & Wine also shared another outlet for ordering additional supplies for the online class - they ROCK!  We opted for the online supplies and they arrived on time for the our digital date night.

Painting was LIVE on Picasso & Wine Facebook page at 7pm PST with Jen giving detailed instruction that was a FUN pace.  We never felt like we were falling behind or not able to understand her, although she couldn't hear us we were able to give her thumbs up and hearts or type messages to her in the chat section of the live feed as we followed along.  My hubby and I truly enjoyed Jen and her husband as they playfully bantered back and forth, laughed, painted and successfully guided us through a GREAT date paint night.  Look forward to our next at home paint date night!

HIGHLY recommend the online virtual painting classes ~ the instructors and painting are great FUN!!  Be sure to check out their upcoming classes, they have FREE ones for not just date night but for the kids and some that are only $10 - now that's AWESOME!!  Here is the class that we did for $10 (https://squareup.com/store/picasso-and-wine/item/happy-campers)  We also had the option (which my hubby and I took advantage of) to 'Donate To Our Artists Fund' by showing your appreciation to the artist that instructs the online paint class by going to the Picasso & Wine page here:  https://squareup.com/store/picasso-and-wine/item/donate-to-our-artists-fund - please let them know you appreciate them!

Below is the list of supplies we used for this class:
Art Supply List: 
2-12x16 canvases
Paints-Red, Lemon Yellow, Cobalt Blue, Ultra Marine Blue, Burnt Umber, White, Black
Brushes-1" Flat Brush, 1/4" flat brush, #6 round brush

Reviewer No. 100!!!! 

5 stars! As good as it gets. 

I haven't been to too many candy stores, but this one tops all others that I have been to. Located in Boise's Northend near downtown, surrounded by a small row of restaurants, bars, and the like in a residential neighborhood, sits this cute and nostalgic candy store. 

Once you walk in you'll be greeted with many yummy smells. To the right of you is the candy corn area and to the left is many plus animals and toys that you can purchase-- there is also one of the penny flattener machines in this area, too. 

Once inside you can get your choice of many different pieces of candy from chocolates to gummy bears, or even get yourself a banana split or brownie sundae (see my photos). If you're in the mood for espresso they've got you covered, too! 

I can only imagine warm summer evenings at this place. I've been twice and both times were after having dinner with my friends in nearby restaurants. I can't wait to take my kids here!

The staff is friendly and welcoming. The prices are fair, better than the candy shop in the mall. The name says soda fountain and I didn't really pay attention to any sodas or notice them.

I've never had Benihana, this was quite the experience. I loved the show which I though it was worth 4 stars but I felt like the food quality to price ratio made this place worth 2 stars.

I had the Benihana salmons with avocado tartar sauce with udon noodles. Which sounds lovely but the dish was not extraordinary. The avocado tartar was disappointing. I ordered salmons because I have borderline high cholesterol and shellfish/steaks might push me over the edge to heart disease land. :( i feel like the show may be worth the experience if you have never done so.

Gets the job done.

If you're looking for a weekend getaway in SB and won't be in your hotel room often but still want somewhere that will do more than leave the light on for you, this quaint hotel is just the spot.

Likes:
-dispensers for soap and shower products that are squeeze bottles (I have recently discovered a pet peeve of hotels that use bars of soap or the twist off cap style dispensers
-comfy bed
-spacious closet
-complimentary parking
-location (walkable to state street, right across from the pier, and a stone's throw away from the little street that has a couple wine tasting rooms)

Appreciate:
-complimentary coffee/tea station available at any time
-complimentary wine and cheese in the evening (I believe 5-7pm). While it may just be cubes of cheddar and pepper jack and carafes of what I assume to be cheap wine, it's a lovely gesture and a nice way to accompany the getting ready for the night process

Not a fan of:
-the bathroom window was at street level (facing the alley that other guests had to take to their room) but provided no proper blockage so we had to time our bathroom visits just so as to not give a peep show to any passersby 

Staff was nice and the rate was economical given that we shared the rate between three people.

Sweet spot for northern Italian food. Darling sidewalk dining and great selection of pasta and fish. The menu is on the small side but offers very distinct flavorful dishes. I had the special...ziti with sausage and the flavor was spectacular. My daughter ordered the shells grandiose arrabiato. It was delicious...full of flavor. We had the olive oil cake for the ending.. complete with lemon curd. So good. Our server was sweet, knowledgeable and attentive. They have a selection of cocktails and wine but will honor the bottle that you bring from home as well. It's a great place!

Also come to one of these every time I'm in Santa Barbara. Now there are a dozen locations but it all started with three friends into endurance sports in 1994. This place is not akin to Jamba Juice, it's very natural and healthy, you can taste the fruit junks. The boosts aren't cheap products either so it's more of a hippie smoothie shop than a fad. For all of this, it's not cheap but it is well worth it.

This review is for this particular location concerning their parking, store size, and items offered.  Ask anyone and they'll tell you that I LOVE whole foods, but this store not so much.  The parking lot is tiny, the store is crazy packed, and there are only TWO restrooms.  The meat department is teeny tiny and doesn't have much of a selection. I was surprised at how small of a store this was and the limited items they carried.  It's almost as identical to the whole foods on south street which is an even worse location with the same store size. I'll stick to shopping at the cherry hill location. Sorry WF on Pennsylvania ave for the low love, but I still love you whole foods market.
Must try... Feta Fries, Lamb Sliders and the Macaroni and cheese.  The band was excellent but the singer was more like background noise.

tried Lamb Kadhai; chunks of lamb with veggies in a very spicy reddish sauce, it was quite good, although the spiciness level was very high (and I am a big fan of Mexican and Korean food..) This Indian restaurant is huge, it seems to cater to large parties and banquets, there were a lot of people there at 10 PM on a Saturday night and they were ALL Indians (or maybe Pakis or Bangladeshis) except me.  So I guess that is an authenticity endorsement.  The waiters were a bit emotionless and robotic in their interactions with me, but they were polite and the food was quite good  This is a hotel restaurant and the restaurant itself is somewhat hidden behind the motel , it is part of the motel structure.

This tour was fun and good, but not great.  

I really appreciate all that the tour guides have to put up with in this city - talking back from drunk people in the crowd, random questions, dealing with traffic and pedestrians, and many, many other tour groups all dealing with the same subject and visiting the same locations.  

My tour guide, Randy, was well spoken and discussed everything as part of the tour.  I appreciated that he did not oversell or overexaggerate anything, and provided a skeptical point of view and was very "matter of fact" about the happenings described. 

Somehow I thought the "Five in One" tour would be five different tours, or perhaps five tour guides, combined in one tour.  But this tour has one story each from five supernatural factual histories from the French Quarter, including Vampires, Zombies, Ghosts, Voodoo, and "Magic".  

At the end, our group was all given a "magic spell" to do at home to attract love into our lives.  Eye roll, but fun none the less.  

I don't know how this compares to other tours.  Our group was large and the tour was fun and interesting.

There's nada I love more than quality Mexican food, and Nada delivers.

It lives up to the hype. From the sleek and sexy cantina bar to the delicious salsa trio with a kick, Nada puts a modern spin on Mexican cuisine. I can't get enough of the salmon tacos topped with chipotle crema, jalapeno corn pico, and cilantro - a fiesta in my tummy. The senor mu shu taco is also a winner in my book.

At lunch, the "taco lunchbox" includes two tacos (no mix and match option available), a side (most of which are healthy - go for the pickled cucumber salad for a refreshing crunch) and two "almost guilt free" donut holes. 

Not feeling tacos? Try the seasonal gazpacho - the greek yogurt and avocado adds a nice creaminess. The chicken tortilla soup is also worth checking out.

You can't go wrong with your selection at Nada. I highly recommend checking it out to get out of your burrito routine.

Great food, great service, great atmosphere. Came here for brunch after Sunday morning workout, and there was space. The St. Paul Bao  was heavenly. Light, with a delicious aoili, tender near and fluffy Bao. The coconut soup was spiced with pepper oil , fresh mushrooms thin cut, and an order of fries. The manager said the kitchen had an extra order of wings, and the table next to us, who happened to be really nice, shared them with us. The wings were crispy, the best type of crispy, airy, a medium weight breading, full of flavor and inside was tender chicken, not at all oily.

I like this place for two reasons- delivery and sushi.

We just ordered dinner for cheat day and although I'm about to go on a sodium overload I think I may have had the best supreme spicy tuna roll in my life- spicy tuna on the outside, California on the inside. 

I've ordered and eaten in here and the place is drab and loud and dark but sterile in appearance (if that combination is possible.) 

The only downside about this place- everyone else knows it's good- so we waited for an hour and some change for delivery...but that's what we get for being lazy, I suppose. 

I might go out and get another Supreme Roll...seriously, diet cheat day only comes once a week.

Having a great time at Picasso and Wine! My girlfriend and I painted a picture, shared some laughs, and fell a little more in love! I am no Picasso, however, after my night with Danielle painting a picture I feel like our art is worth a million dollars. 
I highly recommend dropping into one of the couple classes like the one Danielle and I participated in. If you are looking for a fun date night with your significant other, I HIGHLY recommend this place!

Wow!  This place was packed this afternoon. We went inside, waited in line for 15 minutes. We only got a cookie- dough concrete today and it was great.  The employees we encountered were all friendly and helpful. The staff was also very allergy-friendly and made sure our concrete was made taking the appropriate precautions. 
We look forward to trying this again soon. 
(Although we didn't order lunch here, the counter staff was telling you the wait for lunch after ordering was 25 minutes).

Royal Chef is much bigger inside than it appears from outside. There are actually ten tables for dining in, so it is more than just a takeout joint. I stopped in for a late lunch and ordered from the lunch menu (General Tso's Chicken, Fried Rice, Broccoli with a bowl of Wonton Soup).

The soup was actually the strongest part of the lunch. The chicken consume base was tasty, and the wontons, although somewhat thick skinned, actually had a decent flavor, too. The general's chicken was a large mound of amber glossed bird nuggets. About half of them were the right texture and taste, while the others were either too thickly skinned, or too crunchy to enjoy. Could not always taste the meat within. The fried rice was a large helping with adequate veggies to keep it interesting. Of course, the broccoli florets were there for decoration more than consumption. 

The meal was just okay overall.  I appreciated that there was a dining room where I could sit and eat lunch.  It would have been even better if they used real plates and flatware, rather than styro and plastic, and a take out container for the soup.  Service was provided by the cashier who was attractive and pleasant to all customers.  

The sign out front is worn and faded, and could use a little TLC to keep the shop from looking worse than it is. A little fresh paint and relettering would make China Chef a more upbeat place to chow down (no pun intended).

How could I not like Sonic?  They have a Peanut Butter Shake.  I've had a hard time finding those, so I always enjoy resisting the urge to actually get one.  My waistline clearly shows how often I am successful at this.

You really can't go wrong with Sonic!

How can you miss the mark on coffee and eggs? I ordered scramble eggs but, got fried. The coffee was...blah. No flavor at all. Of course, I had high expectations for the pancakes and UB certainly delivered! 

Their hours are very convenient 24/7.

As always I like my girl to go with me so we can get 2-3 items incase the place is having a bad day for one particular item. However this place went 0-3 on all three dishes. 
The positives. The location and the view. Not the best view from a Dunedin eatery but very good nonetheless. They have several tables to sit at and quite a few seats on the inside railing with counters. The two waitresses were excellent today. Never had to wait for a thing. They were on point. If one of us was out of water and the other waitress saw that she would immediately bring a new cup. They are perhaps the best waitress team of all time also the reason to add a star. Other positives are the extensive beer offerings and the prices of 4-5 for each one. 
The food I most likely would not go back for:
A special of Parmesan crab and shrimp dip was available. It was like warm. It did not taste very appealing and there were textures of coagulation like it was microwaved and cooked in certain areas. There was a decent amount of crab but only one piece of shrimp that we found. 
The cod tacos were also not very good. The fish tasted fresh and cooked properly. However the slaw was undressed raw cabbage and at the bottom of the taco was a large amount of straight lime juice. And not the sweet kind. Some type of cream would have brought this from a 2-4. 
Finally the 14 dollar blackened scallop wrap. Not edible in any way. There was no texture or carmelization on the scallops. The blackening was just a spicy mixture that mixed with some liquid and just poured out of the wrap. We took most of this home and hopefully I can try and save the scallops and get some of the 14 bucks worth. There is nothing worse than blackening season that was not cooked and BLACKENED. Blackened means to blacken the seasonings to char them if you will. It does not mean to just have a spicy seasoning on it. That is called seasoned. 
I would probably go back to enjoy the view a beer and the great service but the food is off limits for us.

Poor Santa Fe...It had a little bit of a following when it was off Frenchmen. I guess because back then they actually tried. Or it was because of the bar crowd *shrug*.
After going for an extended walk one afternoon, I brought my girl to the new Santa Fe location. We'd built up an appetite and needed some food.
 I told her a bit about how it was long ago and had hopes that it would still be similar. After all, it's just a different building, right?
Right?
We stop in and it's empty. I mean totally empty.
I walk in for a bit and finally, someone steps out from the back, looks surprised to see us and quickly gets us some menus. That was the only quick response the entire meal.
I noted that the prices went up. Ok...I can get that. Though some of it looked a bit too high for what it was, but again, we were hungry.
We ordered two beers and some water. Maybe 10 minutes went by before the beer arrived...no water.
Another 10 minutes go by (What? is there an inviso-crowd here that's keeping them occupied?) and she comes back to ask what we anted to order.
My girl ordered the Ensalada de pollo and I ordered the burrito. I asked for it extra spicy. She verified that and left.
While waiting for the food to come, a blond woman and what I was told was the owner came in. She was carrying a dog. Ok. I've seen a few bars that allow dogs so that didn't worry me too much. Like most fluffy dogs, it was shedding like a fiend but hey...as long as it didn't go into the kitchen, it's cool.
Of course, then she took it into the kitchen...where it remained for most of the time we were there!
If only there had been a health inspector in the restaurant...but half an hour into this mess, still no other customers. 
After about a 15 minute wait, our food was delivered.
I will admit that the girl's salad was pretty. Lots of fruit and such on it.
But the chicken was boiled in what seems to be plain water and had no taste at all. Nothing...nada...It was ex-chicken.
My burrito filling must have been mixed and cooked days or weeks before because I could not identify what meat it was. All I could taste was oil. The sauce on the plate was hardened around the edges, obviously microwaved to death. I don't think they did anything to my food but put it pre-made onto my plate and nuke it. Seriously bad and not spicy (Unless oil is the new chili powder...I admit to a certain heart-burn after the meal).
It was a horrible meal and a I would never send anyone there who I liked...or even disliked a bit.
Maybe a lawyer or politician or something. No actual feeling humans though.
And I'm guessing the dog liked it in the kitchen.

This place gets a solid 3 stars (3.5 for the free yelp checkin edamame and groupon) and gets added in to the sushi rotation.

PROS
-Reasonably priced (bill came to 40ish for 2 hungry sushi overeaters).
-Interesting rolls- The waitress recommended the Bloomingdales roll-pink, with spicy tuna, salmon, kani, shrimp, and yellowtail, topped with longan (it's like lychee).
-Really nice presentation- seriously, flowers, and giant leaves all up in there.

CONS
-Service-um...where's my plate? We had to flag down the waiter when it got busy, but when they weren't busy there was serious hovering happening. you brought me the wrong check (we didn't notice) and asked us to fix it as we were literally on our way out? 
-Mixed Tempura was pretty small (although only $7) and wayyy too much tempura on the shrimp. I'm not even sure there was a shrimp in there.
- Is Nicki Minaj appropriate dinner music? Unclear.
- I felt like I was on a date with the people next to us when it got crowded. Which was awkward, because they were on a date, I'd say first or second judging by the conversation and polite laughter.

Definitely a steal with the groupon, and might even go again without!

It really is good, guys and gals!

I can't believe that I've never written a review for the Ted Drewe's Dutchtown location.  Well, I will fix that this morning, my Yeeps!

Like so many Saint Louis staples, what can be said about Ted Drewe's that hasn't been covered?  I have never had better frozen custard, period.  My first TD experience was in my teens, and I didn't return until my late twenties.  Seriously, what is wrong with me?!  Some people will talk about Mr. Wizard's or Andy's.  Hell, even Culver's has good custard, but Ted Drewe's will always be the custard king, no competition.

Now, one problem I have with the Dutchtown location is its seasonal hours.  I'm not entirely sure that it has an official opening date every spring.  In fact, there might be some subjectivity to it.  I always forget about it, and then one day it's open.  I try to go there in the fall, and then it's closed.  

No offense to the Chippewa store, but Dutchtown is where it's at!  The lines are always much more manageable.  Some people are not as comfortable in the neighborhood.  We often call them County Folk.  The quality is just the same, and actually easier to get to from most areas.  The Chippewa location is great, but you wait less and get the same awesome custard.

Two words:  Strawberry Shortcake.  Get it!

The chips and sauce they offer you to nibble on is amazing!!! Yum yum yum! I can never get enough of them. I usually go here for the wings because they're BOSS!! There's many different sauces to choose from so you have no choice but to return so you can try them all. It's a small, older looking building with a rather small parking lot, but I've never had a problem finding a parking spot, even when they have been busy. The food always comes out in a timely manner, so your mouth won't be drooling too much waiting for those wings. Whether you're grabbing a beer or at a table, this is a casual spot to go to. Don't forget, they have a wing special on Wednesdays! I believe it's 70 cents/ wing. Enjoy!!

A friend & I stopped in after the Carpinteria Beer Festival and were looking forward to some fresh food for an early dinner. We waited outside sipping water for about 30 minutes while they prepped for dinner service. That was great considering we had been in the sun for hours, so shade & fluids worked perfectly for both of us.

While the service was very nice, what didn't work so well for us was the quality of the food, including the fish & chicken. The fish just wasn't very good caliber, including bloodlines in the Yellowtail, plus the chicken was undercooked so much that my friend wouldn't eat it. I worked my way around the reddest parts, but we shouldn't have had to deal with undercooked poultry. She declined to order something else, so we settled the bill and figured it was a lesson learned.

Italiano's is the REAL DEAL.

Deep in the heart of South Philly, this place serves up some of the best water ice in the Philadelphia area. According to rumor, these guys pioneered the gelati - the decadent mix of water ice and ice cream.  From what I understand, Rita's doesn't even have the rights to call it a gelati - instead they have to call it a gelato.  The selection of flavors is simple - usually I opt for the lemon, and it's absolutely perfect.  Tart, and not too sweet.

I would agree with Marcello said - you can never really tell when it's open.  But it's worth the trip.

Two Words: Wok Away

I reaaaally did not want to go here, but my potential (training) client wanted to go. I ordered the kung pao chicken. It was really bland and cold in the middle. I guess they only microwaved it for 20 seconds.The sauce was more like a MSG soup. Service is non-existence.

I'd rather "Wok On the Other Side."

I wish we had 1/2 stars because based on the service and the value of my meal I would use that here. 

RTs has epanded their menu, salad bar and added drink specials, however, there is still just something missing in their entrees. 

I had Asiago Chicken and added a salad bar for $1.99 so the total meal was $20.00 .if your a mushroom lover this will make you happy. The overall flavor profile is not as dramatic as you would expect from the ingredients. I expected more, that's on me. I have one of the chicken breasts left for my lunch tomorrow and the meal was good, not great. 

I like creating my own salad, so I come here every few months for that and because their patio is pet friendly.

Yes, 5 stars.

Is it the 4 Seasons? The Ritz? No and no. And it doesn't pretend to be, either.

The location is great, just a couple short blocks to the boardwalk. Sambo's is about a 2 minute walk away. The pier/wharf is just a few more minutes walk.  State Street is not a far walk, either, except that the portion of State Street with all the action is probably half a mile away, still not too bad.

The hotel is clean, quiet and extremely quaint. Free hot (or cold) breakfast each morning, free wifi, free parking, and free treats at night. Walls are a bit thin so fair warning.

Rates are great, too. It feels a bit like a B&B without the forced camaraderie. I would return in a heartbeat.

Two words-GO HERE!!!!!!!!!  I am a huge fan of Mexican food and this is one of the best Mexican restaurants that I have been too. I actually found it on Yelp and the reviewers were right on the money. This is excellent. 
We received chips and salsa to snack on while reading the menu. The chips were warm and salty but not too salty. The salsa had a great flavor. I ordered the chicken quesadilla. It came with a guacamole salad. The chicken was tender and juicy. The guacamole leaned more to the creamy side. Sometimes quesadillas can be bland but the chicken had been marinated, slow cooked, and shredded into chunks. Because it was had so much flavor you didn't really need to add anything to it but I can't pass up guacamole. 
My mom had a poblano pepper and couldn't quit raving about it.  Everything was very fresh and very delicious. The service was excellent and the restaurant was very clean. It is very easy to give this place 5 stars.

Dirty tables
High prices
And the food really isn't that good.

But the thing that is really disgusting about 5 Guys are those scrofulous touch screen coke machines. I mean they can't be sanitary. I've never seen anyone clean the panels when I eat there. Also they are hard for some slower folk to use - too many choices.

As a vegetarian traveling to Tampa for a conference, finding a place that had quick service, different types of food and vegetarian options was awesome. My favorite was the fresh salsa bar - I just have some sort of odd fetish about delicious, unlimited amount of a variety of fresh salsa. I got a drink and the veggie nachos, giving me plenty of opportunities to use a multitudes of different salsa.

Servers were friendly and fairly quick. I will say it felt quite a bit overpriced for what I got, but at least I could eat something beyond mozzarella sticks and iceberg salad.

The better half and I stopped in at dinner for Teppanyaki. 

The location is very nice, but as other reviewers have said, it's quite large and feels a bit empty. 

For us, Service was prompt and friendly. We even had a table just to ourselves. 

Food was decent, but not great. I found the Sushi to be average (We ordered the "Sexy Girl"), but its possible I'm just a snob about such things. For dinner I had the Hibachi Salmon which was really good. I've never been to another Teppanyaki place that offered this so it was a pleasant surprise. The downside was the absence of Teriyaki Steak for the Hibachi. 

Overall I'd probably return, but only for the Salmon, which I did enjoy quite a bit, but it wouldn't be a strong recommendation to others if you are looking for something to just BLOW YOU AWAY.

Great for brunch even though a bit pricey but worth every penny.  I love that the food is a mixture of down home comfort food (grits, bacon, etc...) but upscale food such as bagel and lox.  Also, there is a huge dessert area.  The bottomless mimosas are amazing and as soon as you run low there is someone there to refill you up.  Food is amazing (especially the grits) and even though they have a buffet they still have a menu to order from.  The price is worth the quality of the food and this is a place I would love to go to now and then. Highly recommend but make that rsvp early because it is hard to make it the night before.

Hot busy day and stumbled in absolutely starving. One look at the gorgeous waitress and said a little prayer hoping for fast, and competent service before I just broke down and started spraying condiments down my gullet in a hungry act of desperation. Thought I could get by, by adding some crab legs to a few wings and possibly some shrimp. Wasn't going to happen. Only got to order five wings-thats it. My man got the other five, and a salad with a couple beers. After a bug-carcass filled beer, and a few wings we realized we weren't getting any more food. Not only could we not order any additional food after the first round, but what we did order would never be delivered to us. Server is AWOL although I can see her just inside the window fixing her face in a Covergirl mirror. Deciding we might sustain our lives by eating the salad we eventually got, it arrived all wrong. We cancel the order and crawl to Pete and Shorty's next door for nutrition. Had a far better experience sans young retarded waitress with coochie cutter shorts and tights that didn't match her skin tone. yay!

In some sense, you'd love your experience at a restaurant to be memorable. Great, hospital service, excellent food, interesting ambiance, and so on. On the other hand, you don't want it to be memorable. Intrusive service, lingering tastes, overpriced food, and unclean environment.

Well, I don't remember much at Sahara Grill. Even though I went there yesterday for lunch. Maybe it's because I grew up around cuisine like Sahara Grill's. Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, and specifically Egyptian. My shawarma was normal. I gobbled it up pretty fast and enjoyed it. But it wasn't mind-blowing--nor was it so horrible I could never forget it. Too much pita, not enough beef, but enough fresh veggies, cumin, and tahini sauce to make it worth my while.

I do remember the fact that it cost $7--when it should be 4. C'est la vie in Center City.

We wanted a quick lunch that wasn't fast food and was close to our hotel. We saw that Ellendale's had good reviews, so that was our choice. I am guessing we only got the lunch menu, as it was just sandwiches, pasta, and salads. We each got a salad and they were good but nothing special. I am guessing maybe their dinners are more exciting? The service was good and the ambiance was nice enough (though I can see how dinner might be more romantic).

Yes, it's the original Hooters location, opened in 1983. They're still serving up wings, shrimp, oysters and beer, but have since added to the menu to include wraps and even little dessert bites.

Our waitress, Momma J., who is expecting a little one, along with Assistant Manager, Pat, were on point in making sure the oysters, shrimp, curley fries and wings were exactly to our liking.

I was craving something other than beer, so I got a Red Sangria. Icy-cold and refreshing, it was just what the doctor ordered. My Daytona-style Sweet-Thai wings were also just right. But, the two of them together--not a marriage made in Heaven. No one's fault, but my own.

The waitresses STILL wear the little white tee-shirt material tops and the teeny shorts, just like they did it in the 80's.  Back then, it was pushing the envelope, but pretty tame by today's standards.

There are plenty of TV's all around with different sports on each, should you run out of conversation topics.  One of my friends mentioned the noise level, as it is a bit on the noisy side.  

If ya haven't visited a Hooters by now---where have you been?

In my opinion, you can't come to St. Louis without visiting Forest Park.  Dedicated in 1876, and home to the 1904 World's Fair, Forest Park is one of St. Louis' treasures and no park compares to Forest Park--anywhere.

More than 10 million visitors come to the park each year to participate in softball, cricket, rugby, tennis, golf, archery, lacrosse and soccer. They also ride bikes, ice and roller skate, roller-blade, jog, paddle-boat, canoe, fish and ride horseback. 

An estimated half million people attend special events, such as the Great Forest Park Balloon Race, St. Louis Wine Festival, Micro-brew Fest, Shakespeare in the Park, Wine in the City, and the Scottish Games.  An additional half million patronize the Muny.

It's a beautiful park that holds an art museum, a science center, a history museum, the Muny, the Jewel House, a world class zoo, a boat house where you can have a sandwich and rent paddle boats and canoes to float through forest park (i recommend this:  http://www.yelp.com/bi...), an outdoor ice skating rink, and a number of other neat venues.  Forest Park is surrounded by great architecture, a world class university and a world class hospital.

Forest Park ROCKS!!

Like every other Starbucks around the area same seating inside and outside, drive thru ordering and same with inside. They offer food to order and same with drinks including free WIFI! The customer service from the staff could use some work but other than that it was a great experience.

The place gets 3 stars for having free wifi. This is all important in our world of being techie geeks (admit it - you ARE one, even if you don't think so. own a smart phone? you are one).

another star because the ice cream and the service was good when we went. The con to this place is I feel (because I am not an ice cream shop connoisseur) the prices could go down a bit. The other con is that they need a bathroom. 

But, surprisingly I did not get sick after having their ice cream (lactose intolerant), so that also makes the 4th star.

Portions are humongous. not the negative here...but there is an issue when your favorite item out of the dish is the steamed broccoli. The fish was overly salted, but the corn grits? DELICIOUS. service was superb considering we had a 30 person group. enjoyable, but average food.

This is probably a better Cheesesteak than the score of 84 that I gave it.  I was really liking Lucky 7 and was getting excited for my cheesesteak.  The other sandwiches they were making looked very good.  They use a good amount of meat.  On the ordering kiosk the picture of the grilled mushrooms looked very good.  I got the grilled mushrooms and then paid the extra $1.50 for Sharp provolone thinking it would be a good combo with the mushrooms.  The mushrooms and onions spend a good amount of time on the grill together.  Unfortunately they needed more time and more mushrooms and onions.  They kind of got lost in the cheesesteak.  They ran out of sharp provolone so I got half regular provolone but was still allowed to pay the full $1.50.  Good cheesesteak experience.

Every guidebook mentioned Creole Creamery as a go to place to visit in New Orleans. Since my hubby and I ate at Milk Bar for lunch, we wanted to try this ice cream place for dessert. I like the ice cream parlor decor and the variety of ice cream or sorbets to choose from. The flavors were very unique. 

We had the Banana Cane Malt and Honey Lavender. Banana ice cream was sweet and had a strong banana flavor. Honey lavender had a strong lavender flavor. It was like eating a flower. The ice cream was good and creamy, but it didn't "pop" as I would have liked it. 

After eating at Chinatown Ice Cream Factory in NYC, I expected some more "wow" to the ice cream. 

Cash only.

The restaurant is open but there is only order off the menu with  service from the kitchen. The buffet is no longer an option. They will customize the food from the menu but it is very, very limited. Eggs prepared a few ways, a few meat choices, (ham, bacon, pork or chicken sausage, and turkey bacon) The chicken sausage is very sweet. The breakfast burrito is loaded with eggs, meat and cheese. It comes with potatoes  and a side of salsa. The poached eggs were cooked just like I like them, very soft and runny. The coffee is Starbucks and they also carry Tazo teas. 
Our server was efficient and brought our food to us as soon as it was cooked. Hot and tasty, I just wish there was a little more variety. Maybe some yogurt, cottage cheese, or grits. They were not anywhere on the menu and I am not sure if they could be requested. Might have to ask tomorrow morning as we are staying here at the Hilton Garden Inn another night.

Swamp tour 
Bring BUG spray! These native guides have been running these waters all their life. Comedy, info, super nice and gave us some great family time. Being from FL, living on a lake with alligators encounters on the daily, I thought this would be a boring trip on a pontoon boat. 
I was wrong! Def. make the trip outside of Bourbon and experience the bayou
Pro Tip: see my rain jacket...was very helpful for the cold water splashing!!
The food was delicious and the ambiance was excellent. A great place.

First time at this restaurant. I've been to a lot of the restaurants in this section of Esplanade and I wanted to try something new. Looking at the menu I was trying to figure out if there were vegan options or, vegetarian options that I could make vegan. I decided to try the veggie burrito and just exclude the cheese. That was a great choice! The burrito was filled with deliciously grilled veggies of all sorts. I enjoyed it along with their house made salsa and chips. 

We sat outside, which by the way, was also another great choice because despite the 40 something degree weather they made sure we kept warm. They setup partitions to keep the cold air out and provided heaters along with very warm blankets to wrap ourselves in. The owner kept coming by our table to check on us and ask if we were warm enough or if there was anything he could do to adjust the temperature. I really enjoyed my first experience at this establishment and I will be returning very soon.

I loved Super Tacos!  On Tuesday & Wednesday you can get specific types of tacos for just $1.

The tacos are yummy and loaded with cilantro if you love cilantro, you can request plain too.

My favorite part is the tray of choose your own salsas!

The menu at Drago's claims that the charbroiled oysters are the best bite of food one can find in NOLA.  Well, after eating my way through much of New Orleans, I wholeheartedly agree.  I've never had oysters before because they always looked slimy and gross in my opinion, but these were amazing.  The garlic, butter, lemon & charbroiled flavors were really a culinary masterpiece!  
The dinner I had at Drago's was delicious as well.  I had shrimp ettufee (sp?) and it was great.  My husband had crawfish ravioli that he raved about.
I would highly recommend Drago's to anyone visiting NOLA.  These oysters are a must!

We were in the Arts district and looking for dinner. Yelp to the rescue. Because of the area - there are many a steakhouse and other pricey options in this neighborhood. We wanted something a little more casual and not so expensive.

Sahara totally did the trick. It's a pretty small place, but I knew from the moment we walked it we were in a good location as there was a large group of middle eastern teenagers just hanging out. Another group came in while we were eating.

It says "home cooking" on their sign and I believe it - the food was absolutely delicious, and probably the most authentic I have had. The hummus was so good, very smokey. I got chicken and couscous and it was so yummy! 

Decor wise it was average - totally acceptable but nothing to write home about. Only four stars because the service was a little slow, and inattentive. They never asked us how the food was - not once, not even a the end of the meal. So four starts. We would definitely go back!

Man, this is my go to spot when I'm in NO. I make my best friend take me here at least one while I'm in town. The ice cream is so good and the flavors are heavenly. During Mardi Gras they have king cake flavor which is uh-ma-zing, and during football season the have black and gold which is just as good! Now, this place an get packed on the weekends and it's cash only! Also, don't be a sample hog, that's not cool.

My friends and I come here... Often, and late. Features of this diner that some other Philly diners lack:

Semi-secluded back room for us queer folk*
Friendly service
Ample parking
Delicious dessert variety
Cheese whiz. 


* note: this is where we like to sit. I am not saying they put us there for any negative reason. Just to clarify.

Italiano's is back! Finally! Stopped last night on way home from the shore. I read an article on philly.com saying they were open, I needed to see it for myself. 

We waited in a long line that wrapped around the corner. They don't offer many flavors, 5 or so. We went with chocolate and cherry. Both were as good as always! They are very similar to Pop's with a slight difference. Parking is horrendous but the water ice makes up for it. Solid 4 stars.

The Ritz East, or as Elizabeth B so memorably put it, the "Ritz Pagoda" is my heavy crush of the three RItz theaters just blocks apart in Old City.  These fraternal triplets show the artsy, indie and otherwise unknown flicks you must see, plus the occasional big-budget studio picture.  

Big reclining seats, icy cold A/C and not much of a crowd means you can get as comfortable here as on your own couch.  But don't take your shoes off, please; that's just weird.

Just added two new dishes to the excellent heat profile provided by Szechuan House.

The Chongqing Chicken is a first cousin to the Spicy Chicken Dry Pot Style I have had in the past. High burn with every crunchy morsel. Just below numb on the volcanic scale, perhaps not reaching conflagration due to the meager presence of Szechuan black peppercorns and reliance on red chillies to cover for their absence, but still excellent. 

The Crispy Fish Fillets Sweet & Sour was a large deep platter full of lightly fried fish and loads of orangey thick sauce. More Cantonese, but a strong interpretation. Really liked it in the face of all the other flames. 

The few other plates were good, but not worth taking up more space here in light of all the other fireball delights found in this still surprisingly authentic Chengdu palace.

Payette is near and dear to my heart. I can drink while my spawn runs around. :) The outdoor area is perfect for people who are always attached to creatures that need constant care (dogs, children, husbands). You can bring a blanket, or lawn chairs to sit in the yard. There are horse shoes and enough area for kids and dogs to run around. The beer is pretty good, not excellent, which is what earned 4 stars. But the atmosphere is 100% five star quality!
I come here for the sushi lunch deal like twice a month. It is so cheap for city sushi and it comes with a choice of soup or salad. They have a two roll deal or three roll deal and it's good food!
