First beignet of the trip. Sadly, it was just okay. Thick batter with an abundance of powdered sugar. WAY too much in my opinion. I wish I asked for it on the side so I could add my own amount. I liked how they were cooked to order though, so they were really fresh. Other than that, I was not too impressed.

I took a small team for a special celebration work lunch at Fleming's yesterday. There were 5 of us. The whole experience (with exception of the clumsy valet guy) was exceptional. Service was kind, abundant yet subtle. With the rainy day we started with soup, some had French opinion and others the lobster bisque. Both were very good but the French onion seemed the standout favorite. Four of us had the lunch special which comes with choice of salad, choice of steaks or salmon and half a side (still a large and shareable amount). The salads are large and very good. We had Caesar and wedge salads (not the only options). The wedge was so large that we each had half and took the rest to go. Both salads were covered in high end ingredients, very fresh with delectable dressings. The bread service of warm sourdough rolls with spreads (one and onion, red wine spread and the other a butter, ricotta spread) was refilled several times for us. 

Our steaks were high quality, cooked exactly as asked, tender and flavorful. The filets were served on a smattering of wonderful sautéed mushrooms and drizzled with a mild, thin blue cheese sauce. The strip steak had Brussels sprouts and a side of glaze. One of our party had the seafood Cobb salad with large shrimp and crab, and an abundance of other toppings like egg, blue cheese and glazed nuts.

Everything was excellent with the whole lunch exceeding expectations and my people feeling very pampered - which was the whole point. Service, again, was wonderful. I highly recommend. I read earlier reviews from when they first opened that seemed unimpressive but I experienced that they have worked out the kinks and are performing very well.

Very solid sushi available for delivery via Eat24! Crazy Sushi popped up as an option when I wanted a lunch delivery last week, so I decided to give them a try over my usual sushi delivery spot. Their lunch specials are legit (three rolls plus soup or salad for $12!) and I was very pleased to see the brown rice option for $1 more. 

My order arrived within the promised window (a very reasonable 30-45 minutes) and I was very happy with the quality of the food. The fish tasted fresh and the spicy roll wasn't drowning in sauce. Also, the rice wasn't too heavy-handed, which I was happy about. 

I repeated my lunch order today with the same great results. Crazy Sushi, you've got a new regular!

I honestly was trying to avoid going to BWW just because I knew it was a typical sports bar with wings and burgers, but my experience was very positive. The wings are very good, they're not the best I've ever had but the 16 different sauces is definitely an attractive offer. What also made my first visit extra special is our server, Mahmoud. He was informed that it was my birthday so they did the typical wishing me a happy birthday out loud along with free ice cream. Mahmoud  was very polite and took a great care of our table. 
Now would I go back to Buffalo Wild Wings? Absolutely. The customer service meets my standards and I freaking love chicken wings so heck yes.

This is the first time that I have been to Brio Tuscan Grille for dinner.  It was a beautiful night in October so we decided to eat on the patio.  We met some friends there, ordered drinks and looked over the menu.  No appetizers tonight because I wanted to have a full meal.

He started with a wedge salad.  It looked delicious and I was going to grab a bite but I decided it wasn't a good idea to put my hand where he could bite it.  Dinner consisted of the special ravioli for him (I think it was lobster) and the gorgonzola crusted beef medallions.  It came with roasted veggies, mashed potatoes and mushrooms in a marsala sauce.  We both agreed that our food was delicious.

Would I come back here?  Yes, it's a great place for dinner and lunch. I'll catch you on the flip side.

This store is a candy lover's (a.k.a. ME) dream! They have EVERYTHING! This was my first visit to the Boise location, and it was nothing short of magical. 

Husband and I were checking out Christmas lights and wanted some sweets. We shared a large Marionberry Milkshake ($6.95) and grabbed several candies. I believe it's around $33.00/lb. Some of the délectables we snatched were Peanut Butter Road, White & Strawberry Chocolate Covered Oreos, and a brown sugar based candy I can't remember the name of. We also grabbed a gift box, the last one! All items were so good! They didn't last very long at all. I finished them wishing I had grabbed more! The milkshakes are some of the best you'll ever have. Word of caution - they are super rich, so if you have a sensitive stomach, beware! You may want to save some for the following day. That's what we did, and it tasted just as delicious.

VERY CLASSY ! My wife found us this great place ( under $300 ) to stay overnight in Santa Barbara recently ( as she always does wherever we travel in the world ). We arrived quite late to check in at around 6.40pm on Thursday and Ryan the hotel manager / reception clerk was very kind to us. The Eagle Inn ( boutique hotel - bed & breakfast ) offers a variety of accommodation options and my wife had booked one of the private Casitas - "San Clemente" which featured a separate living room with a large screen TV over a double-sided gas fireplace connected to the bedroom, a huge spa bath in the bedroom plus an amazing fully appointed ensuite with rain shower + regular shower. Ryan noticed that we had expensive electric bikes on the hitch rack of our Tesla Y and offered us free overnight storage in the hotel's lock up garage ( where they stored hotel supplies ). Our ground floor private Casita was fully appointed with everything you might need such as Cable TV with free movie channels, high-speed internet connection, air-con, coffee maker, refrigerator, direct dial phone with voice mail, personal in-room safe, iron & board, microwave oven, AM/FM radio, hair dryer. Parking in the hotel's private lot was free. Ryan also reminded us the hotel provides a complimentary hot breakfast in the hotel's dining room ( at present on the dining room's outdoor patio due to covid restrictions ) or delivered to our Casita. What impressed us the most about our beautiful suite..everything worked perfectly...every switch we touched every button we pushed. The bathroom was amazing...totally pristine ! There was also a small private patio outside the living room. After getting our overnight luggage inside and wheeling our eBikes into the hotel garage we settled down on the sofa in the living room. We turned on the large screen TV over the double sided fireplace and enjoyed our dinner ...delicious gourmet empanadas from Buena Onda which we picked up on the way here. I poured myself an ice cold Almanac Love Hazy IPA and we watched the baseball world series. Dessert was a slice of heavenly Seven Layer Chocolate Cake we bought for lunch. The huge whirlpool Spa bath looked totally inviting but we were too pooped. The luxurious king size bed was totally comfortable and our sleep was not disturbed by any unwanted noises. The idea of a complimentary hot breakfast was enticing...in fact we checked out the hotel dining room as we left and breakfast looked outstanding. Ryan had told us we could retrieve our eBikes from the hotel garage after 8am so we did that first thing on Friday morning with the assistance of lovely reception clerk Cerese. Oh...and hotel guests are offered free use of bicycles. Everything about this beautiful hotel which is very close to the beach impressed us. We hit the road early at 8.30am for breakfast at one of our fav restaurants ( Jeannine's Restaurant & Bakery ) in Montecito. We'll be back for sure !

I have been dying to try this place. Heard alot of great things from people who visited in other places on the East Coast. It shocked us that on a Sunday that they had happy hour. We were not expecting that but price was regular hour if you ask me. My french martini was $11 during hh. We got the crab cakes on happy hour menu for half the price. They were so GOOD. If I had to do it over again would just order a white wine and crab cakes. 

It took forever for our chicken, potatos and spinach to come out. Spinach was super good too. Customer service was good. Wasn't a wait on Sunday night and parking is pretty good and valet is also an option. 

Nice music and love the wine bottles as decor. 

Thinking of bringing my picky auntie here for her bday. If I am bringing her here, I must really think highly of this place.

Famous for its frozen custard.  An icon in St. Louis.  Invented the concrete.  Never had a concrete in my life till today 9/28/2014.  I ordered a hot fudge concrete and it was huge and delicious down to the last bite.  I really don't have too much to add to the hundreds of reviews other than it deserves its reputation as an icon.

Hotel restaurants tend to get a bad rap in the food world, but if you find yourself staying at the Lowes Vanderbilt Hotel, you will be in for a treat.

I decided to dine here for a birthday celebration due to the good press Mason's consistently recieves in the greater Nashville area.

If you are not staying at the hotel, you can valet your car.  Do not forget to ask your server for a vocher.  This is a big bonus in my book because it is always gracious of a hotel to pick up the valet tab for their customers.  

The menu and decor both celebrates traditional Southern cuisine, however it didn't come off as upscale to me.  The menu and decor comes off as thoughtful, well planned with a side of kitsch.  Mason jars make up a majority of the decor.  The rich browns and clean lines make for a relaxing dinning room.  There is a private dining area on the side for larger groups (so keep that in mind yelpers if you are hosting a fun event).  I loved the bar menu, it was a leather bound booklet with a very beautiful picture of a rabbit on it.

I started with the Peach Old Fashioned.  They infuse makers mark with peaches.  The house made hop bitters cut through the sweetness of the peaches making for a well balanced drink.  My friend tried the House Made tonic and gin.  The tonic had a bit of an earthy taste to it.  Once the cocktail was completed, the biggest win was it was Wine Wednesday.  Half price bottles of wine (yes please).

The appetizer selection was good.  They were out of oysters, but I lived!  The crab corndogs are so good and the jars were a great complement.  I loved the pimento cheese and pepper jelly.  For dinner, I had the Chicken Gallatine with spicy collard greens and a turnip green puree.  All the flavors blended together beautifully and the chicken was very tender.  The Halibut and the Mason's burger were all enjoyed at the table.

Lastly, the Elivs dessert was the best.  I am of firm belief that dinner should be chocolate, upon more chocolate with chocolate and chocolate, plus some ofther stuff.  So that being said, dark chocolate mousse, with a bacon white chocolate brittle, peanut butter and bananna jam could have been my 1st, 2nd and 3rd course.

This place has officially surpassed the Melrose as my favorite South Philly diner.  Breakfast is consistently good, and they do dinner right.  They'll even give you a glass of house wine as part of some of the reasonably priced dinner specials.  You can't beat that deal.  And it's much more comfortable than the Melrose, which is cramped for a big guy like me.

Pretty tasty Thai food from a food truck. Food is served pretty quickly, but at the price of watery sauce. Staff is very friendly. 

I tried the red curry with beef. The sauce was essentially soup. But the flavor was good, and they gave a generous amount of beef and bamboo. It came with a good amount of jasmine rice. 

There is a small, basic room next to the truck if you want to "dine in," but you'll still be served with plastic containers and utensils.

All we ordered were oysters on the half shell and charbroiled oysters. Oysters were fresh and delish! Can't go wrong with that. Charbroiled were good but it was just cheese on top nothing special. I wanted to try Acme Oyster House but didn't get the chance to :(

This gorgeous shop is any glamour girls dream!

What caught my eye and got me into this shop were the lovely tiaras in the window. Honestly, I really want one, but I sometimes wonder if that's a level of "the most" that I'm not ready to approach just yet. Walking in, there are all kinds of high end sparklies that any woman would love. This is really high end costume jewelry, not the cheapo stuff that you might find at the mall (not that I have any issue with the cheapo stuff).

They have an entire table full of different rhinestone tiaras and another table full of rhinestone masks. If you're looking for something for a ball or a costume party, this is definitely the place. They even have a case full of rhinestone crowns, if you are really feeling regal and want to add some fancy head gear to your collection.

The shop owner was very sweet and asked if I needed help and informed me of the items that were for sale. I didn't purchase anything this time, but I do really want a fancy tiara, so I will eventually be back.

I was so excited to finally try this place! After passing it over and over again and never going in and even seeing it on tv, I knew that it was going to be good. I went in and I ordered a Black and Gold crunch in a waffle cone. It was sooo good. 

Although it's not gelato, the atmosphere of the place reminded me a lot of Brocato's with the atmosphere and decor. I guess it's the next best thing to Brocato, if you can't make it uptown. I think that this place is one of those NOLA "musts".

The Red Ox Inn is a first-class fine dining experience in an understated, comfortable atmosphere. The vintage sign out front indicates that the Red Ox Inn has existed in some form for years, but the interior and menu indicate that the proprietors are forward-thinking.

Located in a small storefront in the Strathearn neighbourhood, the general ambiance is that of a clean, high quality neighbourhood restaurant, accented by white tablecloths and hardwood floors.

There are maybe about ten tables in total, but spaced well apart from each other. The restaurant isn't too quiet, but not too loud either. You can converse easily and listen to some carefully picked mid-tempo indie rock tunes in the background.

Naturally, the food is the star here. The focus is on great flavor and great texture while still presenting the food in a unique way.

In our party of four, three ordered the (Vegetarian) green pea, hazelnut, and white chocolate soup as an appetizer and everybody loved it. I had a little taste and concur.

I went for the beet salad with goat cheese and received a completely new interpretation of an old favourite. Instead of larger beets cut into rounds, this was served with small, halved beets instead. This salad, while tasty, didn't wow me the way the soup did.

But the pheasant I ordered as a main did. The bird was cooked perfectly, complete with crispy skin. I also appreciated the romesco that they served with it. I'm a sucker for romesco.

Dessert was also warm, awesome and delicious. Service was non-intrusive and efficient - just the way I like it. And while Red Ox Inn doesn't officially serve bread, we asked for some to sop up the soup and they provided us with some delicious, and buttered, rye bread to do so.

If you are looking for a refined, fine-dining experience in Edmonton, you will not go wrong with the Red Ox Inn.

I was in the mood for some rotisserie chicken and thought I'd give Boston Market a try. Typically I pick one up at the deli in the grocery when I want one. But I was exhausted and the idea of a drive thru appealed to me. 

I had a salad at home that I'd put together and just wanted a whole chicken. That was the first thing that surprised me about Boston Market. There is no just buying a whole chicken. You can get a half chicken and it comes with 2 sides. Since it was just for me and my grandma, I thought that would be just fine. 

What I didn't realize is that it's a dinner for one. It really was enough for the two of us, especially with the salad I already had at home. But neither of us cared for the chicken, at all. It has a strange flavor to it. Doesn't even compare to the grocery store rotisserie chickens. Their green beans and red potatoes were good. The roll just looked funky and neither of us wanted it. 

The gal that took our order was very friendly and the line moved at a decent speed. But the chicken...just terrible. Next time I'll run up to Windixie.

As a loyal customer of the Publix directly next door, I've seen this place a million times but only visited a few. Every time I come inside here I think..... huh? This massive warehouse of randomness exists? WHAT IS THIS PLACE!?!? It seems pretty dated, and kind of sad. I don't see Kmart lasting much longer, but then again, there are always people inside buying things, so I suppose they are doing alright.

Last time I was here, I bought a hula hoop for dog-training class. It was cheaper than expected. Before that, a beach umbrella that never really worked. I can usually trust that all the cheap random items that I don't feel like trekking out to Walmart for will be here. Last year, they offered a Mother's Day special on Arbor Mist wine and chocolates... ratchet as that is, I plan on taking advantage of that deal this time around. As for the food, I'll probably skip it and go next door.

Side note, the check out cashier was not friendly. She didn't appreciate my attempts at communication. I have however have nice experiences with some friendly senior employees who were very helpful and personable. That's probably one of the only positives to this store.

We've visited Gateway to India several times since we moved to the area over the summer, and we're fans for a reason.  Don't let the empty parking lot confuse you; they have delicious food here!

I'm not usually a buffet fan, but their lunch buffet is great, and priced reasonably.  They always offer a few standby entrees you've come to expect (looking at you, chicken tikka masala) but the options vary, which is nice because you get to try new things.  They are good about including vegetarian options, too.  The buffet comes with naan.  We've gone for dinner a time or two as well, and enjoyed everything.  Between the buffet and dinner I know we've tried the tandoor platter, palak paneer, baingan bharta (eggplant-- to die for), the aforementioned chicken, tamarind chutney, regular and garlic naan, rice pudding, and mango lassi, with not a bad option on the list.

This place is adorable, and the perfect place to stock up on all the local items you'd pay a fortune for anywhere else.  I bought two 1 lb bricks and 2 12 oz bags of Community Coffee here for $30, which is a very reasonable deal considering one bag was their praline-flavored coffee.  YUM.

I would have loved to spend hours in here looking through all the aisles and goodies, but alas it was a quick trip this time around.  But I'll be back next time I'm in town, to stock up on water and other essentials before the night gets underway :)

Excellent quality meat with amazing spices!! This was my first time having a Ribeye since I am more of a filet type of guy but oh my gosh this was out of this world. The Flavor!!!! Thats all I have to say and how tender it is!! It almost makes me not want to order a Ribeye from anywhere else because I now know its not going to be as good as this place. Once you have to best its extremely hard to match it at another place. The only downside is the sides. Not a bid fan of the sides I have had in the past but the steak totally makes up for that. Cant wait to come back for more.

This cozy two-story cafe, close to the university, is always buzzing with students and draws a colourful crowd day and night. It has a Bohemia quality to it reminiscent of places I've been to in Toronto and Montreal that survive despite the mad sweep of chain shops like Starbucks. The smells in this place are mouthwatering - homemade Indian fare including samosas with a tangy dipping sauce, just referred to reverentially as "The Sauce" by staff and regulars, that's to die for. The Chicken chana masala in a wrap was so good I've dreamt about it that night! The chef and owner Zee Zaidi is super friendly, and the full windowfront exposure and sidewalk patio are great for people watching; or just sit back and enjoying a pistachio chai latte (it has over 30 different spices in it!) and laugh with your friends at the road-ragers racing by. Life seems to slow down here. Grab a table or comfy couch to lounge or linger on. Beer's flowing on tap and a wide selection of bottled imports are available. Don't miss the case of tantalizing desserts with wacky names like "I Don't  Usually Do This..." and "Desserts is Stressed Spelled Backwards." A remedy for your sweet tooth, hungry belly, beer- and good-times cravings.

I like Remedy.  Haven't tried too much of the food, but have had the wraps and am waiting to still try the dosas.  Given that I my roots are from the south of India, I must say that I tend to have very high expectations for the dosa clan of food items which is quite different from North Indian food (naans etc.)

Now, what I have tried I really ilke.  They make an awesome Himalayan chai which is green in color.  Strongly infused with crushed pistachios, extremely flavorful and filling.  It's caffeine free too.  It's really more like flavored milk.   I also like some of the other things out there.  They have a large variety of tea bags that you can pick up for your hot tea.

Remedy has some seriously filling muffins etc. to go with tea/coffee for those just looking for the cafe experience.  Mostly whole grain muffins with high fiber and filling as hell, it's great for an afternoon break from work kind of thing.  I like 'em.

The food looks very good, to be honest.  I can't wait to try some of the things.  Dosa is one, but even some of the more traditional north indian varieties look pretty good.  Another review will appear, once I've tried the food!

For a chain restaurant, this is not a bad meal! 

The hibachi chef we had was talented and the food tasted great. The prices are a bit steep, but you're also paying for the experience. 

The support staff who helped wait on us were all great - refilled our drinks, brought our salad and soup promptly and made sure we had everything we needed.

Something to keep in mind - if you do hibachi and your party is fewer than 8, you may be sat with another party or two. It's not bad (depending on who you're sat with), just something to know!

We came here right before seeing a show at the AMC in Plymouth Meeting, and it was perfect! We would be back.

We always come here whenever we plan to go to the movies at Plaza Frontenac.  They have a large bar to sit at and that's where we plopped our butts down for lunch.  This is the first time I noticed  that they have "lunch plates" on their menu.  Two courses with different options and different pricing.

We both decided to have the soup and the mezza pasta brio for $14.50 a piece.  He went with the lobster bisque and I tried one of the specials, minestrone soup.  His bisque was outstanding as usual.  I was a little underwhelmed by the minestrone soup.  It tasted more like a vegetable soup and there were no little noodles in it.  The mezza pasta brio was very good.  Pasta, chicken in a red pepper sauce.  It was just the right portion for lunch.  No time for a dessert, we have to get to the movies. 

Would I come back here?  Yes, I'll see you on the flip side.

Wow! The last time we ate such amazing food was in  Koreatown LA. We ordered the extra spicy Kimchi Soondubu and a Pajun appetizer. The banchan spread was amazing and the kimchi especially had a really good amount of heat to it. We were so glad to have walked in on a cold wintry night because the food had some extra comfort factor to it. The soft tofu in the soondubu was amazing and the flavor was out of this world. Cracking a raw egg and stirring it into the boiling hot stone bowl added some extra oomph to the dish. We walked out so happy and stuffed. Highly recommended restaurant.

Not really my best experience. It was late fall so the weather was starting to get chilly. The place was cold insidea nd rather empty. We sat down I ordered a Thai Tea and it took forever. When the waiter dropped the tea off he didn't take the order he just headed back to the kitchen area. So now we are waiting, and waiting.......tick tock...tick, tick, tick, tock.....

Finally ahh success -- we order yellow curry with chicken and pad thai with shrimp. When the items arrived the curry looked on point. But the pad thai looked --eh, not good. The shrimp had a funny color, the noodles looked soft and mushy, any way the meal was really just a 2.5 but I gave it a three b/c a 2 is kinda low and well everyone has a bad day.

The "I Wanna Tijuana Taco" is a corn tortilla wrapped in soft flour tortilla filled & well balanced with choice of protein, lettuce, tomato, sour cream, and cheese! Perfectly crafted and "user friendly!" 

The Avocado Bacon Quesadilla with chicken is loaded, and with a creamy cilantro sauce which will win over cilantro haters! The chicken and ground beef fillings have great mexican flavor! 

These two choices with their Burritos are served with "bottomless fresh tortilla chips!" 
Need Salsa? Their salsa bar is killer! My faves include pineapple, verde, and acho salsas! 

Their desserts include Cinnamon Chips, Key Lime Pie, and my choice, Sopapilla, with powdered sugar & a side of agave nectar!

Do ya think I became a fan on my first visit? Simply put, "Sí, mucho!"

This inn couldn't be more quaint and adorable. And the location is perfect. I wish it was more comfortable. Little things like having good linens and pillows would sure make a difference. The windows are not sound proof so you hear everything from the street. And also within the walls of the hotel. It's impossible to have a good night sleep. Little things like the water, fans and fireplace did not work along with the TV having almost nothing you can watch. At this price point, cable and good linens are a must. Nothing you can do about the old inn part and that's part of the charm. With just a little more attention to detail and care this could be a fabulous place. But for now, it's cute, centrally located, but not a good place to rest.

I've been here a few times in the past, and I have to say, Mood Cafe definitely lives up to its expectations every time. Hassan is as friendly as all the other reviewers say, really makes you feel welcome, and makes you want to return again and again.

The menu might look a little confusing at first, but Hassan breaks it down and customizes each customers' order according to taste. If you get a lassi, you'll often get a little cup that contains the rest of the lassi if it doesn't fit in the cup. The chaat is delicious, although I think a big part of this place is the experience and being able to interact with a restaurant owner in such a consistently positive way. 

Would recommend, definitely revisiting this place when I'm in the area, if only to grab a quick lassi.

Way more that the typical bar food, even for New Orleans.  

Great food, great music and super fun.

I will be back.

The shrimp boil at this place is nothing short of amazing and you can smell it down the street. I LOVE their boiled shrimp and this is the place I go in New Orleans when I want it.

Who orders salad in New Orleans? People from California, that's who. Their house salad is one the freshest and coldest that I've had in NOLA and it is rather large. This is also the only place that makes in house Creole Ranch, not the bottled crap. My usual order is a half pound of boiled shrimp and a house salad when I need a break from all the fried food and Gumbo and rice. 

Service can be really awful if they are slammed, you just never know what you're going to get on any given day. The food is worth it though- for me just to find a decent cold salad with house made dressing is such a huge thing to find in a city like NOLA. It's a hot humid city, sometimes you just need a cold salad and great seafood.

I want to preface this review by saying that I have had a number of great experiences at Kanella from before they moved to their not-so-new location to now. However, our last experience, from the service to the food, was oddly subpar.

I arrived at 8:28pm for an 8:30pm reservation and checked in with the maitre d'. At the time, she informed me that the table was ready and that I could be seated if I wanted. However, I decided instead to wait for the rest of my party, who had informed me that they were almost there. They arrived at 8:39pm. At that point, we went up to be seated and were informed that our table was not ready and that it would be a "few more minutes" - somehow, our table had disappeared. We ended up waiting until 9:07pm to be seated with no explanation as to what had happened.

Honestly, if that had been the only issue, it would have been fine. However, the food had some glaring issues too. Two members of our party ordered the poussin special. The first time the dishes arrived, they were completely overcooked to the point that they were almost impossible to cut, and were painfully over-salted. One member of the party just gave up on his dish and just shared half of mine - the pork osso bucco, which while edible, was served in a very acidic yet creamy sauce that probably had too much lemon juice in it. The other member sent her poussin back, and it came back still too salty, but at least cooked correctly.

The service was also chaotic - some of our appetizers arrived quickly while one of them took such a long time, we had to ask if they'd forgotten it. They also gave us a salad we had not ordered, and when we asked them about it, the waiter just waved his hand exasperatedly and said, "just keep it". When the server brought out the poussin the first time, he spilled a bit of the sauce off the plate onto the seat (luckily not onto the clothes of the diner!). 

I'm not sure if they were short-staffed that night or something - the whole experience was just so jarringly different from all the times I've been there in the past. It was also particularly disappointing as it was my sister's last meal in Philadelphia so we had picked Kanella to celebrate - and by the end of the meal, we did not even opt to order dessert. They did give us a free baklava to go - which was very tasty - and two out of three appetizers were delicious, so I'm hoping our next visit will erase this particular meal like a bad dream.

Alittle disappointed with the food. Service was slow and alittle lacking. Lets talk about the food. I had the mini pork belly burger or bun. That was a rendition of a bun mi... Not so good. Bread was crispy but flavor combo was blend.

The chicken wings were ok. Served with cilantro and sesame seeds were ok.

I got the pomegranate mint tea. This tasted like the tazo tea packets. Guess, I drink alot of tazo stuff. Lol

The miso ramen was alittle blend and cold. My soup was subpar and just ok. I have had ramen else where and it was delicious. I was really hoping this place would be just as good but was disappointed.

I did take a sip of my friends curry chicken ramen and it was just ok.

Wish my review for this place was higher in rating but the food was just ok. Nothing bad but nothing great.

I'm somewhat shocked that the average rating for Drago's is as high as it is.  So far this has been one of my most disappointing Nola dining experience.  While the chargrilled oysters are certainly delicious, everything else felt subpar.  The space is somewhat open to the vast Hilton hotel atrium, so the restaurant lacks any feeling of intimacy, and I felt like I was eating in a casino buffet.  I ordered a steamed lobster, but the meat was very chewy and not sweet.  It was served with an asparagus risotto, but it tasted like mushy rice.  My friends all found their entrees to be edible, but lacking anything special.  Banquet food is what we all likened our meals to, and if you're in Nola, you can do so much better than banquet food.

Mmmmm, kwesadila.....Went to Global Quesadilla for a quick n easy dinner on Sunday night.  Good stuff.  Not your stereotype cheesyn tortilla, but something totally different.

Started with chips and queso.  That's a lotta chips and queso for $4.79!  Chips are thin and crispy.  Very generous portion of hot cheese.  Not plain white queso, but some type of cheddar and other mix.  I really liked it.  A good semi-strong flavor, that wasn't just based on spice.

I got the Aztec quesadilla with aztec sauce on the side, wife and daughter split a florentine with added chicken (and red sauce came on the side).  They all come with a helping of shredded lettuce that you can put on yourself.

Since we were eating in (I like to get out of the house to eat), it was all fresh off the grill and very hot.  I have been here before, but forgot that these aren't just a bunch of cheese other toppings mixed in.  It's really a balance of all the items with the cheese.  So if you're wanting a big cheese explosion, it's not for you.  But if you want a variety of flavor in your Q, then this is for you.  My daughter said theirs was like a pizza, which she liked.  My Aztec is hard to describe, but I like it.  Mix of chicken, cheese, taco-sauce like spice, bacon (that I couldn't really taste - so that was a bit of a downer).  The menu describes it a sweet and spicy.  I think that's accurate.  Overall, Global Q is a good, different flavor experience.

Decor is pretty spartan.  That's not a knock, just how it is.  It's really just a delivery or quick-casual joint.  Workers were friendly, place was very clean.

I was hesitant to come here because I was convinced that I'd never find anywhere to park, but lo and behold there is a huge nearby lot that has ONE HOUR FREE PARKING!

I had been to the Burger Republic in Lenox Village but that is very far away from me, so when this one opened and I learned of the free one hour parking a visit was inevitable!

The better half and I stopped in a lunchtime. Coming as a surprise to no one, it's quite busy during that time. The speed of the service suffered as a result, but the food was as good as expected.

I ordered the Four Cheese Garlic Bacon Burger with Tater Tots which is very good, but the Garlic is strong! No one will be encouraged to kiss you and vampires will be sure to avoid you for the rest of the day.

Because it was lunch I did not order any of the "Adult Shakes" or try any of the Beers, but based on my experience at the other location I have no doubt they are worthy.

I absolutely recommend you stop in Burger Republic

This park is the heart of St. Louis, treasured by locals and tourists alike. 

The Zoo, Art Museum, History Museum, MUNY, Shakespeare Fest, Boathouse, multiple golf courses, walking/running and bike trails, hiking paths, fishing, outdoor ice skating, and so much more. 


This is the place for making lifelong memories. Come with friends and family.

Of all the Cafe Beignet locations, this one has the best atmosphere!  The "Musical Legends" park (really more of a patio) is a great place to sit and enjoy your beignets and coffee.  The fans and water misters were very appreciated on a hot July morning, and the live jazz band added to the ambiance.  It was also nice how there was a short line and plenty of open tables on a Sunday morning (especially compared to Café du Monde...)

Unfortunately, the beignets and coffee here just don't stack up against Café du Monde or even the other Cafe Beignet locations.  But it's still delicious fried dough covered in powdered sugar, so I'll shove it in my face anyway!  They also have other food, like omelettes, sandwiches, and even cocktails, so coming here should please everyone in your group.

We finally got around to trying Tiffin and I'm glad we did. I got the chicken tikka masala and the hubby got BBQ chicken. I crave dipping naan in to the masala sauce, so I was very pleased that it was delicious and up to par with others in the area. The BBQ chicken was good, too, but the hubby def. wanted some sauce (thankfully, I'm a sharer!). 

It was okay, but I doubt we'll go back any time soon. The surrounding area is sketch city.

Okay...First time stepping in a Yogurtland and I am officially a fan!!!!!!!!!!!!

Two great reasons:
1) variety. Some of these other froyo establishments don't offer the wonderous topping I discovered at Yogurtland
2) Price, by weight, you really get your monies worth. I only paid like $3.50 for what would be like $7.00 at a Cold Stone, and my bowl was filled with berries and fruit and froyo!!!!

That's all I'm really asking for in a froyo place. I guess it's cool, serving yourself, and getting biodegradable spoons too, but really those two things define yogurt for me. 

Don't worry Redwood Yogurt of Arcata, your $2.50 Peach homemade waffle cone will always be the best!

We came in right after they opened for the day. They were still mopping the floors which rendered them like a slip-n-slide. I had some shoes with decent traction but I was still sliding around - not safe for any customer and inexcusable since their opening time is not a surprise to them.

It looked like there was only one server for the restaurant, that being the wife of the owning couple. She amazingly had control of many tables. But when the restaurant got half full, it was obvious she needed extra assistance. She often greeted customers by yelling from across the restaurant when she saw them. I often heard customers wondering what she said.

I ordered the Pad Thai. She asked if I wanted it mild, medium or spicy. I told her mild since I didn't want to mask the flavors with heat. For the record, mild is more like medium. There was a strong heat presence. So, if you are sensitive to spice and like things mild, I would recommend asking for no spice. Then, perhaps you would actually get mild!

The plating looked odd because there was a mound of noodles topped with chopped green onion on one side of the plate. Then, there was a slightly dried out lime wedge, a pile of thinly spiraled carrot and a pile of chopped peanuts on the other side. It looked like I had asked for Pad Thai with the peanuts on the side! The odd plating aside, the noodles were horribly mushy that they were broken into child-safe lengths. I felt like I needed a spoon to eat it.

One of the first things we ordered was the Korean fried chicken in soy and garlic. We were told it takes 20-25 minutes. It came out after our main dishes even though we ordered our mains after the chicken; so I would recommend ordering it before sitting down if you can. The dish looked delicious and ate that way too. That was this meal's saving grace. The chicken was crispy but thoroughly coated with glaze. Wing size was pretty decent and the restaurant comes with a handwashing station so you can eat with abandon, lick your fingers and go wash your hands before eating anything else.

As with driving a new car out of the dealership lot, the Korean fried chicken immediately depreciates in value (crispy value, that is) when taken to-go. So, I would recommend dining in for your first KFC experience.

The Korean fried chicken is the only reason to come to this place. Just be sure to wear some slip resistant shoes!

Goody's Soda and Ice cream and Carmel corn and... oh my the list goes on and on. What can I add to this review that could possibly help out the readers to know that this is the one place to go for your anytime desert or sweet tooth fix! My family and I drive from across the valley just to go here for an evening treat. And I've never failed to find someone else in the shop that I know. It's not overly crowded but always very satisfying. The store was decorated for Halloween this last visit and each time you opened the front door, a giant spider descended from the ceiling to frighten the unsuspecting guest at the counter. The staff are exceptional at fulfilling special requests, such as I'd like my sundae with a scoop of peanut butter on the bottom of the dish and another on the top, but no nuts please... I have a nut allergy. Okay so I made up the nut allergy part but they did do the peanut butter thing exactly the way I wanted it. The popcorn and candies there are also another hyper child's dream! They will have you wanting to comeback again and again for more delectable goodies. I do believe my dentist also endorses their business. Maybe they should start selling toothpaste and brushes too!?!

Ruby Tuesday (this one in particular) always takes me right back to high school. This was one of the spots my friends and I frequented when we'd visit the Deptford Mall after class. Back then, I always chose the Carolina Chicken Salad or the Chicken BLT.

Yesterday, I branched out with the Spinach Dip and Classic Quesadilla -- which, I believe, is a new item. It came highly recommended from our [super friendly] server.

Unfortunately, both dishes fell short, especially the quesadilla. But what can you expect from a chain? I was also very annoyed because of the noise level. We should have sat around the bar because I have a low tolerance for screeching/crying. I know it can't be avoided, but geesh.

Also know that their beer list sucks. They listed off "Bud, Coors, Miller, Forgotten Boardwalk" to the tables next to me, and then I overheard the server say, "Forgotten Boardwalk's Funnel Cake is similar to an IPA" and might have choked to myself. Aaaand Stone's Ruination is a stout, right? [/beernerd]

But yeah, Ruby's is what you'd expect. Stick to the regulars and the salad bar.

I've had better Indian food and for a cheaper price. 
paneer tikka: cheese cubes were dry, not enough sauce
Vegetable jalfrezi: it seemed like it was just peppers and maybe a few green beans. 
Onion and lasooni naan were pretty good

There wasn't enough food for the amount I paid.

You weren't kidding about the lines. Yet, as promised, they move quickly! 

So here's the deal- I am not from St. Louis, so I am comparing Ted Drewes to Shakes back home. The pricing at Ted Drewes is pretty good for the portions you get. The hubby and I shared a large Fox Treat (raspberries, chocolate, macadamia nuts) concrete. The custard was EXTREMELY soft- more like a milkshake. And the toppings were well blended.  

Good, not quite great. I tend to like a slightly harder cream and chunks of fruit, chocolate, etc. But I can appreciate Ted Drewes. I get the appeal :)

I have eaten at Nada on numerous occasions and have always been satisfied. It starts with the exterior, which is pretty and inviting. Each time I walk in, I am taken back with how pretty the restaurant is, which I noticed is very similar to all of their other locations (I was stalking their website with the 360 degree photos the other day). I love the cute little booths that are tucked away and the seating in the middle is really fun, and not as uncomfortable as I initially thought it would be since you are so close to other diners. All of the tacos have been yummy, the fries are beyond tasty, and the cocktails have been yummy, too. I recently tried the quesadilla salad, and it was just as satisfying. We usually have really great servers. The lunch portions are satisfying and priced right - better than dinner, in my opinion. This is definitely my lunch go-to while downtown. Ooh, and my favorite bonus when I picked up a to-go order a few weeks ago - the bag is reusable and CUTE!

This place was a great find.  My husband and I love Indian food and recently moved to the area.  My husband is a picky eater and most places don't meet his standards.  I ate at the lunch buffet one day on my own and thought it was worth a second visit.  My husband came with me and now we go once a week for lunch. The food is on the spicier side but it's all very well done and very tasty.  My husband likes how they change up the buffet menu every day so it's different every time we go.  For $8.00, it's a bargain.  We love the chicken tikka masala, tandoori chicken, and the saag dishes especially.  We're looking forward to trying it for dinner.

What a wonderful place to accidentally stumble across. My friends and I were looking for a place to grab a quick bite while we waited for our turn at North Bowl and ended up here.

The atmosphere is very warm and cozy. I knew we had picked the right spot when we were greeted by an adorable man with a bow tie! The host is truly delightful, and I heard that he is almost always working.

The service was pretty slow, but only because the place was totally packed. Our waiter, however, was wonderful. He brought our brews out very quickly. I ended up ordering the Macaroni and Cheese--which is covered in bacon! It was absolutely delicious. The best part of the experience was when our waiter agreed to take a shot of Fireball with us! Gotta love it.

Overall, this is a bar I would definitely return to if I was in the area. It's a pretty far ride downtown for those of us in the suburbs, unfortunately!
Plain ole good turkey sandwich. The closest thing I'll find to a hoagie this far south! The Alfalfa sprouts are a nice touch too!

My husband and I spent a long weekend at the Eagle Inn in the Santa Catalina cabin at the end of January 2012.  We had an amazing time and the Eagle Inn was exactly what we expected and more.  

The staff was friendly, professional, and effective--maybe not the warmest, gushing, cuddly types but the got the job done and made us feel happy and welcome.  

The Inn grounds were very clean and in excellent repair with a tasteful and comfortable decor.  Our room was even better!  "Cozy" doesn't even begin to cover how lovely and wonderful the room was!  Immaculate and clean.  We loved the fireplace (yes it was electric but, come on....its southern California!) the dual head shower was...um...inspiring, and the whirlpool tub was also perfect.  We were delighted to find that the tub actually lights up!  hahaha!  The bed was ultra-fluffy and very comfortable...so comfortably that we kept sleeping in past our usual 5am wake up.  I guess that's the point of a vacation :)

The location was ideal.  Two blocks from the beach and lovely stroll at that.  The electric trolly is about a 2-3 minute walk so we never had to drive the whole weekend.  The Harbor is an easy 10 minute walk and so is the Pier.  What we really liked about the location is that the Inn's area is so quiet and peaceful but close enough to the "action" of State Street.

Breakfast was great!  There was more than enough for the both of us to get our morning fill.  The hot entrees were well prepared and tasty.  I also loved how they included lots of extra little treats, snacks, and goodies in the room--chocolates, biscotti, chips, apples, and bottled water.  We paid extra for the champaign and chocolate dipped strawberries--a dozen roses and rose petals all over the place.  If we were to break down the economics of the package ($75) it might not be worth it.  Yes, I'm a coupon clipper and very frugal but I have to say that it was a nice addition and would do it all over again :)

I'm always on the lookout for a good organic grocer, and Dierberghs generally have really good organic aisle(s!). At the Brentwood one, they have all types of organic goods: cereal, bread (frozen unfortunately), granola, sweeteners, etc. They also have vegetarian organic pho broth (who would've thought?). They also have a great liquor and beer aisle. Overall, they're overpriced, but if I'm in the area and need specialty goods or want to troll for a new wine or beer, I usually stop by Dierbergs.

Oh, the Red Pineapple is MY JAM! Pineapple juice, strawberries, banana, pineapple sherbet. Oh, yes.

And if you need a pick-me-up, forget Starbucks, and get the Coffee: non-fat milk, coffee, ice milk. Deelish.

One thing that St. Pete beach seems to have a ton of is ice cream shops. This one is tucked into the ground floor of the Don CeSar, in the big pink monolith's shopping arcade.  They have a wide variety of locally made ice creams, and you can get sundaes and banana splits as well. My sundae was kinda small - not that I expected anything massive for the price at the Don! Maybe I should get the sundae-in-a-sand-pail option next time.

Bonus: there's a Ms. PacMan cocktail table tucked away in the corner, and they also brew Starbucks coffee if you're craving something other than diner-quality java.

It's been years since my last trip, and all I could remember is to try their oysters.. Well, today I did and I am glad to say I only got a half dozen. If you're just getting into the oyster game, these aren't a bad option as:

1 - each oyster is small!
2 - they're charbroiled (aka cooked!)
3 - .. All of this meaning you don't get to taste the fishy smell that others often associate with it :)

This is an okay dunkin donuts. I end up stopping here occasionally for coffee when in the area. It is in a very tight spot and parking is a pain. In the mornings, the drive thru will be backed up almost onto Bethlehem Pike. I once decided to park and go inside because the drive thru line was so long, big mistake! It was seriously impossible to get out without going through the drive thru. The inside of this location is nicer than your average dunkin,with a cozy area for sitting with a fake fireplace. Employees are hit or miss, usually they're nice enough. However, the one time the guy messed up our order by completely leaving the one drink out( it was only two drinks), and instead of being apologetic, acted like it was our fault. No, you just didn't understand us.

While I think Publix has a decent reputation for customer service, the selection is underwhelming in my opinion.  I do like this location since it's downtown and better for sustainability, but I wish they would carry much more organic, fair trade, and/or locally produced items. 

Publix's deli and bakery items make me less inclined to come here: it seems they are usually loaded with excessive sugar, white flour (it's rare to find whole wheat), plus dairy (very hard to find anything vegan). 

Finally and most important to me as a consumer, they are still refusing to sign the Fair Food agreement. I think it's important for customers to know how Publix's core business affects migrant farm workers in Florida, and I will not be shopping at Publix until they sign it.

Located in the Hilton, Drago's serves all types of seafood from salads to oysters to gumbo to fried items.  

As all the other reviews suggest, get the CHARBROILED OYSTERS.  Although I prefer raw ones, these had the perfect amount of cheese/butter/seasoning and everyone loved them at our table (even the non-oyster lovers)

RAW OYSTERS- large, but overpriced for LA and not as tasty as Blue Point or Cape Cod ones

Shrimp and Corn BISQUE- thick and not as salty as other bisques; a bowl might be too much so stick with a cup

Chicken and Andouille Sausage GUMBO- not worth it; you can find better somewhere else

STUFFED LOBSTER- 1.25 lb lobster stuffed with crabmeat and shrimp... it was OK but not as good as the lobster with seafood pasta

LOBSTER with SEAFOOD PASTA- the pasta with mushrooms and shrimp is placed inside the lobster, on top of the meat.  It was delicious and our favorite entree!

Although it is pricey and parking is only valet (make sure you get it validated so it's only $5 instead of $40!), the inside is nice and it's great for a special occasion.

Main complaint: It's really cold in there :(

i'd rather stay home and starve then go here. Just go a little further into Goleta and anything is better then this ]: Just the thought that i could get two delicious bowls of pho for the price of one pho bistro bowl. WEnt once, never went back.
Bob was a great tour guide. We learned a lot of fun facts about local history and how certain phrases were coined.

Came here twice in one day. Didn't try the beignet either time. Can't eat them. Will die.

I had breakfast here and it was all pretty good. My wife ordered some hash browns that really turned out to be like country potatoes that were not very warm and not very fresh.

My andouille sausage omelette with no cheese came to me with cheese.

Things like this make it a three-star experience. That said, I tried coming again the next day because I was hungry and it was just a couple of blocks from the hotel. The line was too long so we decided to eat at the airport instead.

The food at the airport was just as good.

As a California guy, I was skeptical about Mexican in Florida, especially fast food.
I got a big burrito.  It was good, the salsa was good (needed more salt).  Service was very good and the prices were reasonable.
When I go back to Tampa, I will stop here for lunch.

This was a great NOLA find when we needed a veg friendly place but really wanted Mexican food. I ordered a smothered burrito that was literally the size of a jacked man's forearm. No regrets. There were lots of various options, and it was in a nice area.

Crazy sushi is open for its second week.  Stopped in for lunch, and there was no one else there.  They have a pretty extensive menu, lots of options besides sushi.  They have a few different lunch specials including 3 rolls for 12.  This is $1 more than the other sushi lunch specials in the area, but no big deal.  At first glance, they have a lot of options for the 3 roll special plus soup or salad, a list of 43 different rolls.  I went with spicy tuna, Alaska, and spicy scallop, plus a salad.  The waitress came back and said spicy scallop isn't included, I said it was on the list, and she said that was a mistake, so I requested the crabmeat apple.  I got brown rice for all of them.  She arrived with the sushi, and instead of crabmeat apple she had given me apple avocado.  I pointed that out, and she took the sushi away so they could make the correct roll.  She came back and my crabmeat apple was actually imitation crabmeat apple.  That's really not what I wanted, and there was no way for me to know it was going to be the fake crab, so I just didn't eat that roll.  It should say crabstick not crabmeat.

The spicy tuna was good, not too much mayo, and my Alaska roll had a decent amount of fish.  All the fish seemed fresh.  

Bill came, it's a 75 cents up charge per roll for brown rice, but 15% off right now because of the grand opening.  I'm willing to give it another chance, but considering they just opened and should be wanting to impress customers so that they return, especially when Vic's, Machi, and Tsuki, are a few blocks away, I was underwhelmed.

I'm a big, gigantic fan of Mexican food.  I eat it often, and when I do, I almost always choose authentic over any alternative.  When I do choose the alternative, I have low expectations.  Nada, a relatively new addition to the Indy restaurant scene, is one of those restaurants that I classify as such.  However, with its uber-rave reviews, I was excited to try it when the situation presented itself.  Would it live up to the hype?  I don't know about that...

Nada is a New Mexican restaurant in the truest sense.  The food is identical to popular fare served in Santa Fé, NM (a city that is wonderful to its core), but would seem foreign in places like Mexico City or even Cancun, Mexico.  It's hipster Mexican, and that's all there is to it.  With that said, the bright ambiance of the restaurant is enough to earn return customers.  Being open, colorful, and quite loud, it arouses the senses - including taste.

Nada features a small menu that caters to a broad variety of tastes.  Those with carnivorous, omnivorous, or vegetarian preferences won't have difficulties finding something tasty to eat. While the fare is centered around tacos, there are plenty of other dishes to enjoy.  I recommend group dining and sharing at Nada, as choosing one item is too limiting.

I started my meal by sharing the quesadilla "taco" salad, which, if eaten in its entirety, is a meal-sized portion.  It was a creative take on the taco salad, with the quesadilla replacing the crispy shell.  It came with a very heavy amount of spicy avocado dressing.  No one should dine at Nada without having the mac n' cheese.  While the portion appears small on arrival, the diner will take note of the richness and density of the dish.  After one bite, I don't think many will question why it has won city-wide awards.  While I was most excited to try the braised chicken enchiladas, I must report my dissatisfaction.  I found them to over overly salted, which is a water-retaining annoyance.  For a dish with the word, "chicken," in its name, I was led to believe that there would be a decent amount of the bird in it.  How much chicken was there?  Almost nada.  

The tacos at Nada deserve a paragraph of their own.  While small -  and frankly, overpriced, they pack a lot of flavor.  Of the three I tried, I am unable to name a favorite.  The grilled salmon taco, with its jalapeño corn pico, is very "Santa Fé."  The pork belly, evidently the restaurant's most popular taco, packs a rich a nicely spiced flavor.  It is the most savory taco I have ever eaten.  The mu shu certainly puts an Asian twist on the typical pork taco, and it was the most creative selection on the menu.

One could easily dine a Nada for dessert alone.  Don't leave the restaurant without trying the churros - a made-to-order cinnamon doughnut.  My God.  The small batch gelatos (not made in-house) are an honorable mention.  I had the pleasure of trying a Habanero chocolate, which as the perfect combination of sweet and spicy.

Like most of the food, the service at Nada was top-notch.  Our server was friendly and quick, even with a packed house and difficult guests (like me).  Bravo to her.

Skip the enchiladas, but don't skip Nada!  While it did not quite live up to the hype, it is a place I would consider returning.

I've heard (non-yelp) things before eating here and my food was better than expected. The margaritas were strong, the burrito was amazingly delicious, and the staff were friendly and willing to talk with customers. Having the female staff all look like Sucide Girls was an added bonus!

Great introduction to Argentinean food. We stumbled upon it several years ago after a trip to Buenos Aires and felt we were back there after the first bite. The steaks and empanadas are great. Wines by the glass selection great. Topped everything off with dulce de leche pancakes. Initial service when seated a bit haphazard last time around, but they scrambled to make up for it later on. Music on Wednesdays and Fridays great to keep the kids occupied while parents enjoy a quiet dinner.

That shrimp poboy was better than any bahn mi I've had.  $14?! ouch.  but damn it was good. Huge shrimp perfectly seasoned.  great crusty bread. some kinda tangy sauce.  

I want another right now

After trying ACME's and Drago's charbroiled oysters, I came to the conclusion that ACME's oysters are better, but this comes to a close second and definitely worth a try also. We ordered a dozen of the charbroiled oysters, jambalaya, alligator bites, and bread pudding. The reason why I do not like the charbroiled oysters here so much is because they seem to have more of a natural taste. It is gritty with tastes of sand in it and I find the buttery sauce with cheese to be too liquidy. I would prefer it to be more melted and on the dry side. But because of this, you can definitely taste the oysters. The jambalaya is also on the wet side, pretty tasty. Bread pudding was delish. I wasn't a huge fan of the alligator bites as I find it to be pretty mediocre. It almost tasted like fried chicken with it being deep fried. Come for the oysters!

Service was quick and attentive. The restaurant is located inside the Hilton hotel. Parking is validated by the restaurant.

Our visit to Cafe Beignet started with me ordering a mint julep for $5.  "You drink whiskey now?" my husband asked.  "There's whiskey in a mint julep?" I chirped back at him.  The bartender was friendly and warned me that they don't use fresh mint, they use their own mint syrup.  

$5 cocktails and a seat to watch a local jazz band play?  Sure, I'll take it!  The drinks were decent, but not worth ordering a second.  They're making their money off of the people who want to sit and listen to the band play.  You can get some great pictures and virtually free entertainment here.

Since I'd had a few cocktails prior to this, I needed water.  I went back up to the bar and asked for a cup of water.  A waitress, who didn't bother looking up from her phone, curtly told me they only serve bottled water.  I think the bartender would've given me the water, if the waitress wasn't there, just judging by the expression on her face.  I asked how much the water was, and again not looking up, the waitress mumbled, "two dollars."  

That was my last impression of Cafe Beignet, because we left promptly after that.  

Being on Bourbon Street, it's hard to miss.  And being in the center of everything, it's still worth a visit.  Order a cocktail or some coffee, listen to the band, and then GTFO.

$350 for three people. The price wouldn't  be all that bad except the food was really bland. My prime rib was disturbingly pale and lacked any kind of flavor. I had to ask for horseradish which seems like a travesty. It's like putting ketchup on filet. But when the food has no flavor, what else can you do? Usually I'll eat all of my steak or prime rib but I decided this just wasn't worth the calories, so you know it's serious. The salad I started with was pretty good. The $13 loaded potato I order with my prime rib, was not. Creme brûlée was decent. For the money, I expected a lot more.

mmmm... Cheesecake Fantasy. Birthday remix is good too. There is always a line here but with good reason, the Ice Cream is good! You could get one of their signature creations or mix things up and create one of your own. I can't eat more than a "Like It" (small) size cup. I've tried their waffle bowls before and although it tastes great, I just couldnt finish it. You also get very thirsty so you might as well buy some water or something while you're at it. 

The good thing about this location is that you're allowed to take the ice cream into the theater with you. Sit, watch a movie, and eat some ice cream. Can't get much better than that. It beats paying for pretzel bites or popcorn and a soda.
Our meal was excellent and the service was friendly, attentive, and informative.  And we did stare dreamily across the table from each other.

I guess its all about definition. Just how you define the food you have on your menu, how you as the patron define your expectations. I've lived in Italy a fair amount, starting back in 1990 and at times for a few months at a time and usually in Florence so I've had a little experience with Tuscan food which by definition is simple, fresh and well made. Ok here's the deal, straight up before I get into particulars, this is a great place for people who have never been to Italy, have no idea what Tuscan food really is and are generally afraid to eat anywhere inside the 1-170 inner belt. Now for the particulars. I ordered a Beefsteak Florentine (I found it cute they used the Italian word for Beefsteak on the menu), I asked for it RARE, like I made a point of it (it was medium at best). What I got was delivered by the food runner as "here's your strip steak", I replied, no I ordered the Beefsteak Florentine and he disappeared only to return with the water who said "in the back they both come up as the same. My friends, a Strip Steak is NOT the same, Beefsteak Florentine is almost always a T bone, charred on the outside and very rare inside, often but not always served on a bed of arugula. It was also not rare by any way, but as my dinner  guests were into their meal, I did not send it back. Also the meat was served with mashed potatoes which I presume is for the West of I-170 clientele who prefer their food really worked over. My fellow companions ordered the lobster ravioli and shrimp which was very rich which is good but it was just too much. This place should just be more honest about their menu and say its Italian-American fusion for upscale people who like to shop at Sacks Fifth Ave and pay too much for everything(interestingly enough, this place is located in the parking lot of an upscale mall). The service was also not so great, we had to ask for more water for the table and the service in general could only be described as spotty. the bar service was also a bit disappointing, my wife Bellini was closer to an adult smoothie than a Bellini and the waiter seemed to not know what kind of gin the bar stocked.  All in all a disappointing meal that was over priced for what you got. On the plus side the Quattro Bruschetta was very good and I thought the only bright spot on the table.

Very tasty frozen custard. My office in Boston actually got this delivered by the company as a sister office lost a world series bet. The ice cream was delicious and the win made it taste even better. My favorite flavor was the Tedad flavor, at least that is what was wrote on the cap. I think it was some sort of oatmeal cookie. I wouldn't hesitate to return for a visit or order some on my own.

You have to know what to order and what to stay away from. The chicken soup here is very good with big chunks of chicken, fresh cilantro and tortillas strips, different then your average toritilla soup, but I did have to send it back once as it was too salty. The enchiladas mole here are terrific! The carne asada is also good. The traditional enchiladas come with a real gravy, not that hevy flavored cumin red sauce everyone passes off as authentic. The service here can be quite bad. Lots of servers milling around yet hard to find when it's time to check out.

I really like shopping at Dierbergs, this location is close my office so it's a nice spot to grab some items I may need on the way home or sometimes the occasional lunch. Around noon it's not overly busy, but later in the evening it get packed. 

it's a little hard to get over there coming from Clayton, traffic is always an issue.

Not sure when or why the name changed here on Yelp, but this is the same great casual sit down spot inside Whole Foods. 

Oysters served vis the seafood department. Large rotating selection of craft beer. Small but mighty menu of delicious bar bites. All around great experience! 

The menu has changed here and there over the years, and with those changes came a little variability in the quality. The most recent visit has them back on top of it all, though I did notice a smaller portion on some dishes for the same prices as before. I'm happy to pay for the quality though.

I ordered the blue cheese burger and it was damn good. They don't serve them with fries anymore, but it's only $10 and a shareable order of fries is $3-$4. We also had some sweet chili wings and traditional hot. These are larger than before, sauces are average, but they're cooked pretty well. Ask for them extra crispy and it's a home run. 

Grab a pint or a flight and some bites, and hang for a bit! Do your grocery shopping later!

One of my biggest quarantine cravings has been Hong Kong-style Cantonese food. While there's plenty of Cantonese joints in Chinatown, not many are open and have delivery during these 'Rona times.

Fortunately I came across Lee How Fook on DoorDash. I placed an order of Beef Chow Fun and Pan Fried Noodles with Pork. The order arrived way ahead of schedule and the food was deeeelectable. 

They have a pretty extensive menu so I'm looking forward to ordering more from them whenever the cravings return and if I know myself enough, they'll be back by the weekend.

We had a wedding to attend in Santa Barbara and we live only an hour away.  Of  course we thought about driving up and back to save some money, but then it dawned on me.  People fly from all over the world to spend time in the "California Riviera" and yet I had never spent any time enjoying the heart of this coastal city.  The weekend that we spent at the Eagle Inn was a great local get away.  Everything is within pretty close walking distance, including the beach and a little farther away you have State St.  We stayed in the San Clemente suite and the sitting room was a perfect place for me to catch up on my reading.  Beautiful space that I would recommend to anyone.

Good seafood option inside the Peppermill Hotel and Casino.

I like their selection that focuses but not limited to seafood. Had a hard time selecting  a plate so went with a little bit of everything and got the West Coast Cioppino for $22.00.

For those not familiar with this dish, this is a mix of seafood in a soup...here is what this version had: Crab, Clams, Shrimp, Scallops, Lobster and Fish in spicy Tomato Broth with toasted Ciabatta.

I really enjoyed this plate, the variety, the taste and portion size.

They also do all you can eat sushi: lunch $17.99 (11:30AM-4:00PM) and dinner $24.99 (4:00PM-close). Something I can try next time. 

Service was good but cigarette smell does come in form the casino floor.

Amazing sushi, service and staff!! My boyfriend and I went here because we had a groupon. We ordered a soup, at least 5 rolls, and a dessert, and the bill was only $50 (without the groupon). 
We walked in and were seated right away. The sushi presentation was phenomenal, I've never seen something like that in the city. Every roll we had was delicious, i honestly couldn't pick a favorite. I would have kept eating if I didn't get so full. The staff was attentive and our water was always full.
The only downside was dessert. We ordered a tempura banana dessert. It's was so so sooo bland. We ended up just eating the green tea ice cream (delicious) that came on the side. 
I will definitely be back. They had unique, absolutely delicious rolls, I can't wait to be back.

If you are craving steak, this is the place to go. The Angus Rib Eye steak is high quality and cooked to perfection. The restaurant itself is kinda small which could makes it feel a bit loud and take long wait time to get a table.

Based on the beauty of this park, and the fact that it's right on the water, I want so badly to give it 5 stars. However, this park has been completely taken over by vagrants, and it's sad. What used to be a beautiful place to excercise, study, or just get some fresh air, has become a place for vagrants to urinate, bathe in the fountains, and even have sex (something I witnessed while attempting to take a walk).  Since 2012, protesters also seem to love to crowd the sidewalks and common areas of the park and disturb the peace during family events. It's very disheartening.

Enjoyed sitting outside appreciating the jazz concert at this wonderful outdoor venue and tried the bignets which are made fresh to order and had an iced decaf which was nice. Plus they take cc!  Really lovely spot in the middle of the energy in Nola.

I know they're closing the Philly location so this review is kind of pointless but we had a fantastic meal here last night and typing about it will help me relive the delectable flavors so here we go. 

I had an unused giftcard for this cute lil BYO from 2013 (unsure how I let that happen), so when I read online that they would be closing I went into a panic and immediately booked a reservation for 4 for Sunday night. I will say there was some confusion surrounding my party size and reservation time, but let's just chalk that up to a last-weekend-open snafu. No biggie.

First of all, you had me at BYO. The restaurant was empty upon arrival, and my boyfriend and his parents and I were seated nearest the kitchen. I liked the clean and simple look of the place. Our wine and water glasses were consistently full, and our waitress offered to answer any questions that we might have had about the menu (it's kind of an intimidating menu, to be honest). The menu is designed to be a flight of 3 courses, but we each went with 2 and had plenty of food to share amongst the four of us. The parker house rolls that were brought out at the beginning of the meal were delicious and fluffy. This is turning into a 50 pager (South Park, anyone?) so I'll try to keep it short from here on out. Just note though- this is no cheap date. 8 plates ran us about 200 dollars.

-Asparagus risotto: 5 stars
-Spring soup: 5 stars
-Bass: 5 stars
-Steak: 4.5 stars
-Pasta with ragu: 4.5 stars
- Mackarel: 4.5 stars 
-Chicken: 4 stars 

Not only were these plates delicious, fresh, and filling, but the presentation was downright artistic. Beautiful job.

We were too full for dessert but I have to say I was pleasantly surprised, since I expected this to be one of those "let's charge 30 dollars a plate for a portion appropriate for a 5 year old of some fancy food that no one knows how to pronounce" places.

Three stars is defined by "A-OK: according to Yelp*
Four-stars is "Yay! I'm a fan."

You can believe what you want but, this place is better than K-Mart, not in volume or variety but, in customer service... and also because it is a more affordable experience.  I know that I could post plenty of photos that prove that but, I'll save that for K-Marts wake up call on their review (eventually).  

I like this place for a few things especially when I frst return from deployments.  I usually toss all my old spices and reboot here.  Seasonal decor has always been one of my big draws here and they have this huge sale...  I am not sure how many times a year but, it is on everything in the store.  I purchased a wonderful pots and pan set here (the biggest one I could find - teflon, silicone handles, glass lids, red in color - and it has served me well for almost 4 years now).

The furniture here is not Haverty's... That is why there is a Haverty's.  This is on par with the big box stores like Target, Walmart and the dreaded Kmart. They have a decent company buyer because it is obvious that Big Lots is trying to stay atop the latest in thing   E for effort there!

In the store I met Sandy. She approached me and asked if I needed any assistance.  I thanked her and said that it had been a while since I had visited this store, so I was simply browsing.  When I reconnected with her later, I asked her about an item, she was kind enough to walk me to the location where it was shelved.  How nice, right?  Yes, that goes a long way with me.  Thanks Sandy.

This a fun place to hangout, day or night. It is especially nice on a nice beach day. You can have a drink and you are at the beautiful white sands of St. Pete beach. You can play some beach volleyball or just lounge around.

A few friends and I went to Ellington's before a show at TPAC this week, and there were definitely some things I liked about it! But there also things I didn't.

The good? Their happy hour has GREAT prices. A lot of happy hours in Nashville kind of suck? This one doesn't. Seriously discounted prices. All cocktails on their menu were half off. One house red (a red blend) and one house white (a pinot grigio) were half off. And all their beers were half off. HALF OFF. They had $2 oysters, and ALL THEIR STARTERS WERE $5. These are some real discounts. 

More good? The service was good. The wine and the cocktail I had were good. The restaurant is beautiful. Very Donald Draper walking in for a few martinis over his lunch hour. And it's really close to TPAC. There aren't that many dinner options walking distance to TPAC, so another option is good. I'm not huge at sweating through a nice meal, so you won't catch me on a patio until late September but for those of you who like to sweat and or don't sweat - they have a beautiful patio as well. 

The not so good? We decided to try ALL the starters (there are 7 of them) since they were all $5 (there were four of us). While some were better than others, only one really knocked my socks off. Here's what we had: warm olives with orange zest, roasted garlic and brioche (good, but it turned out that two of our party don't eat olives, and the other two of us coudln't eat the 100 olives that were in that bowl! way too many); piquillo peppers with queso fresco and chimichurri (okay); roasted cauliflower with togarashi spice, split pea puree, and ponzu (this wasn't a hit at our table); picked deviled eggs (this was the one - the one that impressed a lot - despite the fact that I'm not a deviled egg eater generally!); cheese curds with green goddess (okay - sort of bland cheese that could have been string cheese rather than a real cheese curd and I wouldn't be surprised); pork loin with white bbq sauce (I think that was the least favorite at our table - the pork seemed really dry and tough and bland); and a cold shrimp dish (I can't describe this one, because it wasn't on the menu, but it was one of the better starters in my opinion; the 7th starter on the menu was a feta with olive oil, thyme, and watermelon, but that's not what we got; all of our group ate shrimp, but I think they probably should have let us know that one of the dishes was different than on the menu). Overall, the food was okay at best. I was certainly happy with the cost ($35 for all 7), but the food definitely wasn't good enough that I'd be excited to eat there for dinner (when entrees range from $20-42). Some of the dishes we had seemed a little too much like bar food for the location and the prices (if weren't happy hour) - cheese curds? In a place as decked out as this? 

The Fairlane Hotel is beautiful (this restaurant is on the 4th floor), but parking in this part of town is practically nonexistent, so you're going to have to valet out front or park in a nearby garage (I was parking for a show at TPAC anyway, so this wasn't such a big deal for me). 

(Note: we had a reservation for 4 at 5:30 on a Tuesday evening before Ilana Glazer's double header show at TPAC. We didn't need a reservation. The restaurant was still pretty empty when we left at 6:40.)

The restaurant is beautiful. And the happy hour is great. I just didn't think any of the food was great unfortunately.

The place is very colorfully decorated. I went with a large group of people and they didn't add additional gratuity,which is good. We went around lunch time and had made a reservation for the table. The staff  was patient with us since we had a few late folk. They kept the drinks, chip/salsa bowl filled. The food came out quickly. I had the lunch portion of the El Meson Burrito with chicken. It was pretty tasty. They actually have two locations in the Plainfield area. The wait staff was friendly.

Uncle Bill's Pancake and Dinner House use to be a great place to go for breakfast or brunch.   Be prepared to stand in line for a short time, it moves quickly.  Sunday we decided it was brunch time and since it was my birthday I decided to go here.  Why did I want to go here?  I love their corned beef hash (I think it comes out of a can, but I love it).  

Uncle Bill, Uncle Bill, Uncle Bill. Why was it me that got the burnt corned beef hash?  Shame on Annie, our waitress, for serving that to me and shame on me for not sending it back.  If I sent it back, the rest of my food would have gotten cold plus an additional wait for it.  His omelet was good and there was no problem with it.  I have never been so disappointed in the food at Uncle Bill's.
