Would I come back here?  No, this place is off the breakfast list. There are too many places that serve brunch and breakfast.

Based on some reviews I was expecting a lot more WOW factor but our experience was pleasant overall.

We made reservations for a Sunday night and asked to be seated by the window to enjoy the spanning view of the water and sunset. We had a nice table at the end near the bar where the bartender was our server.

We started with the mozzarella tomato stack and mussels. Both were good but not fantastic. We were also served bread and butter which we dipped in the leftover broth from the mussels. For dinner I had the shrimp risotto which was by far the best thing we ordered here but still a tad too rich to eat all at once. It was delicious and rich with a buttery wine oil on top that separated from the risotto. Mister had the steak which he said was good but fatty and undercooked. Perhaps a tad overpriced as well.

Dessert options were tempting but since the rest of our meal had been just good and not great we decided to skip it here. We got some cheap local ice cream at Bo's after our meal and even saw a family there who had been sitting a table away from us at the Pelican. 

Overall we would maybe come back or recommend it as a beautiful spot with good food, but it wasn't anything super special. They have a huge brunch that I might be tempted to try sometime but the price is staggering (although relative to what is offered).

Seriously good food. We gorged on abalone and chicken soup, roast duck (the appetizer version, not the Peking), and shrimp with walnuts. Hilarious that this joynt's name is one letter off of the London place Warren Zevon made famous in "Werewolves of London," but I dunno if that's purposeful or accidental.

On a return trip, I plan on trying the Peking duck, just because it's been too long since I had a good version of it. I'm also thinking the clams in garlic sauce might be calling my name.

Know this place is BYOB - bring your own beer or wine, and then settle in for a serious feed. Amid a crowd who's passionate about this place.

I've only been here for brunch. Ordered the egg benedict- the sauce was very good but the portion size was a bit small for $12. It also didn't come with a side. You'd have to order an extra side for $4 on top of that. 

I tried their blueberry lemonade and chile-mango margarita. Both were amazing and fresh. My waiter was very attentive and kind even though it was really busy. Food came out at a reasonable time. The architecture and setting are beautiful. 

I am taking one star off due to the pricing of some of the food. I will be back to try dinner the next time I'm feeling fancy $$$.

Type. . . . . . . . . . ..Banh Mi / Poboy Secret Liar
Location. . . . . . . ..Secret Liar in the back of a bar 
Prices. . . . . . . . . ..Higher 
Beer Selection. . ...Decent at the bar in front 
Food Level. . . . ....Excellent 
Staff. . . . . . . . . . ..Friendly 
Noise Level. . . . ...Very Loud 
Décor. . . . . . . . . ..Dive Bar, cramped back room lounge 
Good for Kids. . ...No 
Parking. . . . . . . ...None, Enforced Streetside 
Cash Only. . . . . ..Yes I think 
Recommended. ...Yes 
Comments: Absolutely delicious poboys with a banh mi like fusion flair. Incredible flavor. Menu changes frequently. Pork belly version was outstanding. Gulf shrimp version was one of the best sandwiches I've ever had in my life. Really fun place. When you try to walk in here, it is literally a dive bar. Head into the back lounge to find Killer Poboys. It's there. Trust me.

My friend and I had a reservation the other night at 7:30. The restaurant looked packed. We checked in and hung out in the little waiting area, it was beyond freezing out. By 8pm, we were going to walk out. Two other sets of people waiting were told to go next door to their other dining room,  which we were told to follow and then finally sat. 

Ordered. They brought out our garlic noodles instantly which would have been better brought out with the main course, but for the fact we were starving it was fine. Noodles were ok. Not hot. Lots of garlic. 

I got a lb of mussels, add sausage, went with their house seasoning and mild. My friend got snow crabs, garlic seasoning. So funny, but it took at least 10 minutes to get someone's attention to get crackers for the crabs. So that was a little annoying. The sausage was over cooked. Seasoning on everything was good. 
This dining room was also packed, noisy and service was a little slow. Also, no hushpuppies on the menu? What gives.

I'm not sure what took me so long to get here. I work in the area and I had heard about it. But it wasn't until a few coworkers wanted to go to taco Tuesday did I Finally take the plunge. 

They offer three main tacos for the $1 taco Tuesday (a steak if you ask me!) we went in right at lunch and had no wait. It's counter service so go to the front and place your order. There are menus available there. I didn't look at the menu as I was opting to go for the $1 tacos but I saw a variety of options available. 

I got two tacos which was plenty for me and I loaded them up with the sauces that are served with the tacos. There are four of them. I found the green one to be my favorite. 

I cannot wait to go back and try more of the menu offerings.

This is a place you ONLY come here for the bar. The bar has plenty of options between ice cold frozen drinks as well as mixed beverages.

The food is gawd awful. Between our table, we ordered the catfish, catfish & fried shrimp mix, jumbalaya and a po' boy....All of it was disastirous. Luckily for us, there was no wait when we came, however it still took a good 40mins for ONE dish to come out.....

No. Gracias.

This is the actually the most funniest thing on the block. It just doesn't fit.  You got all these trendy stores up and down the street. Nice eateries and restaurants all over. Then you got gift shops, craft stores, jewelery stores, books stores, clothing stores... then you get this Adult store in big words no less.

This place carry the usual porn, not that I know what it's in, what's new, and what's good. Maybe the store does stick out like an eyesore, but it's just way too funny to see a store like this as part of the trendy downtown Santa Barbara.

It's cute clean, has a nice Mexican grocery selection. The service was good. My ex had Chiliquilles with eggs and chicken. It was very good but the eggs were over cooked for my taste. I wanted a breakfast burrito but what came out was not what I wanted. The reason I chose this place was to get a breakfast burrito. They no longer have a breakfast menu although there is a picture of one online. I'd probably try it again but obviously not for breakfast.

I have been reading and reading and hearing and hearing that Cheu Noodle Bar is off the hook amazing.  So I finally decided to swing by and see what all the fuss is about...

Well, what is all the fuss about? The fuss is about the YUMMY FOOD THAT THEY HAVE.  And the decent beer list.  And the fun music.  And the daily rotating juice and ice tea.  THAT IS WHAT IT IS ALL ABOUT.  

Basically, this place is awesome. I had the coconut curry noodles, and I added an egg to it. Boy was it yummy.  Really well flavored, not too spicy, and definitely well made.  My friend ordered the yakisoba, which I found to be equally flavorful and yummy.  The beer list is really well cultivated.  The service was good.  My only complaint would be that this place is TINY. I mean the size of a postage stamp tiny.  Teensy weensy. It's really yummy, but it's not good for large parties. Also, if you get there at peak time, you may be waiting a bit. 

Can't wait to go back again and again!

We came to try the Prix Fixe and it was surpringly good.  I had the prime rib, which was juicy, fatty, and flavorful - just as a good prime rib should be; I can't stand overdone beef..  Was it the best ever?  Not quite but it was still tasty and definitely satisfying.  To be completely honest, the crab cakes are probably the better pick, with plenty of lump crabmeat, but sometimes you just really want artery-clogging steak.  The clams casino appetizer was flavorful with plenty of actual clam meat, and the creamed spinach side was on par with that found at any other steakhouse.  The creme brûlée dessert was okay but nothing special: it was creamy but a little too sweet for my liking.  Service was very attentive and the ambiance was great with leather couches and a baby grand.  Business casual dress though so I wouldn't come in jeans and a T-shirt.  Overall, a good steakhouse with a decently priced and tasty Prix Fixe.  I would definitely come for that again but I'm not sure if the steaks and dishes  are actually amazing enough to warrant the full price.  For that, I would probably head to Del Frisco's or Fleming's.

Who eats ice cream even when it's snowing out? This girl. 

Delicious ice cream that is worth any length of wait. They serve flavors you won't find anywhere else and will crave if Nola isn't your hometown. 

Don't be foolish, get the sampler and make sure you try the lavender honey, Mexican hot chocolate, and green fairy.

The ice cream scoopers/employees are more than happy to make recommendations which makes this place even more awesome. Definitely looking forward to coming back.

Home of the old McKenzies which they have still kept the neon glowing, What's there to say about Creole Creamery that Hasn't been said in the over 120+ reviews.  The place is local and uses fresh local ingredients and puts out a solid product and adventurous flavors that, if you dar to try, you will be pleasantly surprised.  An almost overwhelming amount of flavors to choose from and many of them are seasonal and use fresh, local seasonal ingredients and there is absolutely no reason to go to a baskin robbins marble slab or any other national chain when you have creole creamery.. and you should hang your head in shame for doing so!

They have a Tchoupitulas challenge which it just an overwhelming amount of ice cream and there are several people who have actually eaten it.. crazy!  The sundae is available at both locations but the official "challenge" can only be done at this one.

If you want ice cream go to Creole Creamery for a taste of New Orleans at its best.
Where does one begin with this epically bad and disappointing sub, well let's try the dry meat and tasteless bread. No jalapeños just blah blah
I tried the Crater Copernicus sundae (devil's food cake, vanilla frozen custard, hot fudge and whipped cream).  It was delicious.

Kelp Sushi Joint was ok, but there are better sushi options in Tampa.

We were lured here because the restaurant offers BYOB (bring your own bottle) and they do not charge a corkage fee. Wine glasses and cork screws are provided by Kelp.

While I enjoyed the modern décor and appreciated the purse hooks underneath the tables for the ladies I just wasn't a fan of the menu. Most of the rolls were pretty simple (California, Spicy Tuna, Mexican). If I was a timid eater trying out sushi for the first time these rolls may have appealed to me, but in my opinion the rolls were boring. The rolls that were more intricate contained cooked fish, imitation "krab" or fried chicken. None of these ingredients appeal to me.

The sashimi and nigiri options are almost non-existent which raises a huge red flag. My husband could not believe there were no sashimi platters on the menu. When he asked the waitress if the chef could prepare one for us they agreed, but the platter he created only contained tuna, salmon, and rainbow trout. Not much of a variety!

While everything tasted fine, nothing "wowed" us. We will probably not return, but this is a good spot for people that like very simple or cooked sushi rolls.

Came here for lunch today after seeing the reviews on Yelp. I chatted with the owner and found out he owns Chaat House which I've been to before. I ordered the samosa chaat and it was very good. It's a good size portion and everything was fresh. Also ordered a mango lassi and it was pretty authentic (I'm Pakistani so can tell). Total was around $10 and while there wasn't a line when I went, they tend to get packed. Great place and I will be back next time I'm in Philly.

Hey, it's OK.

Had a bit of a Sushi-Jonesing the other night and yelp directed me to this place.  It was good and not overpriced.  Having their own parking is a plus but I can see where those spaces would fill up quickly (with Land Rovers and Benzes) on a weekend night.  After negotiating my way past the beautiful people, I was seated at the sushi bar.  Funny, I was the only one there.  Doesn't anyone appreciate the at the bar experience and checking out the fish personally?

I went with some Uni (shock there, huh) and a sushi/sashimi combo platter.  I'm guessing the old guy might be the owner but he was slightly annoying.  "Hey buddy, large Sake for big man".  Whatever dude, I'm only 5' 5" tall. The Sea Urchin was fresh but a bit too much rice.  The combo platter was plentiful and nicely presented.  Good stuff but nothing to blow my socks off.  The chefs seem to be just going through the motions rather than interacting with the customers and offering suggestions.  Who knows, maybe they don't speak english.

I had a wonderful dinner here with a party of 11.  Our waitress was very helpful and accommodating. The cheapest banquet menu ($25 each) provided to be an obscene amount of amazing food. The hot and sour soup was a standout as were the pork ribs and kung pao beef. I loved it!

At my dismay to having to withdraw cash at Cafe Du Monde, I was happy to find Cafe Beignet at New Orleans Musical Legends Park gladly accepts credit card. Stopped here for a quick break between exploring the Quarter streets and walked out happy. 

I got my beignet fix here! Freshly baked and quickly devoured. The powdered sugar can be a mess and does get everywhere but I think that's just part of the experience. Also grabbed a coffee there and was on my way. 

The ambience is great. I enjoyed the live band playing jazz as well as the option to grab a drink from the full bar there. I miss New Orleans and will be coming back here as soon as I accrue more PTO. Great alternative to Cafe Du Monde.

For brunch, the place felt hung over. The service was fine, but a little dull. Not sure why they open so early if they are understaffed. My steak and eggs ($18) was passable, a little salty, though (whole peppercorns didn't help matters), and the cut of meat wasn't trimmed well. Bloody Mary was standard.

I mostly utilize Panera Bread's lunch catering service for lunch & learn trainings at my job. The boxed sandwich lunches are convenient & really good.

This was my first time visiting a store front as I was on the hunt for some mid-day coffee. 
As I entered the store the scent of cinnamon filled the air. I was greeted by every staff person in site. I was amazed at the menu selection and healthy choice options with a calorie display chart. Well that went out the window when I became fixated on the pastry selection and my sweet tooth cravings began. 

I ordered a cafe mocha and pecan roll. The pecan roll was so big that I was only able to eat 1/3 of it & gave the rest to my 3 year old godson, who too enjoyed it. The pastry and cafe mocha were hot and fresh. The store, female restroom, and large dining area were clean. I particularly liked the recycle bin next to the trash can and the 97 health rating. I will visit again the next time I am on that side of town.

This is my second time ordering food from the restaurant. The food here is top-notch quality and VERY authentic!!  Everything I have ordered reminds me of home. My mother is Puerto Rican and she is not local, therefore any time I can get some "homestyle" cooking I am brought to my happy place. While the restaurant promotes itself as being Dominican, there are many Cuban and Puerto Rican style dishes on the menu. I have ordered the Pollo guisado (Stewed chicken), arroz con gandules (yellow rice with pigeon peas), arroz blanco con habichuelas (white rice and red beans), pastelitos (fried patties) pargo (snapper), and maduros (sweet plantains).  All very well seasoned!!!  I cannot comment on the dining services because I have ordered takeout each time. The interior of the restaurant is quaint and I look forward to being able to enjoy a dining experience there one day. Keep in mind that they are BYOB. The portions are grand so be prepared and have a heavy appetite. The prices are more than fair. I honestly think they could probably get away with charging a bit more for the size portions that they provide. and I'm definitely not complaining because I appreciate being able to get great quality food at a more than fair price and enjoy several meals from one purchase.  

And BONUS! This is a minority-owned small business. I'm all for supporting local small businesses! Wepa!

So I'm here right now at Ninki ..... ordering carryout; waiting at the sushi bar; drinking a glass of Chardonnay. To my left is a quiet large screen TV, a cozy couple, and a semi-stocked bar. Behind me is a chatty group of girlfriends. To my right a large room with multiple tables romantically lit for good ambiance but with outdated decor.  In front of me attentive sushi chefs. 

Oh, what's this? They hand me a 20% off coupon next time and thank me profusely for coming in.  Do I need a coupon for sushi?  Then the waitress hands me the bill. Ouch; $70 for 5 rolls, edemame and a glass of wine....but I haven't tried the sushi yet. 

So now I'm at home and I've just finished the meal. The rolls were small but REALLY good. Unique combination of flavors like tuna and mango, and bonnito (smoked fish skin) toppings. 

Will I be back? Yes, but only with my coupon.

I've been eating here for years, but today I had a Jerk Gator Burrito and it was easily the best burrito I've had in forever.  The best.  I almost fell asleep into a blissful coma after, but instead gave the girl at the table next to me a dollar because it was her birthday.  You know we do that here (here as in the region), right?  Pinning dollars to the feted age makers.  But I digress - - - 

The servers are always pleasant and efficient, and the menu caters to dietary needs.  Pretty sure this Juan's blazed the way for the rest of the block to bring their A game.  Great food, great location, great neighborhood.

I had a mixed experience yesterday at this restaurant. My boyfriend and I biked down Esplanade and decided to stop here for lunch. We were hot and wanted air condition so we opted to sit inside. When we first walked in I was surprised to see how small it is. We weren't sure if we should just seat ourselves, so we stood there for a minute until the waitress told us to pick a spot. The restaurant is cute, but it was actually pretty hot in there and we had a few flies flying around us (I guess still better than sitting outside). 
You get one serving of complimentary chips and salsa, and I really did enjoy the salsa. My boyfriend and I decided to order queso ($7) and a chicken and mushroom quesadilla ($14). My boyfriend loves queso and said that was all he really wanted. However, the queso just wasn't good. That's probably the most expensive queso I've had but may be one of the worst. I also thought they should have brought out another basket of chips with it, since the basket of chips we had with the salsa was pretty small. Since we didn't eat much of the queso, we didn't end up running out of chips until the end of the meal though. My boyfriend was upset and confused on how a place could mess up queso. I promised him that I would split my quesadilla in half with him. The chicken and mushroom quesadilla was delicious!! The mushrooms gave it so much flavor. It was a decent portion, so I didn't mind splitting it with him. However, I think for the price tag it should come with beans and rice too. 
Service was a bit spotty, but I believe there was only one waitress and quite a decent amount of tables to serve. A man (maybe a manager) was helping her and ended up talking to us for a bit. He was very nice. Overall, we had a decent experience, and I would come here again for the quesadilla alone because it was seriously that good!

This is what downtown needed. Some good open public space positioned between the arts (Tampa Museum of Art, The Florida Museum of Photographic Arts, Straz Performing Arts Center, Glazer Children's Museum), close to food (e.g., my fave L'Eden), and next to a scenic view (RiverWalk). The space also hosts some pretty neat events. Overall, this park is nice and free.

Parilla Grill is probably my favorite place in Hyde Park!  I love the casual atmosphere and the open roof for summer weather.  Between the misters and the fans they still get a frat flow going through so it's not too hot.  There are also large tvs that provide great viewing of sports... We watched a tennis match while eating lunch.  I would like to give them a 5 star rating; HOWEVER, the service in the bar wasn't great. 

We take most of our out of town guests here for a drink (or two) and a quick bite to eat.  It's nice to have healthier options and they always have great drink specials.  Everyone in our group ordered bowls of various kinds and I tried BUFFALO meat and didn't die haha.  I actually thought it was delicious!  However, I much preferred my grilled chicken bowl with the works.  One of my friends tried the quinoa and said it was very good.

I like to make a stop at this Walmart since it's located in Meadowlark where my doctor's office is.  It's smaller than  the supercentre but I find it has a decent selection of items in the food section where the prices are cheaper than the nearby stores.  The produce section can have limited items though with just the basics in stock.  I find the snacks and canned food section are fine with good prices.

As for the rest of the store and items, well it's hit or miss.  I was looking for lightbulbs and they only had one brand of the type I was looking for and it was a energy efficient so pricier than others if they had in stock.  However, the price I paid for the item was probably cheaper than other stores.  

Don't expect much help if you need help finding an item.  Associates seem to be difficult to find unless you count some of the younger staff who like racing shopping carts in the store as they were on my last visit.  

The check outs can have at most 5 cashiers working but I find the time in the line ups is never too long so that's good.

We popped in to this cool little spot to catch some local Jazz. Looking to see John or Sophee to say hi as we're friends of John's late Uncle Sam. Anyway, the music never disappoints here. 3 piece band that grew to 4 during one of the sets. We waited for a seat at the bar that never opened up but we managed to catch 8-10 great songs before moving along. This area is a hot bed of hip jazz clubs and a nice escape from Bourbon St. Parking is always a challenge but we circled a few times and snagged a primo spot. I recommend taking a cab and leave the parking worries behind. Although we didn't eat, service seems to be adequate and all of the food looked and smelled amazing.

Came here for my free coffee on National Coffee Day.  I was pleasantly surprised how friendly the staff were.  Normally, I get the rudest people while at DD.  Their coffee was hot and tastes exactly like I remember.

I had a better experience here with the tuna "Pizza" (On an egg-roll wrapper??) but you must ask for sauces on the side - they drown it in THREE sauces - Eel sauce, Kewpie Mayo and Wasabi Mayo.

I also had an "East" roll made with cooked shrimp (safe), frozen tamago (figures) and cuke.  Tasted good, actually.

Yikes!

Better than my last visit here.

Well worth the drive from the county! What can I say that hasn't been said? I love the custard. The consistency is perfect. It looked like there were a million people there this Friday night, but we got helped immediately and barely had stepped to the side before our orders came out. Lots of interesting combinations but I stuck to my tried and true - vanilla custard with Reese's. YUM.

Nice little sushi spot. Decent presentation and a little small on the serving side. The staff was a bit cold.  It did not appear they were from Japan and I think missed out on the type of service and experience I would expect from a Sushi restaurant.  

We had about 5-6 selection of items: hand-rolls, cut rolls, sashimi. Good quality on the fish, well put together assembly.  But I ordered a hot green tea and they did not refill it once... odd.

A little bit pricy for what we got, but not a bad experience.

A (relatively) healthy way to indulge fatty cravings that cannot be properly satisfied at home!

In the mood for fried chicken, I ordered the buttermilk fried chicken sandwich which, complete with sweet pickles and horseradish mayo, hit the spot. I also ordered a side of fries and a cola. The fries, piping hot, were delicious, and the cola was refreshing!

Also, the size of the sandwich was on the mark. It was neither too big nor too small, but just right. The fries were enough for two, though!

The Oysters was Deelish as is all of the Oysters around town. I typically ask for the dish that a restaurant is known for. 
This place was the stuffed lobster. The presentation was lovely, the lobster is a nice size but the stuffing sucked. The first one I had was mushy, so I thought if was undone after tasting it. So they redid another one and I taste that one, it was still mushy. I ask the bartender is that the way it was supposed to be he said yes. it was nasty. However, the Oysters were juicy and tasty. the drinks where good.

I ordered takeout from their website and I'm so glad I did! I live about a mile from KELP and haven't tried it yet, but I'll definitely go back. Their website was easy to use and my food was ready when I got there, which is exactly when they said it would be ready. I took advantage of the 2 roll deal, which I strongly recommend if you plan on getting multiple fresh rolls and a starter. For $12.95 I chose the ginger salad, salmon avocado roll, and spicy tuna roll. I opted for brown rice on both rolls. The fish tasted fresh and all the veggies were perfect. I was feeling particularly fat today so I also ordered the veggie roll and chicken teriyaki bowl. Veggie roll was so good and the veggies were delightfully crispy. The teriyaki bowl was also very good and I loved all the veggies included in it. I ate so much and still have so much leftover!

Pho Bistro is pretty good for pho being available in the IV area. The only thing that I would really have to say here is that the food is slightly overpriced for my liking. Also, I feel like every time I ask for no cilantro in my pho, they don't deliver my requests. Depending on what time you come here, it may be really rowdy due to the crowds outside, but aside from that, the food comes out fairly quickly, which I can always appreciate. I would recommend Pho Bistro to anyone who enjoys Vietnamese food!

This isn't my usual Dierbergs, but was in the area, so decided to stop in.  I'm a huge Dierbergs fan, always have been and this one didn't disappoint.  I trust Dierbergs to have fresh produce, friendly employees and be clean!  This store like all the others is laid out nice. The bakery had lots of yummy choices.  The meat counter looked amazing.  They didn't have the tea I was looking for, but it's always a treat to shop at Dierbergs!

I can't believe it's taken so long for me to get over to the new fancy Rouse's. It was Christmas Eve and I needed just a few last minute items to make both Christmas Eve and Christmas Day dishes. I drove over to my neighborhood Rouse's...and the humongous parking lot that is always 1/2 empty? It was full to the gills. 

Luckily, I had seen a tweet from Anita M that the Baronne Rouse's was blessedly free of crowds. While that wasn't the case by mid-afternoon, it was considerably less crowded that the Tchop location.  

Great selection; nicely laid out store; folks offered to help me AND I found everything I needed and was in and out within 30 minutes. Woo Hoo!

To get 5 stars from me, a restaurant needs to be at or near perfection in taste, price, service & ambiance.  After reading the many YELP reviews I put this on the dining list.  I followed the recommendation to arrive BY 5 to avoid long waits.  On a Monday nite, this was not necessary.  There were only 3 tables dining the first hour with 2 additional tables at 6 pm when the first were leaving.  The parking lot is a little confusing beyond the first 4 cars.  The inside of the restaurant is clean and "fun" with cow hide tiles along one wall.
   I had a delicious $25 (7 oz) filet, served with garlic smashed potatoes and a parmesan crusted tomato piece. Prices aren't posted on the online menu nor stated in any other review.  This was the cheapest cut on the menu. The meat was melt-in-your-mouth delicious, tho' I ordered medium rare and got rare/cold center.  I did not want to risk sending it back and getting it too done on the other extreme.  I enjoyed the gorgonzola sauce ($4 extra option).  The tomato could come off the menu-it was barely cooked, 2 bites and not flavorful.  The potatoes were good and moist (unlike several photos here) but too garlicky for me.  The first course salad with apples & cranberries was good but not a "stand-out".  Hate that they leave such large chunks of lettuce.  The honey balsamic was good but not "outstanding".  Loved the light flaky rolls with honey butter--that was a decadent start to the meal.  I ordered at 5:05 and was served the entrée by 5:35 pm.  With a nice malbec, tax and tip, my meal for one was $45.
   This place has to work through some service issues.  I was seated at the worst spot in the place--in full view of the dumpster when there were many finer places to be seated in the empty restaurant.  There were a dozen employees upon opening for 3 tables. (Good news?  I had a dedicated waiter who served me well.)  But this made for a very LOUD employee party at the bar in a place where music or classy silence might be better than the "sports bar" shouting and laughing "show".  At least 3 employees were on their phones at any given time--including one of the cooks with one hand on the food prep.  A hostess in flip flops, a bartender whomping her gum, a cook coming out to "cuddle" with a female long-haired employee and then go back to food were yucky.
    I don't mind spending this kind of money.  But I want the total package of "class act", which should occur any night of the week consistently with every guest served.

This Starbucks is located in Regency Center, and most of the time, entry and exit is smooth.  There is ample parking, but if you just wanted to hit the drive through, this location is pretty quick. 

Other than that, it is your average expensive high calorie coffee joint.  So far, it's kept pretty clean, and the service is friendly.  

My favorite is the Java Chip.  I get it every time I go to Starbucks, morning, noon, or night.  Yeah, it's a milkshake.  Don't judge me.

Holy moly sweet jesus guacamole!! Do not eat anything other than the oysters! Order the charboiled oysters.  If you're still not full, order more oysters. If you're still not full from that, order more oysters!!

In New Orleans, there are many places to eat oysters.  We ate at 3 different places for oysters during our vacation there, and Drago's had the most memorable oysters yet.  It has this buttery-garlic parmesan, romano cheese sauce with it that was to die for. 

The only reason I'm giving it 4 stars is because that's pretty much the only good thing in the menu.  I went with my family and tried their dishes, and they were alright.  Fish, seafood, fried seafood, steak.  Nothing comparable to the charboiled oysters. But definitely come here when visiting NOLA.  It's at a good location too, next to the pier.  Don't miss out!! And enjoy :)

Haneen was an excellent worker. The manager was busy with paperwork and didn't help even though there was a line. Another employee in the back kitchen ignored requests for help with sour cream, etc. 

Good, fresh food. Healthy options. 

This review is for the airport location.

What a disappointing experience (surprisingly) I had at Lee How Fook.  I'm being generous giving it three stars but I once a few years ago had a decent meal there so I'm rounding up from two stars  Okay, let me explain.

It was a snowy day in Philly that was turning to rain and I had an early 6:30 theatre curtain with a friend.  I took the train into town and arrived early to meet my friend for dinner only to get a message my friend couldn't make it in time for dinner and would meet me at the theatre.  Ok. I decided to just head up to Lee How Fook on 11th Street and grab a meal there.  I walked in about 5 o'clock - no one else was inside except the staff making dumplings at a back table. They all just looked at me and didn't say a word. I said  "Are you open?"  They said yes and I sat down at a corner table.  Finally someone got up and came to me and I ordered the salt-baked squid.  No tea ever came my way - that's a first for me in Chinatown....and it was a cold snowy day outside when tea would have been warming.  The salt-baked squid arrived promptly and it was decent - but by far not the best I have ever eaten.  Unfortunately one of the condiment bottles on the table was so sticky it was actually gross and the hot chili peppers needed a refill.  I exchanged them for the condiments on the empty table next to me.  When I asked for the bill I got it with not even a thank you expressed.  I paid and promptly left and headed into the storm to the theatre where my friend had arrived safely and the play was excellent.

I don't think I will ever eat again in Lee How Fook.  Why would I when there are so many awesome restaurants in Chinatown?

Never I have seen a hotel restaurant so full and vibrant . The quality of food with good service is the key. Their oyster is amazing and I must say the best I ever had. Prices for food is not too bad either . I can certainly come back for the oysters and gumbo .

We absolutely enjoyed our visit to the Creole Creamery. First off --- yummmm! All flavors I sampled were rich, creamy and delicious. Secondly, who can beat outstanding service? We were immediately greeted upon entering and offered samples of flavors our eyes seemed to linger on. My daughter settled upon the "clown" version -- with lavender and a cookie flavor. Very cute way to decorate ice cream with cone, gummy bears and whipped cream. Our "scoop specialist" made it quickly and interacted so well with my daughter while she tried a few flavors. I decided to have the red velvet cake and creole cream cheese. Both very yummy, but I had food envy when I saw someone's brownie Sundae ( definitely my choice next time!) My hubby selected one of the yummy cream soda floats -- very good and generous portion. I was also blown away by the affordability of the menu. Overall, great visit and happy we tried it out. We will definitely return on our next visit to New Orleans! Way to go Creole Creamery.

This place was great! I came here after a day on the water and the food was awesome. I have been to Germany many times and I thought this place was as authentic as it gets! I have to say the service was fantastic and made sure that we had everything. 

When we arrived we were hungry and had heard the pretzel was really good so we ordered a giant pretzel. It came to our table quick and came with sweet mustard and cheese. It was super soft on the inside and tasted wonderful! The mustard was the perfect balance of sweet and tangy. The cheese was actually a little bit of a let down for me, but others seemed to like it. 

I ended up having one of my favorite dishes which was the schnitzel. The schnitzel was pork pounded out flat and then deep fried. It was super good. Others at my table got sausages and they all loved them. 

Overall this was a great meal. I would for sure go back and I for sure recommend this place for great German food!

Just a quick comment; will write more when I have a chance. Place has changed a bit, all for the better. Though it still has the same wooden booths and hole-in-the-wall feel, it's been cleaned up a lot and the new menu board and signage do a lot to freshen things up. The service was very quick for this type of food, they now accept plastic, and the food now reminds me of the good ol' days. Both pizza and wings were crispy and tasty. I'm looking forward to sampling my old favorite, the baked pizza sandwich.

The vibe of this place is far out! The ghosts of 1970 are alive here! The wood, the brass, the planters, the color scheme, the swank... the attention to period detail needs a shout out!! 
Mr Roeper night walk in any minute! (Three's Company reference, millennials) 
But the food is modern and fabulous! The watermelon and feta salad is one of my favorite dishes in The city.  The roasted cauliflower is downright meaty. The diver scallops are large and in charge.  The burger is a winner, and the fries  are delightfully lightly kissed with a touch of lemon zest.  The wine list is fairly priced (thank you) and the selections are fantastic. We had a rosè, a white and a red... all rave worthy. 
Dessert was a perfect ending... mud pie! My favorite was the fresh whipped cream. 
In nice weather, take a seat outside. Or enjoy live music inside. Can't go wrong either way. 
The manager, Scott, was kind enough to come to our table and check in. We were impressed with his enthusiasm. We shall return!

I'm actually really surprised about the poor reviews this place has received.  I've only had good experiences!

The people have always been friendly, I've never had to wait, and the barbecue is on point!  I like the babyback ribs with the collard greens and macaroni and cheese.  You really can't go wrong with the barbecue.  I've also had breakfast sitting at the bar, and people remembered me on my second visit.  

Give them a chance!

Why I'd opt to go to Rouses over Whole Foods:

1. It's Louisiana-owned
2. They have Cajun hot nuts
3. Related to the above, they have an array of other NOLA specialty items (tourists, buy your foodie souvenirs here rather than the FQ)
4.They play New Orleans music rather than hippy dippy crap
5. Their employees are nice without making you feel like you've committed a sin by asking for plastic (to be fair, the cashiers at WF aren't nearly as self-righteous as the floor staff who seem like they'd spit on you if you ask for something that is against WF puredom, like artificial sweetener. Not that I'd ever ask for it, but a friend once had the audacity to do so and was met with a lecture).
6. Kick ass olive bar
7. They just have a lot more grocery items, and more affordable options at that
8. Not everything has to be gourmet specialty foods and products. They have those, but sometimes you want a bag of Zapps chips or a harsh cleaning product for eff's sake!
9. Nowhere nearly as pretentious (for example, you probably don't notice, but WF has plenty of produce that's from Mexico, California and other places).  
10. Aeroponic rooftop garden! How cool is that?
11. Phenomenal booze/wine/beer selection

Issues with this particular Rouses that would have me head to WF instead:

1. The oils area is confusing not only to shoppers but to employees as well. I had three different employees attempt to find me a vessel in which to pour truffle oil from the jug thingamajig and no one could help me. Not their fault as apparently they had just changed all that around, but no one clued the staff in. 
2. There's just not enough organic produce. It would be ideal as well, if the organic stuff wasn't all mixed in with the other stuff.
3. Not enough produce in general (uh, dino kale shouldn't be that rare).
4. Lack of gourmet whole bean coffee


Numbers 2-4 have double weight, as I'm all about the organic produce selection. A fine whole bean coffee i(extremely dark roast that I grind myself) is what gets me through a morning. I realize not everyone is as particular as me, but there you have it. Supermarket shopping is painful enough, I'd rather not have to go to more than one store per week.

Other things to note:

-gourmet and deli sections in this Rouses is really outstanding and similar to WF. I didn't check out the prepared food section too much, so I can't report on that just yet. 
-the staff really did go out of their way to find me an oil vessel. 
-that wine selection blows WF's out of the water

Expect review updates!

We were led here by the glowing Yelp reviews and the fact that we had a wonderful meal at Mad Fish last year (owned by the same person as 1200). What a mistake.

First off the place is tiny and extremely loud.  I ordered the sea bass, but they were out of it - at 7pm?  Next I tried to order the grouper special - again out of it.  Richard, our waiter told me (confidentially per him) that he could give me the 8 oz lobster tail for $24 along with the mashed potato side and my choice of broccoli or asparagus.  Chose the asparagus.  Chip
Ordered the Berkshire pork chop with a pepper rub, mashed potatoes and asparagus.  My lobster was good, but no way was this tail 8 oz before cooking.  Chip's pork chop was a spectacle of gristle and fat.  Despite its huge size he probably got about a half portion due to the bad cut of meat.  His potatoes were pretty good. His asparagus were missing, but when he saw the sad little overcooked spears I received, he figured he'd pass.

When Richard came back and asked if we wanted a box for the uneaten gristle and fat we told him it wasn't necessary and explained why.  To his credit, he apologized and removed the $15 charge for my glass of Groth Sauvignon Blanc, which we thanked him for and appreciated the gesture.

When we got the bill I noticed that I was given an additional charge for the asparagus, even though that was not mentioned when he offered the choice of broccoli or asparagus.

I should say that the house chopped salad, rolls and maple butter were delicious and that's what made me give 1200 two stars instead of one.

Avoid at all costs.  Between the noise factor, lack of listed entrees at 7pm and the bs crap with the vegetable, there are many other places that deserve your tourist dollars more.

i love the decor, i love the vibe of this place!! but noodles..? eeeehhh 

here's what they seriously messed up on-- serving a bowl of noodles (to me) that's not piping steamy HOT!! and people might think "that is so trivial.." NO! b/c of this.. my bean sprouts did not cook.. keep in mind, my egg was also only half cooked.. the high temperature of the soup was supposed to complete the cooking when served.  #2, i gradually slowed down my slurping toward the 2nd half because it was getting cold and frankly, it just wasn't too appetizing anymore..  there were other things that bothered me too like how little soup they gave you lol.. but i'll stop here so i don't sound like a complete jerk.

so being #12 out of 50 on foobooz, i was holding a certain level of expectations..  i see lots of potential here and i did have a fun dining experience with my friend.. but i rather take my money else where.. 

on the plus side, i did enjoy the dumplings (braised ribs with eggplant)-- it's always a plus when i can taste what they say it is inside lol

I, too, am absolutely shocked that a grocery store in Rittenhouse is overpriced. Shocked!

The convenience is really worth it sometimes, especially when I'm coming home from work and want to pick up a bunch of veggies and don't have the cash in my pocket to go to Sue's. And really, nothing that I buy there is so marked up that I feel like I have to borrow against my 401k just to eat. If I need to be frugal, I know where to go.

Plus, the people who work there are friendly. And they deliver, which is a neat option.

Nothing Great...not terrible. It did quench my appetite for Indian.

Vegetable Samosa were plain. Won't get again.  Jhinga Chaat (Shrimp Chaat) was the best overall dish we had. Good flavor.  Will explore the chaat's more on future visits.

Mulligatawany Soup was just ok.

Garlic Naan was awesome. Cooked perfectly and was very light.

Dahi Bhala (Lentil Dumplings) also very plain. They weren't dumplings...more like lentil donuts swimming in cucumber yogurt.

Saag Paneer was most disappointing... reminded us of creamed spinach. 

Murg Tikka Masala... the sauce was very plain. Had a "tomato from the can" kind of flavor. However, the tandori chicken in the dish was FANTASTIC.

Everything lacked flavor and spice. We ordered Medium and got bland.  We will go back only after exploring other Indian options.

If you love (charbroiled) oysters, then this is the spot for you. Seriously, I'm drooling now just thinking about them. I've had them a number of times and have NEVER been disappointed. 

The Shuckee Duckee was pretty amazing if you're okay with lots of butter and carbs. The meat looked like it would be dry, but was surprisingly moist. Lots of good flavor and went well with the linguini it came with. 

We also ordered the spinach dip, stuffed lobster and seared tuna. All of these dishes just lacked the subtle finesse of fine dining, the flavors were not delicate or well developed. Prepare yourself for lots of heavy cream and butter. 

What I liked least about this restaurant was the ambiance (or lack there of). Felt like I was eating in a giant cafeteria. Nothing charming or romantic or cute. Absolutely not worth the hour wait to be seated. Don't even consider this for a romantic date spot. 

Bottom line: come for the oysters and nothing else.

This place was a great find and helped make our trip to New Orleans and Bourbon Street more memorable.  We were only in overnight to do the Bourbon Street "experience" (as adults, not college partiers) and then head to a cruise the next morning.  Visiting in late January/Early February it was a bit cool out side, but Cafe Beignet had it covered.  That is, heat lamps.  And despite being a Friday night, it wasn't so crowded that we couldn't get a table near one.  Bonus, some live music playing in the Music Legends Park.  There was an attendant for the tables as well, clearing them as fast as people came and went.

The Beignet's themselves were good.  I'm not going to say as good as the epic ones located at more famous places around town, but the price and benefit were huge.  And there is a bar adjacent to it for whatever your pleasure if coffee isn't your thing (after all, it is on Bourbon Street)

The next morning we went back for more, including a reasonable breakfast.  Great since we were on the go and didn't have a lot of time to find a sit down place.  They had a variety of options, including breakfast sandwiches, sweets, just about anything.  And the bar was open too.  If that's something you'd like!

Will be stopping by here for sure next visit, which gets it 4 stars!

Salted caramel in a waffle cone. Yummy!! 

Tried a sample of the famous Cookie Monster but wasn't too impressed. Also tried a sample of the lavender honey and didn't like it loll. But those two flavors seem to be popular in the yelp review highlights so y'all should ask to sample it at least. The employees are really nice and patient. They let me try like 5 flavors haha

Did you know there's a Kroger tucked away off the main drag in Broad Ripple? Me neither! It's an old school Kroger that feels like it's stuck in the 1980s, but it gets the job done if you're looking for something basic. The layout is a bit odd, and it feels more like a glorified CVS than an actual grocery store. But, it's convenient if you're cruising through Broad Ripple. Find it back by the new Three Sisters location!

My usual airport indulgence: Tony Luke's Terminal F at Philadelphia Airport. The staff here is actually very pleasant contrary to the general atmosphere of this airports staff. Are usually opt for the same sandwich beef, Liz and provolone or American. Left off them mushrooms this time round them up today and two sweet peppers. Fast, hot, served with a smile. TIP: if you're traveling with more than one person, have them cut the sandwiches two were four slices which is more than enough. Unless you are a professional eater, this sandwich can easily get the best of you.TIP 2: This is the best place to charge your phone at Philadelphia airport. One of the only places you can find a working outlet.

Tucked in behind a number of other establishments, this is the place to go when you want your bad-for-you-but-oh-so-delicious fix. The menu is pretty straightforward, and if you're like almost everyone else you'll get the grab bag of three beignets doused liberally in powdered sugar.

Yum.

Came here for Sunday brunch and walked away with a very full belly and a good buzz! 

Their brunch buffet includes tons of seafood, an omelet station, pasta bar, carving station, custom sushi rolls, fresh fruit, salads, and the usually breakfast foods you'd expect at a buffet. I almost forgot dessert...an entire side of the room is dedicated to a table full of desserts AND a chocolate fountain. The brunch price also include bottomless mimosas which were literally bottomless. Our server never let us empty our glasses and  the mimosas were very heavy on the champagne, so we all got a bit tipsy. At least the alcohol let us forget how much weight we gained during this meal.

As if the buffet spread wasn't enough, they also have an a la carte menu with small dishes. The choices included Belgian waffles, french toast, blintzes, Mahi, and a few other savory dishes.  You can order as many of these items as you want, as many times as you want. Our server was sure to remind us of this, she seemed to enjoy watching how gluttonous our table was! 

Unfortunately we were here during Tropical Storm Debby, so we didn't get to enjoy a beautiful view of the bay, Although, being here while the weather was so awful was very cozy with the fireplace and wood interior. Thanks to the weather it wasn't crowded either, so don't write this place off on account of bad weather. 

At $35 a person, the Sunday brunch seems pricey, but if you have no qualms about overeating and overdrinking, you'll definitely get your money's worth.

This is a very mediocre place.  The location itself is in the same dirty strip mall as Mozzarella Pizza. The inside has that "we don't really care about the looks" feel to it.  It's not dirty, per se.  It just doesn't look very clean.  Everything looks like its falling apart.  It probably gets its business from suburbanites like me craving what we think of as Chinese food.

All that said, the food I had was palatable.  Nothing outstanding or amazing: it was just all right.  I won't recommend against it, but it's nothing that you would think of as that great either.

Pro: the food is delicious, The sauces are unique, and the sides are great. I would go out of my way to come here for the mac and cheese alone. The tenders are better than the wings! Don't ask me why maybe i'm a wing snob. There is seating upstairs so you can actually dine in and it's comfy and clean. 
Cons: The staff are young so they are very un-involved in helping. Of course they are going to be friendly but it seems like unless they know you, it's not going to be an outstanding experience. Nothing specific happened to me but the person upfront seemed 'shy' until a buddy came in. The menu is online but that is the ONLY way you can order if you are in a hurry, unless you come in. There is no take out menu at the front area.  YOU CAN NOT CALL AN ORDER IN. There is no parking so it would make sense to call it in before you arrive, grab and go. But somebody messed that up for everyone. Seeing there is no parking out front, or just about anywhere up there, you kind of have to walk a few blocks. 
It's worth it. If you can find a good space have them cook the food fresh, it's all the difference. 
Beyond that this has to be one of my favorite places to eat in University city.

So, I'm driving on Sunday afternoon heading from Tampa to Orlando, looking forward to a good jolt of Starbucks coffee to keep me awake. After waiting about a half an hour looking for a Starbucks sign, I see one for this location.

I pulled into the lot, and it was pretty busy. I figured I could live with that, knowing that my local Starbucks moves pretty fast through the line. I was sorely mistaken. When I walked in, probably 15 people in line and virtually no one sitting down. After standing there for 10 minutes and not seeing any progress. Myself and a few others bailed. The person in front of me said they seemed more focused on serving the people in the window than people in the building.

I walked over to McDonald's and got a couple of apple pies, coffee and was on my way. The people in front to me still had not been served.

This is not typical of my experience with Starbucks.  Caveat emptor!

Amerigo gets 4 stars for their lunch specials and service.  It has slowly taken over my lunch rotation and brought it to a halt.  I order the same thing every time, salad and spaghetti/meatball combo.  It really makes my week, I kind of look forward to it.  The spring salad is fluffy and fresh with a touch of roasted red peppers for color and flavor.  The spaghetti portion is just my size and it's topped with an extra large meatball.  Now, if this isn't enough, you also get bread and oil.   This whole bundle of joy is a mere $8.  Boom!  Lunch around Vandy isn't the cheapest so this makes my wallet happy.  I do have to note though this isn't the best pasta in town, I mean it's good, but it's no Mama Mia's or Cafe Nonna, but it's perfect for what it is.  I should also note the staff, because this is a lunching place, brings your meal out in almost record time.  They have it down to a science.  (I always eat in the bar area so I don't know if this is true for the tables.)  Thanks Amerigo, see you later in the week!

speedy quick service! our food came out HOT. i came here on a wednesday night with my friends before going out to bourbon street. would say it is a bit pricey but they do have weekly specials. wednesday's was 1/2 off blue crab! & one of the days they have 1/2 off oysters. but i ordered 1 lb of shrimp with a side of corn & sausage.  SO GOOD! would recommend! it was good would recommend getting the pound of stuff then just adding sides. i feel like i can find more boil places to compare to but this was a good starting point! they did give a loaf but it cost an additional $1.95.

If Saint Louis had a "hot, new" restaurant, this would be it. I have been hearing rave reviews about Indo for months now and I finally got to check it out this weekend!
We made a reservation and they are giving you a 1 hour and 45 minute time slot which is plenty of time!

What I ordered: I started with the air chrysalis to drink. I had never tried sake before and there were a lot of other flavors in the drink so I still am not quite sure what it tastes like. To eat I ordered the yellowtail nigiri. It has to be some of the best nigiri I've had in stl. Then I got the Japanese pumpkin. The flavor of the curry was amazingly smooth with just a little bit of spicy. (My picture of this dish is awful bc I guess I moved the phone before it was actually taken, but oh well hahaha.)

I am such a big fan of Indo! I know what everyone was raving about.

There is probably a reason that Kmart has been taken over by Walmart. 

It was decent... it just didn't have the feel of Walmart. I know, what a weird thing to have a snob opinion on...
This particular Five Guys is the best of all and I have tried several different Five Guys locations.  Burgers come out perfectly cooked and employees are very friendly!

Where do I begin?! We took a tour around Indy on a bar on wheels. Could it possibly get any better? It happened to rain the entire length of our trip, but it did not make the experience any less exciting. We drank, laughed, listened to music and most importantly...pedaled ourselves along the streets of Indianapolis. The looks people gave us along the way were priceless. It was as if their eyes were saying, "Ah, I'm so jealous!" and "Why have I not done that before?!" So the bike experience lasted around 2 hours, but don't worry - they are more than willing to make bar/bathroom stops along the way. For example, we stopped along Mass Ave and walked around for a bit before hopping back on the bike of wonder. 

Affordable? Yes, it is! With all of the seats filled, it comes out to be about $25 per person. The owners are incredibly friendly and chat along the way. You're able to have your own music selection, so you have the freedom to jam to anything from JT to the Spice Girls (just a few faves of mine.) With the HandleBar originating in Amsterdam, I'm so very thankful that it has now made its grand appearance in Indianapolis.

This is a nice park in Wesley Chapel! There is endless green here. They have baseball fields, soccer fields, a playground, picnic tables, etc.

There is tons of parking here for all the weekend kid's games. It is pretty clean here as well.

I wish they had a physical building like my local park districts back here where they offer lessons for kids and adults like classes, etc. perhaps they do, and I am not aware of it.

All in all, this park is nice and huge for my dog to play without concern of cars nearby.

i got a coupon for a free sundae from the dentist when i got my teeth pulled. so, i used it tonght. 

i liked it. it was not quite ted drewes but still very good. i liked the variety. i got a peach shortcake sundae. my nephew used the coupon. they also have choclate custard. yum!!! 

would go back!!!

Love this store everywhere but this location is awesome, especially for how small it is. I was able to find everything I needed - great wine/beer selection, prepared foods, and fresh produce. Cashiers' nice and super helpful. Definitely great if you are in the Quarter and need to grab and go.

Stopped here a few days ago after flying in from Florida. We have no diners here in Florida. I miss diner food. We were greeted and seated quickly. Our waitress took our drink orders quickly as well. My sister and I had the chicken croquettes with mashed potatoes and gravy. The croquettes were filling and tasted just okay. The mashed potatoes and gravy were very good. My mom had a turkey club sandwich that she really liked. The hit of the meal, however, was the rice pudding my sister and I had for dessert. The rice pudding was sweet but not sickeningly sweet, piled high with whipped cream and a light dusting of cinnamon. Our waitress was attentive during the entire meal and didn't rush us as we were catching up on family stuff. The next time I'm in town, I will make sure to have my sister bring me here again!

Five stars for everything here - the 25+ flavors of lassis available, the extensive chaat menu, and most of all, the customer service. While the lassis are enough to keep me coming back, the owner is one of the nicest shopkeepers I've ever met in my life. He's so helpful in explaining what exactly is in your chaat, what kind of lassi is good if you've never had one before, and always tells you to try your drink/food first before paying to make sure you like it. Both times I've been here, he's also given free samples of some of the other lassi flavors that my friend ordered!

I've tried the peach and coconut lassis and they were both delicious. I liked the peach more though. I've also had the bhel puri chaat, which is a great mix of flavors and textures - crunchy papri and sev, tangy chutney, sweet mango, potatoes, and other things whose names I'm not entirely sure of.

I definitely recommend Mood Cafe if you're looking for a quick and delicious meal, or a refreshing lassi!

Las Fuentes is a festive, new Mexican restaurant located in a strip mall at the corner of MacKenzie and Heege Rd in Affton.  They serve an Americanized version of Mexican food (lots of cheese, and fried tortillas, etc).  Prices are a tad higher than your average mom and pop shop, but lower than your average corporate run Mexican restaurant.  The servers are friendly, but they seem a little understaffed for the size of the restaurant.  The menu is a little busy and not organized in a user friendly way, but there are lots of photos of the food, which helps.  You have to ask for water.  The chips are good when warm, but just okay when they cool off.  The salsa isn't spicy, but it tastes fresh and homemade.  I had the shrimp taco dinner ($12.25) and the portions were very generous.  The shrimp was cooked perfectly and I left full.  This meal can easily be split.  Overall, I enjoyed my meal.  I would like to see a few menu options with fresh avocado instead of guacamole, but I'm glad they make their guacamole in house.  Overall I had a good experience and the food came out fast.  I still love authentic style the best.

Interesting experience here.

Came here on a Saturday night around 7, and was seated right away for a table for 2.  Not much later did this place get PACKED.  I'm guessing this is a Chinese owned Japanese restaurant because all the waitresses were speaking Chinese.  

They had a variety of rolls; they had the standard rolls and some house special ones.  We picked out four rolls to share and they were all pretty fresh.  Note: spicy tuna and spicy salmon rolls taste almost identical and we couldn't figure which was which...  The smoked salmon roll was rich in flavor and the eel avocado roll had some sauce on it.  Overall, a filling but light meal.

I was accidentally charged a different table's check for $70 when our's was $30.  It took the waitress a while but she came back and gave me $70 in cash and made a joke about how I used the restaurant as an ATM...  haha..

I really HATE shopping at Whole Foods. Not for the same reasons as most people.  I don't mind paying extra for organic food. My fiance is a very healthy eater, and I am TRYING harder to be.  We do a lot of our grocery shopping here, so I'm used to the steep prices. My issue is with the people that shop here. They are RUDE. I'm not sure what it is about Whole Foods that brings out the a-hole in people, but people in this store seem to leave their manners at the door.

For one thing, everyone seems to be in a hurry. They all think whatever THEY came in to buy is more important than what YOU came in to buy.  So... there's constantly people reaching over you to get something (usually without saying "excuse Me"), and lots of "near-misses" with shopping carts.  When we are in Whole Foods, we like to read labels for ingredients and the customers here just don't allow for you to shop leisurely. No matter where you go in the store, you are made to feel like you are in someone's way.  

My rating is based solely on my experiences with the customers. Quality-wise, everyone knows Whole Foods always has fresh produce and we buy a lot of our seafood here. I also like the salad bar, selection of vitamins and herbal supplements and cosmetics.  In fact, if I could remove the customers from this store, I would probably give Whole Foods a solid 4 or 5.

Drago's is super convenient if you're staying at the Hilton. It's not necessarily fast though. Our party of 4 waited 20 min for a table in a mostly empty restaurant. Frustrating. You'd think they'd do a better job of staff management on big event weekends. 

The husband and I split an oyster poboy for lunch. It's nearly a 13-inch sandwich and comes with fries, so it's plenty for 2 people. The sandwich plus 2 bottles (not draft) of Abita Amber came to $33 plus tip. 

The oysters were good. The bread was overly toasted though. Like completely shatter into crumbs everywhere and fall apart in your hands with dryness as you try to eat. Grrr. 

Our friend was able to order off the children's menu - a huge win. Also our server was very nice and kept our water glasses full. 

So again, good for eating if you need somewhere close to your hotel. Otherwise it wouldn't be my first choice.

When I was in college, Blenders in the Grass was my go-to smoothie place, so when I was recently there for a little reunion with my college bffs, I hit up this Blenders over by our hotel.  I tried an acai smoothie and ordered a shot of wheatgrass, both of which were delivered to me quickly and super fresh.  The smoothie made me feel like a million bucks, the wheat grass shot went down easy and I got a taste of nostalgia that continued through a really lovely weekend.

My only regret is that I didn't get to try their acai bowls!  They have those now and they sound heavenly: Organic Sambazon Acai blended up thick with strawberries, banana, and a splash of apple juice. Topped with granola, sliced bananas and a touch of honey.  Well there's always next time!

Love UCSB, Love my smoothie memories and LOVE Blenders in the Grass!

Yelp 100 Challenge: 63/100

The service here is spectacular.  After we parked along the street nearby, I went in to ask if we could sit out on the patio and although the hostess was not spotted, I saw two staffers chatting at the bar area who immediately spotted me, so I asked them about sitting on the patio.  One of them said we could and apologized about not being up front at the restaurant when I walked in, which was totally fine with us.  He was very, very nice and allowed us to pick a table outside and got us menus before our server came out, which was shortly after.  And with the great service - our server was very nice and checked in with us about getting refills, getting more beers, bringing anything else, etc...  She also was well-informed about the menu when we would ask for specifics on items.

Unfortunately though, I didn't like my burger as much as I had hoped.  I ordered the Taco Truck Burger, which came with guac, sour cream and tortilla chips on a burger, so sounded amazing!  But it wasn't something I'd order again, as I thought it was very bland - even with all of the jazzed up toppings.  It didn't taste like the patty was seasoned at all nor the guac, which was odd.  The sweet potato tots though were yummy.  I do like that instead of fries you can get tots, especially sweet potato tots.  I recommend getting the sweet potato tots with the garlic aioli that the server recommended for me when I asked if she could bring me an aioli to go with.  I just wished the burger had been more to my liking.  

They have some local beers on taps, and most are from the east coast.  Patio seating was spacious, looking out to the street/Gulch area and they have heated outdoor lamps there.

Probably the worst Whole Foods I have been to.  The produce selection and scarce and not the most fresh.  The roses are usually in deplorable condition for a place like Whole Foods.  

The cheese department is fantastic there.  Out of that WF staff, they are the most friendly and helpful.

Yesterday I headed to Curtis Hixon Park for yoga in the park by Yoga Downtown Tampa. http://www.yogadowntowntampa.com/YogaDowntownTampa/HOME.html

It was fabulous! The eastern side of the park, with the tiers, is shaded by the museum in the late afternoon/early evening, and all the tiers filled up with people ready to get their yoga on by 6 p.m. Doing yoga outside with a couple hundred people was very cool (only figuratively...despite the shade, it was hot!).

The park is a great place for yoga. It was clean and well-groomed, and has public restrooms close at hand. Having the shaded museum patio was great for my group, as a place to hang out for a while before yoga. Parking in the parking deck right next door was also very convenient.

I can't wait to go back to Curtis Hixon Park for yoga again!

Had a few beers and some sushi here this past week.  The beer was great, but the sushi was???  With the exception of Uni which tasted somewhat fresh, the rest of my sushi was less than desirable.

A friend once told me "Tony, why would go to Reno and order seafood?  Do you see any oceans?" 

I think my buddy has a point.
The beignets are ok-- crispy, square and sort of flat. The flavor is ok and they came out piping hot.

Returned there this week. nice to see that the food is still great.  Fresh local and imported ingredients are used with great care by Samantha the chef/owner.  I had Papardelle with porcini mushrooms and it was great.  the soup in the bread bowl seemed a bit more bread than soup but it was good. It was busy on a Sunday night, but we still managed to get in at  the bar. Nice service from Danny who is a character.  Great Italian. In New York or La you would pay twice as much for this quality.

I got no problem with this grocery store. I think the staff are super friendly which is something I always appreciate. There is a lot of parking out front so you're never having to park too far away. I think they have a great selection of lunch foods that can be both hot and cold.

Prices for cat food are crazy reasonable here. We usually don't purchase too much grocery store cat food but our cat's new diet randomly calls for fancy feast pate because it is low carb. They literally sell fancy feast pate here for 58 cents a can. That's unreal to me, so we stocked up on that. I think we bought like 40 cans it was so cheap! 

This location just happens to be very convenient for anyone living downtown. I will of course be back.

I got so excited when I saw a commercial for Fazoli's. I've been searching far and wide for this place. I went like four years ago while I was in Anderson, SC and fell in love with their breadsticks and pizza. Back then they served only whole pizza's and no slices. In recent years they started selling slices and I don't think the pizza taste as good. The breadsticks are still good for what there worth, but Fazoli's is not at the top of my list for best food in the world. It is good when you need some where quick to go.

Craft fried chicken? Sounds kind of gimmicky to me... until I tried it and said to myself, "Wow, this is good stuff!" I tried a sampling of their three craft fried chicken offerings - white meat tenders, dark meat tenders , and wings - as well as their hand-crafted "Red Neck Pecan Pie." The reason why the chicken is so good is because it's buttermilk battered with a pretzel crust. The chicken's not perfect, however. My white meat piece was a superior experience with its big slab of juicy breast meat and wonderful pretzel crust coating. My wing, on the other hand, was a little dry. The dark meat pieces were okay - one of my pieces was a little stringy - and nowhere near as good as the white meat piece. I typically enjoy dark meat over white meat for its richer flavor, but it wasn't happening here. I really like the pretzel coating. It's nice and crunchy and provides a good balance with moist chicken. The chicken is priced at $11 per pound and each little container of dipping sauce is 50 cents. The pie, which resembles a homemade Hostess cherry or apple turnover, was quite good, but priced a bit high at $4. You'll be amazed at how quickly your bill adds up. My four pieces of chicken, pie, and dipping sauce costs about $10 and some change. I would expect these kinds of prices in Center City, but not in a neighborhood full of college students. Regardless of the price, a solid three stars, four if I didn't eat the wing or dark meat.

I was looking for some Chinese comfort food during my recent visit to Philadelphia and Lee How Fook was a delightful find on the edge of Chinatown. I have to admit, the picture on Yelp of the dry-style chow fun (gwon-chow-gnow-haw) didn't hurt... 

The restaurant has some pretty authentic selections as far as Hong Kong/Cantonese cuisine, at least I could understand most of what was being said behind the revolving door leading to the kitchen. Aside from the two of us, there was another Asian family of 3 that we were seated next to, and the rest of the parties in the restaurant were Caucasian. I would have to agree with Ramen F. and say that the ambiance is not as intimidating as a hole-in-wall place with ducks hanging in the window would be to beginners. The waiters all speak English and the menu is bilingual, all things that help to make the environment more friendly. The caveat is that they also have a "Chinese" menu with additional dishes that we recognized and could order from... 

The half order of Peking Duck surprised me in a couple of ways. First of all, if this was really Peking Duck, then I wasn't very impressed. The Peking Duck that I'm used to has a crispy skin which is prized and is usually served with steamed buns and hoisin sauce. The duck that we had was more like ordinary roast duck, the presentation was a bit low-key. Now, it's possible that we ordered roast duck instead of Peking Duck, I'm going by the online menu to help me write this review and I don't remember if we ordered one or the other. It would behoove those who can tell the difference to ask the waiter what they are getting. In any case, the duck tasted alright as long as it was just roast duck... 

The Flavored Beef Brisket Hot Pot (gnow-nom-faw-bow) was very good, everything that I was looking for as far as comfort food. The beef is of a lesser cut but is braised until the flavors of the ginger, garlic, and scallions are all melded together with the meat into a delightful stew. Eat this with a lapping bowl of steamed rice and you get a delicious beef bowl... 

We needed some sort of green vegetable to balance out all of the meat so we also ordered some Sauteed Chinese Broccoli (hong-gneen-guy-lon) to go with our dishes. The broccoli stalks were crisp but not chewy, and the dark leaves had a slight mustard taste, just as they should. The oyster sauce is thick and sweet, and serves to offset the flavor of the leaves somewhat. I thought the quality was pretty fresh...

I thought the prices were very reasonable... 

We walked away, satisfied and food happy; glad to have found this oasis of Cantonese cuisine during our vacation...

When I actually lived in Philly, I never ate at Marathon Grill. I must have been smarter back then. Or maybe it was just because I had my own kitchen. 

As an out-of-town visitor, I've tried it twice (10th and Walnut and the Chestnut St location), both times on a weekday morning on my way out of town. Both times the food hasn't lived up to the menu and has left me with regrets. On the most recent visit, which, I swear, will be the last, my croque monsieur was cold and my coffee sat empty. 

But in both cases, I have to admit, the restaurant provided a nice, nearby, Center City brunchy-breakfast destination that got me on my way in good time. But convenience isn't all that yummy.

I came for the oysters. I wasn't impressed. Acme's charbroiled oysters are 10x better. I also had the lobster which was pretty good. I had a petite filet on the side. This was gross. 

The overall service was just ok. Our server forgot to bring the sides. By the time he returned I was ready to go. Then he charged us for the sides.  

If you want great oysters they aren't here. Go to acme. Way better.

Generally, I'm not a huge fan of mexican food, but Juan's Flying Burrito is pretty freaking awesome. They've got a huge menu, tons of vegetarian options, and an interesting collection of servers with an equally eclectic decor. They also have an unusually broad selection of margaritas--not as in flavored margaritas, but as in whether they're made with cointreau or triple sec, whether they've got grand mariner floating on top, and so forth. Then again, perhaps this isn't unusual; I seem to (vaguely) remember that Superior Grill has a similarly broad selection. 

Both Juan's locations are equally good, as far as I'm concerned, though I end up at the Magazine Street location more often. The food is always fantastic at either place, and the portions are huge, so if you go for dinner it's likely you'll go home with tomorrow's lunch, as well. 

According to their (rather elaborate) website, there's apparently a new patio at the Magazine Street location. Good weather for it, but it sounds like the patio is largely for smokers, which is bound to ruin your meal. Unless you're a smoker, I suppose. 

Always a great choice, if you've not made it to Juan's yet, definitely go check it out the next time you're craving really, REALLY awesome mexican food.
The chicken and the ribs entrees were overly-salty. I like my foods full of flavor, but not salt. But still it was pretty good, and the parking lot was convenient. The sides were good though.

YUM! This would be definitely be one of my to-go dessert place if I lived here. There was a line when we came and I can see why people would wait in line for ice cream. The line goes back pretty fast though. The shop reminded me of those dixie cafes which gave off such a homely vibe. 

We had the strawberry soda with vanilla ice cream and root beer float with ice cream (forgot the one we tried). OMG. Both were so amazing and addicting. The strawberry soda definitely tasted like strawberry with a bubbly taste. Both ice cream flavours were creamy and soft!

Make sure you bring cash! Check out this place if you're in the area!

Cheu Noodle Bar's Black Garlic Wings are likely to have ruined many future Sunday football delivery orders for me. These things are criminally delicious. I think I could eat an infinity times infinity of them. Perfectly crispy skin, juicy dark meat in every bite, shishito peppers on the side (a personal fav), and that sweet-meets-salty mystery sauce?! With pigskin season around the corner, I'll never be able to enjoy future boring BBQ and buffalo wings quite the same.

Luckily, Cheu is no one-trick winged pony. Their Charred Corn is a messy, but inspired take on elote. I was surprised to see how well truffle oil paired with corn on the cob, although those who worship everything truffle probably just scoffed at such initial skepticism. And while I was hoping for bigger chunks of crab meat, my Cold Jade Noodle entree got better with every dash of sriracha, every chopstick-clasped peanut (the real winning taste here).

Cheu is a small, casual space that doesn't take reservations. We only waited maybe 15 minutes for a seat at the bar, but in that time, the staff let us place drink orders (the special was $4 Foster's 24 oz. "oil cans") and guzzle brews on the sidewalk. They had a great beer selection otherwise (Oskar Blues Mama's Little Yella Pils, 21st Amendment Watermelon Wheat, and Allagash Tripel, to name a few), but I opted for value pick this time around. I'm typically a traditionalist when it comes to noodle joints, but Cheu's creativity was just too delicious to ignore. Now give me infinity more Black Garlic Wings, please.

I am giving this chain restaurant 4 stars, and you, the reader, 4 reasons to eat here!

1. Great toppings like grilled mushrooms, grilled peppers, bacon, etc. And... they're... free! Or at least included in the price. 

2. Fries are decent...maybe slightly above average. You literally get a sack of them. Enough to share with 3 - 5 people. 

3. Burgers are always JUICY. I don't know where the beef comes from, and frankly I don't care if it was frozen first or flown half way 'round the world before I ordered it. When I get a hankering for a hamburger, I really want it to be juicy. 5 guys always delivers.

4. No waiters. Sorry people who wait tables -- sometimes I just want to pay for delicious food and put it in my mouth without interacting with strangers more than necessary! 

Prices higher than typical fast-food joints but nothing crazy.
good place to pick up some booze or snacks at ok prices(for the Quarter) you can also find boudin, andouille and tasso here to bring home with you.
