Obsessed with this place. Haven't actually been there but after living in South Jersey for over a year we struggled with finding a reliable place with not just good pizza but good food across the board. This is now our go-to place for pizza and everything else on the menu.
The food was really good. The sauce on my shrimp & crab legs were perfect. It wasn't too salty but sweet. If you here try the bayou rolls.

I must have drove past this place a million times when going to South Philly.  We decided to stop in for dinner before our Wells Fargo show.  

There is plenty of parking.  The inside looks recently upgraded.  Very nicely decorated. 

Plenty of mouth watering desserts at the front entrance.   

We were given a basket of tasty bread. The cornbread was made on site and we are every crumb. So yummy


Hubby had the crab imperial.  It was a Portobello mushroom stuffed with real crabmeat.  It had a side of baked potato and asparagus.  He also had seafood soup which I ate and loved.

I ordered a salad which had chicken, strawberries, cranberries, lettuce, blue cheese and topped with a vinaigrette dressing. 

We definitely had large portions.  We took half our food home.

For dessert hubby tried the bread pudding.  He never had it and LOVED It.    I had the chocolate pudding and scrapped the bowl.

The waitress was really nice and helpful (which I remembered her name).  She made us feel like her only table.  

What a pleasant surprised.  This place is great and I will definitely be back. :)

The Peppermill is always so much fun! I have find memories of the Peppermill restaurant in San Jose, CA. My family would go on weekends and I have never forgotten the mystical ambiance and the rainbow sugar. 

Well now I have finally made it to the Peppermill, RENV,  woohoo! I woke up and had a hankering for something delicious and light since I have an entire spa day ahead of me and need to be in a bikini. So! Oceano! It was a quick trek from the Tuscan Tower Suites. I arrived and was blown away by the vibrant Ocean decor! Jellyfish chandeliers, dimly lit lighting, reflective ceilings that remind you of bubbles and waves as if you're looking up from the ocean floor. Great whites, giant turtles. It's an underwater fairytale.

The wine selection is nice too. I had the Whitehaven Sauv Blanc. They also offer a Pinot Gri though the Sauv was very crisp and refreshing. There wasn't an over bearing sweetness. 

Now the sushi. The Nigiri is better than the rolls of you are doing the buffet. The buffet isn't super fancy, but it's fun. They offer more elegant choices aside from the saucy Americanized rolls which is the bulk of what makes the buffet. 

I had good service and for all you can eat sushi for 18.99 Uhhh, ya can't beat it. If your taste is more sophisticated I wouldn't completely recommend the buffet, rather the standard menu.

Service was also exceptional!

This is my favorite meal option at the Hyatt. They have really great people working- positive, friendly, efficient, and attentive. I appreciated the express lunch for $9.95- what a great deal. You can go serve yourself soup (I LOVED the tomato bisque!!!) and they have rolls and butter as well as a small salad bar and dressings that are included with the express lunch. Then you get half a sandwich and they bring that to your table. My husband and I both had the egg salad sandwich which was pretty good. A soda is also included with your meal. I think the unlimited soup and salad is worth the $9.95 on its own!

I went back tonight to order a bowl of chicken noodle soup to take to eat in my room and it is a huge container of hot soup with a lot of curly noodles, big pieces of grilled chicken, green onions, carrots, celery, a few matzo balls (I think- I didn't really like them that much) and these big "kreplach" which are like dough balls with meat in them (I don't think it was chicken but those were tasty once I realized there was something inside) in a nice and hot broth. It was $10 for a bowl but I understand why- it's a big portion and a hearty soup- very good. I appreciated that they had me go sit in a big cushy chair in the bar/lounge area while I waited for my soup to be ready to go, and even offered me a glass of water. I wasn't given a soup spoon to go- just regular utensils with a regular size spoon but that's a small thing. It was nice that they didn't give plastic utensils but real silverware and cloth napkins. 

Overall, this is where I recommend at the Hyatt- relatively affordable, very good food, friendly service.

Found it on Yelp (because you do NOT eat sushi in a new city without reading anything), and have to agree: this is solidly four stars.  The sushi is slightly overpriced (compared to the West Coast anyway) but fresher than I expected, and the presentation is really superb.

Damn those charbroiled oysters are to die for. Don't just go for the half dozen like we did... we actually ordered another half AFTER our meal because they were so good. I had the shrimp and grits and they were fabulous! I deducted one star because of the service. Our server wasn't very personable. He didn't really have any dishes to recommend and couldn't explain the dishes to us.

How have I not eaten here before?  Stopped in last minute with some friends and had a wonderful lunch at M3.  Loved all of the browns and the atmosphere, made me feel very welcomed and comfortable.

Our server was fast, friendly and helpful!  I loved loved the menu! As a person who watches carbs I really appreciated the low carb menu options.  I went with the Atkins flank steak option that came with 2 sides.  The steak was tender and cooked perfectly.  

Add the atmosphere, friendly service, great food and friends.....perfect place to grab a quick lunch!

After seeing a very good performance at the Rep, the D's and T's made it back to Brio for dinner with a bottle of a very good 2000 Toscano Alte d'Altesi.  It is worth noting that Brio does not charge corkage for the first bottle.  The glasses were acceptable.  Our server does need a little work on his cork removal skills.  This is not the first that we have had recently who broke the cork when the cork was in good condition.  They need to learn to be gentle with them until they start to move.

Ms T and Ms D had a Tomato Caprese salad that they both liked although the tomatoes were clearly showing that they were out of season and they were stingy with the balsamic.  The portion was very good and they were not stingy with the fresh mozzarella.  Mr D had the Tomato Bisque and I had the Lobster Bisque.  Both were very good.  The lobster version was well flavored and rich, with bits of lobster meat.  I felt it may have been a little over thickened with a roux or another starch, giving it a bit of a slimy texture, but it was not a serious issue.

Ms D ordered Veal Marsala and , Mr D had Veal Milanese.  Both were well presented and received solid reviews.  The marsala version was a classic style with mushrooms and Fettuccine Alfredo on the side. The Veal Milanese was topped with cherry tomatoes and white wine caper sauce and had roasted potatoes on the side. 

Ms T chose the Lobster and Shrimp Fettuccine and I was able to snag a spool of the pasta and can say that it was very nicely sauced.  The sauce was billed as "spicy lobster" and it was nice to feel a little heat from what was probably cayenne.  There were flakes of crushed red chile apparent in the dish.  The pasta was properly cooked, there was plenty of seafood and the right amount of sauce.  By that I mean it was not drowned.  Half of this came home with us.

I agonized over the beef, chicken and veal dishes and then veered off course and chose lasagna Bolognese.  I love lasagna and this is as good as I have had in a restaurant.  The flavors were elegant and well developed.  Everything was balanced.  In particular it was not covered with an inch of Bechamel, even better, there was none!  The texture was tender, there was plenty of very finely ground veal in the meat sauce plus sauce Alfredo and mozzarella.  I enjoyed a taste of fennel seed in the meat sauce.  The whole thing went very well with the wine.  It was a huge serving and I also brought more than half home.  

I was not sure what to expect from Brio, given that it is part of a giant chain, but we had a very good experience.  Many people complain about the prices, but I did not find it to be out of line.  Four dinners with soup or salad, wine corkage, coffee and ample servings for about $32 per person is not overpriced.  Also consider that Ms T and I made four nice meals from this.  The only negative aside from the missing corkage skills, was that the place is very noisy.  So while I prefer to go to the one-off places, I could certainly see us going back based on this experience.

I had a date and he suggested Brio. We wanted to sit outside for dinner and we both wanted wine. Goal achieved. It was alittle bit of a wait for a table, so we grabbed a nice glass of wine at the bar. Our bartender Bailey, was very knowledge and quick to serve us. I had the Moscato he had the Red Zinfandel, both excellent choices, because we had more than one glass each. 

Once we were seated on the patio, our server Seth was quick to greet us with water and menus. The menu was not overwhelming, I had the chicken with faro, and vegetables. He had the shrimp with faro and vegetables. They looked like the same dish when they arrived, and sadly Seth was not sure what faro was. For those of you that don't know, it is similar to rice. Dinner took a little longer than we thought it should, but we did have the wine and nice conversation. 

Next was desert, they had 5 options to pick from. We both selected the crème brulee, it was just the perfect ending to the meal.

Salty, ill prepared crap. I ordered the legendary pork sandwich end it was in fact legendary - legendary as in one of the worst salt sandwiches I have ever had. On top of that I ordered broccoli Rabe. It had so little broccoli Rabe that it was not even visible. I've seen more parsley on potato salad. The french fries were cold mushy it tasted like frozen turd.

It was so bad I made the trip back and returned the entire meal. That is when the manager kicked in as well as the grill team. They accepted responsibility and made me a new sandwich.

I have eaten enough meals to know when it is corporates fault and not those on the ground. The food was not fresh and the recipe is overly salty. 

Cold fries is on the staff. They are a rare treat and should be served hot an crisp. I eat oatmeal in the morning. 


The second sandwich was just as bad. It's the ingredients - terrible.
The fries were hot and crispy this time but again way to salty. 

Note to Tony Luke - you can add salt, you can't take it off. Also  the broccoli rabe was tasteless and mushy. You got an extra star for the staff and store manager. The food is crap.

Kermit's is a great addition to the neighborhood.  It could, however, certainly be greater.

I've tried a few of their offerings and, so far, the only thing I'd definitely get more of is the pizza.  They have different varieties of crispy, thin-crust pizzas for your nomming pleasure available by the slice.  A greater variety is available if you order a whole pie.

I've also tried their mushroom pocket, which I found too greasy.  Their coconut macaroon was pretty tasty, but seemed somehow too much.  The desserts generally look pretty good. They serve La Colombe coffee, which should be good (I haven't tried Kermit's version, so can't speak to it, but it's always great at La Colombe itself).

There is no seating inside, so if you're not taking your food to go (or getting it delivered), then you can stand around awkwardly eating your stuff.  Or step outside and take in the industrial landscape of Washington Ave. and 22nd.

Staff is generally friendly.  Prices are what you'd expect to pay somewhat closer to Rittenhouse.

This is hands down some of the best ice cream you will ever have. It is made fresh in shop and you can tell. The service is super friendly, however it is very efficient. The last time I was here there were only two young ladies working behind the counter. The line was so long it was practically out the door yet they kept it moving. The wait wasn't too long either, considering. This is our place to go when in need of ice cream in the New Orleans area!

Waited 30 minutes to get seated and I wouldn't say it was worth it. Started off with the fried pickles/peppers and the portion was very small. Also, the quality overall was just alright, there were so many duds in the batch (just pieces of fried breading with nothing in it)....and since the portion was so small, the duds were that more noticeable. I did like the thousand islands type dipping sauce it came with though. 

For the main attraction, I went with a classic burger. It was cooked to the right temperature but my boyfriend and I both thought the patties were pretty small. We were really hungry from walking around all morning, so almost ate it all but it most definitely wasn't anything special. I wouldn't wait for this place, very average all around

When someone told me this was the birthplace of frozen custard, I knew I HAD to try it out.  

I ordered the smores flavor...wouldn't go that route the next time.  The graham crackers got this weird, soggy, sticky-ish consistency.  The frozen custard itself, though, was delish!

-1 star for the price.  I thought it was pretty expensive for essentially ice cream.

This is a good option for Thai on the Mainline.  It's small, quaint, and offers a nice selection of tasty dishes.  I love the sauteed ginger flounder, which is a rich and delicious stew-like concoction.  The mussels appetizer is tender, well-spiced and very flavorful.  The curries can be made extremely spicy and the green curry, in particular, is excellent.  The pad thai is also very good.  Whenever I'm on the Mainline and in the mood for Thai, I come here.  It's small but offers much better cuisine than the chains in the area for a good price.  Our waitress was very pleasant and sweet.  Definitely recommend.  We also get take-out here quite often, and that has always been great.

We were nervous ordering BABY BACK RIBS (4/5) since BBQ isn't their specialty & surprised at how good it came out with the meat falling off the bones & coated in a sweet sauce with a pinch of spice. For only $4 more, a full rack can be yours, too! Usually, we get their FISH & CHIPS (4/5), which is a good sized fillet and even better chased down with a beer! We added a HOUSE SALAD (4/5) that was lightly dressed & came with cucumbers & tomatoes.

CHEESE & ALE DIP (5/5) was probably the best cheese dip I've ever had (No exaggeration!) and I don't usually gravitate towards any type of cheese dips, buttt it was a good amount to share with friends (sooo cheesey good!) and came with a lot of fresh bread to soak up all the deliciousness!

I've been here at least three times and ALWAYS sit outdoors to enjoy the beautiful weather. Sunday afternoon was hot, but started to cool down later on the evening. 

SERVICE (3/5) was spotty - didn't get refills on water, but I think that's 'cause there was only one waitress taking care of everyone. They have a lot of IPAs, Pale Ales & Sours with only one Porter/Stout, sooo disappointed they had just that one selection.

The attitude of the employees deserves a 4/5 for getting drinks out in an efficient manner, especially serving coffee at 7am, but my iced coffee was no bueno! I used to work early hours, can't imagine reverting back to it; It definitely requires a "can do" attitude, so I appreciate it a lot. I decided last minute that I wanted a shot of hazelnut syrup and went on merry way to work only to realize too late when I took a sip that it was all sugar (ugh!!). I have a sweet tooth, but this was way overboard, like she at least added 3 pumps of hazelnut syrup. I should've had a sip before leaving...it was 7am and I had an unusually early meeting, so I needed to get going (my mistake for not checking!), but once you add too much sugar, it's not redeemable! I was super disappointed and to top it off, being a klutz, proceeded to spilled it all over my car, not Dunkin's fault...that was not a good day. I do love hazelnut, so for a good part of the day my car smelled good! ;)

I'm not a Five Guys fan.  I'm just not.  It's not you, it's me.  My husband, however, is a big fan. 

It was his night to pick dinner and he picked Five Guys.  This was our second visit to this location and our first w/ DoorDash. 

The order arrived hot, fresh, and fast.  

Here's why I'm going four stars.  Hear me out.  My burger patty was delicious.  Like, I'm not even sure it came from a Five Guys delicious.  It was well seasoned and well cooked.  Seared with crispy edges and a tender center that was just perfection.  No other Five Guys in the surrounding area has been able to do this. 

The jalapeños on top were grassy and fresh.  

Four stars from someone who, generally, is not impressed by this burger chain.

Flying solo for day two and having seen more than enough of the French Quarter, I decided to treat myself to a swamp tour.  I called a day ahead to see that the tour I wanted was available, then booked online (online reservations are discounted), then called back to confirm that my desired time was approved (you can't actually reserve a specific time online which adds a seemingly unnecessary step, but oh well).  

Sunday morning and a cold front whipped through NOLA overnight.  I piled on all the layers I could find in my suitcase thus earning my bf's new nickname for me: Southern Hobo.  I'd arranged for an 8:30am pick-up from my hotel and the bus arrived at 8:45.  It's about a 45 minute drive from the Quarter to the swamp just on the north end of the lake, and our bus driver chimed in with some narration here and there and otherwise let us jam out to some good tunes (U2, the Beatles, etc).  

It being an uncharacteristically cool morning there was not a lot of action on the swamp.  Captain Rob certainly kept us entertained with interesting facts and witty jokes, and he took us out much farther than usual in search of alligators and snakes.  We did see a few as the sun began to peek out from the clouds, and a couple were tempted over by marshmallows and hotdogs.  I'd hoped for more bird commentary to fill in the gaps, but the gentleman next to me and I had our own little avian nerd-out at the back of the boat.  We were on the swamp about two (freezing) hours, so water and a snack were a good idea for me.  Definitely bring water on a hot day; you'll need it!

After some shopping, we headed out to find something to eat. My nephew suggest the Big Cheezy. Driving into their small parking lot which were empty should be a sign for me to just find another eating options but my nephew really wanted to eat there. Walking in should also be a sign for me to leave. My nephew is autistic so once he decided on something, there's no changing his mind. The place looks really gloomy. It took them awhile before taking my orders because they were changing shift and busy counting the cash register. I got the Crawgator which are alligator and crawfish sausage with cheddar and pepper jack, carameltized onions and grilled green peppers on sourdough. The sausage was good but the sourdough bread taste stale. I did order a side waffle fries which was great, I mean no one can actually messed that up right?  My nephew decided on the Pizza Mac. Tomato basil sauce with mozzarella cheese and pepperoni and a side order of tomato basil soup. Nephew usually kills his food but he only ate the pepperoni and some of the pasta. I taste some of his soup. It was ok. Don't think I would come back or recommend this place.

I don't even know the words I need to describe the food we had here. 
We stopped in and grabbed a spot at the bar since we had no reservations and were really just looking for a couple small plates to split on our slow bar crawl down Frenchman Street.
The Beer-Braised Kurobuta Pork Belly is the greatest food item in America. I'd sign that statement in my own blood. The juiciest, smokiest, most delicious pork belly is with a light amount of sauce on a little pancake. Don't you dare split this dish with more than 2 people. In fact, don't share it at all. 
The Bacon-Wrapped Bleu Cheese Stuffed Dates were also very very good. I love dates and these hit the spot. I'd honestly rave about them more, but when paired with the pork belly, it's hard to give them the credit they would get if they had to stand on their own.
And finally the Seared Scallops on tabbouleh sauce, ginger-lemon raita. The best scallops I had in the city. These were $14 and I paid $31 for the same amount of scallops as an entree in another location.. so not only were they better here.. they were a dang steal.
Cocktails were great as well, but did I mention the pork belly? This place is a must-do in NOLA. Bar seating was comfy and we still got to enjoy the live band. Will be back!

This place is fantastic!  We came for dinner with the family for our daughter's birthday because of all the great vegan options on the menudo her.  This was our first time to this neighborhood and to this restaurant and we already can't wait to come back.  The area is great and there's lots of cool restaurants and shops and parking was no problem either.  It reminded us of Hoboken.  Anyway, we were greeted at the door with a smile and immediately seated.  We immediately loved the atmosphere of the place with a real old time feel coupled with western touches and a band playing upstairs.  The waiter came over and told us it was happy hour so we ordered the $5 old fashioned (awesome) and it was $1 off all drafts and there were so many great beers to choose from.  I couldn't decide on a beer so the waiter said he would be right back and he came back with a bunch of samples for me to try.  Wow!  The menu here is so great we wanted to order everything! And you can get a vegan version of almost everything on it too.  So we decided on buffalo vegan wings (there were also great sauce choices but we settled on the buffalo).  The wings were incredible!  Then we got the vegan junkyard fries which also blew us away as did the amazing vegan nachos.  My daughter ordered the vegan chicken parm over penne and this was so light and crispy with a killer spicy marinara sauce worthy of a top Italian restaurant!  My other daughter got the vegan chicken and waffles.  Everything was so good we were just speechless.  The service was the icing on the cake as our server was so personable and attentive and took our orders without writing a thing down and got everything just right.  We can't wait to come back.  This place is truly one of a kind!

Indian take out is one of my guilty pleasures and this place is going to be a new one in the rotation. I ordered takeout online from kababacue and we ended up there about 10 minutes later. I was greeted happily and my food is ready minutes after I arrived. I ordered a spicy curry with vegetables and to go. I got busy and was not able to enjoy it until a couple hours later, but it was still fantastic! It was pretty spicy and a massive portion! I wish there had been less rice and more vegetables, but that is a small critique. Definitely worth a try if you want some Indian food in the university area.

I'm fortunate to live in walking distance of this awesome market so I'm literally stopping in for one thing or another several times a week. I've yet to have a bad experience here. The staff is extremely friendly and helpful - which has not been my particular experience at the store on Tchop. I would say it rivals the customer service found at Whole Foods. 

The produce section is a bit small, but does carry most of the things I want. I like that they offer herbs that are grown on the roof top of the building. The vino selection is incredible and they regularly host wine tastings. The wine connoisseurs are very approachable and have given me great suggestions on $12 table wine for dinner.

The made-to-order sandwiches are like $8, HUGE and they do not skimp on the meats and cheese. Great bang for your buck! The "Asian soup" is akin to pho and has been hit or miss for me personally.

Lastly, I love the tables littered outside on the sidewalk. With fall weather approaching, it makes for a convenient people watching spot.

Last night I flew in and took my buddy and his family to dinner for watching my house.  Originally we were going to eat down the street but the kids are picky eaters.  So we popped in here and took a bee line to the stairs where we were seated in front of a huge projection tv (over 80'!!!)  To start I ordered a beer and a dozen char grilled oysters (**** stars) they were delicious and had a hint of parmesan on them that made them taste SOOOO good.  For my meal I ordered the muffleatta (***1/2 stars) it was HUGE and tasty but had a little too much olive oil drenching the light and toasty bread for my taste.

I gave the fries to my buddy's daughter and had a order of pepper onion rings (**** stars) light, crispy and well seasoned is all I can say about that one.   This this place is touristy. so you can expect to pay a premium on the food.  But you get large servings and will definitely leave full and with a doggie bag.

After reading the many positive reviews, I was anxious to try this place out.   Although I was prepared for takeout on this visit, I was surprised that it is ONLY takeout.   This is one of my pet peeves about Yelp i.e. That  this is not clear in the survey questions.  But I digress....

Everything from here was tasty.   The baguette is good but not as good as others available around the city.  It is pleasantly chewy but very dense.   I would rate it 4 stars.   Croissants were great and large 4.5 stars, and available in ham and cheese, chocolate, and plain.   I also sampled a variety of pastries - key lime, lemon, cheesecake square, and coconut. All strong 4s.

Coffee is also available for takeout but they also had Vietnamese iced coffee ready for takeout!   Yum! 5 stars and a great surprise on a summer day.    Parking can be challenging.  Service is great.

BETTER than Cafe du Monde!!!

Less crowded (at 8am my mom and I were the only ones enjoying the patio, but really, who is out on Bourbon at 8am besides the beer trucks and street washers?  Me and my mom!) better tasting.

The beignets here are made.to.order.  We went to Cafe du Monde once and it was obvious they had been sitting.  These came hot and fresh.

The cafe au lait is also made.to.order.  Again, hot and fresh.

A great alternative to Cafe du Monde.  Scratch, a great "instead of" Cafe du Monde!

I was there last night, & Oh My! Can I say? This place was PACKED. They have a great selection of frozen custards. Although it was super busy, I was pretty impressed by how fast and efficient they were. I definitely recommend coming here if u just want some nice cold sweets. There's also bathrooms on the side of their building.
It's your basic urban Walgreens in New Orleans, this particular Walgreens was new after Katrina, so its in good shape. Clean and well organized.

This is a dive of all dives. No sign on the outside - look for the Erin Rose bar. Push aside plastic doorway guards, shimmy past the bar and squeeze into what is likely an overcrowded tiny room. That room is Killer Poboys. It's cash only, small menu, tight seating and tasty eats. I loved my Gulf Shrimp Poboy. It comes with grilled, not fried, shrimp and is lightly dressed.  A giant squeeze bottle of Fancy's Hot Sauce sits by the register for you to dose your sandwich if you're one who likes it hot. (By the way, I am do.)

I'm so glad I persevered to find Killer Poboys and can't wait to come back and try another tasty - and filling - poboy from their menu!

A++++++++++++++++++++++ flavor. We ordered the Cajun Classic bucket with BOIL House flavor, extra high heat, and split it between a party of two. This particular combo could easily be demolished by one person but we didn't want to get too full before our dinner at Luvi that night, so we settled for having this as our "appetizer." #WINNING

I was so sad when we exhausted our supply of shrimp and crawfish. I could easily have eaten more but we had dinner plans elsewhere so I just sat there amidst a sad pile of crawfish and shrimp peels. It was SO GOOD that DH and I tried to count all of the places we've had crawfish so far: NorCal, SoCal, Vegas, Chicago, Chicagoland, Dallas, Atlanta, Middle Georgia, multiple places in Florida that I can't remember, and last, but not least, NEW ORLEANS! BOIL definitely ranks in the top three. The flavor was spicy, savory, and garlicky with a hint of smokiness. 

Extra high heat was not as high as I'd expected. On my personal scale, it was more of a 3.75 out of 5. Bdub's Mango Habanero inflicts way more pain than this one did but it was still a good sauce. One major disappointment was the size of the crawfish. They were SO PUNY! The shrimp were a nice size however. I would have preferred more sauce to dip all of my peeled seafood in but the pickin's were slim in that shallow platter. 

This is another joint I'll definitely be revisiting on my follow-up trip!

My first day in New Orleans landed me in the French Quarter. I looked across the street and noticed Cajun Encounters. When I am in an unfamiliar city, I tend to take a tour.

I got helpful suggestions on what tours were available. I did a city tour and a swamp tour. I did the city tour immediately. The helpful gentleman suggested that I grab a drink or snacks a few stores down. He indicated that by the time I got back, the bus would be there.

Sure enough, after getting an individually wrapped s'mores snack and a bottled water, the bus was here. I boarded and showed him my ticket.

It was extremely humid during my entire trip. I welcomed being in an air-conditioned bus. It was comfy and allowed me to take great photos of the city.

The tour consisted of showing more of the French Quarter. There were also stops at the St. Louis Cemetery (it's gorgeous for a cemetery) and Morning Call for some beignets. Our tour guide was knowledgeable and had a terrific sense of humour.

It was sad to see all the abandoned houses after hurricane Katrina. Folks picked up and left for good. We also saw the downtown area and the contrast in building architecture. New Orleans has recovered nicely since that hurricane hit.

Two days later, I did the swamp tour. The bus picked us in front of the Cajun Adventures store and drove us over to the swamp area to catch a boat.

It was pretty humid being on the boat. Luckily, the boat had a flat roof, which helped. I saw a lot of animals, including wild boar, raccoons, and alligators.

It was odd seeing alligators eating hot dogs and large marshmallows. I guess that they are been conditions to eat those items. I got great shots of them swimming and eating. I loved this tour!

If you buy two or more tours, you do save a bit of money. There was also a plantations tour. Perhaps I'll give that a try the next time I visit the city.

I recommend going on these tours. You have plenty of fond memories visiting New Orleans.

(58)

OK, the food is very reasonable in price and fair to middlin' in taste and quality.  The menu includes some nice home-style Italian faves.  It's the type of place you grab a bottle from your wine rack at home, jump in the car, and go enjoy an impromptu night at this Mom and Pop operation.

Pop is in the kitchen throwing together mass quantities of food and Mom is out among the Friday night half-filled restaurant looking like she is hating every minute being there.   Her miserable puss exudes a bad vibe throughout the restaurant.

One time I was there,  Mom was having a shouting match with one of the servers in front of the customers, to which the server exited on the spot.  It was a most uncomfortable evening.  So I waited awhile to go back.  

The Shrimp Fra Diavolo grabbed my attention and the nice spice hit the spot.  Dinner Rolls buried in garlic and oil are just leaving my taste buds 3 days later...overkill there.  The salad which was included might as well not be... iceberg lettuce and a dab of Italian dressing sitting in a tiny puddle in the middle of the salad doesn't do it for me.

Service is OK.  The girls are working their butts off.  I guess they don't want to face the wrath of Mom.

While I was very sad to learn that the previous establishment at this location was gone, it is nice to have another Indian restaurant give the northwest side a try after a few others have moved on.   

I always stick to the basics when visiting a new Indian restaurant for the first time and so went with the palak paneer with mild-medium spice.   It was very good; the paneer was fresh and the spices nicely balanced.  The spice level was consistent with what I would call mild-medium, meaning, there was noticeable spice, but it wasn't hot (no sweating or runny nose).  I also tried some of my friend's dish which was an eggplant selection and it was delicious!  I'll definitely order that on a future visit.  We shared some garlic naan which was fresh and flavorful.   

Service was great, everyone was very friendly, and clearly took pride in making high-quality food.  They didn't seem to mind that we spent kind of a long time occupying a table visiting after we were done with our meal (there was no one waiting, and still some tables open, I promise!)  

I'm looking forward to my next visit!

I used to eat at the very first Chipotle back in Denver when it first opened. It was so popular it became a chain VERY quickly. I was really kindof shocked to see it everywhere all the way down here in Florida.

There is a reason it is so popular. The food is AMAZING. The meats are all 100% organic and all ingredients are of the utmost in quality. And 6.25 for a burrito the size of a nerf football, the price can't be beat!

This location should be 5 stars, but gets 4 for the parking nightmare involved in trying to eat there. Whoever designed this complex should be sent to Abu Ghraib and waterboarded with hot salsa. If you try and go during the lunch rush you will experience the scenario. It can be extremely frustrating.

Amazing, unique tasty food, though - which can be only said for a few chains.

We were out exploring the new pier and grab reservations at this new place.  We have tried the one down south on Captive and to be honest were not too impressed but we were there late right before closing.  Although I thought the food was pretty tasty.

This once seems to not be as pricey as the other.  Could be the other's location but whatever the reason this seemed a little better with the cost.  

The venue is really nice.  The back area is like being on the beach with views of bay and pier.  The breeze kept the temp bearable and we did not seem to have an issue with mosquitos.  

Although we had reservations the wait was still long and about 30 mins past our reservation.  Given covid restrictions we are giving a lot of slack on this.  Once we had our table out back we met our server who was very 'enthusiastic' but it was a looonnngg time between visits to our table.  Again this is a new place and covid so I really want to give them the benefit of the doubt.  

I was actually very please with both the cook and flavors of the food.  We split the tuna to start.  Tuna was nice and the slaw was very tasty.  I had the skirt steak salad and the steak was cooked perfect.  Deb had the shrimp tacos.  Cooked nice with a large portion.  She didn't realise it came with the rice n beans.  Would have swapped that out.  

Drinks are 'rumy' and sweet.  Decent selection of local brews and of course some good rums.  Try a flight!  

Overall the food was better than expectations and the wait times I am chalking up to covid and being new.

Bleh, skip it.

Atmosphere: On the busy Bourbon Street. Decided to come here for breakfast on our last day before heading back home. Outdoor seating, order at the front.

Food: I ordered the  Cajun Hashbrowns. I originally wasn't expecting much to begin with, but when the order came out it looked like something I make for myself at home (except my food would've looked better). Presentation was boring, food was bland, all for $9. My parents got omelettes and those were blah too. Nothing memorable at all.

My dad read somewhere that these beignets were a competitor of Cafe Du Monde's, so I figured we should try it. Once again, BLEH. Sure the beignets here are larger, but they were so damn heavy and I felt like I could taste raw dough. No bueno, especially  after the likes of Cafe Du Monde's light and fluffy goodness.

Service: Again, I wasn't expecting much. The guy who delivered our food did not shed one smile or word as he plopped our food down on the table. I was okay with that until I saw him literally toss down a plate of beignets in front of en elderly couple next to me. Powered sugar was everywhere. No thanks, douche.

Can you tell I'm not feeling this place? I hope you do. Try elsewhere.

I have to saymy first time at bare burger was more mediocre than great.Bonus points for the owner and staff who are all very friendly , that aside there were some hits and misses with my dinner here.

Arrived around 5:25 to meet a friend for dinner. We sat at the "bar" and soon realized there is not one boozy beverage option. I'm all for organic sodas and shakes but I like the option of a beer or mixed drink with my post work meals. I stuck to water and my friend opted for the blueberry soda. I sipped it , and it was a little sweet for my liking but he seemed to enjoy it.

The menu was explained to us by who I can only assume to be a more seasoned employee but sadly he walked away and our actual server though nice seemed to be very green. 

Ordering was a little painful , there is only one computer to input the information into so we had to verbally tell our order which was written down and then typed into the computer after the other employee was done.
We shared the rings and fries , def do this option you get 4 different sauces and a decent amount of fries and around 7 onion rings.

The rings were on point a pretty solid breading to onion ratio, I appreciated the extra sauce ( buttermilk ranch ) brought out by the owner and the favorites for us both were the habanero mayo, and smoke sauce which is basically BBQ. The ginger ketchup tasted like a tikka masla sauce missing the remaining spices. The fries left a little something to be desired. The first handful were crispy and well seasoned the middle layer not so much. They were limp ( luckily my dining companion likes them limp... The fries that is) so I ate the crispies and he had the limpies . 

I opted for the black bean burger after getting confirmation from the kitchen that it didn't contain any tomatoes or shrooms.
I requested two types of onions, lettuce and my pickles and jalepenos to be on the side( not a side).
My black bean burger was seasoned well but a little too dry. A huge jar of pickles came out on my tray ( apparently this is a the side of pickles not pickles on the side) I didn't think anything of it until the check came and I was charged 3.60 for the pickles. I questioned it with the server and based on the minimal responses it seemed he rang in my pickles incorrectly . Christian offered to pay for the pickles since he ate them ,  but I was annoyed none the less. I guess I was expecting a correction since the error wasn't mine but to not argue the point I just paid the check.

I appreciate the fresh, organic ingredients and friendly service/servers but there were equal amounts awesome and meh to this meal. 

I can't say I'll be back soon , maybe when they can serve booze and have been open a little longer to work out the kinks.

They offer a lunch special for 12.00 m-f 11-2 and if you follow them on social media you can get a free milkshake .



For right now 2.75 stars ( I don't think 2 is warranted but 3 is me being generous )

This trips Chinese food was a little disappointing - everywhere.  Duck in Lychee was awful, all fat and no meat.  Oyster with ginger and scallion hot pot was good, unusual, monster Oysters.  Prices were fine and service friendly.  The place was packed.

My friends and I decided to go to the BOIL Seafood House since we were craving crab legs! 

Upon walking in we were greeted by the host who we put our name down for a reservation. The host stated it could be a possible two hour wait in which we were willing to stay for. The host also stated that the bar area is first come first serve so we sat there and waited until our seats were available. 30 minutes passed and we see empty tables in which we're "reserved" way before us apparently so we decided to order our food while we waited. Another 30 minutes passed and the host stated there was 2-3 groups in front of us which was fine but the thing is there wasn't anyone waiting in the front; maybe they reserved online. 

Our food started arriving to the bar and we started to eat, at this point forget the table. The host did a really bad job at accommodating my group of 6. We all uncomfortably had to eat at the bar some of us standing up eating, etc. I just wish the host gave us updates instead of us constantly having to go to her. Now the bartender was AMAZING! He was super quick, funny and made sure we had everything we needed. 

This was my first time ordering crab legs so I was super excited and wanted the full on bib and butter experience! I ordered 1lb of snow crab legs with the boil house seasoning  which is 4 seasonings in one and then you pick the "heat" as well; I got medium. The crab legs do not come with any sides so I ordered the bang bang shrimp for $11 which was pretty tasty and a side of Cajun French fries (SO GOOD)! 

Overall the food was great! So my 3 stars go to the bartender and the food!

Stopped in for dinner. Very quiet place but it started to pick up as we left. It is way bigger on the inside than it looks. We got the med nachos and bbq shrimp to start
 The nachos were so unique and yummy. That was my favorite dish. The bbq shrimp was yummy but hard to eat. We almost lost a shrimp. We got the lemon rosemary shrimp and steak frites for dinner. They were good! Overall nice restaurant! Our server was super nice.

Go here if you want to say you went to the French Market but I can't think of any other reason you would want to waste you money here. The food was ok, the service was ok and the restaurant is a little run down.

Do yourself a favor and go some where else.

This location is new and you can tell. It took almost 30 minutes to go through the drive thru. The whole point of a drive thru is quick service. I'm not sure if the employees are not properly trained yet or this was simply an off night. I absolutely love Fazoli's and was excited that one was coming to Plant City. This was pretty disappointing.

This is a huge restaurant right on the water off the causeway.   Excellent risotto and grouper.

The views are amazing from the restaurant (there are huge windows facing the water so it doesn't really matter where you sit).

Another new discovery in 2014 and a fantastic fixture in our community! Semenza's has been in business since 1980, serving up delicious pizza and wings with ice cold beverages. The current owner, Pablo or J.P. as some call him, has been working here since 1994 and bought the business in 2008! I've been living 2 miles from this place for the 5+ years, driven past it more times than I could possibly count, and yet hadn't set foot in there until last night! 

I came in really late (9PM) and talked with Pablo, got the story, asked how the food was, and asked about their food. At first he joked that it was all mediocre, but you could tell he was proud of it. I told him I was a wing snob, and he modestly told me they were known for them and I was sure to like them. So on his suggestion, I ordered the "Small Special", 1lb of wings and a small 2 topping pizza, to try this place out. 

So how were the wings you ask? Fantastic! These rank in my top 3! Turns out Pablo used to work over at JOX, which serves up some of my favorites, so he knows what's up with wings. The wings were crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside. I ordered the Nitro BBQ, aka Nitro Nutty sauce at Legends,a favorite combo of mine, and these wings were covered in it the best way possible. You could see all the chiles in the sauce, and smell the intense vinegar and chile scented steam coming off of them. These wings rock!

Well what about the pizza right? It's a pizzeria after all. The best way to describe this is it combines all the characteristics of a good pie, in a way you've never had before. The crust is on the thinner side, but there's almost two layers to it. The top is chewy and doughy in all the right ways, but the bottom is cracker thin and crunchy! My pizza had jalapeno and bacon on it, and it was delicious. I've never had a crust like this though anywhere and I'll definitely be back for more. 

I'm so happy that I discovered Semenza's finally, met Pablo, and can proudly tell everyone about it. This is just another one of those Reno institutions that more people should visit. The food is worth the drive, and I can see it being a really fun place to crack some beers and kick it with friends.

I've eaten here half a dozen times. Most of the time at the bar. Service always good. Food great although some items overpriced. The pesto pasta dish is one of my favorites . I can't believe it's a light (600 cal) menu item. It's more than enough for two meals .

Finally made a trip to The Lime after a trip to the Container Store worked up my appetite. It's your usual walk-up Mexican restaurant...burritos, tacos, salads, etc.  Things that set it apart from Moe's or Chipotle

-An extensive salsa bar (10 selections including pineapple salsa)
-Mini ice cubes (yes, I notice these things)
-Soft corn tortillas (most places only have crispy)

The staff was very friendly and helpful. And, for it being lunch rush, and very busy, there were still plenty of seats.  I did like how with the soft corn tortillas, they doubled them up (they have a tendency to fall apart).  Queso was really good!  Atmosphere was a little loud for my preference. 

I'd definitely come here again, but probably wouldn't choose it over Chipotle.

I'm gonna have to disagree with most people including my Yelp friends (yikes!) and say that I really didn't care for this place. I came here with my boyfriend and a couple friends for dinner one night recently, and sadly we weren't impressed. I'm a big fan of Asian noodle soups, so I was really excited to try this place, too! 

I got the coconut curry noodle soup which sounded promising. The curry broth flavor was initially pretty good, but it was soon overpowered by the huge glob of peanut sauce they put in the bowl. In general, I like peanut sauce but I found the flavor combo really weird, and the peanut sauce was thick and jelly-like in texture, which I found gross. I ate about half of the soup and then gave up. My boyfriend and another friend ordered the brisket soup. Neither of them liked the dish again due to the "off" flavor. My other friend who ordered the hand torn soup did enjoy her meal, though. 

On to the drinks...I'm not a big fan of canned beer to begin with, but I figured I'd give a new one a try. They have several options, but I didn't find any standouts on the list. I  decided to go with the Brewers Art brown ale which I found to be super bitter. I wasn't excited about any of the other beer options, so I decided to stop there. One of my friends didn't like the beer she chose either.

Also, the place is quite small and only has a couple tables up front, so the four of us had to sit side by side at the bar. It was hard to have a conversation with the whole group because it was pretty loud in there. 

Overall, I was just disappointed because I've heard so many good things about Cheu. Given my experience, I probably won't be back. I will just have to stick to the more traditional Asian noodle soup places that I love!

Thank you Yelp! This place is one awesome find!! Awesome creative tasty flavored ice cream! It's the Heladeria in Lares, Puerto Rico only this time it's in Louisiana. 

If you're like me, and can't decide on just one or two or three flavors and know that it'll be a long time before you ever get to visit a place like this: get the 6-MINI SCOOP SAMPLER for $5.50 it's an awesome value! All the flavors I had were delicious. Highly recommend all of them. 

MEXICAN HOT CHOCOLATE
LAVENDER HONEY
GREEN FAIRY (absinthe ice cream with dark chocolate chunks and candied orange peel)
DOBERGE CAKE
CAFE AU LAIT
PETIT FOURS (almond flavored)

This place totally made my day. Screw the snowballs and froyo in this city.  Come here.

My single favorite place to eat. I think they put some thing addictive in their food because it's the only thing I constantly crave. Pig tails are unbelievable. To think I didn't even want to try them. Wings I've managed to duplicate at home but I still order them. Matzo ball brisket Ramen with extra noodles that the last meal I ever want to have. I like sitting at the bar. Cleanest kitchen ever and Ben the chef is a machine. I love watching him work. Try their new restaurant it's wonderful too.

I tried the strawberry custard with hot fudge and it was very good. I would definitely recommend getting a solid topping instead of a hot liquid, because it melts the custard very fast, turning it soupy.
The second time around, I got the vanilla custard with peanut butter and waffle cone bits. I definitely prefer the vanilla custard as a base.
The lines moves fast so don't be intimidated if the place is crowded. I felt like a true local, coming here and enjoying custard on a hot summer day.

Delicious burgers with great flavors and super fast delivery. I usually order on caviar and it arrives within 30 minutes still hot! Love the buffalo chicken sandwich as well- not too spicy and great flavors. Gotta love a burger done right!

+ great wings
- slow service, no wifi

This is the original Hooters.  It's nice inside, with updated decor.  Lots of booths, and super friendly waitresses.  I was disappointed they did not offer free wifi.

Bar is very open and loud, so be prepared for a not so quiet meal.  But it is Hooters, so you really can't complain.

Cleanliness was good, both up front in the dining area, and the men's room.

Egg roll was good.

Fried rice was excellent, with bits of scrambled egg.

Vegetables were excellent, crisp, like I like them.

Chicken was undercooked, and soggy/chewy.  I should have taken it back.  The white sauce in my dish was good, not too salty.

I really like this park. It has a sweet view and hosts lots of great events like food truck rallies and Rock the Park. I always try to stop by for a stroll if I'm hanging out downtown. The only thing is that it seems so empty at night I constantly wonder if I've missed the zombie apocalypse or something. I wonder why more folks don't use it. I've never found it to be unsafe at night. I'm looking forward to going to the mayor's mac and cheese event!

Charbroiled Oysters = buttery, parmesian-y goodness that has probably upped my heart attack age about 5 years!  

Everyone says to come here in NOLA, but I had NO IDEA it was going to be one of the best things I eat on the entire trip!  We went to Acme Oyster House the day before, and lets just say that Drago's trumps Acme's dinky little barely-recognizable shriveled oysters to the ground.  If you're ever in NOLA, you gotta try this!!!

It's not 5 stars though, only because I feel like all the butter, garlic, and parm kind of covers up the seafood taste of a fresh oyster, which I really enjoy.  The succulent texture is still there in Drago's charbroilled version, but if you think about it... you could slather butter, cheese, pepper, garlic and herbs onto a stick of cardboard and it would probably sell like hotcakes!

We had some of their regular oysters too, which were just as outstanding!!! YUM TRY IT!

The food was extremely fresh. Getting there 20 minutes after opening-time was a good idea! Well, not to say it wouldn't be fresh otherwise, but...yeah. It was our first time here. Lunch buffet, FYI.

The outside is very unassuming. The inside...beautiful lighting. Very clean. Very polite staff. 

My most favorite, FAVORITE thing from Indian restaurants is lamb saag. Followed closely by saag paneer. Hey, I just freaking love saag. This place had saag, but in the form of chana saag, which I haven't had before, but thoroughly enjoyed. The cauliflower pakora was amazing. Not too fried or greasy. The chicken masala was pretty outstanding. Huge chunks of chicken in an amazing sauce. 

They give you a choice of regular or garlic naan. This thrilled me. The naan took a moment to bring out because it was obviously being made fresh. It was SO good.

Minus one star for beef curry. The meat was tough, the sauce was pretty flavorless as far as curry goes, and only really tasted like...meat.  And additionally...beef curry? I won't say any more.

I also love tamarind chutney and this place does it right! I'm also very used to Indian places having firni as a dessert, but this one had 'fruit creme' which was pretty darn good. It was some sort of mango creme with different little chunks of fruit in it. By the time I finished my tiny bowl, it really reminded me of melted ice cream. It was good, though!

If I go to Reno again, I think I will want to come here again, but I REALLY hope they have a lamb dish next time.

This location has undergone some pretty major expansion and renovation changes in recent times... and this was much needed as it used to be FAR TOO BUSY for my liking on a regular basis. Now, I still think it'll get pretty darn busy on occasion but it's now perhaps Remedy's largest location in town. And the seating is colourful, the walls have fun patron contributed art, and there are numerous seating options both indoors and outdoors. 

My favourite beverage at ANY Remedy location is always the Kashmir chai, but I do love some of the other chai options (and I've yet to try them all at this point to be honest!). I do like the food that they provide: it is ample and there are numerous options. I'm probably most likely to visit here just for a beverage, but I do really love the chana masala wrap for example.

Place was legit with a menu that was pretty diverse. We loved the grilled oysters and fried crab claws. The sirloin steakwas actually pretty good for what it was! If we ever around again, we're coming back.

Best hotel restaurant food I can recall.   Located in the Hilton Gardens off O'Brien just south of the Airport.  Went there after trying some samples at the Dine Tampa Bay kick-off.....and wanting to have more from their $25 three course special menu.

There were 3 options in each category, so we shared great beef satay and generous fried calamari apps, good salmon with rich salad as well as tender filet with mashed taters, followed by bourbon bread pudding and chocolate mousse that we intended to take home but somehow consumed before boxing.  The portions were perfect, so we left satisfied without stuffing.  Nice upscale touches such as a fine corn/avocado relish with the satays, great calamari toppings, and a cinnamon-shaker outline of a fork on the dessert plate. Service by Catrina  was unusually attentive and skillful as we arrived early and had nearly her entire attention.

We also checked out the regular menu that offered other items of interest, and a good beer/wine list.  Prices on some items are a bit high, but not for hotel food. And the $25 special was a real deal.  We may get back again to sample more.  This is a fine illustration of the usefulness of Dine Tampa Bay....esp. in the Summer doldrums before the Elephants arrive.

Send To A Friend   Link to t

My fellow conference-goers saw the sign for all-you-can-eat crabs and that made them want to come here. Then we got here and they ordered something else anyway. D'oh!

My po' boy wasn't the best I've had. And they forgot the remoulade that comes with it, and I had to ask twice for it. And they forgot my companion's drink. And my other companion's silverware. And they never brought my water.

The food was okay, but the service tonight was a mess. Probably the worst I had all week in N'orleans. Just disorganized and scattered. I even got charged full price for the onion rings that she forgot I ordered until later, put in late, and got after every course was already finished.

I would said this restaurant is unique in many ways. The cuisine, the setting of the restaurant, the attention of owner make the place great to eat. There are gluten free item and grass feed beef as their advertisements of the material of the food. 

I like to mention a little about their sound system. It is front row seat to the concert. The restaurant invest a very good sound system that is pleasure to the ear. They also hide their speaker very well. Imagine they play the Star Wars music. May the force be with you. 

We have order the taste of the islands and the blacken mango salmon. The taste of the island include curry goat, Ox tail and jerk chicken. The goat is a bit heavy smell. The jerk chicken is great with the seasoning they have. The best is the Ox Tail. The Ox tail with Caribbean spice make this dish special.

The blacken salmon is prepare with Caribbean blacken spice. It is very nice. It serves over cook pineapple sauce. The fish is tasty. This dish accompanied with a side salad. The desert we have is the coconut cake. The coconut cake has layers of coconut cream. It is guilty pleasure. 

The greeting of the owner from the restaurant make this place special. The decorations is modern and it is gear up for upper class power lunch or dinner. Nice touch. Service is great and the cook is the owner wife. It is family run with attention to the details.

I have to go here every time I am in St. Louis.  My favorite is the Dutchmen's Delight.  It's custard with hot fudge, caramel sauce, whipped cream, almonds and butterscotch.  Yummy!

This used to be a tiny shack in the middle of a parking lot.  Now it's a medium size shack in a parking lot.  No restroom, but there is water on the side of the building if you need a drink.

There's plenty to choose from on the menu - many kinds of custard, sundaes, banana splits, etc.  The line gets long after a ball game or on a hot summer night, but they move VERY quickly to get your order.  If you want to get it to go and have to drive awhile, they wil give you dry ice.

It was almost midnight on a Tuesday and we had just returned home from a full 13 hour day of traveling; we were hungry and tired. Instead of opting to go to a sit down place we decided to drive thru Steak n Shake. It had been forever since we had been to one so looking at the menu was something we had to do. I was hoping to get a chicken melt, but I didn't see that on the menu. Instead, they had a grilled chicken sandwich and that seemed to be the only chicken sandwich I saw, so I ordered it. My husband just wanted to order a burger with fries. There was a car in front of us so we didn't think much of it. We placed our order and were told to pull around to the window to pay. The car in front of us was still waiting so that's exactly what we did too. It took about 10 minutes for the car in front of us to get their meal and then we pulled up to pay. Once we paid we waited for about 6-7 minutes before our food was ready. I guess it's a good thing they cook our food to order, but that was a long time to wait IMO. We were handed our bag (we double checked it for accuracy) with drinks and were on our way.

So I'm still at a 4 stars, but as I'm trying different meals, I find that the panang is not doing it for me.  And I've had the larb gai every time I've been here and the cabbage wedges keep getting smaller and smaller - this last time they were cabbage strips.  I may be wrong but I thought you put a spoonful of the larb on the cabbage wedge and eat it.

I'm going to stick with the red curry and try some other items and find my favorite thing here.  I like the larb gai a lot, but would love it if the cabbage strips turned back into wedges.  :)

And I learned tonite that they will be modifying their menu (taking off most of the American stuff, like burgers and adding more Thai stuff) and best of all, they are looking into adding delivery!  YAY!

A gem in hiding, if you ask me.  I have always loved whole foods and shop here regularly.  I had stopped into the taproom a couple of times for a beer with the hubby (while rewarding him for shopping with me), but it wasn't until recently that I learned the real secret of the Tap Room.  

Are you ready?  They have an amazing menu of bar food (including raw bar food) for extremely reasonable prices, and the best part is - it is all food from whole foods so you know it is high quality and as fresh as it gets!  We have had their fresh ground burgers, oysters, fresh cut fries, organic chicken wings, etc.  They even have happy hour deals with flights of wine and $5 (yes, $5!!) cheese plates which look incredible!  Don't miss a beat - and run, yes run, to the WF Tap Room!

This was our second stop while in NOLA and I'd highly recommend heading here if you're looking for a casual lunch or dinner spot. It'd also be great if you're looking for somewhere to catch a game as they're are a few TVs around. 

Our waitress warned us that the entrees are very large and I wasn't that hungry so I split the fried catfish po boy with a friend. The catfish was lightly breaded and fried to perfection. I added some remoulade on top and it tasted amazing! And the baguette was flaky on top while soft on the bottom. We also got the hush puppies as a side and they were very well spiced. 

Just a heads up if you're going with a large group -- they can't split the check, but they can take up to 4 cards. 

So glad we chose to come here! I'll be back next time I'm in NOLA!

A GOD-send!!!! They have something for every taste.  Flavored teas, Super Sonic Burrito, Mozzarella Sticks... like a short order cook in your very backyard.  

This particular Sonic is less than 3 years old and is definitely in the right place and came along at the right time.  The staff are swift and quite pleasant.  I enjoy stopping in here especially during the drink specials.  9-11am .99c drinks and 4-6p 1/2 priced drinks (i may have the details a little switched around, but that's the just of the drinks specials) totally WIN WIN situation!

The food was surprisingly good for a place with such a nice view.

I wanted stone crab and wanted to try a new restaurant.  I love IC Sharks, but sometimes I want more attentive service.  I also love Oystercatchers, but sometimes I don't feel like paying $70 for a single (but huge) stone crab claw.  At Rusty Pelican, my husband and I could each have half a pound of claws (which came out to 3 good sized claws) for the middle price of $48.  Not a bad deal.

I also enjoyed the fried calamari and the grouper I had for my main course.

Dessert was utterly forgettable.  I had the apple dumpling that the server recommended.  It was a little too sweet, and the pastry was soggy.

Our server was very nice and quite attentive.  The setting was definitely dated, and I commented to my husband that the Rusty Pelican is a popular wedding venue.  The view certainly is nice, so go for it if you want an outdoor ceremony.  But the indoor spaces are completely generic.

Okay, so I'm trying really hard to write this review in the cleanest way possible, but I really don't know where to begin.

I must say, its a little shocking when you think you are getting a deep tissue massage and body scrub in a private room, then walking into a literal bathhouse, where a bunch of women (old, young, fat and thin) are in "all their glory".  This is not a place for the shy gal, but I decided to not make a scene and go with the flow.

The body scrub was good, but I wasn't crazy about having a half-naked lady climb all over my back for the deep tissue massage, or the countless number of women walking by and checking each other out (I guess you can't help but look at one another).  I can't say anything else without being inappropriate, but they do have private rooms for a dry massage, but not for the body scrub/deep tissue massage package.  

I will come here again, but will not be entering the shower room/hot tub room/body scrub room (its all one big area). Next time, I will opt for a Swedish massage in a private room. The place is clean, their prices are good, and the people who work there are very nice.

How can you complain about a big ol' plate of breakfast grub and endless pots of coffee?  You can't!!!

Had a traditional breakfast platter consisting of eggs, meats, potatoes and (of course!) pancakes.  It was enough to feed a small army, and all tasted as you'd expect from a place known for their diner-style breakfasts.  I especially liked their thick-cut bacon and the pancakes were hearty and filling.

Two thumbs up, Uncle Bill!

I'm from Milwaukee, and we pride ourselves on serving up the best frozen custard in all the land. (WI readers should probably stop here to avoid massive outrage)

Ted Drewes is amazing - it's as good as anything I've had anywhere else and if I'm going to be honest it may be a wee (just a wee) bit better than what I get at home. That was hard for me to admit but Yelp is about honesty, right? 

I had a small s'mores sundae and everything about it was perfect: the custard was perfectly creamy and not overly sweet. The chocolate was luscious, melty milk chocolate and applied in just the right amount. Add in some marshmallow goo & graham cracker bits.....wow. Everything was in perfect proportion - not too much of any one thing. High quality ingredients and friendly staff complete the picture. 

I'm told that Ted's has lines even in the dead of winter & I can see why. I had half a mind to get right back in line myself and order a second helping.

Sometimes, I pretend to be more French than I actually am... and french restaurants like The Marc definitely help me pull of my french facade! I was pleasantly surprised by how charming The Marc was, and the service was excellent. The fish I had for lunch was to die for (it was the feature). Delicious! I had never heard of The Marc before and I'm always up for trying new things. I was quite surprised by how popular it was, the entire restaurant was full at lunch, although it's not a huge restaurant. The Marc is definitely more of a fine dinning experience, but would be a great place to bring clients. I would love to come back here for dinner as all the photos look great and the reviews sound wonderful! Marc, I'll be back!

Solid lunch spot in treasure island!! My parents wanted a burger while on vacation so I yelped burger and this place came up. When we walked in, we were the only people in there. I was a little hesitant to stay but I'm glad we did. 

All 3 of us ordered cheeseburgers. The captain burger was huge! It came with thick bacon, cheese, tomato aioli on fresh brioche. It also came with French fries that were hot a delicious.

First time at The Big Cheezy and it definitely lives up to the hype. First, Excellent customer service, Thomas who took my order greeted me immediately when i walked in with great enthusiasm and he's extremely knowledgeable about the menu. Now about the food: i ordered the Original Pairing which is a simple grilled cheese and tomato basil soup. The soup is only okay but the sandwich is awesome! Perfect portions, neither too small nor too large. Clean restaurant, cool music and free wifi! This place is winning on all levels.

I came here once before, I swore I'd never be back.  It was just filthy inside and I couldn't imagine ordering food from such a place.  However, this past weekend, after a night of drinking, we were heading to Hilltop and realized we needed food first.  Hilltop's grill was closed, so we called Black Thorn since it was nearby and ordered a pepperoni pizza to go.  

Once at Hilltop, we opened it up and immediately made a bunch of friends.  The pizza was good.  Although everyone else LOVED it.  It seems Black Thorn carries such a good reputation, that people are just trained to say it's the best.  I'm not sure it was all that... but it was good.  And pizza at the end of a long night of drinking always hits the spot.

By the way, they quoted me 45 minutes before my pizza would be ready... but we picked it up under 30 minutes after ordering.  And unlike my first experience here, the bartender (older gentleman) was super nice, helpful, and cool.

I should have tried the pizza. We meandered by and were pleasantly surprised that the valentines items were on, well I guess, clearance. Mmmm clearance desserts. We got a little heart shaped chocolate truffle layer cake thing, it was chocolaty, truffly, moist and cakey. Everything you'd expect.

I tried Wishbone take-out and I thought it was just alright. I had the dark classic chicken with chipotle lime mayo, mac and cheese, and a biscuit. The chicken wasn't bad, but not too memorable given the novelty of it. The mac and cheese was too salty for me. It's a good idea with the mascarpone and all, but it just wasn't right that time. I did like the chipotle dip and the biscuit was great. I wanted to try the bahn mi and they didn't have it anymore. So much for that. If I were to give Wishbone another shot I'd try some kind of sandwich instead of the chicken tenders.

Overall, it's not a bad spot. I just didn't care too much for it and it's a definitely a bit pricy.

Hot ol' afternoon, kids in shorts, pretty girl on my arm. This is summer. 

We don't have frozen custard where I come from. Straight up do not even know what it is. God it's good. It tastes like America, and freedom, and 1956. Sitting on a bench with butterscotch custard melting way too fast down my arm made me all kinds of nostalgic and I have no idea why. Like a kid without a care in the world and my whole life ahead of me. I'd go again just for that.

Frozen custard = the fountain of youth.

Went to this Brio for the first time last summer for the Yelp garden party. Didn't really get to try much more than a couple of flatbreads so I didn't have a good picture of what the place was like. I just know that they're owned by the same company that owns Bravo Cucina Italiana...so I expected good things from them. I am confused by the names...Bravo...Brio....the menus seem to vary slightly as do the prices. I've been to Bravo in Pittsburgh and Brio in Florida. So I wonder if the names just vary by region?  Anyway!

Sean and I decided to check it out last night after going to see a movie at Frontenac. When we got inside, there was a crowd of servers and hostesses all just mingling near the front podium thing. We were ignored for a few minutes while they casually chatted. Not really a great first impression. But I was hungry and didn't care. We were seated a little after that and we were handed menus.

Wow. Chicken milanese costs $19.95? Wtf. I thought it was more around $15 or so, at least from when I last ate at Bravo. But I am not entirely sure what the deal is with the different places so maybe Brio is more costly or maybe it's because it's at Frontenac. I dunno. I opted for the lobster and shrimp ravioli. It has some kind of crab thing on top with limoncello sauce. Never had that at Bravo so decided to try it. After all, for about the same price ($20.99) I might as well get something with more expensive ingredients, right? It was VERY VERY good....if a little rich. I ended up with severe heartburn later on but it was so worth it. The salad had crabmeat and a little tangy lemon flavor to it. Mmm. 

Sean opted for the last item on the flatbread menu...some type of sausage and pepperoni thing with ricotta on top. Needless to say he ordered it w/o sausage and scraped the ricotta off, but he seemed to enjoy it otherwise. Oh, and I had a glass of wine. They were sold out of the kind I wanted but I was able to get a recommendation from our server and he let me try a sample before getting a whole glass.  Food came out LIGHTNING FAST. Was really surprised! Pleasantly surprised, that is. ;)

I think I'd come back here but it's kind of spendy. Maybe to get the chicken milanese because I know it will be good, just not sure how ready I am to drop 20 clams on a chicken dish.

Juan's makes funky, delicious "Mexican" food.  I'm not sure what you really call it (punk-Mex?) but it's good.  It has an eclectic mix of burritos, quesadillas, and other fare.  

I like the Western burrito myself--grilled veggies, a meat, some sour cream and cheese.  Their Bacon Azul quesadilla is a big mess of cheese, bacon, beef--throw salsa and ranch dressing on it (included) and it will help put you in your grave with a smile.

Great for vegetarians too!!

The original Magazine location has a completely different atmosphere than Mid-City; it's got a funky vibe to it and draws a lot of clientele from the Lower Garden District.  Staff is great.

We got our first taste of NOLA at Cafe Beignet. I didn't know what to expect. Honestly, beignets aren't all that amazing. They kind of remind me of Chinese "fried donuts," which are also not that amazing.

But what does this place have going for it?  Even at 9:30 in the morning, there's music in the courtyard. The singer was quite good and we got to enjoy our breakfast outdoors in an area with a bunch of misters to keep us cool. The ambiance is what sets this place apart.
It's busy all year round for a reason!

Beer sampler was alright, there were only four spots available on the paddle.  It would have been nice to try six since they were only about 2 ounce glasses.  While they didn't have too many beers on tap to choose from, a lot of them were IPA's and a couple of them were local crafts - my favorite of the four was a well known Marlette Red from Virginia City, it' somewhat standard around town.  The two guys behind the bar were very friendly and eager to answer any questions I had about the beers.

Since it was happy hour we ordered the cherry chipotle wings and the sweet potato tots.  When the wings came out I was terribly disappointed because they were shriveled to the bone and loaded with sauce to hide the fact that there was absolutely no meat on them.  I'm not ashamed to return something when it's inedible, so I kindly told the guy my issue with them and he gladly took them back.  However, the sweet potato tots were FANTASTIC!  I enjoyed every last one, slightly greasy, but fried to perfection.  And for only $3 you can't go wrong!

I'm glad I had the chance to check another happy hour spot off my list.  I will definitely be back for a glass of wine during HH, since I noticed a great price on a certain type that was written on their chalk board.

Went here last night to try out the food and I have to say, fellow Yelpers, that I was slightly disappointed. 

Got the feta fries ($7), small bruschetta ($8), small butternut squash ravioli ($8), and fish tacos ($9). I knew what I was getting into with the feta fries, but why not just melt the damn cheese so I don't have to pick it up with my fingers and PLACE it on the fries? The fish tacos were alright, but I expected the fish to be breaded. Sadly, it was not and the fish was a little too fishy for me (yes, I realize that sounds silly). The redeemers were excellent; the bruschetta and the ravioli. I have no idea what they put in that ravioli: cinnamon? butter extract? crack? but it was effing heaven. It's the butteriest butter flavor you can have AND the ravioli is surprisingly sweet. It would be a slam dunk for me, but the $8 is just sooooooo small. I knew going in that portions would be small but they're really teeny tiny. 

We also had the orange blossom sazerac ($9) which my boyfriend loved and the Lavender Lace ($7), a champagne and lavender bitter drink which I thought would be more lavendery. I probably won't come back but I'm glad I tried it. 

Also, as a side note, this is one of the more low-key places on Frenchmen and it you sit in the back you won't have to yell to talk.

We loved this place and you will too. When we entered the smell of fresh oranges was in the air. They were cutting them up to make a homemade orangechello yum! This is a small space but it's comfy and inviting. You can pull up a seat at the bar and sample any of the many many flavors of vodka that are made in house. We enjoyed candy cane vodka, jalapeno heat (wow that one packs a punch) and so any more. We loved or bartender she was so friendly and very passionate about the products. Of course we purchased a bottle to go. I can't wait to revisit and try some more seasonal vodkas.

Forest Park Forever!

Forest Park is bigger than Central Park in NYC, can you believe that?
There is something for everyone in Forest Park. And best of all, it's probably FREE! (or costs something minimal). 

What can you do?
Walk, jog, bike, skate on the trails
Picnic, have a party, enjoy a beautiful day outside
Fish at Jefferson Lake
Ice Skate at Steinberg
Go to the MUNY!
Go to the Zoo!
Go to the History Museum!
Go to the Art Museum!
Go to the Science Center!
Go to the Planetarium!
Sled down Art Hill
Listen to Shakespeare in the Park
Watch fireworks
Watch movies on Art Hill
People watch
Rent a paddleboat
Eat at one of the restaurants in Forest Park
Visit the Cabanne House
Go to the Earth Day festival
Visit the Jewel Box/Greenhouse
Play around the World Fair Pavilion
Bird watch at the JFK Forest and the Nature Reserve Prairie
Visit Flegel Falls
Archery Range
Baseball/softball/football/soccer/rugby/cricket/sand volleyball
Play golf
Play tennis
Play handball or racquetball

There is always something going on in Forest Park, as evidenced by the crazy amount of cars once winter disappears. How can you not love what is probably the crown jewel of St. Louis??!? There is nowhere anywhere in the world like Forest Park.

It's Whole Paycheck.  The prices are ridiculous and I have to say the food bar here, when I go during lunch always seems like things have a layer of "been out too long" over it.    

I do not get my regular groceries here, because I'm not Caucasian enough  to waste that much money.  

Their take out sushi is cheaper than going to a real sushi place and getting take out.  However, the lines as so long during lunch time you're not really saving that much time.

People look at me with bewilderment when I tell them that the best Chinese food in Santa Barbara is at Mama Lu on Milpas.  However, you have to be able to read Chinese and order from their "secret" menu.  Are they assholes for not translate the menu and keep their delicious authentic goods from the general population?  Not really.  I think "lost in translation" is the reason why a restaurant like Wok on the Wild Side has so many negative reviews and why many restaurant don't even bother with translation.   

I have never seen a restaurant generated so many opposite opinions.  I was intrigued by my fellow reviewers and I had to see it for myself.  Is this place really bad or simply misunderstood.  

The restaurant was clean and simply decorated.  The owner was from Dong Bei (North East China) and a first time restauranteur.  It seems like the combos were not well priced compare to the entrees and personally I would not recommend stir fry dishes that had being sitting out for more than 15 minutes.  I got the entree size xiang la pai gu and it came with a bowl of steamed rice.  I counted 11 meaty ribs pieces  with jalapeno, onions, and dry red chilies.
