The sauce was very spicy and flavorful, but I agree with others that it was salty even considering that Sichuan cuisine tends to be heavily seasoned.  Most restaurants use cheaper long grain rice, but here they used starchier short grain rice that Chinese, Korean, and Japanese prefer because sticky short grain rice pick up sauce better than hard fluffy long grain rice.   

I spotted a pan of kou shui ji next to a line of ubiquitous looking stir fries.  I can't help it but get a small box to go.  Kou shui ji literally translates to salivating chicken, so good, you'll salivate thinking about it.  Its boiled whole chicken cut into more manageable chunks, with bones and skins, soaked in a sauce made of spices and red chili oil.  This was not on the menu and it was very good and authentic.  Now, I am definitely intrigued and already planing a future visit.  If they can tone down the sodium by a notch this place would be 4 stars.
In my opinion this is the best Mexican food in town and a great value.  There are lots of choices and the beef has a great flavor. Never had anything bad here including service.

Had a hankering for really good seafood, and not fried, simply boiled bucket seafood like in Mass, Cape Cod etc.  Sadly I can't find anything remotely like The Boiling House near home (Yardley PA).  I remember my days living in Hoboken NJ and going to Just BeCaws in Jersey City.  Well, we found a suitable comparison to Just BeClaws and within only 40 minutes south in Cherry Hill NJ.

Look for the red fishing boat along Marlton Pike about, just 30 yards north of the Jaguar/Land Rover dealership on Marlton Pike in Cherry Hill.

They are located deep down the center of the shopping center stores back on the right down the steps.

With the pandemic, we called to check on inside seating and their protocols which met with our approval these days. Everyone is masked, many servers with gloves and cleaning between patrons.  Tables were spotless and readied with napkins, plates lobster bid and plastic disposable gloves.  No menus, QR code scan in a placard or you can use the Yelp menu.

Let me start by saying Dave, our server, was fantastic.  Handled all our questions, was courteous friendly and definitely attentive. 

Upon figuring out the menu and our interests we opt to pick our own dishes vs the larger multi-option dishes for the table.  I built my own seafood pot with Dungeness Crab Cluster, two large clusters weighing in at 1.25lbs of fabulous, succulent, perfectly cooked meat that was boiled with old bay and some garlic butter.  Was meal that will be remembered.  

My spouse had the seafood fried rice -- lobster, shrimp, king carb, Dungeness, snow carb meat, mussels and egg and mixed veggies.  She loved it.  As an add on, we ordered one Andouille sausage, it had kick, was a perfect complement to both our meals.

BYOB, parking lot, credit cards, attentive staff, great food.
Can't wait for the hankering to show up again soon.

See our pics.

The small shop in south east Philly sells Ecuadorian and El Salvadorian food.  They also do delivery within a 10 mile radius!
 
Here, the pork pupusas were pupusa-ey-: meaning always satisfying- the combo of grease, masa, and some salty filling, but not the best around town. If we are playing favorites, Tamalex and Cafe Canela are my baes because of that thorough greasiness.
  
I was more impressed by the empandas. I tried the crab and the beef. Crab filling was good and also not one you see regularly, but the beef were maybe some of my favorites around town. The stuffing is a stewy mixture of beef and potato.  Now that I know, I think there is a fair chance I will drunkenly order about a dozen of these for delivery in the near future. It wouldn't be my worst idea.

Went her on a Sunday night with a large group to celebrate a soccer tournament thing. Our little shin dig happened to be at the same time as someone's wedding celebrations which was an interesting experience.

Anyways, on to the food.  So many dishes kept on coming out. The table must have had 9 dishes total.  We had:

- Sweet and sour pork with tripe and some other asian meats
- Mayo shrimp with peaches
- Seafood soup (not sure what it's actually called but it's delicious)
- Fried fish with spices and red/green peppers
- Soy sauce chicken
- Bird's nest with chicken and vegetables (peas, carrots, celery)
- Lobster with chow mein noodles
- Chinese mushrooms with bok choy
- Seafood fried rice

Service was typical of Chinese restaurants (minus points for seeing the waiter go into the washroom and not wash his hands properly - nasty).  Food is average. Prices are cheap. Wouldn't be my top pick for chinese food in Edmonton but it's decent.

I miss Ted Drewes! I lived three blocks from Ted Drewes as a scrubby little kid. I used to go almost every day during the summer. I remember my neighbor and buddy, Donn, would always go with me. We'd eat our sundaes on the walk back, and like clockwork, Donn would always drop one once we got home. 

Not only does Ted Drewes frozen custard keep you regular, it's like an orgasm in your mouth. (Except you don't have to perform fellatio on anyone.)
Fantastic service and excellent food (as evidenced by all the raving reviews here already). Stop reading and start eating, it's a great local spot!

Curtis Hixon Park is an awesome centerpiece for downtown Tampa. It is located downtown, and is right on the Hillsborough River.  Across from Curtis Hixon Park is the beautiful University of Tampa.  It is an amazing view. 

Curtis Hixon Park is a focal point for many to see because of the many different views of the city of Tampa. You will also see that the Glazer Children's Museum is in walking distance as well as the Tampa Museum of Art. 

If you are looking for a place to eat, check on the Sono Café at the Tampa Museum of Art, or walk across the street, and you will find one of my favorite places Anise Global Gastrobar.

Often times, there are many festivals going on at Curtis Hixon Park. Some are pretty darn spectacular, and some are just okay. Two of the most favorite events I have been to at Curtis Hixon Park was the Burger Showdown, and the Bollywood Red Carpet Pre party for the Indian Oscar Awards. Burger Showdown was just a big huge party with tons of vendors with the best burgers in Tampa.  Picture this for the Bollywood Red Carpet Pre-Party - Imagine a Wednesday or a Thursday night with the best loudest, fun, dance music playing. It was a blast.

I also love Curtis Hixon Park because it is super pet friendly and family friendly. There is a really nice little water area for the kids to play. There is also a playground for the kids, and a dog park for your dog. 

Every time I go here, I love it more and more. It is a little bit smaller than many city parks, but just the surroundings make it great.

I can't forget, Sundays they have farmers markets here in the morning, and in the evening on Sundays, they also have Yoga. 

This is a perfect location to enjoy beautiful downtown Tampa.

I kinda like this place somehow even though everything about it screams 'this is overpriced, you know you're only paying for the convenience of its proximity to your work, but go ahead you do you boo.' YES, I bought the local artisanal coffee beans that I freshly ground into a paper bag even though I already HAVE gifted coffee beans at home, still waiting their turn. YES, I justified roast beef at $12 a pound and Amoroso rolls at double the price ShopRite sells them for. With that said, this place has rescued me during those bleary-eyed morning commutes to work when I forgot to pack my breakfast and coffee creamer. I also discovered a new flavor of coffee creamer they sell here, so there's that. Only self-checkout options is wonderful. The layout is WEIRD though (you enter on the left even though everyone knows you go RIGHT into grocery stores, and I still forget which is the proper way to walk to check out.) Regardless, I'll be back here probably weekly, tail between legs.

I knew I was in trouble when I moved 5 minutes away from Mr. Wizard's.

All of their concretes are fantastic... I have to agree with Steven B's review where he says the custard here is rich and creamy. You can throw anything in there and it's going to make your head spin it's that good. I usually go the cookie dough or Oreo route, but most recently I splurged with a friend on the strawberry shortcake and banana split. If you haven't tried those yet, definitely make that a priority. I've also seen people walk away with ice cream cones that HAVE to be 6-7 inches tall!

It's fun to sit outside at the picnic tables on a balmy St. Louis summer evening. It kind of completes the experience when you do that, rather than take it home.

Couldn't be a bigger fan of this place. It's a staple in my summer routine!

So I should say this right off the bat....I don't eat ground meat. Right, that means no burgers for this girl. Guess yall are wondering how I can review this place. My hubby loves this places so every now and then I'll go. There's hotdogs and veggie sandwiches. So first I tried the hotdog. Eh...it's a hotdog. Certainly not worth the money the charge for it. Also, the wrap it in foil which made the bun soggy from the steam from the hot meat. Then I tried the veggie sandwich. It was a ton canned mushrooms, a couple slices of tomatoes, lettuce, onions and bell pepper. The bun was nothing but mush so I really needed a fork to eat the veggies. The veggies were extremely bland. A nice veggie burger not lose veggie sandwich would go a long way here.

The fries are okay. I would prefer a crispier french fry myself. They offer regular or seasoned. We ask for light season, if not they put so much it burns your mouth and doesn't even taste that great. 

The atmosphere is great. The staff are always friendly. Service is quick. You get free peanuts in the shell. Also, it makes my hubby happy to eat here which makes me like it a little more.

Verdict: It's not the original but it's not a bad alternative at the airport.

This place is located in the outskirts of the airport terminals, in what seems to have the local food offerings. You'll also find the Philadelphia Pretzel Factory right across the food court. The Tony Luke's here isn't cheap by any stretch but you'll pay the premium when in need of a Philly fix.

I loved going to the original Tony Luke's before they started popping up everywhere. They made a decent cheesesteak but you could get that in a lot of places in Philly. This place probably does a better job than most with their pork sandwiches.

Looking for that familiar flavor, I ordered the roast pork with broccoli rabe. There wasn't anything really on the lighter end but I did find and order the cooked spinach side dish. The sandwich was exactly what I expected and I enjoyed every bite. The spinach side was tiny and a bit salty but otherwise good.

Even though this terminal is at the far end, there's a shuttle that brings you right here from one of the more central locations. If you have the time and crave some more authentic local cuisine, this place might be worth the trip.

Cafe Beignet is like a hot chick with no substance. There's a reason you want to hit on her, stick around for some time, and would call her in the future. But her personality is the reason you may lose her phone number.

When it comes to Cafe Beignet, the live jazz music was the reason I went in, stayed a while, and would come back. But their food is the reason the latter may not happen.

Their typical touristy Cajun food was decent, but it lacked flair, culture, and was far from memorable. In a city like New Orleans, there are so much better options. Unknowing tourists must come here for the awesome vibe which features patio dining and amazing live jazz music in the middle of a classic courtyard.

I loved eating on the courtyard taking the energy of New Orleans in. The entire experience transported me into another world. Unfortunately, the food brought me back to reality.

My recommendation is that you eat somewhere else. Just come here for some dessert, coffee, or a beer. 

In the end, Cafe Beignet truly is like the hot with no substance. That makes it mistress material.

This is my go-to delivery location when I am at work.  They are always quick, always friendly and have yet to mess up an order unlike the IUPUI location that always screwed up.  I have been in here several times to dine in as well and the place is always clean and quick.  What else could you want from your JJs??

When doing the tourist thing in the French Quarter, we popped by on a Thursday night because my husband became addicted to beignets while we were visiting New Orleans. If you're also doing the tourist thing, this is a lovely place to stop in the evening. We only had coffee and beignets, so I can't speak to the quality of the other food, but the beignets were good and there was live jazz. A great place to sit and relax a bit.

I like to call Rouses the "local" version of Whole Foods. They have a great selection of local products and organic foods. 

Just found out you have to throw a party in 20 minutes? No big deal...they have trays of finger sandwiches, cheese & meat trays, veggie trays and dips that are all fresh and ready to go. This comes in handy for football season when all the sudden you have a hungry herd coming over. 

Their prices are competitive in comparison to other local grocers and have come across some good sales.

I just had a RX called into this location because it was near where I am. First time here. I usually just fill prescriptions at a CVS. I like that they accept GOOD RX if it is less expensive than my insurance and the send me a text when it's ready!

Walked up the counter...said "you got cheese"?
Order taker rolled her eyes and poured out, " puhleeze"

Now that we determined that fromage is the fare
I scanned the menu board while irony hung in the air

Got the cheese sammich with some cheese covered waffles
My dining partner the soup, sammich combo, said it wasn't awful

In fact he dipped his cheeser in the soup
Invited me to do the same with my cheddar from the hoop

Iced tea was weak, Gold Peak colored water
They need the right tea brand, cmon do what you oughter.

If you want your comfort food in the form of cheese
I suggest you stop in here and order what you please

The first two lines of my little dining ditty
Never even occurred, more like Walter Mitty

Service was fine, the food came out hot and gooey 
In this case it's good that your food is really chewy

Will return again one day and order more melted cheddar
For some grilled cheese goodness you cannot do better

$5 minimum on card. The frozen yogurt is 51 cents per ounce, which can add up if you don't really pay attention to how much you're putting in the cup. I like the flavor offerings, but they're pretty basic. Toppings are also limited too, but there are candies and fresh fruit. Plenty of seating and they have Cartoon Network on a tv set running all the time.

My husband, son, and I eat at El Sombrero at least once per week.  Obviously, we love it and it is by far the best Mexican restaurant I have experienced in Nashville.  ORDER THE CHICKEN FAJITAS!!!  They are the best and the salsa is always a little spicy which I love.  The drinks are cheap and during the week they run 2 for 1 margarita specials.  

We go not only because the food is great but because it's so clean and the service is amazing!  We have eaten at the restaurant towards closing and seen the waiters wiping down the booths and high chairs with sanitizer.

Most importantly, this place is definitely kid friendly. They usually give the kids candy after the meal, they have clean high chairs, and they make my son feel like a celebrity when he visits.  He smiles as soon as we walk in the door.

I was so happy when they finally finished re-constructing this park. This park has been a part of the downtown scene for many years. However, this has undergone a major renovation which was finished earlier this year. Now it's completely redone with new outdoor furniture, event stage, loading docks, City of Tampa owned multi-use/community building, picnic tables, barbecue grill, wide open lawn areas, playground for the kids, water mist zone, bike rack with a few rental bikes, etc. This is also another water taxi stop. 

Its multi-level terrain provides for a very scenic view from every angle of this park. I see a lot of potential for many different types of events in this area. I was thoroughly impressed by the redesign of this park. It was worth the visit.

You know those restuarants that you drive by all the time and think, eh.. it's probably just fine, but not worth stopping for... well that has been my thought on M3.  However I will tell you, I was pleasantly surprised on my last visit!  The food is average to good but the atmosphere is lovely, the wine list is stellar and very reasonable, and they are willing to make many accommodations for dietary needs.  I came here with a colleague for a ladies night and we thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.  I had the lemon herb chicken, double veggies, no quinoa, and my friend had the kale salad and a pasta dish.  Everything was very good.  We shared a $20 bottle of Kendall Jackson (yes, $20 - not even a happy hour price).  I was pleasantly surprised to see the place quite busy on a Tuesday night, so much so that I even had to wait a few minutes for a table.  Words getting out on this great neighborhood joint!

As I was fighting my lurking hangover and was awaiting a late night flight, Our group was in the mood for a killer burger but didn't want to be cooped up in a true restaurant setting.

One major thing I appreciated, more like loved, about Burger Republic is the quick turnaround service for their establishment.

From boozy (and non-boozy) milkshakes to some mouth drooling burgers this is a great spot in the downtown area to grab a bite.

This is the home of the 96 burger which won the world food championship as the highest rated burger.

I opted for the Anniversary Burger which of course had pork belly as I needed as much bbq in my life as I was in Nashville. The burger was pretty darn delicious and I left with one very happy tummy. They seriously have their burger game on clutch!

Maybe I just like the Lenox Village location better? I'm not sure what was off, maybe the service, maybe the burger. We stopped in for lunch on Sunday. We walked into the restaurant & went to the hostess stand. We wanted to sit on the patio, but saw the sign to check in with the hostess. There were 3 employees talking at the stand & seemed like we were interrupting them. We asked the hostess if we could sit on the patio with an umbrella. She looked at the table map & grunted & reluctantly said okay. 

Our server came over & took our drink order. She was nice enough but seemed like she didn't want to be there, & she wasn't around much. I ordered one of the brunch cocktails ($7). It was loaded with lemon seeds. I think there was about 10 in the glass, then in the straw & in my mouth. I ordered the 96 burger, which is bleu cheese topped with honey-balsamic glazed mushrooms, onions and bacon, finished with crispy shoestring fries & garlic-horseradish aioli ($11.50). I ordered it with fries. If you order sweet potato tots it's two bucks more. 

I ordered it medium rare, more medium came out but at least it wasn't well done. The burger had a good flavor, the aioli wasn't too overpowering. It wasn't my favorite burger though. The fries were just okay. Everything just seemed okay. Last time I was at the Lenox Village location, I just remember everything being better. Maybe I'll have to give the Gulch location another shot.

First impression:

I was lucky to attend Chipotle's soft opening (disclaimer: I got to eat for free). I'm so happy this pleasant, clean, and friendly location is opening so close to my apartment. There's not much that I can say beyond the fact that this is, like all others are, a standard Chipotle.

Or maybe it's not -- this restaurant shares a historic building with a Starbucks. It used to be a Del Taco, but you can't tell that anymore. The parking situation here is a bit hairy. You'll have to make an awkward turn from Grand to get in here, and dodge Starbucks drive-thru customers. A yummy burrito, though, is worth life's minor inconveniences. (Another inconvenience: It's very noisy here. Expect to yell and be yelled at until they figure the acoustic situation out.)

That's about it. Glad to know Chipotle's in the neighborhood now.

There is nothing in the world as good as this place for genuine frozen custard. Make no mistake...this is not ice cream, it's frozen custard. 

I've been coming here for years! My recommendations:

HAWAIIAN DELIGHT-Concrete or sundae with pineapple, bananas, coconut and macadamia nuts.

SOUTHERN DELIGHT - A concrete or sundae with praline pecans and butterscotch yumminess 

CARDINAL SIN - A concrete or sundae with tart cherries and thick hot fudge

ALL SHOOK UP - A concrete or sundae with Reese's® peanut butter cups and bananas Elvis style

TERRAMIZZOU - A concrete or sundae with pistachios and Ted's secret blend of chocolate

Mmmmmmm! Drooling.

Icecream was just ok. 
I had their blueberry crisp icecream and it tasted so artificial. Eh, would not go again.

Dear sweet Pollo Tropical why don't I eat with you more often? There's no denying my Hispanic heritage when you are around! I love to use your creamy black beans as sauce mixed with your cilantro mayo. I don't think there's anything you offer that I wouldn't rip apart in seconds. You sammiches are fresh, if a bit small, but you serve beer, and sangria. I don't care that you are a chain because every time you have done just fine.Your staff is friendly, your restrooms clean, and even your sauce station which is a disaster of modern engineering is impeccable. Hasta luego my fine feathered friend!

A real treat for seafood lovers. This low key, hidden from the main road joint was one of the best discoveries I've found recently. My birthday coincided with father's day so I didn't want to deal with the hassle of going out on fathers's day weekend and decided to celebrate my birthday a week early here.

The dining room area was beautiful and modern. While most seafood boil places are set up like a bar, at Boiling House, you feel like you're in a fancy modern restaurant. The service was also amazing. You can choose from the menu or make your own seafood boil. First, you pick your seafood then pick the sauce that you want and finally, the spice level.

I opted for their Sea Festival, which came with king crab, snow crab, Dungeness crabs, lobsters, potatoes and corns, sausages, two pounds of live crawfish, 2 fresh lemonade and garlic noodles. This order was about $150 and fed 4 people. I highly recommend the Boiling House sauce and spicy. The seafood was just amazing, everything tasted fresh and they had some huge crawfish. The sauce was very buttery and flavorful. The main surprise hit was actually the garlic noodles. Their noodles had a chewy textures that held against their super flavorful sauce.

Overall, this place was solid. Although on the higher price of things, you cannot really complaint because of their location. I will be back here many times and bring lots of friends! I wonder why the place haven't had a higher ratings. Although it may not be Louisiana or Texas, Boiling House is representing the East Coast pretty well. Four for the food and one extra star for awesome service.

I think The Prime Rib is one of the best classic Philly steak houses.  Located on the ground floor of the Warwick Hotel near Rittenhouse Square, The Prime Rib has a rich clubby look that hits you as soon as you walk in.  It is very attractive and we were also warmly greeted by the hostess.  We were taken to a great table near to the piano player - who let me state here was 'awesome'.  He performed long sets and played everything from Piaf to Chopin with a little Brahms and Broadway show tunes thrown in. The meal we ordered from the wonderful prix fixe menu was superb.  A seeded bread roll began the feast followed by a green salad topped by their well-known house dressing - think creamy parmesan.  The juicy prime rib was done exactly as requested and we enjoyed the delicious sides of creamy spinach and steak fries.  I loved the horseradish dressing which probably was intended for the roast beef but I used it as a tasty dipping sauce for my fries.  An excellent Château du Pin Bordeaux wine accompanied the meal. Dessert was a piece of moist chocolate cake and a well-executed crème brûlée. Service was excellent by both the waitress and the attentive busboy. I had not one complaint and a happy & full stomach when I left The Prime Rib!

For a typical Chinese buffet (but with a Japanese name?), it has a slightly more impressive selection with the same, average buffet quality - they have oysters on the half shell, crawfish, lots of crabs, a hibachi grill, a pretty solid sushi selection, and a chocolate fountain. Obviously quality is sacrificed at a buffet, but this place is so cheap, who's complaining, right? I was stuffed here with pretty good tasting food. 

Lowlights - fat free ice cream was terrible and obviously filled with artificial sweeteners (my siblings got the fat free while I opted for the regular fatty ice cream, which was extremely creamy), and the service. Service was terrible - we had to wait quite a while for our used/dirty plates to be cleared so our table was constantly cluttered with dirty plates as we progressed throughout our meal.

It's a standard buffet, what more do you want for $12.95?

Very mixed feelings...I think it's 3.5 stars, and I would like it to go up because it's exactly what Fairview Heights needs. 

If this is the only sentence you read: Try the juice bar orange juice. Holy crap. That stuff is amazing and makes you think, WTH have I been drinking for years?

What I really like:
*Wednesdays=Double Days where the ad that is currently ending and the ad that is coming up are both valid. You don't have to come back weekly. 
*The theme of the store. It's cheaper than Whole Foods, and it has more variety than Trader Joe's. I like that it does try to source locally and has a very impressive organic and gluten-free selection, along with an encompassing homeopathic section. 
*The small grocery carts, which are a lot easier to maneuver.
*The produce: Lots of turnover and really good prices. Separated by nonorganic and organic. And the employees will offer you a sample if you ask them about it.
*The juice bar. I thought this was really stupid at first because it's in the back, and it's not made to order. The girl makes a bunch, bottles them, and puts them out. There's carrot, a green one, berry, and the oh-so-amazing OJ. It blows any other orange juice out of the water. Makes me want to go out, buy a $300 juicer and see if I can re-create it. It's like that ginger ale ad...only in oranges. The only sad part about it is that the prices are pretty um...high. $6.99 for 64 oz of OJ. $3 for a little bottle of green fluids. 
*The beer and wine department: The guy who works the aisles knows his stuff. Hit him up for recommendations and he will happily give them to you. If they would have wine/beer tastings once in awhile, that would be the cherry on top.  
*The homeopathic aisles. I don't know how good they are, but there are remedies for every ailment. Some have guides, but most do not. A info kiosk would be great.
*The spices. This is self serve and it's pretty much hidden. Works like the bulk center. You can buy how much you need at a time, and the prices are fairly reasonable too. I did notice that someone left red pepper flakes uncapped last time I was there; that's so...considerate.

The Undecided:
*The convenience: I like that they have quick meal options. They have a salad and antipasto bar, self-serve, reasonably priced. They have cooler cases with quick meal and salad options; also reasonably priced. They have a pizza bar, which looks to be reasonable. They also have a sandwich bar, $4.99, which is okay. It honestly was like a half sandwich to me, and while it was good (not amazing), I was still hungry afterwards. Small coffee counter.
*The bakery: Really nice selection, but do you really have to display your breads out in the open like that? All I can think about is people sneezing and coughing over them and touching them. Because you know that's happening...because it's happening everywhere else in the store. Plexiglass can be shiny too, you know.
*The meat and seafood counter: I really like their options. They have some stuff already marinated and/or stuffed and all you have to do is cook it. There's a really thoughtful curation of sausages too; not particularly unique, but it hits all the highlights. Really good variety of seafood too. But the shrimp on special looked grossly frozen and dried out behind the counter, much to my surprise. 
*Prices: Like anywhere else, you're going to have to do your homework. It's not exactly the cheapest prices around, but it's not the most expensive. For example, they were promoting their salmon for $5.99, but Schnucks had the same for $4.99 the same week. Coconut milk is like $2 a can, which costs more than Global or on Olive, but where else are you going to get coconut milk on the East side? Also see above for the OJ price. Does it sh!t gold? Apparently so!
*The bulk aisles with granola, oats, grains, make your own peanut butter, and dispense your own oils and vinegars: This is comprehensive. It's awesome. But I think it would be a lot more hygienic if it was behind the counter and they had associates dispensing the stuff...you just ask for how much you need and they measure it out for you. 

No thanks:
*The people who come here. I can't figure the best time to come yet. It's been packed whenever I come, although during the weekday seems to be better than at night and the weekends. People chat in the middle of the aisles without any clue that there are people behind them wanting to go through. Or the woman who parked herself  and her big cart in front of the 3 foot long beef section to peruse her ad while other people were trying to get some beef. Or the mom who let her kid slam into carts with his little shopping cart while doing nothing about it. Or the other mom who used her hands to get peanut butter samples for her kids, sucked her fingers, and then WIPED HER FINGERS on the bulk barrel top behind her. YEAH, I WAS THE ONE GIVING YOU THE DIRTY LOOK.

It's a new kind of grocery store in the Metro East; one that definitely deserves to succeed.

Ordered takeout from Tiffin so i can't really comment on much except for what I actually ate. So far i've only had the lamb saag which i thought was terrific.

I wish I could say more but since i'm only a novice with indian food i can only state whether i thought it was good or bad. For now I will say that it was good, I will have to update when I have expanded my palate and knowledge for indian foods.

NOTE: THIS IS REALLY A 4.5 STAR REVIEW!!!!!

The reason I am docking half a star for Kelp Sushi Joint is because they haven't mastered the sticky rice thing yet and the rolls fall apart when you pick them up. Or at least that is what happened to us when we stopped in the other day.

Otherwise, this is definitely the freshest most imaginative sushi I've had so far in Tampa Bay. This is the kind of sushi place you'd find in Chicago or Miami or Philly. Awesome variety of rolls, wonderful ambiance/decor, excellent service. I expect this place to get very popular very fast. 

NOTE: THIS PLACE SEEEMS TO FOCUS MORE ON COOKED ROLLS.

The only negatives I see that could affect its success is the location, which you can't really see unless you look very hard. It's not right on Bay to Bay, it's deep in the crevices of a little strip mall on Bay to Bay. Also, the place is very small and has only 4 or 5 tables inside. Lots of outdoor seating, if you are into that. Me, I prefer A/C and no bugs. That could present a challenge as I can easily imagine that once this place gets more popular, inside tables will be scarce. They should have made the kitchen smaller and the dining space larger.

Yummy rolls you will be craving all the time.

(5/10/13) We were told that this was one of the good places to go if you wanted to enjoy some local food without the tourist trap prices. My friend and I arrived just before the happy rush, which meant we were able to find a table before it became crowded.  I tried the shrimp tempura (pretty good), lobster egg rolls (o.k. - tasted mostly like cabbage, the lobster wasn't noticeable) and lamb sliders (pretty good). In general, the food was o.k. but not necessarily memorable, however, the goat cheese cheesecake was very good - not to sweet and just the right serving size.  I think that I would go back for the cheesecake.

We were told that the restaurant doesn't really do table service, so when the staff isn't nearby, you just pop over to the bar and place your order. Unfortunately, the live band wasn't playing during our stay.

Have tried both takeout and sit in meals here.  

I've tried two types of Biryani here, both the Chicken and the Lamb Biryani.  I preferred neither and do not recommend ordering Biryani here.  The grain of basmati rice that is used in the Biryani here is a unique grain/type.  If I can describe it, the rice itself looks like it has absorbed too much water/broth during the cooking process.  Specifically each grain here has a certain plump-ness that is very unusual.  My fellow dinner companion one evening, who is more knowledgeable in regards to Indian food, felt the same way and we asked if the grain that was used was indeed basmati, to which we were told it was a variety of basmati.  Perhaps it is, but given my thoughts that maybe it has absorbed too much water, it is not spiced enough.  Given the thoughts of the chef in that, his dishes are not exactly authentic recreations but reinterpretations of Indian cuisine and "fusions of classics" this is most likely by design.  Either way after three tries, I'll skip this dish here from now on.

I've also tried the Lasooni Gobi and Chicken 65 and can offer up a review that these appetizers are good.  These versions are similar to that of original with slight variations in spices.  Finally the Garlic Naan is good.

I can return in the future but I'll definitely skip the Biryani.

My friends and I came to Three Muses after being recommended by our new friend, Jeff! He was our guide during a bike tour not far from Three Muses. 

Great music, great food and lovely atmosphere! My friends and I sat at a small table, they played jazz on the stage, and we shared a meal. Service was great and everything was delicious. We had an awesome time.

We walked into the Chipotle Grill as the Girl making the burritos was eating on the line, as she put her burrito down and with the same gloves to make our meal. We immediately walked out as that is completely unacceptable in more ways then one! We felt awkward as we turned around and walked out.

Here, just like everybody and their mama, I'm gonna let yez know that the salt baked squid is very good: light, crispy, tender, and yeah, salty... all at once. Taking bites of squidward with shredded green onion and hot pepper slices are good bites, that's rights. They're good bites paired with a cold beer, if you remembered to bring em. BYOB.

The pan fried noodles weren't as tasty and toothy as the last time we slurped em, however. The addition of hot chili oil helped a bit. Oddly, they were much better cold the next day. See, so they were still good enough to take home with us. 

By the way, the only Werewolves of London reference I made at the table wasn't obvious enough, I guess... "I hear that a little old lady got mutilated late last night." Everyone just seemed quite concerned instead. Well, that's what I get, aaahoooo.

this is a review for the pharmacy:

i was in town for a few days for a conference, and my old pharmacy in st petes was giving me a hard time about filling it (and quite frankly alot of attitude) so when i tried to transfer it over here to pick up during my stay, i was met with amazing efficiency and a great friendly attitude! absolutely LOVED the pharmacist and the staff that answered the phones / helped me out when i got there. Thank you pharmacy for such a great experience!

Cafe Beignet was right across the street from my hotel while I was in NOLA. The location was the only thing this place had going for it. The outdoor patio was nice, as was the music, but we had to cram into a corner to eat our beignets when we came here because it started raining.

As for the beignets? Came here to compare them to Du Monde's. The consensus? Bleck! These were a lot heavier and denser and had that fried, oily taste when: A) the oil is too cool and the food has to fry for a longer time; B) the oil hasn't been replaced in a while. Ended up having a stomach ache after I ate one of these. Glad I shared my order with the table. Heh heh heh.

Pass on this one.

We took a 5 in 1 night tour a couple weeks ago.  Our tour guide was animated and knowledgeable.  The stories were cool, but not scary or eerie.  Also, the streets in the French Quarter are packed at night and there were at least 5 other similar tours going on at the same time.  It's only $25, so it's a good way to kill a couple of hours.

I've now visited a half-dozen different frozen custard places, and while I recognize this is pretty much "the original" and the mecca of frozen custard fans...I still think all of it tastes basically the same!  However, Ted Drewes wins in the toppings department.  I've never found such great combos or extensive topping selection (pistachios!) at a custard shop.  I also really liked their graphics on the cups, building and signs.  Prices right in line with other similar chains, and much faster service even though they were packed!

Am I the only St. Louisian who thinks Ted Drewes is just a little overrated? Just me? Okay. 

The custard is good -- not exceptional -- good. 

I'll give them credit for having exceptionally speedy service.

The first time we went here was a bad experience. Every restaurant is bound to have them from time to time. However, we were enticed to go again recently and had a much better experience all around. Service was much quicker, friendly, and the food & drinks were excellent, in true Cinco de Mayo fashion.

All in all, we'd go here again in a pinch, or if someone specifically invited us here, but we still prefer the CDM on Nonaville Rd. Absolute, hands-down best Mexican restaurant in 20 miles.

Way to go CDM! Keep it up and you have lifetime customers!

Wow, what a great find! Wifey and I stopped in for a drink one day while walking aroudn the shops in the area. The bar is decorated with tons of old wood, pews from a church and a great wood bar. The drink I had was fantastic, albeit I don't remember the name. Definitely a craft cocktail type of place, but you get what you pay for. I'll for sure be back to drink!

This place has ben on my radar for years! I mean look at the pictures..... all delicious seafood! And not gonna lie, all the youtube videos of people eating seafood has made me want to try this place even more. 

Hubs and I came here on a date night and it was a nice shake up to our normal dinner night out. DO NOT wear anything cute- you will get messy. 
At least I was a hot mess.... anyway, the seafood here is super fresh. 
We got two different pots with their famous sauce. I would get the crab legs, and shrimp again but I would actually try a different sauce. There was nothing special about their special sauce. We also got their garlic noodles- if you come here for only the garlic noodles, I would not judge you... they are that good. 

This spot is also a BYO which is a big plus! 
I'd recommend this place if you are a big seafood fan or want to try something new. Personally I cant see myself being here too often unless its for the noodles.

Review for baked goods only (no pizza)

Kermit, I so wanted to like you. Your cute name, your plethora of clever baked goods, your pizza slice bike racks, your friendly staff. 

Pizza and baked goods, why aren't more people doing this? I'll tell you why. When we were there, they were making something with onions and the whole place smelled like your mom's house when she's making stuffing. Nice right? Except both the delicate almond croissants and the box they came in had adsorbed the odor as well. Swell, just the flavor combo I was looking for! The sticky bun and the salted caramel brownie did not absorb the odor. The sticky bun was kind of a misnomer. More like a honey bun, lacking in cinnamon and raisins. The salted caramel brownie won rave reviews from others but for me, the chocolate was overpowered by the "caramel" which for the life of me tasted like eating a stick of butter. 

It should be noted that there's no place to sit and eat your goodies.

Springfield Beverage will be opening next door.

This was our first stop on our culinary tour of NOLA. Got there right when it opened, they were quick. I got the shrimp po'boy and my husband got the beef meatloaf. Both were excellent, the shrimp was slightly better. A little pricey, $14 for the shrimp. Tiny little seating area in the back. Definitely a little gritty by my standards but not by NOLA standards.

My favorite park in Tampa! This place has regular functions, which make it a desired location for tourists and locals alike.  Looking over the water is a beautiful view of the unique architecture of The University of Tampa. 

Located in/around the park is a playground that brings the inner child out, two kid friendly water features, a small (off leash) dog park, and the river walk passes through the West end of the park. 

If you're looking for a nice place to have a picnic, wanting a beautiful walk, or taking to family out for fun day/night, Curtis Hixon Park is a good place to go.  Fun for all ages.

I'm not the biggest expert on Indian food as I've only had it a handful of times, but most of the food I ordered from here was pretty good. I ordered one of the lunch specials - Tandoori grilled Paneer (cheese) simmered in a creamy tomato sauce/homestyle lentils flavored with tomatoes, cumin and garlic/diced winter squash stir-fried in a tomato onion sauce - and was pretty satisfied with it, although the red sauce on the Paneer was so RED that it was a little off-putting. Interesting way to serve cheese, to say the least, but the lentils were by far my favorite thing on the plate - very good. I also tried the Onion Bhaji which was really good, the red onion naan bread which wasn't bad, and the spicy mixed pickles - pickle lover that I am I had to try them, but I couldn't tolerate the taste of them at all and they ended up in the trash. Some sort of flavor in there just didn't work for me.

We had some issues ordering online - I don't know if our computer system was just slow or what, but we had a heck of time getting our orders in before 10 a.m. (which is apparently what you have to do if you order a lunch special to be picked up). It took us a while to connect so that we could pay for it via PayPal (which we didn't even want to do but it seemed like we HAD to). I had decided to order some extra stuff to bring home to the fam, so I had no problem bringing my total over the $20 minimum. Three coworkers decided to put their orders on one bill, but had trouble ordering online, so I went ahead and put their order through on my account (since I had finally figured it all out).  Anyway, lo and behold, suddenly there was a pay cash when you get there option so I guess I went through all that PayPal nonsense for nothing. Needless to say, I don't think I've ever been so frustrated ordering anything online in my life.

It also seemed to take forever to get our food which we had ordered to be picked up between 12:00-12:15 p.m. Well, we didn't get out of there until 12:45 p.m. so that was a lot of waiting, especially since we had ordered well ahead of time. The guy at the counter was helpful and friendly though, so that helped.  

All in all, it was just an okay visit. Like I said, I don't go for Indian very often so I don't know if I'll wind up here again or not.

A-OK!  Not necessarily living up to the hype but I can say I enjoyed myself.  I'd come back more for ambiance than the food.  Everyone in our large party enjoyed ourselves for the most part. Our poor server (Amanda I think) killed the mood a bit with her artificially high "friendly waitress voice" that had the table cringing all night.  

We made reservations for 11 and were squeezed into a circular booth that was two sizes too small for us.  I'm not sure if that was the biggest table they had or if other larger parties made reservations first but it was a tight squeeze!  We enjoyed the guacamole, queso (made with gouda, yes please!) and salsa trio with chips.  The chips were perfection.  Light and airy, just perfect.  All were enjoyed.

Their tacos take center stage.  An order comes with 3 tacos, and I wish that you could mix and match like so many other places in town.  I enjoyed the bbq pastor tacos with a generous squeeze of lime.  I would have preferred these without the bbq, but they still were some pretty killer tacos.  It seemed everyone around the table was equally pleased with their meals, especially those that got the Nada fries.

I ordered walnut shrimp through Caviar. Food arrived fast. It comes with rice. The shrimps are big and fresh. Lightly breaded and not greasy. The mayonnaise sauce is a perfect complement for the dish. It's not too sweet. The walnut isn't hard. Broccoli is fresh and perfectly cooked. Definitely recommend this dish

Had my hopes set high for this one. Real high.  Accolades from everywhere and everyone.  I was not blown away in the least.  Sadly.  There is always plenty of room in this city for a fantastic Asian Fusion restaurant, and Cheu just didn't get it up for me.

Small plates were neither special or memorable -  For example, wings though perfectly crunchy, lacked the zing or enough black garlic sauce to differentiate them against any other wings in the city (perhaps except for the crunch factor); the sweet potato rangoon, was just that, and the brown butter and goat cheese somehow got lost on me.  

Their noodle dishes left me wanting so much more, as I have had far superior noodle/ramen dishes both in fusion-esque Chinatown locales (duh) and specifically Nom Nom Ramen (whose broth, flavor profile and ingredients trump Cheu's noodle dish by far)  The broths across most of the noodle dishes lacked the depth of developed flavor, and the ingredients just seemed rather ho-hum (the greens for example, seemed to be both under-cooked and over-cooked, over steamed; the pork shoulder lacked spice, was overdone)

The service is great, and the space is tiny but intimate.  Food just did not live to my expectations - as the flavors did not impress or stand apart from any similar offerings in the city.

This place is amazing!!!!!!!! I came here expecting average or decent but this is the best seafood I've had in my life! I got a chance to unintentionally interact with the owner and he was super nice and went out of his way and that says a lot about the business and the people that run it. I came in one afternoon and was able to be seated right away. As soon as I sat down, the table was noted to be wobbling. I didn't even notice and apparently the owner that was sitting with his family quickly sprang into action to fix it. I personally thought that was amazing! The waitress explained the menu pretty well due to me being a first time customer. I got the House Special which was the best option for the variety of food that I wanted. I kid you not guys, my food came out in less than 15 mins!!!! The crawfish was cooked perfect and they were HUGE! The crabs were perfect & the shrimp were huge as well. The sides were cooked to perfection and perfectly surrounded in Cajun sauce. I got the Cajun seasoning and medium which ended up being hotter than expected but I don't mind the extra heat-so just be aware. Overall the service was pretty awesome-of course it got pretty busy after I sat down but everyone else seemed pretty happy with the quality of food.

Chimi's Fresh-Mex is better than average for the area. Salsa is just the right amount of chunky and the tortilla chips are served warm. They have El Yukateco habanero sauce at the table and I love that! 

The Margaritas (we had on the rocks) aren't made with the finest tequila and it appears they are made with gold tequila although I didn't verify this. But they get the job done and taste good enough for $7 (large size). In fact I was pretty trashed off just one. So be careful on the drive home. 

Beef Fajita's are tender and make for a good meal. Its not the sliced medium rare deliciousness I've come to expect from Texas restaurants, but its still pretty good. 

You'll have a good meal and enjoy yourself here. So give them a try!

I went to Juan's today for lunch. I have always heard great things, but had never been myself.

I ordered the flying enchiladas. These enchiladas come with chicken, beef and shrimp with a side of black beans and spanish rice. The enchiladas were very good. I wasn't sure how the combo would work, but these were some of the better enchiladas I have had. The server brought two squeeze bottles containing a red and green salsa. The red was my favorite. 

My buddy got the flying burrito and loved it. 

Service was good even though the place was crowded. 

I was lucky and got a parking spot directly across the street. Remember to pay the electronic meter and put the receipt on your dash. Nothing ruins a good meal like a boot on your Maybach.

This is a STL landmark. You will never find better custard concretes anywhere. The only hard part is picking which flavor to get. I went with the tiramasu. Absolute heaven. My last day here, couldn't leave without one.  Next onto lunch, yes doing it backwards it's that good

Ted Drewes is a must have if you're downtown St. Louis. It's just tradition. Also everyone else in Stl is here so you might as well join the party. Don't worry, the line may be intimidating, but I assure you it moves quickly! 

I love their concretes and every now and then I splurge to get "The Christy." It's a sundae with an entire brownie at the bottom of your pile of vanilla frozen custard, hot fudge, and caramel. I usually shoot a text to my pancreas to say, "PREPARE THE INSULIN." It's so delicious and sugary sweet and my teeth hurt thinking about it but I love it so. 

The staff is friendly and works very quickly to get you your sweet treat. I pretty much recommend all the things here so make sure you stop by!!!

The specialty rolls at Crazy Sushi truly live up to the name of this restaurant! With dazzling presentation (seriously some of the best in Philly) and unique rolls, Crazy Sushi keeps me coming back for more! My favorites are the riceless rolls, especially the Aries, which is spicy salmon, shrimp tempura, and avocado wrapped in seaweed. If you're a sushi purist, go for lunch! Their lunch special is 3 rolls for $13 or 2 rolls for $9. Love that the prices are so reasonable (especially for the quality of food!!) and that it's a BYOB!

Right in my backyard and I admit I haven't been here in maybe 10 years.  

Recently on short notice I was invited to have sushi here for lunch. Pass up sushi ? No way !   And I'm so glad I didn't. I'm in and out of the Peppermill property all the time but never seem to hit Oceano. That will have to change.  

Located in the north front end of the property, this restaurant has been updated with a bright open atmosphere. The sushi bar is in the back and very large.  Whenever possible I always sit at the bar, I love watching the chefs work and can ask questions about their recommendations and where their fish comes from.  That day I had Resty as my chef, as well as 5 others at my end of the bar. Service was spot on. And he still had time to answer all our questions about the fishes and preparations. 

Wow, the mussels are probably the plumpest ones I've see in town with great flavor and tender.  The menu had some of the usuals from around town, but new and very different creations.  I tried the Baked Alaska and Salmon BTLA rolls. Loved the Alaska, the BLTA was interesting, I did dislike it but would have like more crispy salmon skin in it than bacon.  The nigiri I tried was fresh and on small thumbs of rice. Even the rice had a nice flavor to it.  

If you haven't already, add Oceano to your Reno AYCE sushi list.  Lunch $21 and $30.

We've been going to Antonio's since the mid '90s.  We've tried Italian places all over Pinellas County.  With great flavor, food consistency, quality and quantity, we continue to go back.  We've tried everything on the menu over the years.  Our particular favs are the Frutti de Mare with the Fra Diavolo sauce and every veal dish is awesome!  Despite the prices being a little high, you do get your money's worth.  Their fried calamari is the best in Tampa Bay!  Give it a try!

For all y'all fro-yo lovers, once you have St. Louis custard, you'll never go back!!

Ted Drewes is a classic part of St. Louis - especially in the summer! My husband and I tend to get the concretes, not the sundaes, because we like have everything pre-mixed. They have tons of great mix-ins!! My husbands favorite is mint, brownie, cookie dough and hot fudge. I'm usually not a fan of mint when it comes to ice cream, but theirs in light and sweet and is one of my favorites! I try something different just about every time, but just about anything with the butterscotch is delicious! One I haven't tried is raspberry...I'm thinking I need to get that soon. Also, if you get more than a few mix-ins, they usually have to put it in a bigger cup, which is awesome because you feel like you're getting more than you paid for. On the other hand, I don't think I can get a medium/large any more - it's super filling!

This place can get pretty darn crowded. Parking can sometimes be a challenge, but the line always moves fast!

The only down side for me is the fact that they don't offer peanut butter as a mix-in!!! Ted Drewes, please add peanut butter to the list!!! Reese's just aren't enough! I need both!

Walking along in New Orleans late one night we stumbled across this cafe that had live music playing outside. 

We waited a few minutes and a table opened up so we sat down and enjoyed the music. 

We ordered some beignets hoping it would be better than Cafe de Monde. Let me tell you, they did not disappoint. Matter of fact, they beat Cafe de Monde hands down! The beignets were nice and fluffy with just enough powder sugar that it didn't ruin it. They also came out nice and hot which made the powder sugar melt in your mouth with each bite! 

They had a server that was walking around and taking orders, which I felt sorry for her because she was all over with no help. You could go up to the window and order however with as crowded as it was on a beautiful summer night, they need at least one more person outside. 

The live band that was playing was amazing as well. 

We stayed about an hour and then moved on! 

This is definitely the better place for beignets! Go down, grab a coffee, beignet, and listen to the music.

Pretty good lunch buffet.  I was surprised that there was a bit of heat to the food, as my experience with Indian buffets is that they are extremely mild with the seasoning.  The palak paneer was tasty, thicker than many other places, which I prefer.  The lamb was tender and spiced well, the naan was soft and warm, the mango dessert was delicious.  I didn't particularly like the chicken tikka masala, but this isn't usually one of my favorite dishes anyway.  

I was hoping that there would have been a fish dish on the buffet, or something that I hadn't tried before.  

I was surprised how nice it looked on the inside, especially because the exterior of the building looks dilapidated.  

I'd like to go back to try the dinner menu.  Overall a very good experience.

Went here about 1:00pm and was told that to get a hibachi seat would take about and hour to get seated, mean while there were a few open tables, not seats but hibachi tables that was available and unseated.

So we decided to get a table, first of all that in the area they have about 6 high tables and I must say the tables are closely bunched together you can hear the other's tables fulfill conversations with out trying. 

We decided on the drink and I got the blue ocean it was good, I ordered hibachi from the table and my scallops was over cooked very rubbery. The shrimp was also over cooked.

This would be a place to only get sushi from even them they took so long just to make one roll. 

I won't be visiting this location again.

AND DON'T GO FOR THE SOFT-SHELL CRAB (I was told they are almost always out)

I am torn. I really like the location and the atmosphere of this restaurant.  The drinks have always been yummy.  BUT.....the food leaves very little to be desired.

Every dish we have tried ranges from just ok to nearly inedible. Do Not Get the grilled Caesar salad!  I think the cook knows the food is just ok so he/she makes up for it by disguising it with a very heaved handed salt shaker.

We will keep coming here if only to stop in for a cocktail but it sure would be nice if they amped up the food quality!

For some reason I had higher expectations of this place. I've been to Korean spas all throughout the country and none have been as bad as this one. First and worst of all, it's SMALL. It's not worth the $25 entry fee. My cousin and I went at 8 o'clock and had a scrub and massage scheduled. Upon arriving, we were two out of four women in the placeThe scrubs went well but the massage was lackluster. They used the lightest pressure on me! Once both services were finished, we decided to shower and enjoy the rest of our time enjoying the 
 salt rooms. For those of you unfamiliar with Korean spa rooms, they are supposed to be heated. However, both rooms to the crystal salt rooms were wide open..
We ventured inside to a cold and dark room. Not how it's supposed to be! Apparently, they were getting ready to close (early) and had turned everything off! Unacceptable. With 45 minutes before their scheduled closing time, this was a bit surprising, not to mention disappointing.
They also provide zero amenities for purchase. Most Korean spas have razors, slippers,towels, face masks, additional add-ons to make your stay pleasant. None of that was found here.. only hairdryers.
So basically, We paid $175 each to get a body scrub to take two showers and sit in a steam room. Not to worry though, at least I had a dry head when I ventured out in the cold. This place is a joke. Never again.
I've been coming here since 2011. They always got good deals on food and other things.

Last night my husband and I had an INCREDIBLE dinner at iNDO! It was such a pleasant, relaxing evening spent savoring the most wonderful flavors in a beautifully designed space. 

Our server Joss was so kind and also happy to make food and drink recommendations for the evening. After hearing some recommendations, we went with them and ordered the Makai Ceviche, King Crab Nigiri, Seafood Laksa, and A5 Wagyu Nigiri. 

The Makai Ceviche arrived first. It's a smaller dish, but packs so much flavor! Leche de tigre, herb salad, shallots, puffed hominy, and aji amirillo make up this delicious dish. It's a wonderfully refreshing cool dish to enjoy on hot summer nights. And those puffed hominy are so good!

Next the King Crab Nigiri arrived. The nigiri arrives with two pieces, so it's perfect to share on a date. Joss told us the King Crab had just been flown in that day, and you could definitely taste the freshness! The sweetness of the crab had a wonderful contrasting taste with the saltiness of the nori. 

My favorite dish of the evening, the Seafood Laksa, arrived next. I swear each dish the kitchen delivered got more and more incredible as the evening went on because my goodness the flavors in this dish are unrivaled. The curry broth and chili oil boasted intense, savory flavors that paired perfectly with the crispy salmon, PEI mussels, prawns and ikura (red caviar). The glistening ikura were like savory little boba popping into subtle savory tastes of salty brine and oil. My husband and I were in heaven slowly enjoying this dish down to the last drop of broth in the bowl.

Our last entree we ordered was the A5 Wagyu Nigiri. Not only did this nigiri arrive looking like it should be on the cover of Feast or Sauce magazine, but it also tasted amazing as well. Slivers of perfectly-cooked Wagyu Beef topped these beautiful bundles of rice. So, so good. 

During our meal my husband and I enjoyed three different cocktails: The Art of Eight Limbs, Shikoku 75, and Enchante. The Art of Eight Limbs consists of plantation pineapple rum, orgeat, coconut milk, Thai basil, lime, and bird's eye chili tincture. It's a wonderful drink for those who love themselves some sweetness. The Shikoku 75 is made up of jinro 24, st. hillaire "blanquette di limoux," yuzu, and popping lemon boba. This refreshing citrus cocktail boasts crisp lemon-fresh flavor with a hint of sweetness as well as a lemony finish when you get to the popping boba at the bottom of your glass. For those who like a stronger drink, the Enchante is for you! Arette blanco, tamarind, Thai tea, and basil make up this strong spiced cocktail. 

We concluded the evening with a Fluffy Ice on Coconut Custard. Treat yourself to dessert and try this for the most creamy, cold, coconut goodness your tastebuds will possibly ever experience. 

Overall, I can't recommend iNDO enough to anyone and everyone! The staff, the food, the drinks, and the space are all just incredible. PLEASE, please, please do yourself a favor and experience this sensational venture by Chef Nick Bognar! You won't regret it!

Looking for comfort food? Im pretty sure a picture of their gourmet grilled cheeses with a side of either tomato soup or waffle fries is next to the definition in the dictionary. Mmm cheese. Makes me happy. 
Ive tried several and they are all good, some heavier than others. My top 2 are the alligator sausage and the orginal(4 cheeses on sourdough served double decker style) The bread is thick and  super buttery. This location also has creole creamery shakes if you want to live it up. 
They also offer salads for the timid. I wish they had a drive thru but then again I do want to live past 40. I like how they are called 'adult grilled cheese'.  Thanks to them, its now my favorite thing about being an adult.

Haven't been to Olive Garden in awhile. But had a gift card to use.
We love the endless salad and bread sticks.  
I chose to try something off the "smarter fare" menu.
The Scrimp Scampi with Asparagus in Angel hair pasta was pretty tasty.  It was a smaller portion but just enough for me.  You got plenty of shrimp too!!!  At 519 calories it was perfect but a little pricey.
The hubby got the Mushroom Ravioli in a cream sauce.  Highly recommend this!!!
And then the 5 Cheese Ziti Forno which is always a classic favorite. 
Our server Dee was very attentive.
We took advantage of the Take home a Pasta for $5.  Put them in the freezer for later!!!!

Not as solid as I was hoping for somewhere only a few blocks from the beach. They definitely charge appropriate to the location, but the quality and taste isn't any different from my land locked city where I eat sushi regularly.

I got a dragon roll which was tasty but not wrapped well as each piece fell apart when I picked it up. Also the proportion of each element seemed off... Too much avocado, not enough sauce, etc.

I also got oysters for a special treat. They were again mediocre. I will probably return out of convenience. Attentive servers.

This place is heaven.

Came to NOLA in August 2012 and Creole Creamery was one of our destination spots, even if it was a bit far from the French Quarter. We spent the day walking around the neighborhoods nearby and exploring the graveyard (which, incidentally, we came to because the graveyard where the Voodoo Queen is buried was closed to the public that day. Something about someone breaking the lock on the gate there). When done exploring, we were all drenched in sweat and craving both water and some ice cream. It was an added bonus when we were hit with the AC upon walking in. 

The shop itself is old fashioned. Warm atmosphere, welcoming employees, and that AC...can't complain when you come in during the summer! 

I love that they have samplers here. There were so many flavors that I couldn't decide on which to settle on. So I picked a bunch!

I don't remember all the flavors I got, but what stood out was the Blueberry Mojito flavor. Everyone I was with tried to steal this scoop from me, much to my chagrin. If I had known this was so amazing, I would have skipped the sampler and gotten a cone with this stuff. It's like crack. SO good! And I loved that it was specifically a summer flavor. The other flavors were equally delicious, but didn't hold a candle to the blueberry one. 

Water here is $1.50 and is ice cold when you get it. They have an ice cream challenge here that my friend and I were thinking about trying, but the risk of brain freeze made us chicken out. Maybe next time, if I ever come back to NOLA...

Mood Cafe is as close to perfect as you're going to get.  Being chaat rookies, we didn't know what to order....not an issue here.  The owner asks a few questions and starts piling things into a bowl.  This may concern some less adventurous eaters, but after three tries now, we've gotten three different chaats and all of them were excellent.  

I don't really know how to properly describe the food other than:  rice puffy, chewy, nutty, somewhat spicy, somewhat sweet-y, fruity, yogurt-y, crunchy, veggie perfection.  The service is super friendly (every time without fail) and the lassis are solid as well.  Do yourself a favor and head over here on Sunday, grab a chaat to go, and head down to the park for the farmer's market.

Great neighborhood pizza place. A gem in the rough (neighborhood). Simple pies but sometimes that's all you want.

Food: 5/5
Location: 3/5  - too small just take it to go!
Service: 3/5

if you're going to cheu noodle bar for ramen, you might be disappointed. 

the owners, ben and shawn, have their philosophy written flat out as you enter the small restaurant. they state that they are two white guys trying to run an asian fusion restaurant, and that although their cuisine is informed by asian tradition, it is not defined by it. basically, have an open mind and don't think about whether this is "authentic" asian food or not. if you take the food at face value instead of trying to define or categorize it, you can judge the food simply for how it tastes, not how it is SUPPOSED to taste.

now, with that in mind, i ordered the brisket noodles to try something different. the brisket was a bit dry, but the matzo ball and kimchi were good on their own. but i felt like together, the flavors didn't mesh well and the dish never came together as a whole.

the miso ramen was actually decent (if non-traditional), but i've had so many bowls of miso ramen in my life that it truly has to be spectacular to blow me away.

my vegetarian friend had the cold sesame 3.0 and said she really enjoyed it. i love soy as much as the next vegetarian, but i'm never one to opt out of a meat dish when it's available.

if you don't want to wait, grab a few of your friends (3 or more to be exact) and make an early dinner reservation (between 5-6:30pm). we made a 5:30pm reservation and didn't have to wait at all.

overall, my impression is that the food is decent and the service is excellent. but i probably won't be back, because it is a little too "fusion" aka experimental. and my palate prefers something more traditional asian in taste.

Well, I'll have to remind myself that this isn't the place I'm looking for. 

My family and I decided we wanted just a quick buffet-style restaurant after a wonderful Sunday service. Despite the reviews, we came. I've been to Golden Corrals all over this country and I feel like I can't count on this company to deliver quality, delicious food. Well, not here. It's ok to satisfy an appetite but nothing extravagant......nothing impressive. 

I'll pass next time. I haven't found a good home cooked buffet style in this city. Some body help!! Mississippi Belle didn't fell short. So did Golden Corral. 

Service: it depends on who you get. Sometimes it's good and sometimes not so good. 

My question: can somebody please clean the ladies restroom???! I declare its a luxury anymore to find a clean restroom (sigh). 

Anyway, the next time ill pass. The price has increased. For $50, we could've eaten at a decent place, with a decent atmosphere with clean bathrooms.

The Lemon Crumb is my favorite at Ted Drewe's; a combination of vanilla concrete (frozen custard), lemon cream, and crunchy graham crackers. It is a refreshing summer treat! 
Sometimes the lines are long and can be confusing, since there are multiple windows and no one seems to know where to line up. 
In my experience, service is fast and courteous at Ted Drewe's! There is an adjacent parking lot, but I imagine it can become full at busier times. 
If you are visiting St. Louis for the first time, I highly recommend giving this place a try; it's an institution!

Well, it's hard to even force yourself to go to a place when you walk by the kitchen door (it was opened in the Marsh parking lot) and see one of the chefs drinking from the water bowl and spitting into one of the sinks where food was nearby. 

I'll definitely be back as the staff was nice and it seems like a good restaurant with nice interior, but the health department should probably inspect this place if they allow their staff to drink out of mixing bowls and spit out water into the sinks where they cook and clean dishes.

Eek.

I love ice cream! I love that they have so many flavors, and not just your run of the mill flavors either. I don't have a favorite because I love them all so much. 

I am disappointed that they don't experiment with other sweeteners though. As a diabetic, I'm always on the hunt for good ice cream that uses different sweeteners. I'm extra disappointed that their sugar free ice cream is not made by them. But I am happy to report that if you're lactose intolerant, they have quite a few great and unique tasting non-dairy treats for you.

Yes, gang, a four star experience in New Hope...go figure.  But my experience is very limited to sitting at the bar, chatting with Jessica the excellent barkeep, and thus the service was impeccable.

3 stars--There was only a handful of taps for brew, I had the Yards Brawler...pretty good stuff...close to something I would have more preferred, but it was fine for one day.  Also they had an adequate bottled beer selection and wines looked decent too. 

5 stars--To start, the Thai mussels rivaled any mussels you would find in the tri-state area.  The coconut curry broth was a velvety smooth base which clung to each mussel, was not watery, nor overly spiced but just perfect.  The mussels were so tender, perfect texture, no grit, and definitely not the "pungent" tasting mussels you get at other places.

3 stars--For a light entree I had the duck salad.  There were 5 medium to small, fairly lean slices of duck over arugula (not much), apples (about a 1/4 apple), a small handful of walnuts, and a tracing of goat cheese in a lightly dressed rosemary vinaigrette.   Flavors were complimentary, the size and price were not.  But it was a good salad.

5 stars--Service, see above

Yah, I'm a fan, especially in New Hope where tourist traps with mediocre food await your wallet.
Great selection of healthy vs unhealthy toppings! They have tons of fresh fruit like blackberries and strawberries and also some cheesecake bites

This is a definitely a great place to have Mexican food in and around Lenox Village. With an impressive choice of tequilas (almost 25) and free chips and salsa, one can unwind under the stars outside or inside, amidst the neat decor. The waiter was extremely friendly and accommodated our vegetarian needs. Why this place gets 4 stars is that it one of the few Mexican joints which readily made me a veggie chimichanga. This is the stuff I used to dig when I went to school and habituated a neat Mexican restaurant and ever since then I have never found a place which would make me a veggie version. The taco salad was ginormous, but tasty. I would totally trip on this place again.

The bartender was very knowledgeable about all the fish options and helped us create a good meal of multiple appetizers. He explained the menu well and how their housemate dips complemented the fish dishes. I enjoyed everything I tried from the raw and chargrilled oysters, the alligator, the gumbo soup, and much to my surprise even the soft shell baby crab. There is a bar and large projector style tv screen upstairs as well as well as dining available outside on the wrap around balcony. Definitely a cool spot worth the wander inside. I've learned that by the outside look of something it is very hard to judge in this town how the restaurant will be.

Pretty good BBQ in St. Pete. Quickie's replaced a different BBQ place, but the layout is similar. I think they mostly just freshened up the paint. The smell of the interior of the restaurant is heavily smoky.

I came here with my family and my parents in law. Service was friendly, if under-staffed. We were able to walk in at 7:30pm on a Friday and get seated right away.

There is a kids menu, but it doesn't exist in physical form. My kids got the mac and cheese with a side of tater tots (I had wanted them to get broccoli, but the restaurant was out of it). They loved the tater tots but the asiago mac and cheese was too fancy for them, I'm afraid.

We started with the bacon wrapped shrimp, which were excellent. I had the "pick two" with brisket, spare ribs, collard greens, and green beans. The brisket was passable. The spare ribs were excellent, very meaty, with a nice dry rub. I really enjoyed both the collard greens and green beans. My husband had the pork 3 ways, and he said that the spare ribs were much better than the baby back ribs, and that the pulled pork was better than average. He enjoyed the green beans too. His other side was a side salad (there's an upcharge for that), which was pretty generic looking.

They have a full bar, although we stuck to beer (or hard seltzer). The kids had juice, and my daughter complained that her orange juice tasted funny.

The parking lot is too small for the size of the restaurant, so you might have to park in the grass off the street.

I love this place,  The pizza is the best thin crust in town!  And the fried chicken and popos are well, yummmm.  I suggest calling ahead to place your order as the chicken takes a while to fry.  They also have a salad bar and a full bar (21 and older please) with gaming.  They also have air hockey and a small arcade.  The place is great for families and get togethers.
I really like the fact that they employ teenagers as they need to learn the value of work and money, besides who want to see a gown man bring them pizza - it is an entry level job.  Although I do think they need a little more supervision as there have been times I have gone in there and some of them are not doing their jobs (on cell phones, sitting while the place is dirty and just ignoring customers.
All in all its a great place!

Not bad for tex-mex cuisine at cheap prices and of course LARGE portions.  I came here a few weeks ago with my boyfriend and it was still crowded at 8:30-9 at night, but we didn't have to wait too long.  Once seated we ordered and the food came out really quickly.  I ordered the Kamehameha Nachos, which was huge!  Yet somehow I still managed to finish it.  Teehee.  My boyfriend got a regular burrito, which he too seemed to enjoy.  For dessert we got the wedding cake and white chocolate raspberry cupcakes- I'd much rather the wedding cake one!  Being a cupcake fanatic, I was pretty impressed by the cupcakes.  They aren't the best cupcakes I've had, but coming from a place that doesn't specialize in desserts, I was pleasantly surprised.  

So the only problem with the place?  The food just didn't seem to wow me.  Yes it was good, but also forgettable.

I tried a slice of buffalo chicken pizza and a slice of sausage. Neither was anything to write home about. The crust was a little burnt too. I went to this place after being in the hospital for 2 days. You would think I would like it having hospital food, but not at all. I only went because it was right down the street from the pharmacy I go to. Eh, bad move. I thought the atmosphere was really cheesy (no pun intended).

I love it! It's cheap, filling and it's delicious. The location could be a little tricky to get to, but there's a front and back parking, a front and back door so don't be afraid to go through the back door. During lunch and dinner hours it may be a little busy, and when I say busy the line may go out the door so try to stay away from those hours.

Must try if you haven't already!

Sometimes the anticipation of a thing is better than the thing itself.  This is NOT the case with Ted Drewes.  I had heard so many glowing recommendations for this fabled frozen custard that when the time came to try it, I nearly turned back for fear that it would be nothing like what I had imagined.

Fortunately I was wrong.

I'm relatively certain the recipe includes fairy dust, unicorn breath, and the egg of a golden goose, because no other ingredients could possibly make such a creamy, rich, robust, and flavorful frozen custard.

The staff was VERY patient with me as I hemmed and hawed, and asked about nearly every type of concrete on the menu.  When I finally decided on the Tadad (magical custard mixed with chopped Dad's oatmeal cookies - SO good) I knew I had made the right decision.

My only regret is that there are only two locations, and neither are in Indianapolis.

I tried again and this time all 5 cups of concrete were dripping and melted. This is just not how concrete is supposed to be so it is just very disappointing, especially for a place that prides itself on serving "concrete" custard. We got the TeDad's, peppermint, brownie, and pistachio. The peppermint was actual crushed peppermint candy so it's very minty. I didn't try the pistachio but it was green and not just nuts folded into vanilla custard. We've also tried the mint and root beer, which are syrups mixed in. The mint was ok but the root beer was not very good. The flavors were fun to try but we'd get something else next time to explore.

Heeeere's a surprise. Sicillian Pasta Kitchen is a pretty decent place for Italian comfort food!  My parents have been talking about this place for years though every time I'm in Edmonton, it never works out for us to go here.  

Just to make sure everyone reading this understands.  This isn't Sicilian style food, it's North American Italian comfort food.  It's also not Italian fine dining fusion either.  We're talking lasagna, fettuccini alfredo, spaghetti and meatball type of place.  On those cold Albertan nights when you need a hot carb-y meal to stick to your bones while your car heats up.
