I had the gnocchi with cream sauce and then they broiled mozzarella cheese on top.  I know, super healthy, right?  However, the gnocchi were soft, the sauce had just the right creaminess to it, and who doesn't like cheese broiled on top of anything?  

It's a casual family restaurant.  Dining room is a decent size with several sections though you are fairly close to other diners so they can fit more people so it's not really an intimate experience but better than a Cheescake Factory or PF Changs.  It's average in decor.  It was a Thursday evening around 5:00 PM and there was ample seating when we arrived, however, the restaurant was full when we left.  It's in a small strip mall that doesn't offer a ton of parking but is likely adequate if the restaurant isn't busy.  They take reservations.

It's a good option for the area if you are looking for a casual place with reasonably priced, larger portioned Italian food and a great place for kids too.

I often go to Panera to pick up bagels for morning meals. The bagel packs are thirteen bagels and two tubs of cream cheese. These bagels always start the meetings on a great note.

Friendly service, good bagels (they can't compare to the bagels in New York and New Jersey, but what can?), and a full menu keep me coming back.

A solid 4 is just about right.  Came here with 2 others this past Saturday for brunch/linner (?) around 2 PM for some boozy grub.

Outdoor seating was nice.  Server was awesome, funny and swayed me towards the bottomless mimosas, which are $15.  At $8 per regular glass, after 2 you've already got your money's worth, so I opted for that.

We started with the short rib nachos, then had our entrees:  1 burger, 1 breakfast burrito and 1 chicken and waffles.  The portions are definitely a tad smaller than they should be for the prices, but everything was very tasty, albeit a little underseasoned.  I think the nachos were actually my favorite, but they can't hold a candle to Los Camaradas.  My breakfast burrito was huge and was filled with a yummy peppery hash (plus I got a heaping mound of salty, addicting fries on the side), but they cut the burrito in half before serving, which is a huge pet peeve.

My friend liked her burger, but didn't love it.  Presentation was just meh, as well.  My BF liked his chicken and waffles (and grits), but without the requested berry jam on the side he probably wouldn't have enjoyed it as much.  Still not as good as The Dutch.  Plus, the plate was too small to maneuver around to eat off.

Overall, I'd be back if I was in the area.  I would like to come back for dinner and cocktails one night and sit inside.

Came here on the Saturday during the Mardi Gras celebration and this place was moderately full =]. I ordered 3 beignets to go for $3.99. Service was slow & cashiers seemed very chatty and uninterested in giving good customer service. we waited about 20 mins until we got our beignets and saw three people who came after us receive their orders.

We got our beignets in a bag with a ton of powdered sugar at the bottom.  It was super messy so I grabbed a fork =] best way to eat it is to tear at a piece with a fork, shake the bag to recoat the beignets with powdered sugar and then tear at a piece again with a fork and eat it. 

A lot of people raved about Cafe du monde, but I personally like Cafe Beignet a lot better. If you like your beignets super doughy and soft, go to cafe du monde.  If you like it a little crunchy on the outside & super soft in the middle go to Cafe Beignet

I love, love, LOVE this Rouses! The staff is really friendly for the most part and I never find myself looking around frantically for help. 

The burrito bar yields HUGE burritos for about $6. The pizza is sold by the slice for about $3. They sell the dough for about $1 a bag.

The deli section is great, everyone there is super helpful. 

The bakery section has lots of sweet treats and the breads always  taste fresh.

Then, of course, we have the cheese section. Best cheeses in any Rouses I have ever been too. Lots of great cured meats as well. Pair these with some of their fresh produce and you are good to go!

An easy 4 stars for this place, which I am quickly becoming a regular!  The menu has many tasty items listed, pretty much forcing me to come back again to try them!  I've been in for brunch twice and was pleased on each visit.  

Most recently, I had the White Chocolate Belgium Waffle, served with Honey Butter and maple syrup.  It was so sweet and delicious!   I knew I wanted something to balance out the sweet so I got a couple eggs on the side.  These also came with home fries and I was pleased to see I was only charged 4 bucks for this addition.  

They have a full bar, and plenty to offer.  The atmosphere seems a bit formal, but the friendly servers take the formal edge off.  I'd like to see more brunch options, but the main menu has a lot to choose from including Chicken and Waffles, which I see in my near future!

Service was a little slow on our last visit, but we did walk right in the door at opening so that might be expected.  Overall, I'm very happy and can't wait to further explore that menu!

I loved Zea.  This past weekend I traveled to New Orleans for an extended romantic weekend.  I was recommended to come to Zea from the owner of the B&B we stayed at.  Upon our arrival we were greeted with friendly staff.  I was highly impressed that the menu had a fantastic selection or food.  I was more impressed with the prices.  I had the half rack of wet Thai stylist ribs for only $14.  When the ribs came out I wa impressed with how big they were.  They looked like a full rack to me.  The meat was very tender and the food was filled with flavor.  

Now, I'm from  Texas & we are big on our BBQ.  I was impressed.  The food was great and extremely affordable.  My plate would have been double the price easily back at home.  I definitely got my moneys with & will stop by the next time I'm back in town.  The dirty rice was so de-lish that I wanted to place a big order to take home with me.  The closest we have to dirt rice is Pop Eyes.   I'm embarrassed to say that we ate every bite & did not have left overs to take home.  The staff was super friendly and the restaurant was clean & beautiful.  I loved how you could see the kitchen though the glass window.  Very classy appeal.   5 Stars to you Zea!

A friend from work introduced me to this restaurant some time ago. I didn't think there were any good Chinese restaurants in Mercer county, but this place proved me wrong. The spicy Szechuan chicken is quite spicy but amazing. My parents joined me here once for dinner, and my dad still raves about that chicken. The chili beef in oil is also quite delicious.

I will say, though, that I went with some friends for dinner once and learned that while they are really good for main dishes, their appetizers are not so good.

My favorite stop on the way home for a super big ice coffee. Everything is fresh, the occasional brownie or blondie delish, and staff is always pleasant. Sign up for their frequent shopper card and get free stuff.

Nom! Nom! Nom! Very few restaurants have made their way into my cell phone contacts but Black Thorn has most definitely made the list.

I've had Chicago style pizza many times, and would have to say that it's not exactly the same, but exhibits some similar qualities:
1) It takes forever to bake, so order at least 45 minutes in advance (hence why I keep their number in my phone!)
2) the sauce is very thick and tomato-like
3) the crust is thick, but not Chicago style thick

Besides that, Black Thorn pizza has a taste all it's own. And it's delicious! Paired with a pitcher of beer and it's a gorge-fest for sure! 

The only reason it's a 4 and not a 5-star review is because it's usually really smokey in the restaurant and their call for pick up system is somewhat archaic. The loud speaker from which orders are called is very difficult to hear/understand...I think it's from 1975. Other than that, it's a "must" in STL anytime.

I think it's all hype. Based on Yelp reviews, I ordered the CG - Oyster and was not happy.  I bit into shell a number of times and I wasn't a fan of the flavor of their sauce.  

I ordered a Caesar salad on the side and that too was not the best quality.  There were a few brown leaves in my salad and the dressing tasted store bought,  with canned parmesan cheese on top.  

I don't plan on going back to Drago's.

I can't believe I haven't made a point to review Remedy yet! I come here on a fairly regular basis and don't see that changing any time soon.

When I first moved to Edmonton a year and a half ago, I was told by countless people that I "needed" to try the chai at Remedy. Once I finally made a point to check it out, I completely understood the enthusiasm. It's absolutely fantastic. I especially enjoy the Kashmiri chai which is flavoured with pistachios and rose petals. Divine! Plus it's decaf so you don't need to worry about grabbing one before bed.

As for the food, I find Remedy to be hit or miss. You can order the same dish two days in a row and end up eating something that tastes completely different. Sometimes it's fantastic and sometimes it's nothing particularly special. It's never been very bad though. I do love how vegan/vegetarian friendly the menu is. I tend to order the vegan butter chicken whenever I go here for food. Yummy!

My biggest issue is how slow the service can be. I honestly don't really blame the staff for this one. I don't know how the managers can justify having one person on the counter on a Friday night. It's ALWAYS busy at Remedy so this shouldn't be a surprise. Don't go here if you're in a hurry at all.

We came in on a Saturday afternoon (around 2:30-ish) and it was PACKED.  I don't think I've ever driven past this place and not seen it packed, so I wasn't really surprised.  The line moved fairly quickly and I noted that if we had gone next door to Five Guys, we'd be waiting just as long.
It seems we hit them on a bad day though - they were out of chips, lettuce (and later, cheese, but luckily that was after we already got our food).  Also, when we got to pay, we ordered margaritas, but then learned that they were also out of stuff to make margaritas.  Hmm. Oh, and there were no forks, only spoons.  I guess it was a delayed shipment, but it's surprising that a business open for a few months is still running into these problems, especially since this is a chain.
Anyway, all that aside, the burritos were awesome. We both got steak burritos (and a negra modelo).  I got the corn, guacamole, the hottest sauce, black beans, and brown rice on mine.  The corn was super sweet, the guacamole was not skimped on (which almost makes the $1.75(!!!) worth it), and the sauce was awesomely spicy (but I did put some chipotle Tabasco on a few bites).  The pinto beans looked a little weird, but I typically go with black beans anyway.  And, although the rice wasn't crunchy, I think it could have been cooked for just a tab longer.
The restaurant was a little dirty, but I'm not surprised - there were so many people and tables were getting snatched up so quickly, there wasn't really any time for them to get cleaned.
It's too bad that you can't have your margarita or beer out on the patio, it'd be nice on a warm day.
Anyway, the wait is worth it, but don't go in expecting a quick experience.

So this is my second visit to New Orleans, and I've been to a lot of the must go places. Any person you ask will say that you have to get the famous Beignets from Cafe Du Monde which I have tried, but to me I think that Cafe Beignet is really special when it comes to beignets. The beignets at Cafe Beignet are light and airy if that makes sense. They have a great texture that can only be described by going to get one. I recommend anyone that is looking for nice treat to give this place a chance. 

I believe there are three location which include Bourbon street. The cafe is not super busy and fast with service. The decor is so cute and French inspired. I think my mouth loves the Beignets more than my waste, but hey that's what the gym is for. Awesome is the only word that I can think of for Cafe Beignet!

This place closes at 10 on the weekdays. Just a FYI. Because we tried to come by twice during the week and it was always after a full day of walking around and we were looking for something a little sweet before heading back to our hotel. But it was always closed. Finally we came back on a weekend (a little earlier but it opens till 11 on weekends, I think) and it was packed. They're located inside a jazz courtyard area where a jazz band was playing live. You can just stand around and watch/listen or there's tables scattered all over if you wanted food from Café Beignet. We walked up to the counter though and just got an order of beignets to go. It took a little while to come out - it was busy and they do offer other foods besides beignets and I'm sure they make it to order since it was piping hot when it came out. Also they first brought it out on a plate before we corrected them and they went back and put it in a bag. As for the beignets themselves, did not stack up to the Café du Monde at all. The batter must've not been thoroughly mixed because there were like little clumps in the dough. It was a very odd texture and I didn't particularly enjoy it. Other than that - lots of powdered sugar and taste-wise, it was good. Also it's a bit more expensive than du Monde's. Might come back to try there food food but I think I will stick to the original Café du Monde for their beignets.

When I attended my showing of Book of Mormon at Forrest Theatre I caught a glimpse of Bareburger opening across the street. So being the burger lover that I am I instantly bookmarked and planned to attend before one of my next concert extravaganzas. And while trying it out before I went to see Lykke Li led to a 3.5 star experience mostly due to me ordering wrong, I do have to curve a bit higher to to their commitment to local and organic goods, and their eclectic selection of burgers.

As son as I read the menu and saw meat burgers made from beef, wild boar, goat, bison and then some; and veggie burgers made from either black bean or sweet potato & wild rice, my mind was instantly blown by the prospects. Especially when I was gazing upon the eclectic artwork of the menu and crazy interior decor that the place had to offer in the process.But ultimately I went with the Grindhouse for the Elk meat, country bacon, manchego cheese, and paprika mayo that it had to offer. But while it certainly was a filling burger, it just didn't offer any of the spicy or gamy tastes that I was expecting from such a combination. In fact I hardly tasted both the manchego and country bacon; and as a former cheese monger who has sold Manchego's of various ages, and an avid bacon addict, that was a serious first.

But despite the burger that was devoid of the flavors and ingredients that I was expecting, Bareburger won me over with everything else. while not the best I've had the side of fries were flavorful and plentiful. The spicy pickles that were more than just cucumber packed a sufficient and sour wallop, and the classic lemonade was quite refreshing.

With 14 signature burgers & a big time create your own burger menu, 6 salads & 5 signature sandwiches, and all kinds of milkshakes and fountain sodas; Bareburger has plenty to offer for both carnivores and veggie lovers alike. And while my first burger didn't deliver as expected, I'm definitely enticed enough to give it a few more attempts to come!

I've been here 4 times already. The first couple of times my hot pockets were excellent with  crusts that were fresh and flaky. The problem is when the hot pockets and pizza are not fresh and need to be reheated. The bread ends up tasting soggy and not good at all. I think this is the kind of place you go in the mornings for fresh goods, but when late afternoons and evenings come, the amount of foot traffic is probably not great so the food sits behind the counter for a while. Also, I'm not sure what's up with the cashier girl behind the counter. She seems like she really doesn't want to be there.

So not sure if they the restaurant was under contruction or whatever but happy hour ended up being at the bar area by the pool. Which was fine with us. 

We got the brussel sprouts which were really tasty. We got the wings which had a thick herb topping on it. The wings were crispy and good but the herb topping and sauce were kind of lacking. We also got a salad that I cant remember in detail but I remember there were apples in it. It was crisp and refreshing. The drinks were kind of weak which was disappointing.

This is my second time at B&B and this place doesn't disappoint. The Kale salad with bang bang chicken is  great. The bourbon wings are so so. Friendly staff and chill environment, definitely worth checking out.

Ease of check-in/check-out was a 5.

Noise level inside the room (30) was a 3.

Parking is tight and street parking is very limited.

It is less than one block from the beach, but none of the rooms have a view. The rooms were cute, a little run down and the tv was small and far away from the bed, which made it hard to watch while in bed.

5 stars for ease of brining my dogs ($15 extra per pet per night). Dogs are not allowed on the hospitality room and are not allowed to stay in the room alone.

Wine and limited cheese/crackers in the evening and coffee/pastries in the morning. The coffee was pretty darn good.

Wow - I've spent years trying to find Chile Rellenos like I grew up with so I could take my Mom there...sadly, she passed over four years before I found El Merendero.

This will be my Mother's Day tribute review:

Mom - you would've loved the Chile Rellenos here - light, fluffy, tender, tasted fantastic.  Just like we used to get 30+ years ago.  Wish I could've taken you here.  I miss you (probably why I'm still always on the hunt for the best Chile Rellenos - I think I found them, but I'll keep trying, just in case).

The beans were fantastic, and the tortilla - wow!

This is some good chow!!!

This is probably my favorite Safeway in the old pueblo.  I usually stop by here on my lunch and get a quick bite from the deli department.  Food is always fresh and staff is always friendly.  I think they have recently updated their "sushi" bar to include better quality sushi.  Yes, I am guilty of grocery store sushi, but in all honesty, theirs is not bad!

This

Service was absolutely amazing. I can't not speak highly enough about how wonderful the people are at this place. We came without a reservation and were informed that they could take us right then, but they had a table coming in an hour. PERFECT! :-) I took a seat while my husband went driving around. I ordered right away so I wouldn't take up a lot of their time. Unfortunately, my husband spend literally half an hour trying to find parking. I requested the food be packed to go because I was afraid I would run out of time they gave us. Then right when I asked them to pack it up, he found a spot. The server was so kind and made us a whole new dish. I can not thank them enough!!!! You can tell when someone is genuinely nice vs nice in front of your face and then when they get to the back, want to throw a tray at the wall. At the end of our meal, they apologized (I don't even know why!!!) They said sorry for making us feel rushed (which they didn't) and even gave us a complimentary dessert to go. This is what I call true service. 

Onto the food - This is a place that seems like they change their menu often (based on what is available and fresh), so I do not want to get into much detail on each dish we ordered, but I must say that everything we ate was DELICIOUS! The risotto was nice and light and so flavorful. All of their foods had a balance of sweet, salty, savory, etc. It was just perfect. The scallops were seared wonderfully and the beef was cooked to perfection. I can not tell you how much I loved it here. Oh, and the muffin bread....OMG! It's like crack. I loved it. Mmmm, so buttery and moist and flaky. I hope they serve this on an everyday basis!

Next time, i will make sure to make a reservation. :-) Thank you for such an amazing date night with my husband!

If you ask the tourists, they will tell you ACME is the best place to get oysters. If you ask the locals they will tell you skip ACME, don't waste your time- because DRAGO'S is the place to be!!!

My fiancé and I stopped into Drago's on a Thursday around noon for nothing more than oysters. Lucky for us we scored spots at the oyster grill and got to watch the quick shucking, prep and rotation of oysters on and off the grill. The oysters BBQ-ing on the grill looked mouth wateringly delicious, soaking up the buttery, garlic, herb parmesan sauce poured on top. We ended up ordering a dozen raw ($13) and a dozen chargrilled oysters ($18).

The raw oysters here huge compared to anything we've seen on the west coast. They were served with lemon and a cocktail sauce. The oysters were fresh and tasted really good. 

The chargrilled oysters were everything you could imagine and more. They were served hot off the grill and dripping with sauce with a side of garlic bread. You could taste the grilled flavor of the oyster with the buttery concoction. I think my fiancé ended up wiping the plate clean of the sauce with his garlic bread. 

The service was excellent. Our waiter was prompt and made sure we had everything we needed. Believe it or not, as much as we wanted to stay and eat more we were in and out in about 30 minutes. We were on vacation and had more places to see and try! I highly recommend trying the oysters at Drago's even if your have your mind set on visiting ACME and Felix's. One other observation we made was right after eating at Drago's on our way to Deanie's we walked passed ACME and their line was ridiculously long. Avoid the wait, go to Drago's for better oysters and excellent service.

Bubble tea is as delicious as it is addictive, and there is no better place to sample its sweet taste than at The Tea Cottage.  The no-frills, non-descript interior of wooden chairs and tables are accented by the crates of fresh fruits and boxes of syrup bottles that line the walls.  Behind the counter there are usually two server working furiously to keep up with the demand and lineups.

But what exactly is "bubble tea" you ask?  Don't let the name fool you.  Many of the drinks don't even have tea in them.  The "bubble" part refers to the spaces in the wide straw between the soft balls of tapioca that one slurps up in the process of drinking.  The tapioca is referred to by the Asian name "Sago" and are chewy, golden-brown balls made from the starch of sweet potatoes.  They also look like bubbles, which is an alternate explanation for the drink's name. For people who dislike the texture, the drinks can be made without sago but it's worth trying - the sago is essentially flavourless and a lot of fun to chew!

The drinks themselves have a syrup or fresh fruit base, mixed with milk, juice, or tea.  They are 32 ounces and shaken in a plastic cup, over which a colourful thin plastic cover is attached.  When the drink is ready, the customer stabs the very wide straw through the cover, and enjoys pure taste pleasure.

Syrup-based drinks are very sweet and available in a variety of fruit flavours.  There are also coffee varieties, from plain coffee to mocha, to coffee with almond.  By far the most popular drinks are the ones with fresh fruit.  Mixed with ice, fruit, syrup, and the milk, juice, or tea base, the creation is essentially a smoothie with a sweet kick.   Some of the varieties include strawberry, cantaloupe, and avocado.  Yes, avocado is a fruit, and it makes a very tasty smoothie - a nutty flavour with just a hint of sweetness.

Since bubble tea originated in Taiwan, there are also a lot of uniquely Asian flavours to try, such as the gritty and vanilla-like taro root and lychee.  You can find all of this and more at the Tea Cottage, as well as a variety of hot coffee and tea drinks.  So get adventurous, and you might just find yourself going back for more.

I tried to make a spa appointment for my husband for Father's Day looked on Groupon ans that's how I found this location the price was right but never had a chance to go there because I called over the phone to see if we can make an appointment and the young lady said 3:00pm then she said hold on then she said 3:30pm. I said okay then she asked me if she can call me back I said sure because I was driving and my husband was trying to get the information. Then she calls me back and says can you come at 4 Mrs. T and I said sure so me and my husband was on our way there 13 minutes away soon as we pulled into the parking lot she called me and said Mrs T can you come at 7:00pm I said enough is enough no thank you thanks for trying to get us in. Because which it was on a humbug this was a first time that I called she hould've looked in the book and said that the time was booked instead of me keep holding on and keep calling me back and forth the price was right we might try it again but for right now we're getting ready to go have something to eat and we might try then in a later date. And We might go and find another massage later today. And what's so crazy about it is we found a place I told my husband I just want to take a peek at it took a picture and the parking lot is not even crowded I believe they don't have enough staff but I would like to come back and give them a try. And that's why I gave them a two star if we have went and got a massage and how the people treated us then it probably would have been more but for right now is it to start limit and she tried to get us in and that's another reason why she. And what's so crazy about it is I came all the way from Philly getting my car checked out at the PACIFICO dealer and I ask my husband would he like to go get a massage and that's why we went over to New Jersey.We have to find somewhere over here to eat and also I would love to still do I massage but hot stone spa will not have our money today. I had to get back on here and to let y'all know don't you know the hot stone spa text me and told me that they are ready for us. And our appointment is at 5:00pm. I told my husband check this text out which I was thinking it was from my job and we had just came from eating and doing a little bit of shopping do they really think that I'm coming back their today at the all this confusion heck to the no I'm getting ready to go home pull my shoes off drink a glass of wine and relax. I'll see y'all on a next go-round. And the person that was answering the phone is really confused and y'all need to get her straightened out because you're going to lose a lot of customers.

Very good concept. My family thoroughly enjoyed it, but it missed the mark for me. 

Kids all got, mac & Cheezy signature sandwich. It was literally cheesy sandwiches with Mac n cheese piled on top. The kids loved it and was in heaven. My husband got the crawgator signature sandwich and loved it also. I got "the juice", after viewing the screen with the pictures scrolling. 

However when I got the sandwich, the meat was pulverized, and looked like potted meat. Then my green peppers were missing also. I asked them to takes it back to add my peppers. By the time this evolution took place, I bit into my bread and it was too soggy for me to eat more than 1 bite. Not sure if I would go back here again.

Just popped in with hubby for a small snack and sat at the bar. Ordered the 1/2 Yucatán shrimp which is a special for them because I smelt the garlic from someone else at the bar, best decision ever. It's the best peel n eat shrimp I've ever had and I honestly need more. I could make a whole meal out of it. The bread that comes with it is out of control delicious, warm n soft perfect for dipping (pro tip) lol enjoy!

yumm! great ice cream. probably best in the city. perfect for hot nights with a date (milkshake, two straws-- anyone?). if you're having a hard time finding a parking spot on the street, park in the CVS parking lot across the street

I Like:

-  Their barbacoa beef.  It's like a beef roast, just falling apart and full of flavor.
-  The freshness of their ingredients.
-  The slight lime-flavor to their rice.

I Don't Like:

-  The fact that chips are extra.
-  At THIS LOCATION, there is not a lot of seating.
-  It's just a touch pricey, at least compared to Moe's, Chili Burrito, and others.  

Okay, so it's a bit more expensive than Moe's and the other "deluxe burrito fast/casual" chains.  It's also just a bit tastier.

This is the nice new TBBC West have location with some cool wooden tables and long bar inside and an outside patio. Very tasty beer offerings as well as mixed drinks. Good service when we were there. Seems to be a well executed spinoff of a Tampa classic.

My friends were raving about this place so I knew I had to check it out to see what the fuss was all about. They were telling me that one of those food shows did an episode there and it was clearly one of the best places to eat.

I went there one night and ordered a rib meat mac & cheese that was sandwiched in between two Texas toasts.

Very good. I approve of Eats!

I don't know what the big deal is about this brand. Maybe you have to 'be there' as an Elite Yelper in the newest store to get the full experience. I dunno, but somehow I doubt it. 

Nothing wrong with this location just as there's nothing inherently WRONG with this ice cream, but none of the flavors I tried made me want to keep buying it. The first one I ever tried was the Brambleberry Crisp. Did not even finish the pint. The 'crisp' part was annoying to eat, very hard in comparison to the other ingredients and I did not find the fruit swirl to be especially tasty.

The Darkest Chocolate, which I bought at Whole Foods, was fine but I will continue buying Haagen Dazs chocolate over this. I think it tastes better.

Pistachio Macaron, also purchased at Whole Foods, was too sweet and there was a dearth of pistachios. Again, I'll take Haagen Daz Pistachio over this, as it is absolutely loaded with large pistachio pieces, the flavor base is mild and it doesn't put me into a sugar coma. Talenti Pistachio gelato is a second runner up to Haagen Daz's for a full nut experience.

Sure, it's nice that Jeni Bauer has been around since the late 1990, started out small and is now nationwide. Kudos to an enterprising, hard working woman. Even though I don't eat ice cream very often, $12 a pint is an extravagance for me, especially as none of the flavors appeal in the least.

Taste is highly subjective and clearly Ms. Bauer has an enormous fan base that doesn't include me.

My friend and I took this tour when we were in town and we LOVED it. We found the deal on GroupOn and were able to book it the next day. We had so much fun. Our tour guide was awesome and very friendly and knowledgeable. We were totally full at the end of the tour. I've already recommended it to a few friends and family the next time they're in the area. It was fun walking around to the different restaurants, trying the different foods and getting a bit of history of the city, as well. Totally worth it-- make sure to check it out.

A must go for Frenchman street. Out of all places that has live music, it is the only one that has both great food and tasty cocktails. 

I got the wildflower cocktail, it is absolutely amazing! One of the best I have had. The drinks are all quite unique and I might have to warn you ahead of time that the bartenders have a heavy hand. If you are light weighted just get a beer. 

For food, it is mainly small plates so probably best to share with another person. I got the crostini, pork belly and gumbo. They all taste fantastic even though my fav is the pork belly. 

Highly recommend!

It's really not that bad, guys! Sure, you have to wait in line for a while compared to other stores because they never have enough people up front, but I find that they usually have what I need. They have an organic produce section, all of their produce is fresh and is comparable to Safeway or maaaaybe raleys. They seem to always have deals in various items and they have a surprising wide selection of pet products. Sure we would all love to shop at whole foods 24/7 but when or if you need to save some money, skip walmart or Safeway and come here!

This restaurant is evaluating for their food not their local brew beer. The two star was given due to after food experience. After dine their food I have to go to restroom several time. It take me a day to clear my stomach pain. Some of the food is not up to the quality. 

The restaurant do have a lot of customers. Seem like a good joint. Especially the private local brew beer. It has the brewery just next to it with tour. I did not try it. I am straight to the restaurant. 

I got the blackened rock shrimp and the Belgium Blonde. I like the Belgium blonde beer. The rock shrimp dish include the spinach fettuccine, mushroom, andouille sausage, yellow bell pepper. The sauce is creamy. The rock shrimp is firm. Not sure which item did not measured up cause stomach diarrhea. May be the sauce. Anyhow my experience is not good with the food.
Perfectly mediocre takeout Chinese.  I get the mixed veggies with tofu and yes, it does have too much oil in it but this isn't Chinatown.

I've heard from people who know chaat that the "chaat" at Mood Cafe is not authentic at all.  The food is still good, though, so my advice for reducing cognitive dissonance in experienced chaat-eaters is to come here, eat the food & ignore the fact that they're calling it "chaat".

The chaat here is full of crispy bits, as well as bits of fresh vegetables (radish, onion), nuts, and sauces or chutneys. In addition to the Crazy Chaat I've had before, I also quite like the Punjabi Chaat -- it has the crispy bits and sweetness I like. Samosa chaat was fine; the samosa was warm, soft and comforting, pretty standard.  Shahi chaat has lots of nuts, but the combination of textures didn't suit me.

Lassis are good here. I've had rose and cardamom lassis & they were both good.

Mood Cafe has great vegetarian options that are good, healthy, and fresh. I highly recommend them!  Be aware that there isn't much seating inside.

The first sit-down dinner place I tried in Reno, and happily, still one of the best in town!

M3 http://m3reno.com/ seems to be Version3 
of Moxie's of Reno http://moxiesreno.com/
--- and, having tried them all, I can tell you that M3 has all my love, in-spite of it not being the closest to my house. 

Now, that's not based on the service by fine folks, but the more extended and awesome menu choices available at M3.

( Good news: I was chatting with one of the owners in Feb2016, and they are planning on extending the Menus at the other 2 Moxies to include some of the hits from M3! 
Hooray!!!)
-=-
Highlights:
ANY of their Steak or Salmon dishes, Get the Tacos!...

 with my deep love and thanks for their Atkins Plate (aka LowCarb/Paleo/Keto Style)
===
ATKINS $13
chicken breast or hamburger patty /  choice of cheese / avocado  mushrooms / choice of two sides- cottage cheese / sliced tomatoes / napa slaw / soup /salad flank steak $14 salmon $15
===
M3 QUESADILLA also excellent.

Good soups everyday!

The desserts are a little hit and miss, but that's likely on me... I don;t have the sweet tooth I used to... so many desserts are off-the-charts sugary to me.

Was glad to see they were open late on a Friday night - open til 10, we got there about 9:20.  We had the larb gai, the green curry with chicken and the duck fried rice.

Sounds like a very similar menu to what lived in this spot before.

The food was good, the staff was very friendly.

We sat outside at a picnic table in front of the truck next to a small water fountain/feature that helped with the Dale Mabry road traffic noise.

I need another visit and try another dish to make another assessment.  But so far, it's a quick, good Thai fix.

A late Sunday lunch at this petite eatery came at an ease. There were plenty of available tables to choose from. 

We ordered the yakisoba with lamb sausage and shio koji corn ramen. The yakisoba was extremely heavy with spices, snap peas, mushrooms, and cucumber raita. The sausages were tasty and had a crispy texture. The cucumber raita was thick and yogurt-like. The contents went well with each other, but in hindsight, I wished I had ordered the cold noodles instead. This yakisoba is more suitable for the cold weathers. At the end of my meal, I was perspiring. (To be fair, I think the air conditioner could've been turned higher. It was a 90 degree day and the restaurant was overly warm.) The shio koji corn ramen was a lighter fare with arugula, enoki, corn, and roasted tomato. It was an interesting and innovative mix.

Along the wall, they have produce, produce organic, deli, prepared foods, seafood, butcher, packaged lunch meats, frozen seafood, the bakery, dairy, florist, and then pharmacy.

The store is clean with 2 entrances and an extra entrance to the florist and gift shop.  They have a selection of balloons and will make you a balloon bouquet.

There's a decent wine/beer/liquor section in the center of the store.

In general, prices are higher here, but the selection is usually decent, and products are fresh.  If you can only shop in the evenings, go on a Tuesday.  I think their newest deliveries arrive on Tuesdays, it's the day after the latest sale has started, and it's not very busy.

I had been asked to check out this place, but for some reason had never gotten around to it. Coincidentally, a friend asked if I wanted to go, so off we went! I am so happy I visited this restaurant, because the whole experience was great. You know how you get great service and not so great food or vice versa? I appreciate that this was the whole package and wish I found that at more places. I am a little sad that it took me so long, considering it is right down the street from my house; but now that I have been, it has been added to the list. 

You know how some days you just want a nice cold Rum Punch after work? It happened to be that day, and it was the best rum punch ever. Rum punch may not be important to you, but it is my favorite drink. 

I suggest making a reservation, so you can be seated upon arrival. I chose to sit inside because I don't like to melt in the summer.  However, during spring, autumn, or winter, sitting outside would be splendid. 

I was seated and my server was Phil (Hi Phil!) - he was great! I had a couple questions about different things on the menu and which he preferred, and he knew the items inside/out. We started with Ceviche. I am no ceviche connoisseur, but it is by far the best I have had yet. It was so... perfect. Refreshing, light, and I would return just for the ceviche. Did I mention the ceviche was superb? It makes me smile just thinking about it.

I ordered the crispy skin salmon, which comes with green beans and fingerling potatoes. I need to tell you about the Poblano citrus salsa - it made the dish. I love salmon, and I love skin-on salmon; crispy skin-on salmon? Oh yes indeed. The Poblano citrus salsa though - I need this in my life. It was just so... heavenly.

My friend had the taco salad. I didn't taste hers, nor did I want to; I was too busy with my own food. She cleaned her plate, mentioned how good it was. One can presume it was good, since there was little conversation once the food arrived. 

A few more rum punches, a couple more margaritas for my friend, and we were satiated. But alas, there was dessert to be had! If you know either of us, you know we both have a slight sweet tooth (ok fine: *I* have a sweet tooth). I ordered the chocolate ganache and she ordered the flourless chocolate. The flourless chocolate was good; but I need you to know the ganache was decadent and rich and makes your sweet tooth sing. The desserts are handmade - e.g. made by hand from scratch. Upon recollection, I only got one bite because my friend ate all of my ganache. 

Thank you for a wonderful evening!

Before I met my husband I thought I knew what fine dining was, but I just knew what fine dining was in Colorado. 

On our first trip to New Orleans, many years ago, he took me here for dinner. We had a six course meal of the most petite and perfect courses, from oysters prepared 3 ways to sweet potato soup, salad greens, fish, white chocolate dessert. I can't remember all of the details because it was ten years ago, but now every time we go to NOLA we make a point to eat here and have never been disappointed, even after Katrina!! 

I distincly remember being surprised that we had eaten a full six courses, but they were such perfect portions that we never felt stuffed, just sated.

Save your pennies, it costs us $100/person with alcohol and tip, but this is truly a memorable experience. They have an impressive port selection too. 

Service: if you want to know what it feels like to have a personal butler, eat here. They must have three people serving each table, it seems like they anticipate your needs before they even occur to you! 

Epicure Tip: they sell a cookbook, buy it. I have made a number of recipes from it and they are easy and great, plus it tells you about the history of the family that owns the restaurant. 

Epicure tip #2- if you're broke but still want to check it out, the bar serves food too- you can get some apps and ambiance for $40

We will be back 02/08, I should make my resy now 'cause they book up!

Edit 02/10/08 - It is still the greatest dining experience I've ever had: house-cured salmon, caesar salad, corn and shrimp chowder, sauteed spinach, asparagus with Boursin melted over it (I never would have thought these two would go so well together but am going to try this at home, it was awesome!) , two glasses of Jordan Cab, strawberry shortcake- and I still could walk! I love that they portion and pace everything perfectly so you can taste all that they are capable of while still feeling comfortable. Tab was again $100/head and I have no regrets- it was worth every single penny and we will be back again in two more years.

For a restaurant week date night, I decided it was time to try Bistro La Baia. I have passed this cute little Italian spot plenty of times walking through my neighborhood and checked out the mixed reviews here on Yelp. My boyfriend and I decided we'd see for ourselves what we thought of Bistro La Baia.

We were easily able to make our reservation by calling about a week in advance. While on the phone they let us know that they are BYOB. I noticed that past reviews note that it is cash only, but we learned that they do accept cards now. Upon our arrival for our Sunday night dinner, we were seated immediately, and brought water and bread with oil and balsamic.

Contrary to other reviews, the service was extremely prompt. We placed our full orders from starters to desserts and within minutes our first dishes were brought out. We were so shocked by the quick service that I checked the time, and learned we had been there 15 minutes when our entrees arrived. The entire experience start to finish took 48 minutes, but we did not feel rushed at all. I was seriously blown away considering what I had read from others regarding slow service being a big issue.

To eat, we started with the Eggplant Rollatini and Arancini. The Arancini was not crisp on the outside, but the flavor was good and the sauce was delicious. The Eggplant Rollatini was delicious and similar to the arancini, the sauce was perfection. I'm super picky when it comes to tomato sauce and I would genuinely eat this with a spoon. For entrees, my boyfriend had the Pappardelle con Salsiccia. The pasta was fresh, sausage was flavorful, and the sauce was delicious. The dish was very hot temperature wise as well, which was great because we made our walk over in the snow. For my entree, I had the Chicken Parmesan which was a gamble on my part. I tend to skip ordering chicken parm out, because I'm really picky. However, the picture of the dish on their website intrigued me so I went for it. I'm so glad that I did! The chicken was not crispy, but it was thinly sliced and portioned well. I ordered a side of veggies with it instead of the pasta. The veggies were so well seasoned! For dessert, we tried the Chocolate Cake and Panna Cotta. Both were great, but we both preferred the chocolate cake.

From start to finish, the service was attentive, the food was delicious, and the portions for the price were perfect. We're super excited to return with friends and enjoy this neighborhood BYOB gem!

Really nice area with lots of events going on. I went ice skating here recently and had an amazing time. Plus there are always events going on here. It's a really happening spot with great views and lots to do.

Amazing selection of ice creams, both boozy and plain. 

Had the popcorn flavor, I loved the buttery popcorn flavor but could've done without the harder little kernels. Soggy popcorn bits didnt add too much for me, maybe caramel popcorn would've been better?

If I didn't have a wife that wasn't a snowball connoisseur, I would have never known that Lou-Lou's even existed.  Located on Papworth Street in Metairie, this small stand is just a hundred feet off the "river side" of Veterans Memorial Blvd.  In the world of NOLA /Metairie snowball stands, this place is relatively new and offers most standard flavors; including a dual flavored soft serve ice cream machine.

The only flavor I have sampled so far was the chocolate cream; which was pretty good.  The chocolate was not so sweet that all you tasted was sugar; so the real chocolate taste came through.  They've got the ice perfect, and you'll never confused this with shaved ice, as it literally disappears as soon as it hits your tongue.  I also had the opportunity to try the vanilla soft serve ice cream and it was also good to go.

The best thing about Lou-Lou's is the location, as it's one of the few locations located at the foot of Vets.  And there was also no real line to speak of, so I was able to walk right up and get my fix.

Starbucks. The usual sort. A seriously crappy parking lot kinda sucks the awesome out of the joint, and I'm not a fan of the velvet chairs (the leather on S Howard is superior)

And the phalanx of loser smokers out front kinda ruins the entry... but thats everywhere these days, so I can't blame Starbucks for idiot addicts killing themselves...

Friendly and helpful staff make it all OK. :-)

RSVP is strongly recommended and can also be done online. Food is flavorful and delicious. The ambience is classy and colorfully playful. Drinks are quite good too but beware the margaritas are stronger than they taste! Service each time I've been have been excellent. Prices are mid-range. I'll be back for that queso!

We had been wanting to go here for a while and finally made the time. It was a quiet day after work, which was fine, I can live without a crowded bar. For drinks, we tried the Gran ginger fizz which was pretty good and the 2nd Street Sazerac which was just ok. We decided to order some appetizers and he had the chicken spring rolls, he said they were ok. I had the country cauliflower, not ok. They were much too salty which I felt took away from the health factor that I was going for. The service was great and the atmosphere was cool, but I don't think this place is for me.

OMG! Their Char-Grilled Oysters were orgasmic!

Drago's boasts having the Original Char-Grilled Oysters. Kudos for such an inventive dish! So delicious and large and buttery and cheesy and smokey! The bread was fresh and perfectly crusty and they serve just enough to sop up the wonderful juices left behind. 

This is my "must-eat" pick for New Orleans! Kudos Drago's!

Decor: 4/5
Service: 3/5 
Food: 1/5

I got the special and had them get me one of each fried chicken.
Props for trying to be unique but I wasn't impressed with the texture or taste. The only thing that I liked was the locally brewed soda

This is a great restaurant with fresh ingredients and amazing food!
On Monday January  9 , 2017 Angie was an excellent server with a pleasant smile while being very friendly.

Angie was very accommodating by providing me with my infused  cumber water .
The staff highlight today was the exceptionally pleasant Host who seated us and my server Angie.

Lets get to the food. I had the salmon Fresca with a mimosa, both of which were good.

Wow we had an incredible great luncheon for  the first of the year 2017 with many more to come!
You own it to yourself to have lunch here it always yummy!

One of my favorite dish is Salmon Fresca!


Gloria~


My experience today was amazing! November 16,2016 time 2:58pm 
The General Manager Vin Lambrecht  was very accommodating with excellent service from him and the staff!

Thank you Vin  for being so amazing! 

Gloria~

So sad this gem of a restaurant will be closing for good in a week. They have the best pizza in town! I had the cherry picker for the first time tonight (my hubby always wants meat pizzas!) and it was amazing! Their margaritas and ice cream are also delicious! Reno is going to miss you!

I returned to Szechuan House, the hidden treasure of a restaurant found on Rt. 33 in Hamilton Township, Mercer County, New Jersey, for another mouth numbing meal last week.  The last time I was there I underwent a root canal the next day without need of additional anesthesia.  It was that good! 

Yes. This is a joke, but you might not think it funny if you don't take the warning seriously. If you are thinking "Mexican" spicy, you are in for a rude awakening.  Szechuan spicy is an entirely different dimension of heat.  I love Jalapenos and Habaneros, and even Ghost Peppers, and you can pile them onto my Flautas without me blinking.  Put an equivalent amount of Szechuan peppercorns, hot chili oil, and those cute little red Chinese peppers into a dish, and your review goes from 5 Star to 5 Alarm.
  
I love it, but it is an acquired taste. As someone said about this style food, "Numb is a flavor."
 
Last week, I was surrounded by Dan Dan Noodles with Minced Pork and Chili Vinaigrette, Steamed Dumplings with Chili Vinaigrette, Amazing Eggplant (that's the name), and Hunan Beef.  

The Dan Dan's were spaghetti diameter, and had a nice ground pork sauce with a mild spicy quotient.  Very tasty and a nice start to the meal. (4 Star/3 Alarm)

The Steamed Dumplings with Chili Vinaigrette was found in the Szechuan Delicacies part of the menu toward the back page.  Six fairly large, hand stuffed and pinched, with the red chili oil and vinegar for a bath. There was a pleasant sweetness that I experienced before the heat arrived. Not sure how that was done, but it played well on my tongue. (5 Star/4 Alarm)

The Amazing Eggplant came on a large plate piled with the thin Chinese Eggplant, in a brown, spicy sauce with a light meat base.  This was delicious and stole the show. Tender, medium heat, and addictive. (5 Star/3 Alarm)

Hunan Beef came with an equal supply of broccoli in a shining brown Hunanese sauce.  The beef was thin sliced and very tender.  The Chinese chilies swam in the sauce at the bottom of the serving bowl.  Solid choice, if not completely inspiring.
(4 Star/ 3 Alarm).

This was a totally satisfying meal, reminding me of my Chengdu daze.  The 5 Alarm dishes were not selected this time as my friends were not accustomed to Szechuan cuisine, and they needed to be broken in slowly.  But, if you are ready for the HEAT, I suggest the Fish Fillet in Hot & Spicy Sauce, the Diced Rabbit with Szechuan Peppercorn Vinaigrette (a cold dish with serious hot), or the Beef in Hot & Spicy Sauce to begin your Vulcan adventure.

The savory food is better than ever, but their online ordering is not as useful as it could be. I would like it if the food were ready for pickup and followed all the instructions. Otherwise, what is the point? Steak or chicken is a bit gristly at times, so I usually get the pork.

Poor Hacienda!  I really think it deserves better ratings that what is has been getting!  Yes, there are things that I would change, but nothing that would turn me away from ever going there again.  
I have always eaten in the bar area, so maybe that's what is making a difference?  The service is always quick there, the food comes super fast, and they make sure everything is ok and ask if you want drink refills.  
The bar is a great area to watch any sports that are on, because the booth face a huge TV.  Also, they have a large area on the side of the bar that would excellent for LARGE parties.
I would like a little bit more variety on the menu, however.  For example, they don't have just beef enchiladas in red sauce.  Why not?  And I've been trying to find a Mexican restaurant that has California enchiladas (chicken enchiladas with green sauce), but haven't one yet.
I've never had a bad experience here, and I think Hacienda deserves a second chance!

Staff was friendly and there was almost no wait getting my food.  The food itself was really fresh and tasty even after getting it home and eating it.  The only downside to this chipotle is the entrance it is kind of hard to get in from the one side and easy to get in from the other so if it is on the opposite side of the road from you you have to be careful or you will probably miss the entrance.  Besides that they offered the same as other chipotle and we just as quick and as efficient as other chipotle .  Come here it is great and great tasting getting in may be hard but besides that you will enjoy.

Went to Joellas for the second time yesterday and again, loved the food. Yesterday's special was half price chicken and waffles ($4.50 say what?!) so of course we had to take advantage of that. They offer a variety of chicken, i.e. tenders, wings, 1/4 white or 1/4 dark, and you can vary the spice level. Add a dipping sauce if you like for $.60, the spiked honey is good, but my fave is still the Ella's favorite. The waffles and chicken we had yesterday were cooked well, the chicken was moist and tender, and we left full and happy. They offer plenty of sides, if you're looking for a more traditional chicken dinner. The soda fountain has some cool options to traditional sodas, and of course they have tea and lemonade. I noticed that they also offer beer and wine, which is pretty cool for a small casual joint, and bonus, they serve local brews from Sun King and Bier Brewery! Yay local! I like this place and I hope they stick around. Great alternative to the other chicken places!

My boyfriend and I came here on whim, as our first choice lunch restaurant was booked and it was too cold to aimlessly wander. We came here as Yelp recommended, with high reviews. If I had only ordered the burgers, I would have given Bareburger a higher rating, as my county fair burger (with bison meat) was really delicious! I was excited to try something new, and didn't know what to choose as the menu had bison, elk, and a bunch of other different types of fascinating burgers. My boyfriend "built his own burger" with a great beef patty and delicious gluten-free bun. I love how the entire store is organic/natural, GMO-free, and had many vegan and GF options! 

However, after scarfing down my burger (which was really small for its price--but I guess it's expected for an "all natural" burger"), I ordered a cocktail and sweet fries. The Rachel Carson looked delicious--with homemade lemonade, rosemary, blackberry, and rum--but came out full of ice and really weak. The sweet fries were underwhelming as well, with really soggy interiors and mediocre sauces. The service was a bit uncomfortable as well, as our waiter didn't seem to know what to do and was pretty awkward....

I am a very simple guy who likes to eat nigiri sushi with the rice and raw fish on top and lil bit of wasabi and soy sauce. so I come here for their lunch buffet usually for under 20 bucks. and I order their nigiri sushi which is a pretty good selection for the price paid. the sushi is good quality and professional the seaweed is crisp and not soggy. they also offer free miso soup with the buffet which is a plus. they also have sushi rolls but im not a fan of those. but love it every time I come to reno I visit. service is average nothing outstanding at least they come and check up on me.

Well seriously, who doesn't love Remedy. It's the perfect place to go on a date or meet up with your girl friends for coffee chats that last hours. I've had some great drinks and food at this location and some even better heart to hearts with great friends. The staff are wonderful people, it's close to campus making it an ideal off campus, but still kinda close venue to get away and study. 

I find this location is quite busy so you may have to wait a little while to find a table. Over all though I would never pass on an opportunity to hit up remedy, it's pretty rad!

I do not eat much seafood, including oysters, so maybe I'm not the perfect person to represent a review for those who go for this type of food. But, for the friends of those others, listen up! This place feels like a Hometown Buffet with it's minimal decor and tons of basic wooden table and chair seating. You have a million and one waiters running around, yet service is relatively slow. Yet, the prices are $15+ for an entree. I'd give the ambiance a 2; then again, this is a restaurant in a hotel, albeit a Hilton. 

As for the food... My oyster-lovin' friends ordered some of the half-shell (raw) and the charbroiled oysters. The raw ones came out dirty and translucent. They tried a few, realizing the oysters tasted fine but left grit in their mouths. They waited for the waitress and she took them back. We got a second round quickly; they were much cleaner, although the table was still amply dirty from the first round (from melting dirty ice), which I would have thought the waitress should have cleaned since we had no extra napkins (only linen ones on our lap). The second round was cleaner, but still translucent; they gave them a 3-star rating for flavor. 

The charbroiled ones came out after. They said they reminded them of steak, giving them a 4-star rating. I tried one, and aside from the gross texture, it looked better than the raw gremlin-fetus ones and had a decent flavor. Smoky, cheesy, though a bit salty. 

I ordered the blackened chicken over linguini with alfredo sauce. The chicken was actually pretty darn good, perhaps a 3.5, though the linguini was overcooked and the alfredo reminiscent of something out of a can. Reheating the leftovers the next day, however, it tasted much better. Somehow the chicken didn't get dry in the microwave, but the pasta dried up and tasted a bit more authentic and less like children's food. 

Either way, considering the slow service (though hospitable waitress for us, apologizing for the error of the cook), the bad first attempt at both the raw oysters and my meal, and the pricing and ambiance, I would likely not return and give it an overall 2-star rating.

This is the closest Supermarket to my house, so I am in here all the time, although I generally try not to do my major shopping trips here because they are SO pricey!  "Save" Mart my ass!  Unless something is on sale, it ain't cheap.

There was also this time when two employees were standing directly in front of the doors, on their break, smoking, and talking about porn.  Classy.  I complained to corporate about that, though, so hopefully it was taken care of.

Still, all around it is a clean store and not a bad place to pick up a gallon of milk when I need to.

Pretty packed 'regular' grocery store in the FQ. Presumably because of its prime location, the store is pretty crowded and the aisles are narrow. Being a food-oriented tourist, I came to here buy some souvenirs for home (chiles, creole seasoning, cajun seasoning, peychaud bitters, etc). You are probably better off buying these things here than at central grocery, which has a huge line of tourists just for muffuletta's and is probably overpriced. 

I made the mistake of buying Café Du Monde coffee here (the ubiquitous yellow container). Don't! There is a $3 mark-up on those things so you are cheaper off buying these at Café Du Monde itself.

At first I wondered how can a yankee sub shop compete with New Orleans Po-Boys and then I got to thinking about how many subways are popping up around town so the demand for a non poboy sub is obviously there. I had been to Jimmy John's many times when I lived in Ohio and they are way better than Subway. Better bread, more meat and an even fresher ingredients all add up to a better sandwich. I cannot wait till the franchise owner Drew somebody moves into New Orleans proper in Mid City and I will definitely frequent them more other. $4.50 for a great sub cannot be beaten anywhere, not even by a poboy.

I'd only been to this venue for a wedding in the past and most recently got to try it for their Sunday Brunch for a friend's birthday celebration.  I can say I was impressed with the wide assortment of items in their buffet including a pasta and omelete station.  Anything you could think of was available for consumption and the dessert area was endless.  I was also pleasantly surprised that the price included all you can drink mimosas and also allows you to sample anything off their made to order brunch menu as well.  

Our extensive group ended up having one of everything at the suggestion of our most amazing server, Sandy.  The best part of this experience, besides the company of my tablemates, was of course Sandy.  She advised she has worked at this establishment for the past 26 years and her jovial and nurturing demeanor was by far well suited to our large party.  Definitely somewhere I will return!

I come to Reno fairly often from California and I Really like Save Mart. This one has the same great service, clean & organized store, great selection, great prices, great produce and a great wine selection.

I found everything I was looking for and most of it was on sale. And the cashier that helped me out was so friendly, it made my day better.

THANK YOU! Save Mart I'm a BIG Fan.

The best Thai restaurant in Tampa bar none. They used to operate solely out of a truck but now they have a brick and mortar restaurant. My husband and I order Thai 5 on a weekly basis because once you've had it, your cravings won't stop. I alternate between the Chicken Panang Curry, the Drunken Noodles, and the Chicken Pad Thai. My husband loves the Pad Se Ew, and we always order the steamed pork potstickers as an appetizer. The food is clearly fresh, authentic, and extremely flavorful. Be careful if you ask for Thai Spice it will be hot even in medium form. Prices are reasonable but you will have to wait 20 to 30 minutes for preparation.  It is worth the wait.

I came to try out their beignets early on a Saturday morning. It was a perfect time to come because there was no line and I was able to order right away. I ordered three beignets , a cup of strawberries,  a coffee and a bottle of water for a total of $16. The cashier lady wasn't that friendly. I sat at a table and the brought my order. The coffee wasn't that good. 

It was nice that morning because they had a band playing jazz music which was nice and it was a beautiful morning to sit down and listen to some music.

If you want a little bit of entertainment with your dinner, hibachi is always a fun choice, but Benihana let me down a bit.

I've eaten at various hibachi places before and this place doesn't quite measure up. The stuff seems overpriced for what is offered (except for the drinks which were super strong!) and the tricks didn't really impress me. I've had better shows at the place I frequented for lunch in reading.

We ordered the chicken and shrimp for two with onion soup, salad with ginger dressing, shrimp appetizer w/ vegetables, and fried rice for $36. Add on the drinks, dessert, and price to upgrade from the steamed to fried rice and our bill was in the low $80s.

Also, it was rather loud; I could barely understand our server/chef(Eloy) and it doesn't include the drunk woman with 2 kids and her husband at the other end who kept berating him for small mistakes(dropping a utensil or failing to catch something in his pocket).

Overall, I just wasn't impressed.

Very good old style ice cream.  

Back when I was a kid, Uncle Andy's was just so-so. However, in the past 10+ years or so, they've really improved the quality of their ice cream.   The ice cream is rich, flavorful, and on point. They offer a nice variety of flavors, shakes, sundaes, etc. the servers are usually courteous and friendly--service with a smile. 
They also offer a variety of candies/confectionaries, cookies, pastries, etc, as well as morning coffee. 
Amazingly, they've managed to maintain some old school games, including a  Ms Pac-man table style arcade game. This adds to the old school charm of the facility. 

Located in the ground floor of the historic (and pink) Don Cesar. Parking can be a little difficult for non-hotel guests.

Standing in line at Blake's on this fine April evening, a 60+ guy chatted me up (drunk off tequilla, he said) and asked me if Blake's is worth all the hype. I told him simply "Well, I'm from New Mexico, so I'm biased. Yeah, it is." The trouble with hype is that it can let you down. Did Blake's know they would be THIS popular within a week of their opening, with lines spilling out onto Speedway, and lines forming out the door? And why? I told the Blake's clerk, who came from New Mexico, that Tucson residents love hamburgers. Do we? Can it explain the insanity over In-N-Out burger when they opened- the lines, even now years later, are insane. Is Blake's a gourmet hamburger? No. Is it the greatest burger I've ever eaten? No. The fries- not amazing, but tasty. Do I really like Blake's, and the flaming hot Hatch green chili? Yeah.. I do- a LOT! Would I stand in lines or drive-thru on the street for it? N!. And I bet with that kind of hype, a lot of people are left saying "What's the big deal?" What is the big deal? It's new, everyone talks about it, it's from New Mexico? I hear it even now with In-N-Out burger: some people don't get it. That's the great thing about diversity and having a huge selection of hamburgers in this city to choose from. I have a few go-to places for good, really good burgers. But for fast and quick and delicious spicy green chili burgers (and an occasional burrito), I'll be going to Blake's.

And a Nutella milkshake...seriously? Bring it on.

Fleming's periodically offers wine dinners throughout the year. A friend and I attended their "Wagner Family Wine Experience" which boasted a 4-course dinner with wine pairings for $99 per guest. The first course was a summer market salad which included shaved brussels sprouts, bacon, walnuts, dried cranberries, pickles, and lemon balsamic vinaigrette. Not only was the salad fresh but it was so richly layered with sweet, savory, and salty flavors. It was paired with: Sea Sun, which is a California Chardonnay. Good pairing overall, because of the crisp and slightly tart wine. The second course was a crispy chickpea and eggplant croquette. Although this course was paired with fresh arugula, smoked chili, and a romesco sauce, both the texture and the flavor profile fell totally flat. It was paired with: Caymus- Suisun, which was the only redeeming part of the 2nd course. It was medium bodied, well-balanced and dark red fruit forward. Next, the third course was the crowd pleaser! It included peppercorn filet mignon with roasted asparagus. The steak was generously hand cut and the asparagus was perfectly prepared. In addition, the plate included zesty cauliflower mash with a chimichurri sauce. There was no extraneous fat on the steak and it was perfectly prepared at medium rare; fork tender too. It was paired with: the Caymus Cabernet Sauvignon from Napa. Not only was this wine full bodied, but it was a perfect complement to the savory filet. The fourth and final course was an olive oil cake (which I was not prepared to like). Thankfully, it was nothing like I imagined. Instead, it reminded me of my great grandmother's cast-iron sweet cornbread (score!). Plus, it was accompanied by lemon curd and macerated blueberries - tart, sweet, and rich flavors. A light yet decadent dessert, which was paired with: Emmolo - a sparkling white wine. The wine had both a fragrant nose and palette, which included notes of honeysuckle, lillies, and stone fruit. Overall (and aside from the 2nd course), the food and wine pairings were well executed and thoughtfully combined. It was definitely worth the $99 price tag (gratuity not included).

With all the great food choices in Philly, my husband and I were totally let down by Kanella South.  

Dip trio - they let us swap out the sardine dip with hummus because we are vegetarians.  The hummus was a let down, the consistency wasn't smooth and something was just missing.  The feta dip was good, and we weren't really fans of the fava bean dip.  Some of the warmed up pita bread that came with this app was burnt.  

Halloumi Cheese appetizer was ok but a pretty small portion.  

The bureki filled with feta was actually our favorite app of the night.  The honey and beets were a nice touch.

We shared the mushroom pie made of phyllo dough (can't remember the name) and the dish was a bit bland.  The mushrooms were seasoned well but everything else wasn't.  

The beers were tried were awful.

I think Philly has a ton of amazing food options available, I would definitely skip this one.

During my visit to STL, this place was recommended by my bf's entire family. Like, they swore on their lives this place has the best ice cream in the world.

Well, let me tell you. They were not wrong.

TD's has the largest flavor variety of any ice cream place I've been to. I ordered the Tiramisu and OMG words can't even describe. It was so creamy and delicious. I finished my whole serving and I'm the type of person who can't handle too much of one dessert. I usually take a few bites and I can't finish it. This wasn't the case with this amazing cup of magic in my hands.

The wait in the below freezing weather was well worth it. Lines moved fast, but it was busy that night and I'm a Texan who's not acclimated to cold weather so it seemed like 10 years. 

Once that delicious goodness was in my belly, nothing else mattered. Not my red nose or numb fingers.

Try it if you're in STL!

I was in the Westin resort for a conference and wanted to try out Contigo...

Great ambience, and though I stopped by alone to grab an early dinner before returning to the conference I was promptly seated and received excellent service from all the staff. 

I follow a Meatless Monday routine and was a little disappointed to notice the menu had absolutely no vegetarian entrees - only vegetarian options on the menu were a few appetizers and the salads. But when I asked my waiter, Joel if any customizations was possible, he immediately pointed out a number of the entrees that could be made vegetarian. 

While waiting for the food to be brought out, I was served some great bread and olive oil w/freshly chopped herbs. 

I chose the plate of 2 arepas and a side of fried plantains. The arepas were made with a squash medley filling which was delicious!!! And extremely filling as the order came with a side of simple salad greens. 

I enjoyed the appetizer of fried Plantains as a dessert... they were drizzled with honey/agave nectar.... yummmm. 

I definitely did want to stop by and try some of the traditional non vegetarian offerings the next day but was not able to get away with my conference schedule. 

Will definitely come back for more during my next visit!

24 hours a day the geriatric waitresses quickly satisfy the hungers of all kinds of clientele. I've been caught here early on a Sunday morning after a night of many libations. The mix of late night party-goers and early morning church-goers is somewhat humorous. 

Uncle bills does breakfast a little better than the fast food joints... but not much. It's still greasy, low-quality stuff. For me it's perfect after a night of car bombs and kamikazies, but my parents like to go here for lunch... sober... and sometimes drag me with them... and the food doesn't taste nearly as good. 

Service is rigid, yet prompt. The place is huge. Even when there is a line out the door, you'll be seated in less than 10 minutes. They probably have over 50 tables in the place.

We visited Prime Rib again to celebrate a wonderful vacation in Puerta Plata and as a sendoff to our friend returning to Ukraine. Our waitress this time was Christina and man have we been blessed with great servers. The entire support staff are wonderful, attentive and polite as well. 

Christina was a good sport with the 3 liter bottle of wine that was brought. It's a really good thing it's BYOB bcuz 2 small mixed drinks at the bar came to $24. OUCH

As a party of 7 they did a great job bringing all our food out at the same time. I really appreciate the timing involved in making this happen.

The Quick: Go for the view alone. You are right on the water with gorgeous view of Palm trees, blue waves, and even actual pelicans! 

The Details: In terms of food, the lobster mango salad was great, I would highly recommend. I also had a side of brussel sprouts which was prepared with a generous amount of bacon and olive oil (just the way I like it). My co-worker ordered the grouper and wasn't overly thrilled by his meal. 

The Rusty Pelican was very good. There are better seafood restaurants in Tampa, however the tropical view and friendly staff are worth many repeat visits.

My friend and I went here for happy hour a few weeks ago. Though I work next door, it never even occurred to me to try this place out for happy hour or a meal. Something about its location in the back corner of the mall just made it seem a little sad. 

I had an odd start, because when you first walk in the bar is nowhere in sight. The host greeted me kindly, but did not offer to help me find where I was going. After wandering near the bathroom, and then near the sushi bar, I found the real bar! The bartender was very professional and prompt. He made no time for chit chat, but that was fine by me since he made sure my drinks were delicious and strong. Between my friend and I, we tried about a half dozen cocktails and all were surprisingly great. I really enjoyed both varieties of sangria, especially. We also tried a few sushi rolls and appetizers. Everything was good. Nothing to die for, but good. Great for happy hour prices. 

I would definitely come back here for happy hour, to have a couple drinks and apps for dinner before a movie.

Ahh Ted Drewes.  My friend and I used to skip school and end up here instead.  I have a million favorites.  Great Pumpkin and Big Apple each with a whole slice of pie ground in, Polynesian, and more recently blueberry.  However, nothing can hold a candle to the Bunny Crete.  My friend and I called every single day for weeks to ask if it was in yet.  They grew to know and loathe us by the time the beautiful treasure finally came in.  The Bunny Crete is vanilla custard, cream cheese, raisins, carrot, and nuts.  It's only around for Easter.  I'd try to make it at home, but what would be the point?

WOW. Had lunch in Greenwood and we were looking for desert. Yelp led us to Handel's and I am so glad it did. 

I had a chocolate sundae with coconut cream pie ice cream, chocolate sauce, chopped nuts, whipped cream and a cherry on top. My friend had the turtle sundae and my wife had a cup of the coffee chocolate chip ice cream. 

It was ALL amazing. Some of the best ice cream I have ever had. The coconut cream pie ice cream had large pieces of pie crust in it. Delicious. The chopped nuts were not just peanuts. It was a mix and it was fresh and delicious. 

Two thumbs WAY up. Incredible.

Uhhh seriously?  I'm shocked at the high reviews.  I will flat out say from the get-go... we are Yogurtland fanatics, so all yogurt places are held up to the Yogurtland standard.

-The price: relatively expensive compared to Yogurtland (Yogurtland is 30 cents an ounce, this place is 38 cents an ounce).

-The yogurt: not firm at all, didn't have the right tart flavor... totally was melting at a faster rate than normal.

-The toppings: meh.  Nothing special.  The fruit was not particularly fresh, and the dry toppings were similar to most joints.

-The service: fine.  Nothing extraordinarily good or bad.

Two stars, because why go here when we could go to Yogurtland?  It's even worth the drive.  Won't be returning, not worth the money.

Remedy is the best! 
We have seen this location morph and grow through the renovations and it must be the biggest Cafe in Edmonton. With the best chai in town you can't go wrong. If you enjoy pistachios I would highly recommend the Kashmire chai. But each chai is unique and delightful in its own way. Don't forget to grab a stamp card! 
The food- to die for. We haven't had a bad anything ever! Love the Chana masala and naan! 

Being so close to university the 109th location is typically full of students but we always manage to find seats and a spot to sit.

I really enjoyed the dark tenders and the multiple sauces. The fresh cut fries were great as well. My husband did not like the wings. The breading seemed to be a thick double dipped type and was the same on both. It worked well on the tenders but not on the wings. They may want to revise their recipe and stick to a classic fried chicken recipe that is much thinner. If you don't enjoy dipping chicken in the sauces, I can see how it would be bland. Some people just don't like any sauce on wings. If you are like me, where you love all types of homemade sauces and flavored mayos, this place is for you.

I had my birthday dinner at the Prime Rib tonight and I had a very nice experience.

I walked in the back entrance and was warmly welcomed by a kind lady.

I was then give a very nice seat in the main dining room and the ambiance was great. There were leopard rugs, beautiful leather chairs, live music including many verses of "Happy Birthday" and large white tablecloth tables! 

Our server, Alex, came over and took our drink orders. I got a ginger splash with a maraschino cherry. Others in the party got a variety of drinks including scotch, Chardonnay and coke.  

After a little while, our bread was finally dropped off, though I wish it came a little quicker. Either way, the bread was amazing. There were a variety of options that were all served warm and with freshly whipped butter.

At about the same time our bread came, we placed our appetizer orders. I decided to get both the house salad and seared ahi tuna, which I shared with another member of the party.

The appetizers came out very fast and were of great quality. I really enjoyed my house salad and all the toppings were very fresh. Even the dressing was good, especially with the level of creaminess. It took the salad to a whole other level. While the ahi tuna was small for the price, only three pieces for $22, it was good. I gave one piece to another party member. While he liked it, he commented that he wish it came with soy sauce. Personally, I thought it was fine without soy sauce and I especially enjoyed the lemon juice and sesame seeds on top.
