Finally, since I was at The Prime Rib, I had to get the prime rib. All I can say is that it was amazing. It was tender and full of flavor. The sesame seeds on top took the dish to a whole other level. It was also very big that I couldn't even eat it all!

While I didn't eat too many of the sides, I munched on a few. The potato skins were delicious, they were nice and crispy. Also, the grilled broccoli was great! Other people in the party raved about the sides especially the potato skins. 

Others in the party got tuna and crab (we joked that it was the most fattening thing on the menu). 

For dessert, I got the chocolate sundae. It was very good! It was served in a bowl that was surrounded on the outside by cake and a giant scoop of ice cream on the inside. It was topped off with homemade whipped cream smothered in chocolate sauce, pieces of peanuts and topped with a cherry! I also had a little of the chocolate mousse cake and while it was good, I wouldn't say it was spectacular.

While I had a very nice night, there were a few minor downsides. First, the waiter Alex was nice, but made a few minor mistakes. First, two others decided to split the shrimp cocktail, which we informed him about, but it was not split when it was brought out. Also, someone was given a lobster soup for an entree, which he did not order. Everyone at the table was a bit confused on how this mishap happened. 

Luckily, the owner came over and easily resolved the problem with the shrimp cocktail. Speaking of him, he was very nice and professional and introduced himself to the table.  

Unfortunately, I was very disappointed with the two hostesses when leaving, they were on their phones and did not even wish me a goodnight. 

Altogether, Prime Rib could improve their staff, but they serve superb food! I would definitely recommend!
New guy on payroll is rude and slow. I wish Hassan was there when i went bc i would have pulled him over to the side to mention it. Kid needs to get his act together or find a new job.

Good Italian restaurant, but over priced. Taormina's is a nicer Italian restaurant than most other ones in the area for sure, but the problem with it is that is can be very inconsistent at times. The biggest problem with Taormina's is consistency in terms of food quality. I've come here before and the food is great, other times the chicken tastes dried out and not as flavorful as previous visits. My most recent visit here, I got the Chicken Alfredo with Rigatoni; the chicken was dried out and flavorless, and the Alfredo felt like it had been sitting under a hot lamp for a while, not fresh. I had previously gotten the exact same dish, which I though was fantastic, but that was a few weeks before. My friend also was upset with his dish as he got the Chicken Parmesan, in which the chicken was very chewy and not edible. Again he has had it in the past and it was fine. All of this isn't even mentioning the pricing here is expensive. For literally pasta with chicken in it costs me almost $20, and they don't put that much chicken in the dish. Everything here is a la carte, so with your $20+ meal, you don't get any salad or anything, just some bread and peppers. Sometimes here the food is great, other times it is whatever. It's all the luck of the draw.

The atmosphere is pretty nice in Taormina's; they keep the place very clean and it always looks inviting. The place is pretty small, but they fit a lot of people in there and it doesn't feel too cramped. Service is decent too, never really had a major issue, and whenever their is a problem, the servers seem to be able to fix it somewhat. Basically, if Taormina's priced their meals more reasonably, I'd be a much happier camper, but for the price you pay there, I expect a much better product when I go. I hear the Ivyland location of Taormina's costs even more, so there's that.

Food (B+), Pricing (D+), Atmosphere (B), Service (B)

Cheu is comfort food heaven, especially on a cold winter day. Some of the best soup you can get in the city, and a few things are vegan by default or can be made vegan - just ask! 

I've only ever been here by myself (on several occasions) but I wouldn't hesitate to bring a date here either. However it's so popular that I would recommend coming here off-peak i.e. Monday-Wednesday. I've never walked past here when it's been open and not seen it jammed. Feels like the place belongs in NYC.
Great Service! Had the buffet and it was really good...there was a lot of variety and I got full so didn't even get to taste everything I wanted to.. Very happy

I legit thought this was the Northside's version of The Eagle downtown, but it really has a lot more in common with KFC. $8 fried chicken options with a choice of sauces. I tried the mac & cheese and fries sides, but found them both a little bland. It was (thankfully) not that busy when I visited, which was nice because I've been warned of some pretty long lines. Staff was friendly. Atmosphere feels like a chain (which it is). Overall, my experience was definitely mediocre and I have no plans to return.

If you're stuck at the airport and need a Cheesesteak, this may be your place to get one. But it seems the pork is where it's at. So if you're reading this, take a risk and get the pork over the cheesesteak.

Don't be fooled by the good reviews 
This place is beautiful 
But as far as the food goes
Such a disappointment 
You are closer to Mexican food at a Taco Bell 
I have tried Mexican from about every Mexican state 
What the sell here is a cheap shot at Mexican American cuisine 
I had a plate with potatoes so called barbacoa which was about a teaspoon full
An egg and some sauce 
I would have been more satisfied with a cup of noodles 
Ps their so called chorizo is more like ground beef with some nasty seasoning

We had a terrific and unforgettable time at this throwback, classic, over-the-top retro French continental Euro style eatery. The decor is super fun and intimate. You are transported in time by the wooden Parisian style red velvet interior. This is a super fun and romantic spot if you're prepared to kick back and take your time eating and enjoying a night out together with the special people in your life. 

* The early bird is a good deal or they run a coupon in the local booklet you can grab around town.. 
* The bread served with your meal is a wonderful warm soft loaf with black and white sesame seeds and a crispy sugar exterior. It's pretty divine my humble opinion..
* They serve a beautiful traditional salad with a garlicky vinaigrette dressing. Pretty and tasty
* We did a couple veal dishes and the saucing is heavy, but everything was pretty tasty if not quite spot on.. A little too much sugar sweetness for my palate..
* The pacing is slow so if you're in a rush.. this may not be for you. But if you can converse and relax you will have a great time visiting and taking it all in. The regulars we ran into here were also very friendly. As were the servers.

Unfortunately we ran out of time for dessert so we'll have to come back..

This is a family establishment and they take pride in their food, the family recipes, and the history. It's a special place. It is perhaps dated and maybe musty but this is also its charm. It's old school and wonderful.

A couple reviews have noted that it's not strictly French. As the menu subtitle notes it is continental European cuisine and a variety of continental classics are offered from veal, frogs legs, escargot, and French onion soup, to marsalas and schnitzels.

Definitely one of a kind experience. Good Times Czech Restaurant on Tierra Verde is similarly old school but can't' compete with the decor and romance here. :)

i visit this tasty, 9 dollar soon doob spot every time i go home.  no, seriously. every.  time.  

best soon doob ive ever had (with the exception of my momma's, of course)!  and quick too!  they come in a variety of flavors (kimchi, beef, mushroom, etc) as well as varying degrees of spiciness.  the meal comes with great panchan, a raw egg (to be added into your soon doob mid-boil), and a stone pot of rice which is later turned into noo-rung-ji with warm boh-ree-cha (barley tea).

the waiters/waitresses are so cute in the traditional korean garb and pretty much leave you to your delicious tofu unless you need something, then you can either flag them down or push the button on the side of the table.  ive eaten and sat there talking with my fellow soon doob loving friend for hours before, and they dont mind.

ALSO: you can call in your order ahead of time, so that it's nice and piping hot right when you get there to eat.

Stopped here on our Route 66 road trip adventure. Going on a Route 66 trip, this is one of the iconic historical places to stop at. My dog and I sure tried to stop at as many places as possible!

I love that this place is dog friendly and that you can order straight from an outside window! Most people seem to ask their frozen custard from the back of their cars. There really isn't any seating here. They have some different types of custard you can order, but they are known for their concretes. You can add in different toppings and order them in different flavors. I ordered a coffee one with almonds and coconut. The ones I ordered seemed more melted than what I had expected. It may have been because it was a super hot day. There workers were friendly and everyone loved seeing my dog! He was super well behaved and patiently waited for his own cup of custard! I bought him a plain vanilla kids small cup... but you can save a few bucks because they have FREE doggie sized ones! I had no idea and had already ordered and paid, then another worker stuck his head out and asked me if I wanted to give my dog his own cup. I said I already bought one and he said next time, just ask for a doggie one, it's free. My dog being 96lbs could probably have easily finished his small cup along with a doggie cup lol. It was pretty packed when we went, but it moved fast still. They have so many windows open and you get your sweet treat pretty quickly. Like I said, there really isn't any seating, but most people enjoy their treats on the spot at their cars. It's like a ice cream tailgating party!

If I am ever in the area again, I would come by here for a dessert stop! If you are traveling with your dog, take them here!! They welcome you and your pup! Not the cheapest, but prices are also pretty decent.

I only come here because it's close and cheap and we don't have a freaking Target! Okay, maybe if they had a Wal-mart I wouldn't complain so much, but NO we don't even have that! 

I only come here when I'm in desperate need of something I can't get at Albertsons. Just the smell when you walk in is enough to make me turn around and walk right out.

Can someone please build a Target now?

This is one of the largest parks in the country. There's tons to do, as well. Jogging/biking/rowing/games, you name it.

Additionally, it houses some great venues - the Zoo, the Muny, the St. Louis Art Museum. It's very open and easy to get around, and in my experience, it's never hard to find parking. It also is in a good spot - right off the highway and near Washington University in St. Louis. Check out the Jewel Box for some pretty pictures.

This place is totally decent. I've been here once for dine-in and once for take-out. No complaints. 

What you really need to know is this: Crazy Sushi is currently offering a "two rolls for $6/three rolls for $8" opening special. Crazy sushi, crazy cheap. 

When I dined in on the first day they were in business, this special was not offered. Don't know when it will end, either. Get it while you can.

OK, now that I can write about a Lowe's in Indianapolis, I can tell you that this place is clean and has one of the better garden centers in the inner part of Indianapolis with a very good selection of shrubs and trees. This is a store in a neighborhood of established homes and mature trees, so young trees are not in high demand and there are not good conditions for young trees unless they are replacement trees. So if you're looking for trees or shrubs, this place has a lot of them. 

The prices seem to be better here on some things than on others. The fertilizer was very expensive, but the mulch was cheaper. The sprinkler selection was especially better and cheaper than most other Lowe's, but then again, Broad Ripple and Meridian Kessler have established lawns and many of them have sprinkler systems, so it may be lack of demand. Service here is good and prompt. 

They also have a pretty good selection of products made here in the USA! That is definitely one thing I have not given Lowe's props for is their sheer number of American made goods from mom and pop manufacturers. I try my best to choose those products if I have a choice.
This location can get pretty busy at times and parking can be a pain during peak hours since it's located right next to a campus.

SERVICE:
The staff were both very nice and helpful. We brought our mountain bikes to ride at a trail in Goleta, so the staff were kind enough to lock it in the back garage for us when we weren't using it. The check in and check out process was easy. I really enjoyed the 24-access to coffee and tea. The warm and freshly baked cookies were yummy too!

LOCATION:
This inn is one block from the marina, so it is located in a very walkable community. The problem we experienced is our room was located next to the main street, so it was loud. I heard people partying on the street and trucks driving by, so my quality of sleep was very poor, which was unfortunate because we wanted to relax and get away during our visit in Santa Barbara.

The worst part of our trip in this room was when the fire smoke detector randomly turned on around 9:30pm! It blasted our ears and we didn't know what was going on. I was so nervous and thought there was a fire in the building, so I asked my husband to go downstairs to find out what was going on. The evening staff person entered our room and couldn't figure out why the smoke detector turned on. She was finally able to disconnect the battery from the smoke detector, which silenced it! She contacted the manager who informed her that the Inn got new smoke detectors, which sound a really loud alarm when the batteries need to be replaced. This occurrence was nerve wrecking and an extreme annoyance.

QUALITY OF FOOD:
The made to order breakfast was special. I've never stayed in an inn that provided made to order breakfast, so I really enjoyed this part of our stay. On our first morning, we asked for breakfast in bed and the staff delivered it right on time. The second morning, we decided to sit in the dining area, which was also nice.

I probably will not revisit this Inn simply because the room was a major annoyance for me.

Stopped here randomly during the day. It wasn't packed at all. I went to the back and ordered some beignets. It comes with 3 per order. I was given a number and I sat down and didn't wait long before they come out. As expected they were covered in sugar. Fine. But they blazing hot to the touch. And terribly greasy. After suffering through the 1 and a half it was so difficult to eat the rest.

I don't think this place is worth going out of your way to visit. Cafe Du Monde is far superior. They just do it right. Here, it's greasy and the inside was filled with oil. Pass.

Five guys is a great burger joint!  Fresh ingredients, including non-frozen beef and hand-cut french fries, Yum!  They have a sign identifying which farm the potatoes actually came from.  Plus, you get a TON of fries in your bag... probably enough to share with a friend... if you wanted to.......... or not!

Not that great. Watery ice cream

You know, I wasn't a fan. Everyone loves this stuff, but to me - being from Kansas City, where we have Culvers, Freddy's, and Sheridans - the richness was nonexistent. Quite the contrary, it was as though someone super blended my concrete, then added milk. You ever had ice cream that melts a little too much, and the sugars mellow, and the cold warms, and it's just kind of, meh? Yep. You've had a $5 Ted's creation. 

I even sent the first one back, tried a second one - the s'mores - and...no change. I guess it's a St. Louie thing - but in my opinion, you's guys don't know what good is. Come to KC, and try Sheridan's, or Freddy's. It's like injecting your pleasure centers with freezing cold, fluffed sugar-butter covered in a thick layer of broadening perspective. 

If you try something else, you could never do Ted's again. Sorry I had it, and sorry to put you onto Sheridan's - I've ruined custard forever. 

You're welcome.

Came to Rusty Pelican for their Easter brunch after hearing really good things about it. Initially this place was one of the options for my birthday brunch, so it was already on my short list of places to eat brunch. 

The restaurant is located right on the water and has a spectacular view, one of the best in all of Tampa Bay (or at least from the restaurants I've been to so far). 

The buffet was plentiful. There was a wide variety of seafood, a carving station, breakfast foods and tons of dessert. The carrot cake was excellent, as was the apple cobbler. 

The service was pretty good. I was impressed when I asked if the guy making omelets could make me an egg white omelet and he told me they weren't doing that for Easter but that he would make one for me anyway. He came and brought it directly to my table, and it was great! I guess the restaurant does different brunch options on non-holiday weeks. 

This restaurant has an old, cozy feel to it that was really nice and warm. I will definitely come back to try brunch on a regular week and really enjoyed my experience here. Brunch with a view is always an A+ for me.

Everyone says that the Sunday Brunch is where its at, but I was there for dinner.  Overall Nice Atmosphere, The food was good, but I felt the portions were a bit on the small side for the price. The service was average, the server was "unsure" about a few things on the menu and didn't really seem that interested in resolving the que

I visited Nada over the weekend and was definitely impressed. When we arrived, at around 8:30 Saturday night, there was a 25 minute wait. The hostess took our phone number, and when a table was ready, we received a text bidding us to return to the restaurant. This was a pretty cool service, as it allowed us to wander down the street to a game store instead of waiting uncomfortably in the entryway.

The restaurant itself is gorgeous; The lighting is dim, but the dining room is filled with cool nooks where customers are seated around mismatched tables. One wall is filled with circular ends of colored glass bottles; the other side of the wall is located in the ladies room, where the tops of those bottles just poke through. So cool. The ladies room is also amazing, BTW; each stall has a different amazing wallpaper with crystal light fixture.

Food was great. I ordered fried avocado tacos that were 'oh-my-god' delicious and nada fries, which are not fries at all, rather, crispy baked potato bits covered in sweet chili sauce and crema. I also got a blueberry lemonade, which was reeeeeally good, but not very generously portioned. 

Nada is definitely NOT like my favorite taco truck at all, but it's a fun place to go for a night out. Their interpretations of street tacos are novel, and overall, I had an excellent experience.

Indian restaurants are somewhat scarce in the Indy-north 'burbs and Amber is the only one I know of in Carmel proper.

Located in a small strip center at the northwest corner of Carmel Drive and Meridian Street, this unassuming Indian eatery combines efficient service with decent fare.....if a bit pricey. Then again, given the price of gas lately, a short drive to Amber more and more frequently trumps the longer drive to some of our more wallet-friendly Indian haunts in the city.

The food does not disappoint and personal faves include the Nav Ratan Korma - a vegetable curry that is creamy and deeply satisfying - think Indian comfort food! Lamb Vindaloo is usually what my better half chooses here - so spicy he needs a refreshing Mango Lassi (yogurt and Mango puree -based drink) to vanquish the flames!
One thing not to be missed, in my humble opinion, is the Kashmiri Naan bread. It's a bit sweet thanks to its nut, shredded coconut and dried cherry stuffing and boy does it ever pair well with the savory side of the menu!  Also, be sure to try the Gulab Jamun (mini fried dough balls in cardamon-infused honey syrup) or Kheer (Indian rice pudding - I often get extra for breakfast the next day..LOL) for dessert.

Amber is open seven days per week and offers a lunch buffet from 11:00-2:30 pm. Catering is also offered, though I've not tried that yet.

Oh, the guilt. 

THE GUILT. 

How the heck did I literally inhale that veggie burger and truffle tots as "efficiently" as I did? Seriously. The shocked look on my friend's face clearly showed that I most certainly chowed on the "Taco Truck" version of a burger waaaaay quicker than what could be classified as humanly possible. And, although some may roll their eyes at the $11.50 price tag for a burger and a side (plus $2 upgrade for the "truffle" tots) but I can attest that this was one of the best veggie burgers (and tots) that I have had in quite some time. 

I appreciate that you have the option to choose a bun preference that included Brioche, Pretzel, Gluten-Free, and Wheat and that vegans like myself can opt for the House-made veggie patty and still enjoy any of the 12 styles that they have available ranging from the "Tennessee" or "Jalapeno Popper" to the "Hawaiian" and "Shroomin" with just minor tweaks. The burger was nothing short of hearty and full of robust flavor. This hungry lady was happy and stuffed!

My only issue came with the 2 glasses of wine ($9) that I ordered. My first glass tasted a bit "off" and had some discoloration that hinted that this vintage may have been sitting out uncorked for wee bit too long but when the bubbly waitress came back around to see if we were still feeling dehydrated, I went ahead and ordered a second glass to keep up with my appetite. I should have refrained as the second glass definitely hit all signs that the quality of the wine was an issue. Perhaps, it was my newfound sluggish state (due to the heavy load that I just ate) or the swell spirits that we were in but we didn't send the glass back. So my glass just sat there untouched. 

For my next visit, I'll try one of the brews instead as they have quite the extensive craft beer list here. 

Overall, this is a nice addition to the Gulch neighborhood and the food is solid. Just be sure to bring your appetite and Sommeliers beware!

When I lived in St. Louis, Black Thorn Pub was always my go to bar. You can't go wrong here.

It's a great neighborhood dive with friendly people, friendly bartenders, a good beer selection, great Chicago style pizza that rivals actual pizza from Chicago, and lots of activities including foosball, air hockey, shuffleboard, darts, Golden Tee, and my all-time favorite: an original Donkey Kong arcade machine. 

Chicago has some great bars, but I have yet to find one that offers all of the things that Black Thorn Pub offers. 

St. Louis truly has a gem in this place. Don't take it for granted!
Decent Mexican-ish restaurant in Indianapolis.

I was too excited to get ice cream that on this first visit here, I didn't confirm what time they opened!   Derf!  I'll remember noon for next time!   

Initial smiles from the girl behind the counter who had such a bubbly personality, made me like this place already! 
Second thing, sooooo many flavors!!  I asked her some popular ones and her faves and she directed me to the chocolate freezer.   Yep!  They have one freezer dedicated to chocolate flavors!

After a few samples I settled on getting the mini scoop sampler.  4 mini scoops for $5.
Mexican Hot Chocolate
King Cake
Coffee Pecan Brittle
Salted Caramel

I didn't sample the King Cake prior to getting it but from what the girl described, and being a signature NOLA dessert, I got it.  I think I would enjoy a regular cake version of this more than this ice cream adaption, but it was interesting none the less, and had the flavors she described.

The other flavors I got were equally delicious, but the winner of this sampler is the Mexican Hot Chocolate.  Dark and creamy with a spicy note that lingers. Next time I'm here, I would definitely come back for another scoop of this and to try others on their list!  


(NOLA trip: 2/2015)

Over in this area today so did my shopping at this Dierbergs.  This is the one I use to drive to before Edwardsville got a Dierbergs.  It was nice to be back in this store and it's as wonderful as I remember.  They have amazing sandwiches made up in the deli!  Take a peek if you haven't, they look so good!  Shoot, now I wish I had gotten one!  I love this store.  Everyone is so friendly and helpful; another great Dierbergs!  This one also has a LuLu Chinese Express inside the store.

I came by Olive Garden for some lunch carry out on a Sunday when I was in the area. Online ordering was easy and they have a drive up curbside area. We had to wait a little while for our order which I understood when I saw them bring out a large catering order to another car. The waitress was friendly and made sure we had everything we ordered. I got the Asiago chicken pasta and my daughter got a chicken kids meal. The Asiago chicken was really rich it was hard to eat much of it in one sitting. The sauce was really thick. The breadsticks didn't taste as fresh and buttery as I love about Olive Garden but they were decent. I had ordered some extras. It's not a bad place to stop by for lunch. I would probably do it during the week though when they have lunch size options.

Happy Hour Monday- Friday from 4-7 p.m.


Specialty drinks such as Sake Bombs, Hawaiian Punch, and Apple Saketinis, along with $1 Domestic beers. 

Savor freshly shucked Oysters on the Half Shell for only .99 each!

Bar menu features Catfish Bites for $3.99, Garlic Herb Fries for $1.99 and other delicious bites!

Delicious ice cream - totally worth the trek from French Quarter! I'm so glad Creole Creamery is off the beaten path from Magazine street. 

With so many unique flavors more than I can count on my fingers and toes (Salty Smokey Almond, Cookie Monster, and Creole Cream Cheese...), I'm glad that I got the Blueberry Pie in a leak free waffle cone.  I enjoyed it and truly reminded me of Blueberry Pie! My husband enjoyed the Cookie Monster with cookie dough, Oreos, and Chip AHoy!

Despite being a sample hog (I didn't the comical poster when I walked in!), the staff was friendly and patient. 

Best ice cream shop in New Orleans, I can see why it ranks in the top 50  shops in the nation. Skip the beignets and come straight here!

Located in the small shopping plaza with the Dollar General across the street from Schnucks grocery.  The restaurant is in a huge store front with lots of windows.  The main entrance is through the left set of doors.  While it make look dark from the outside, don't worry, it's just the tint on the windows.

Upon entering, there is no hostess stand so it's a little confusing.  The waitress saw me immediately and was able to assist.  Right when you walk in, there is a large open room filled with tables and booths with a busser stand on the back wall.  To the right of the main entrance is a second room with a bar, high top tables, and some TVs.  If you don't see a waitress, just walk to the bar since there was a bartender available.

I placed a to-go order and it was ready within 10 minutes from my call.  My order of Bun Thit Nuong (vermicelli noodles with grilled beef, 2 shrimp, 1 large egg roll, fresh veggies, peanuts, and fish sauce) was a large portion.  The meat was not tough, the shrimp were cooked perfectly, and the egg roll was only slightly soggy after the car ride back to the office.  I would absolutely order again, but I've got my eye on the pho next, or banh mi next.

Overall, food is good, service was good, décor inside and out is lacking.  I would rather have good food over good décor any day!
The atmosphere is fun and the food is very tasty. The margaritas are also worth a try! It's a very laid back place that I like to return to.

As far as Thai food goes, I admit that I am a bit picky, bc I grew up eating some pretty fabulous Thai food. So as far as Thai Cuisine & Cafe, It was OK, but nothing to write home about. I tried the tom yom soup and the padthai with veggies. The tom yom seemed like the kind of soup you can buy at the store in a can....except they added chicken. I was pretty disappointed in the soup overall- it lacked the lemongrass flavor and spiciness and was pretty watery. My entree earned them a little redemption, but overall the tofu was shriveled and overcooked, and the noodles lacked the full flavor I am accustomed to tasting with pad thai. A bite of green curry from my friend seemed especially salty as well. 

As for the pros- they have clearly established a nice place, and the cozy decor was cute. We came with a party of 13, so it was nice of them to accommodate us in their small restaurant. The owner seemed pretty nice and eager to please. Parking is not an issue, there is a lot in the back so that is a pro.

 I dont know how recently they opened, but they have a few kinks to work out. I may try it again, but probably not for a while.

Definitely over priced. I ordered a mushroom and cheese bruschetta plate and was wholly underwhelmed. It come on a sizzling plate and the cheese looked melted but was actually quite cold, as if it was an afterthought grabbed from the refrigerator before being brought to the table. 

Also, while I was there, it was after the lunch rush so there only a handful of tables with people. However, I was sat at a table near to 2 people in a business networking meeting. So while the place was mostly empty, I had no choice but to over hear their conversation about financial planning and insurance.

As Bette Davis said in Beyond The Forest, "What a dump." However, in the case of Uncle Bill's, it gives character. I can honestly tell you that UB has not been remodeled or redecorated since I moved to STL in 1979 and that is part of its charm and ambiance. To be honest, it had been at least 8 years since my last visit to UB's and when I walked in for my recent breakfast it was as if things had never changed. That was because they hadn't.

We were quickly seated, which surprised me since it was a Sunday and around 9:00AM. I guess everyone was either at church or sleeping in. The restaurant was still very full and the tables are cramped very close together. Keeping the closeness in mind, you may want to keep that in mind when picking your subject of conversation. The lady next to us was telling her friend about her son in prison. I had to bite my tongue, I so bad wanted to ask her if her son had a bitch or if he was one of the other inmates bitch. 

Our waitress was very attentive, made sure we quickly had our morning coffee. She also had a good sense of humor, she chuckled when I asked if there were any off the menu specials. Since they had no specials we went with the Country Fried Steak and the 2 Pork Chop Breakfast. Both came with two eggs and hash browns on the side. In addition to these hearty breakfasts, we shared an order of biscuits and gravy. 

The Country Fried Steak was very good, a nice big piece of tender beef breaded and covered in flavorful milk gravy. The pork chops were not as good, they were a thin cut and overly cooked making them dry and tough. I was hoping for a thick, juicy chop. Our eggs were  cooked over easy and done well, as were the hash browns. They're not your traditional hash browns, but are more an American Fries.

The star of the breakfast was the hearty serving of biscuits and gravy. We got two huge flaky biscuits covered in milk gravy filled with pieces of sausage. Next time I need a comfort breakfast, I may just come here and order Biscuits & Gravy with a side of hash browns.

Friendly staff, very well kept for a diner, and FAST service. Like I'm talking my breakfast came out in less then ten minutes. 

I can always appreciate a clean diner because they are few and far between. There is also plenty of places to park which is nice! Much better then Oregon Diners parking lot, yeeesh. -- I came here for a quick breakfast and indeed it was. I ordered the south philly omelet and it came with hash browns. The hash browns were great! The omelet was just okay. It was about 80% provolone cheese. It overwhelmed the omelet itself. I probably wouldn't order it again.

While glancing at the dinner menu, I will definitely be back to try a better meal here!

I have attended several Yelp events here (all incredibly awesome) but never come here of my own accord for dinner.  As it was on the short list for a friend of mine before a concert, and I love trying new places to Yelp about, I voted Mason's.  At dinnertime on a Thursday, the bar area was absolutely packed and loud and seating was impossible, so the actual restaurant space was our choice for dining.  The concept behind Mason's is classic Southern cuisine with a French twist.  Sounds fantastic.  The deviled eggs with bacon jam (I feel anything with bacon jam automatically wins) and pickled okra were so effing delicious and the perfect little appetizer to split before dinner.  My friend got the shrimp and grits and let me tell you, come hungry if you order this.  There was no way she was finishing that even if I helped her.  Their burger, with garlic aioli over mayo, was perfectly done and not too gigantic.  Also it came with arugula over traditional lettuce.  Overall a great combo that didn't need much adornment.  Mind you, the prices here are a little steep, but you can always go the tapas route and split some appetizers.  They have a huge wine selections and a lot of local brews on tap.  The space is dark, intimate, and quiet.  The service was great.  Overall a good experience and I will be back.

For burgers, this place gets a four star rating.  The inside will remind you of an "In and Out Burger" or "Steak & Shake."  But it sets itself apart.

The fries are cooked in peanut oil and are the long type of fry with the skin on.  The oil was fresh as the fries tasted "clean."

The burgers were very juicy and had real cheese instead of that hydrogenated vegetable oil that most places use.  I could have eaten two of these burgers but I'm trying to cut down a bit!  This place is way better than Ruby Tuesdays or Chilis for burgers, but has more of a fast food type feel.

The only downside was the bacon.  It tasted like that precooked stuff you can buy in Costco.  It was real bacon, but tasted off.

No hot chicks working here to report!  But plenty of beer gut guys and housewives.  Its in a strip mall with Trader Joe's.

Walmart is Walmart. No reason to hate Walmart unless there are rude employers, but I never encountered that. 

This Walmart is where my eye doctor is usually the workers are all nice, just depends on who us working. Some of the ladies are just gems. Others are... Mehhh.

Saw this had opened and have been meaning to try it based on what all my Midwest friends say.  I only stopped in for a sweet treat and the flavor of the day was turtle. I got a one scoop in a dish and took it home.  It didn't disappoint.  I was told I HAVE to come back and try the butter burgers so that's next on my list :)

Yes yes yes. I'm currently taking a break from devouring the lavender honey ice cream, which is astounding. Creative options abound; it was very tough to choose between the many varied options ranging from cookie monster to passionfruit meringue.

Hey y'all lets get crazy!  I was here yesterday as a first timer because i had a sushi addicted friend from hoboken visiting me.  

it's always hard to bring an out of town visitor into a space you've never yourself been - we walked into a super clean, trendy looking, mod space and I immediately got nervous - the place was like empty! But it was a Sunday on a holiday weekend so it makes sense considering center city as a whole was pretty quiet. my nerves were calmed as soon as the food came out - and i was quickly impressed with my first bite!

first off - the yelp check in gets you free edamamme.  hello! what a great deal.  the edamamme was fresh and salty and cooked perfectly.  great way to start off a great lunch. 

the staff was very fast and very helpful always refilling our drinks and bringing the food out fast. 

the presentation was GREAT. my rolls came out with a lil umbrella and my friends rolls came out on a platter with a very cute decorative sauce.  we were both HIGHLY IMPRESSED. 

the veg roll choices were overwhelming. 

obviously, as a vegan, i didnt have any of the fish rolls - but my friend said they tasted fresh and she enjoyed it a lot. 

overall i would say this is a five star place.  we didnt order any of the specials or utilize any of the combos available but i would say the menu offers a full range from very affordable to very opulent.

This meal was positively lovely.

We arrived on a Friday evening a bit early for our reservation.  The table wasn't ready yet so we sat outside on their small bench and the server who greeted us brought us some water.

Finally at our seat we perused the menu and settled on the heirloom tomato salad (feta on the side) and the bloody beet steak (yogurt on the side)  Both dishes were as excellent to taste as they were to look at. If there is something they know here, it's wow factor with food.  They have great presentation.  The beets were perfectly cooked and I love the play on meat even though it didn't contain any.  Each dish stood on its own and was rich but not overpowering.

For my entree, I went with the short ribs.  I expected tender short ribs but I was blown away by the sauce and the sides.  This dish was a symphony of flavor and even though I don't eat much meat these days, this dish was easily up there with some of the best I've had.

Service was excellent and they kept both our water and our beer glasses full (we split a bottle of Pumking)  This restaurant was an excellent way to begin my labor day weekend and my plan now is to come back for the squid ink pasta.

F & F, you've got a new fan.

The sushi was terrible. I am a huge sushi lover and found the sushi disgusting. They also wanted to charge me for ginger. Their price is $20 for lunch not $14.95. They also had only one serve for the entire Restraunt. Don't waste your money here. Go somewhere else have a proper descent quality sushi.

Ya'll come back! And you all should because this is the funnest tour company around Nawlins'

Took CE for a city bus tour, a swamp tour and a combination Whitney/Oaks plantation tour.  All three were absolutely wonderful experiences that expanded our horizons of New Orleans and the surrounding areas. We learned so much and had such a delightful time with every host.

Some things to note:
In the cold weather months you probably won't see many if any alligators on the swamp tours because they are bruminating (new word I learned that's sort of gator deep winter sleepy time).
Depending on where you get on the tour mini bus, you may or may not get a seat near the front or the back. If you are someone very picky about where you sit on the bus try to find out what the first stop is and get yourself to that first stop to get on and get your favorite seat.
When you're headed back at the end of your tours, frequently drivers will be kind enough to drop you along their designated route. So if you're on the way, you may get an extra special drop off as long as it doesn't inconvenience other passengers.

Remind her that there are no bathrooms on any of the buses so be sure to always use the facilities before you get on and off!

TL/dr: Best tours in/around New Orleans, hands down!

A new grocery store that is a smaller branch of Giant; welcome into the neighborhood! 

This location is amazing! It is clean with fresh produce as well as cut produce. It also has local pasta tomato pie and cheeses. It has a vast wine selection as well as organic dairy and a large freezer section this location appeals strongly to families in the area. I can see long lines in the future  for Heirloom.  (And South Square has some fierce competition!)

I recently attended one of the chef's dinners at Amerigo. They sell tickets to these dinners and have them once a month in Nashville. They also do the dinners at the Cool Springs location, on back to back dates. We were greeted & escorted back to at large room in the back of the restaurant. In that room was a HUGE table with people seated. There were 26 people on each side of the table. 

They had a large team of servers who brought out the different courses & drink pairings. The menu changes each month obviously & chef Steven Robilio told us that he tries to source local things for whenever they are in season. This February dinner was a little hard to get local produce, but the meat we had was local. 

Each course was explained & brought out. The timing was pretty good. We had 5 courses along with 5 drink pairings & it was about a two hour affair. I did notice that a lot of the people who attend the chef dinners were repeat customers. I also noticed that a lot of the clientele were seniors.

My favorites of the dinner were the pork lion & the meat balls in the Italian wedding soup. The pork lion was sous-vided & so tender. The meatballs were seasoned will & delicious. One thing that I did notice about the dinner was it was heavier than other course meals I've had in recent times. Maybe the clientele likes to feel like they're getting their monies worth, & they are. We left stuffed. 

One of the drawbacks about the intimacy of the table was it was almost hard to eat the food as the chairs literally touched each other. I kept finding myself trying to to elbow the gentlemen seated next to me. I think it would be much better if they either sat people at the ends of the tables or maybe used the table located on the elevated section of the room too. 

For the $50 price tag (plus 30% gratuity) I think it was a bargain in the Nashville food scene. I've been to course meals with pairings that end up over the 100 dollar mark easily per person.

This is a continuation of the previously written review: 

After the servers argument, he offered for them to cook me a new one, I agreed, but hubby was done at that point and he had had it, I saw a side back waiter and asked him to just bring my overcooked steak back, wrapped and we were ready for the check. The creamed spinach was good, not grand, the Greenburg potato skins were pure fried potato skins, no potato at all and served with a sour cream and horseradish sauce. Do it at home and save the big bucks. 

My big dilemma is we have more open table certificates that we would have loved to have used and we have no problem mentioning yelp, but they do, so I'm trying to even reason why I would want to return at this point Douglas? I hope you enjoyed your unwarranted $50.00 tip... Oh and I do hope that you read my little note on the receipt. The staff used to be welcoming, accommodating and friendly, seems to have gotten a bit snobbish, but I can take my $50.00 tips elsewhere and get a filet cooked properly without the sideshow. The service used to be stellar, but those days are gone.  

It's now a great place for older worn out men trying to pick up very used "ladies" or so it seemed, the blend of tables from floor to floor and the acoustics left conversations flow though out the restaurant, this is what made my night, have your piano player come in earlier. 

BTW, I made a dry aged standing rib roast for Christmas and hubby said it put yours to shame, I can also teach you how to cook a proper steak.
I haven't been to New Orleans in 6 years, but distinctly remember having the best veggie burrito of my life here.

Alright, I appreciated their willingness to seat a large group, especially one with 4 kids. But beyond that, it was terrible. The service was alright. The food was horrible. I hadn't eaten all day and was starving, and I couldn't even muddle through more than a couple of bites of the terrible pasta. And I'm a total pasta lover. I don't know how they could've screwed up penne with meat sauce so horribly, but they did. This is definitely not a place I would go back to.

If you find yourself wanting ice cream, this is the place to go (skip Coldstone, where I swear their mint ice cream tastes like toothpaste..ick.)! They have some unique flavors (with clever names) to choose from, but their traditional flavors are equally well done.

My personal favorites are Cookie Monster (which I believe has Oreos and cookie dough) and Black and Gold Crunch (which may or may not be seasonal, not sure). 

Tip: If you can't possibly choose one flavor and instead want a selection, you can order a sampler which has four small scoops. It's not too much more expensive than a normal scoop! 
They also cater (we used them for several events when I went to Tulane) and have even been known to create a new flavor for an event.

Three Muses was amazing! I went to dinner here with several friends and we decided to each order different items and share, which I'm always a fan of because you get the chance to try more! 

I started my meal with the Spaghetti Western cocktail, which is a rosemary and Campari spin on a Bulleit bourbon Old Fashioned. Living in Louisville I know the Old Fashioned, and this twist on one was delicious! 

Our group then shared the Cheese Plate, Marinated Olives, Smoked Tomato Bruschetta, Italian Baked Mac & Cheese, Two Run Farms Lamb Sliders, Bacon-Wrapped Bleu Cheese Stuffed Dates, and some delicious crab dish that I cannot recall the name of. Everything was amazing! The only thing I didn't try was the dates, because I'm not a fan of bleu cheese, but I had some of everything else and I would definitely gladly order any of these dishes again. My favorites were the olives, the mac & cheese, and the crab dish. 

The atmosphere was also great. They had live jazz and the service was awesome. 

If you're looking for a spot to have dinner in this area I highly recommend Three Muses! Just make sure to make a reservation, because it's small and it's a popular spot (so much so that there's a time limit for dining, but not to worry it's more than enough time, they just want to make sure people don't linger here all night and not give others a chance to experience this awesome spot).

Let's be honest for a second: long distance relationships suck. So, when my boyfriend came to town this weekend, I wanted to take him somewhere amazing!

Having visited Thailand this past summer, my standards are pretty high now whenever I'm on the hunt for good Thai food. This place honestly hits the nail on the head. First of all, I love the decor inside--it's super peaceful and cozy, and very intimate, without being stuffy.

Most importantly, the food is amazing. We started off with the Veggie Spring Rolls, which were awesome. I hate it when spring rolls get too mushy. These had the perfect amount of crunch! For the main course, I ordered the Chicken Pad Thai (always a crowd favorite) and my other half got the Drunken Noodles. By far the best Thai I've had on the Main Line. The presentation was beautiful. 

Our waiter was also marvelous. He removed our appetizer right as we were finishing up and brought our entrées out immediately after. He was very attentive and even cracked a few jokes with us. I wish I could remember his name; we gave him a great tip. 

Siamese Princess helped me have a truly warm and happy reunion with my boyfriend. I will definitely be back! I might even bring my parents here when they come to town next week.

I've watched Ted Drewes on Travel Channel over and over, so I just HAD to go there to see/taste it for myself (despite of lukewarm reaction from my boyfriend's family members).

We got there around 11 am. There was no line, so we proceeded to order promptly. My boyfriend got Cardinal Sin, and I got Pumpkin Pie. They were both yummy; however, they weren't as solid or shall I say "concrete" as I thought they would be. Is it because they had mix-ins? Or is it because it was 11:00 in the morning? Well, they were good but not the best custard I've ever tasted.

Notwithstanding, I'll go back there and try different flavours if an opportunity arises.

We took the half day plantation tour, visiting Oak Alley and Laura plantations. I've been to Oak Alley before. It is definitely a photo opportunity. Our tour guide here was obviously new and very nervous and not so great. I remember two stories that stood out the most when I visited 15 years ago: How they use a pineapple to signify when guests have overstayed their welcome and the whistle walk from the outside kitchens to the inside dining rooms. Well, this guide didn't even know about the whistle walk story.

Laura was FABULOUS. Our guide here was Bryan Dupree and he was a wealth of information and had a great sense of humor as well. We all really got a sense of what it was like living here in the past and what it was like for the slaves and owners.

Even though the Oak Alley guide failed, the overall experience was well worth it and I'd recommend it to anyone visiting New Orleans for anything beyond the drinking scene. There is another company that does the same tour for about $5 less, but when we were there, they were out of commission. Just letting you know there are options. Chat with your concierge.

After a looong tradeshow day (and a late night the night before) my coworkers and I were looking for a comfortable place to sit and some filling comfort food. Pasta is one of my go-tos for that purpose, so I reserved a spot at Amerigo. 

I've had the super authentic and the not-so-authentic Italian fare and Amerigo comes in somewhere in between. But I like it.

For apps we had the cheese fritters. I didn't find them particularly "Italian" but after eating them,  I think they should be served everywhere.

I had the shrimp bisque as well and even though I shouldn't have, I scarffed it all up.

Since rich and filling was the theme, I continued with the fettuccine imperial (grilled chicken and pancetta with mushrooms in parmesan cream sauce). It was excellent. I feel like I should have branched out, but that wasn't really my goal.

I didn't feel like I was back in Florence or anything, but the service was friendly, prices outstanding and the food was yummy.

I stayed at the hotel across the street from this grocery store so it was pretty convenient. I'm not sure if this store is 24 hours or not but I feel like all times of the day and night it was open and there is always police and/or security presence visible. And I can see why! There are definitely a bunch of sketchy characters here. I wouldn't feel comfortable going here alone. Most times I just needed to grab something quick like water or snacks, but the lines are always long. This place claims to have the cheapest prices in the French quarter but I disagree.

Came here before concert that we had planned. Got there early on a weekday and location wasn't busy at all. I thought for sure we would get amazing service this time around. 

We're sat right away.  Host/server (possibly even manager, not sure) tried to sit is at a table near the entrance. We asked to sit further back and almost immediately regretted it. 

We got our drinks immediately. Didn't get straws. I asked to sample soup, before deciding if I want a cup in addition to my meal. She wandered off and wanted to take our order before having me sample soup, which didn't make sense. It finally clicked and she brought me a sample. She took a little while to get our orders in, but we did get bar drinks at a decent pace. 

She didn't come back to check on us for a while. We got silverware and straws from another server. 
Our food came out, person who ran food didn't offer to add cheese to our meals. About halfway through our meal, our server came back to check on us. A little late for that. 
The gentleman in front of us must've been a regular because it seemed a manager and about four servers came by to check on him. 

Food was good. Service was okay. I like the food, so I think I'll give them another try. Maybe it was an off day. I was in the restaurant business for six years, so I know it happens.

This cosi is a good one! The lines can be out of control long around lunch time as everyone is grabbing lunch between classes, but the staff handles the rush well! The separate the ordering lines so that quicker orders are tackled pretty much immediately. If you just want soup head on up to the register! 

It can get pretty loud in the place during the day with students popping in and out so I wouldn't recommend for studying. Although it's a lot quieter in the evening when students have moved else where along campus and it's open decently late it you prefer a spot like that for studying. The upstairs seating is also always a good option as a lot of people forget about it. Otherwise this is a pretty standard cosi nothing to complain about. Oh and as with all my other reviews of cosi's throughout the land get the chicken TBM melt!
The best Rouses in the city. Always fresh meat and produce here.

This particular location of CVS is right on the corner of Napoleon and South Claiborne, near Ochsner Baptist Hospital.

Products: What you might typically find at any of these big box pharmacy chains---OTC medicines, Rx medicines, beauty products, supplements, photography accessories, snacks, etc. There are usually well-stocked, and their prices not unreasonable. 3 stars

Service: The management has definitely imparted the importance of the greeting when a customer enters the establishment. There's at least one cashier working at any time, but sometimes 2 during busier times, a security guard is almost always present, some pharmacy staff in the back, and they have "doc-in-a-box" service available for those requiring quick, non-emergency care. 3 stars

Facilities: A typical brick-and-mortar, flattop building you'd expect from this chain. There is ample private lot parking, and a drive through for the pharmacy. The major issue I've noted with the outside is the trashcan is not emptied often enough. Other than that, the exterior is quite nice. The inside is aisled, with the medical services in the rear. There is nothing really remarkable to say about the interior. It's usually tidy, though. 3 stars

Overall: This is a regular stop for me when I require a pharmacy. There is a Walgreen's across the street that's typically filled with all sorts of riffraff I try to avoid if I can. If you're in this area, go here instead. 3 stars

Umm... I wish this wasn't so walkable from my house. Any gains I make in fitness this summer are going to be completely offset by water ice and ice cream. 

I am the first to admit that water ice isn't totally my thing. I'm not from here and it just never appealed to me much, I didn't get the hype. Italiano's water ice, though, this is on another level (I haven't tried Pop's but I hear that place in on-par). Way better than John's!

There was quite a line on a Sunday evening around 6 but it moved quickly. Even with a relatively limited selection of flavours it took me forever to decide. I was jonesin' for a cone so I went with the strawberry ice cream and it was absolutely killer. However, when I sampled from of my friend's gelati with coffee ice cream and chocolate water ice, I was sold. Totally getting a gelati next time I come. I'm thinking black cherry water ice with vanilla ice cream.

It's nearby Jackson Square, the river, and Cafe du Monde.

I ordered the Alligator Sausage appetizer, and the Gumbo.

The Alligator and Remoulade sauce were tasty.  it was well seasoned.  The portion was a bit small for the $10 price.

The Gumbo is a skip.  It's taste was lackluster.  I would have preferred it with Alligator sausage, rather than Andouille.  It was $5 for a cup, and $10 for a bowl.

The server was super cute and animated.  Some of my party members said she seemed slightly rude, initially, though.  

They also had great, live, jazz music, as well.

With such a variety of flavors, from the everyday "favorite choclate" to to off-the-wall "blueberry mojito", there is something for every taste here! Along with a few favorites that make their daily appearence, there are several new flavors every week. There's always something new and exotic to try.

Want more than just ice cream? They also make decadent sundaes (not that the ice cream really needs anything) and fabulous sodas! 

Feeling daring, try the "Tchopitoulas Challenge": 8 GIANT scoops or ice cream, toppings, whipped cream, and wafers- $25. If you finish it all by yourself, you get a placard with your name on it!

Family friendly and located in a lovely part of town, on Prytania St., right down the street from the Prytania theatre (such a good date night all set up for you!)

If they have it, try the Oatmeal Molasses Cookie flavor (YUM!) or, if it's Saints season, the Black and Gold Crunch is always a crowd pleaser!

WARNING: CASH ONLY!

This Publix has been a staple in my life since my parents moved to Feathersound 10 years ago and I love each and every visit. Now, I've been a fan of Publix for as far back as I can remember, but this one has a bit of special flare that makes me love the brand even more. It isn't that they have anything in particularly different but jus the way the store is laid out. It appears to be a bit smaller than most stores and each visit is easy to navigate the store and finish a shopping trip in less time. 

I also appreciate the number of checkout lines. There are maybe 3-4 less than other larger Publix stores, but I've never had to wait in line for too long upon each visit/checkout. The staff here is so friendly and I love seeing the management at the front every time. 

Lastly, the parking situation here is brilliant. Since it is a shared parking lot with the SunTrust and other businesses there is tons of available parking. It's so easy to enter and exit, let alone find a great space. 

Love this Publix, as I do many of their stores.

the charbroiled oysters=LIKE CRACK! i thought it would be extremely heavy and sickening but definitely not! I could eat 50 without feeling sick. the alligator nuggets were okay, more tender than i've tried so it was good! got a seat at the bar with no wait, so check at the bar area first!

Don't eat at many spots in SB regularly...except for this one.  Granted, the place has lost a little bit of its luster over the past 7 or 8 years, but its still okay.  

First draw, the outdoor seating and general ambiance of the place - you get that eating in a courtyard feeling, which is awesome.  I usually eat lunch here when I'm in the area, so I haven't eaten inside yet. 

Like I said, the place has degraded since I first came; not sure if it's because of a change in management or recipe or if my tastebuds just got more mature...well, not really that, just that the menu has changed.  They used to serve this really awesome salad that they sadly, no longer even remember was there.  But I'm usually satisfied with the empanadas and a salad.  They have soup and salad combos too, but I never order those.  

Service is generally good - the place is rarely too busy and overcrowded.  Price - normal, you can get a decent meal for under $20 for lunch.  

Parking - This is downtown SB, so you're probably already parked in a parking lot nearby.

Popeyes normally ranks in the top 3 of my favorite fast food places, but... not this one. The spicy chicken wasn't spicy, and the meat inside was dry and stringy, and a bit rubbery. The line was very long, and the tables inside were very dirty. Not sure I'd come back to this particular Popeyes.

If you're looking for affordable, yet quality sushi, one of my favorite spots to recommend would have to be Crazy Sushi in the Rittenhouse area. An added bonus? It's BYO! 

It's a slim, sleek space with comfortable seating and a sushi bar at the end. 

Salad
 
Salad was fairly standard with fresh Romaine. The ginger dressing was clearly freshly made. 

Vampire Bowl [$9]
Spicy tuna tartare, avocado bowl
  
A must order in my mind is the Vampire Bowl, their unique take on tuna tartare. I loved the contrast in textures with the crunch from the tempura and the creaminess of the avocado bowl. The sweet wasabi mayo was balanced by the light heat from the spicy tuna. 

Vegetable Tempura [$5]

The GF's a sucker for veggie tempura and this didn't disappoint. A thin layer of tempura coated mushrooms, sweet potato, and carrots. It came accompanied with a light tempura dipping sauce. 

Beef Negimaki [$6]
Scallion, thin-sliced beef, teriyaki
  
On this trip, the negimaki was a bit disappointing. The beef could have been more thinly sliced and better seasoned, though I appreciated the bite of the scallion amidst the teriyaki glaze. 

Triple Sushi [$25]
Tuna, salmon, yellowtail, tuna roll

The triple sushi featured some of our favorite nigiri rolls, including salmon, tuna, and yellowtail. All very clean-tasting and fresh, the platter also came with a tuna roll. I appreciated that the tuna was whole and not minced within the sushi. 

Uni Sushi [$8]

I was also in the mood for uni so asked for an order of uni sushi. Then again, when am I *not* in the mood for uni? Sourced from California, these were creamy, light, and buttery. 

Bloomingdale Roll [$13]
Spicy tuna, spicy salmon, spicy kani, spicy yellowtail, spicy shrimp, avocado, longan
  
I was also intrigued by their Bloomingdale specialty roll. The pink seaweed seemed a bit more delicate in texture and taste, supporting the sweetness of the lychee. This contrasted with the subtly spicy mixture of tuna, salmon, crab yellowtail, and shrimp (whoa!). Due to the laundry list of items, the flavors were a bit muddled, but definitely veers toward the sweeter side of a sushi roll. Interesting! 

Sweet Potato Roll [$5]

Of course, we also had to try our standard sweet potato roll. Crazy Sushi has one of the best iterations, with a wonderful juxtaposition of creaminess from the sweet potato and a light crunch on the exterior. The black sesame seeds studding the surrounding rice made for a perfect bite. 

So if you're not looking to go omakase and want a relaxed sushi meal, I'd recommend checking out Crazy Sushi. Whether you're looking for Americanized rolls or nigiri done right, they've got you covered.

St Louis tradition! Custard is my favorite form of ice cream. It's so smooth and creamy! This custard is delicious with tons of toppings to choose from. I can't give it a 5 star because they only have vanilla! What? No chocolate? Every custard stand should have chocolate custard. I must admit, for someone who never orders vanilla anything....this was still very good!

Oh....my....gosh!

We had never been but heard soooo much about this place.  Had no idea it's this little dive bar with plenty of parking (the time we went) and where you just walk up to the bar and order your pizza and drinks, then find a table.

We asked what pizza was popular - which one had we been hearing so much about.  They recommended the Chicago style.  We got a small and still had 2 slices to take home.  It was so freaking good!  I can't way to go back.

Love the product (Ice Cream), but not so fond of the long lines and the slow service! The line on the night we went wrapped around the store and then extended outside. But even one you order, you still have to wait for your name to be called to receive your ice cream. I was surprised that 2 scoops of ice cream in a cone would take longer than 20 minutes after I've ordered and paid!.

The office had a working lunch, so ordered in using 569.DINE. I don't know what they pack the food in, but it's always delivered with the hot stuff hot and the cold stuff cold. Man, does that work.

There were five of us, and I couldn't keep track of everybody's food, but it was gobbled up heartily.

Here's what I saw around the table: two large house salads that were huge (and they were ordered as sides), fried fish sandwich, Dagwood, cheese quesadilla.

I got a small house salad that was still massive. It was fresh and crunchy with beautiful, crisp cucumber slices and diced tomato. The bleu cheese dressing was tasty. I also got the original hamburger with Cheddar. I ditched the bun, but it looked rather fresh. The burger came with lettuce, tomato and onion; I used all of that. Even though the burger was flavorful, it was a bit dry. They didn't ask how I wanted it prepared, a shortcoming in my book.

But the pickle was delicious and tangy!

Ordering from Market Pub House worked for our group, because of the variety of offerings. There was something on the menu for everyone.

Typical fast food americanized Mexican. The young lady at the counter was very sweet and got our orders right. Service with a smile, she bid us a good day when we were leaving. 

Food came out fast and they got all the orders right. The women's bathroom was clean and well stocked as well. If I were in a pinch I'd go back to this location.

Still delicious and they follow dietary requests to a T. I love their American-style Chinese classics like egg rolls, fried wontons and chow Mein, the menu is classic! Plus they are really nice. What more can you want?

Food is good and the prices are very reasonable. I recommend the veggie burger (homemade with nice chunks of vegetables and beans) as well as the pressed chicken sandwich. My boyfriend got the turkey burger last time we went and it was awful, so I'd steer away from that. Their frozen yogurt is my favorite menu item...it is the oh-so-popular tart flavor and at $4 for a large it can't get any better. Overall a good, reasonably priced place with a large menu to satisfy almost everyone.

I have been here a few times.  My primary doctor moved out of the area, then retired, so in the meantime I figuired I would try this place.  Well, I am very impressed.  They exceeded my expectations.  They are quick, they have a lab and an x-ray machine and probably a lot of other things I couldn't see.  It's a good place, and you don't need an appointment.  I would just suggest getting there when it opens so that the wait is minimal.  They are a 4-4.5.  My former primary doctor was a "3", maybe a "3.5" on a good day for wait times and overall customer service.  Why settle for the status quo when companies like this can do what a traditional doctor's office can more efficently.  They also have a pharmacy onsite, so that even saved me time.  I would go back.

charbroiled oysters are now a staple of the New Orleans culinary landscape.  supposedly Drago's started it all.  

this location is located under the Hilton Riverwalk, and we were staying there so.... we made the trip downstairs to enjoy the oysters and show.

we sat at the bar and enjoyed watching those guys work the Friday evening rush.  three giant grills were all covered in oysters.  the'd let the heat build, apply some garlic, cheese and butter sauce and the fire would soon follow.  flames would start to rise up and they'd battle the flames with a garden hose.... serve the bubbling oysters and reload the grill!  it was fun to watch.  

we only had the charbroiled oysters and they were good.  I'll make a special note that the hostess and our waiter all checked on us several times and made feel like they really did appreciate that we came in.

Went here for lunch and had steamed shrimp and teriyaki baked wings. Great food and quality. The customer service was outstanding by our waitress, always checking in on us, making sure our table was clean, and topping off our drinks.
Standard DD w drive thru option!

Walking here and back home, helps me justify the calories.
(Round trip is about 5 miles)
My favorite concrete is M & M's, for some reason - I just keep ordering it time again and again. I also like raspberry.
However, every year my first order is always just a dish of the custard plain - to experience the best frozen custard in the Midwest.
Whatever your favorite is, it will make a great concrete or sundae. You'll also enjoy checking out all the celebrity autographs in the window

Alton Brown's favorite beignets when in New Orleans and I agree!  Compared them to the beignets at Cafe Du Monde, and the beignets here are the clear winner!  Delicious beignets!  Perfect crispness on the outside.  Steaming hot and served with powdered sugar on top.  

The atmosphere at the Bourbon street location cannot be beat as well.  Lots of tables and chairs to enjoy the beignets and the live music!  Definitely more inviting than Cafe Du Monde.  

Definitely must do when in NOLA.

I just had a couple of pizzas delivered tonight. It's Mothers Day, my hubby is working, I didn't want to cook, and wasn't in the mood to go out... Anyway, this definitely hit the spot and I came up with the ultimate veggie lovers pizza to order from Pizza Factory. They don't have much for veggie lovers in their specialty pizza selections, but this should definitely be added, in my not-so-humble opinion.  ;)  

I ordered a medium gluten free cheese pizza and then added: mushrooms, spinach, red onions, artichokes, and tomatoes (I got them cooked, but you can have them added after it is baked, too). It was a beautiful marriage between all of the veggies and their amazing sauce. Their sauce has a delicious fresh tomato taste. By the way, their gluten free crust is probably the second best out there that I have tasted so far (and it's quite a bit less expensive than my number one choice plus a bit thicker and therefore more filling). 

I also love the fact that their gluten free pizza comes in a medium size. It's the only size (most restaurants only offer gluten free in one size), but many only offer them in small. This is much better for us. 

My son prefers Meat Lovers types of pizzas; the more meat... the better. I ordered him a Wolfpack. It contains: mozzarella cheese, ham, Canadian bacon, sausage, pepperoni, salami, and bacon. He was one happy guy!

I was also happy to get a special price on the Wolfpack pizza tonight. When I called, I asked if there were any specials and they happened to have one that included this in a medium size. 

We actually ended up paying a bit less tonight for these two medium specialty types of pizzas than the last time I had Dominoes delivered and ordered a medium plus 2 small gluten free pizzas (two of them were 3-toppings each and one gluten free was a specialty). Both times we had leftovers, but we actually have quite a bit more leftovers this time, with a more generous amount of toppings, and higher quality. I honestly thought I was saving money at Dominoes. Nope! (In case you don't know... Once you start adding in gluten free pizzas, the coupons don't apply, they are more expensive for the same size pizza, and the crust is always a thin crust that may or may not taste very good.)

Every time we go to this particular Pizza Factory, it just seems to get better and better. This was the first time having them deliver, though, and it went smoothly, too. 

We are actually planning on meeting many friends there again later this coming week and no... I'm not getting tired of it. I believe that they are much better than most (if not all) of the similar types of pizza places locally. This is especially true out of all of the ones who deliver AND have gluten free.

their tagliatelli al limone with freshly grated Sicilian bottarga is mind-blowing!  if I were to know when my last meal on earth would be, I would make sure to have double portions of this pasta on my table. it has the perfect balance of brine from the bottarga and acid from the lemon - which brightens up the entire dish and keeps you coming back for more.

seriously, it is a must try!
Typical casual fast dining place in Nola. If you have a quick lunch order a head, cut the line, and eat while everyone waits in a long line :D

Oh, Ted Drewes--want to touch the heiney!

I am not from St. Louis.  My husband is.  Ted Drewes on the ol' Route 66 is perhaps the first place we stopped on my first trip to The Lou, which just happened to be in the dead of winter.  Why, in the dead of winter with a parking lot full of Christmas trees, were there loads of people in line for more coldness?  Why?  Because it is damn amazing, that's why.  And really freakin' fast.  

Don't let the line frighten or deter you, 'cause it's just one short wait before creamy dairyland bliss.  My first concrete (basically a blizzard, but with better chunks and handed to you upside down to demonstrate its concrete-ity) had real peach slices swirled through the vanilla custard and is tied for my favorite concrete with the TeDad's--local St. Louis oatmeal cookies are mixed into that tasty treat.

I love that the place runs like a well-oiled machine by teenagers working towards a Ted Drewes-sponsored college scholarship and that you can buy cartons of the stuff for your own enjoyment--we even had some at our rehearsal dinner!  Even better, they'll pack a pile of frozen custard with dry ice so it survives the trip from STL to Chicago.

Yeah, I know STLians are sort of fanatical about Ted Drewes (but that's sort of normal from what I can tell, because they're basically fanatical about anything STL in general), but this is not unfounded loyalty and love.  I used to say that a trip to STL was wasted unless we visited my frozen custard heaven... now my love/hate relationship with lactose limits the visits I can handle.  Even with the belly aches, though, every trip to Ted Drewes is so worth it.

*Edit* 2/5/08

How dare you, Ted Drewes.  I move to St. Louis in the dour month of January and you're CLOSED?  WHAT???  And now it's February and you're STILL CLOSED?  Geez, if I'd known better, I woulda stayed in Chicago til Spring!  Bah.

If you have a large group of friends that want to do this, its a great time, the only downside is that it is pricey and you still must provide your own alcohol. My only recommendation for the owners would be to offer a "reserve a seat" option, not just a "reserve the whole bike" option. I would personally love to do this more often during the summer, but struggle to get my friends to do it with me. You can only have cans and plastic bottles on the bike...which isn't a problem if you stop by Sun King for some fresh cans on your way to your bike appointment. 

I went for a ride on the HandleBar late in October as a team building exercise with some of my colleagues. The driver was great and even suggested several common stops/routes so that we could get off and go into bars to have a group drink/shot. 

My team at work commonly discusses our experience, and we often talk about doing it again in the spring. 

About 2 weeks before Christmas I got a Christmas card in the mail from one of the owners. Handwritten, custom HandleBar Christmas Card thanking me for using them and wishing me happy holidays. That kind of customer service goes far in my book.
We come here all the way from center city for the shaved ice. So, so yummy. Bean paste, red band, jellies. We've tried the strawberry and green tea so far. Worth the drive.

Five-star food and three-star experience makes for a four-star first impression. After my first few meals at Doc Fords on Sanibel Island, my expectations were incredibly high. This location is fairly new, thus some wrinkles need to be ironed out. 

First of all, I was impressed with the ample parking considering this area tends to give me anxiety. Metered lot and short walk to the main entrance. 

Hostesses were friendly and welcoming. Wait time was 35-45 min on a weekday afternoon during a holiday week. Inside seemed crowded so we requested outdoors. Our first table was melting us, so they kindly moved us to a table in the shade.

The patio deck faces sunset so be prepared to sunbathe. The ground below offers more space between tables plus umbrellas. Water views and gulf breezes made it more relaxing. Would recommend they "bird proof" the area. Birds squawking, swarming tables and stealing food wasn't the Doc Ford's vibe I took from the island. 

Our server was such a pleasant person but may have been too busy for us. Everything was slow to arrive, and visits were too few and far between.

Our food was absolutely delish! Yucatán shrimp was just as heavenly as remembered. Gluten free flatbread pizza was divine!! Some portions were slightly smaller than Sanibel but no one left hungry.

Came here for restaurant week and obviously had to get the prime rib. The prime rib was cooked perfectly and the mashed potatoes were delicious. The only bone I have to pick with this place is the quality of the appetizer. The salads were so messy and drenched with dressing and where's the fresh grated parmesan cheese? Yes you're a fancy classy restaurant with perfectly cooked prime rib but that doesn't mean the presentation and quality of something simple as a salad can be ehhh. I would recommend for having such simple and few choices of appetizers, they should still be presented at their prime.

I give this place 3 stars AT BEST. I honestly think the food was 2-star, but the cool decor, atmosphere and the creativity bump this place up another.

As others have mentioned, I came in knowing that the noodles at this place would not be authentic. That's fine by me, as long as Cheu's interpretation was tasty. However, I was disappointed, even with my bar low. 

The Pork Belly Buns- were good, but a bit on the greasy side because they pan-fried the buns itself. Then you top the pork belly, and you get a the heaviest single bite you can get. Pork belly was good, but I've had better, at many places. I felt like the pork belly itself was lacking something. I added their house spicy sauce (on the table) to cut through some of the greasiness.

The Pork Belly Ramen (I love pork belly, can you tell?) broth was lacking depth. The noodles were a bit hard and gritty. The sea beans were CRAZY salty. The pork belly was the same as those in the buns- good, but nothing I haven't had before.

If I were to come back, I would try the other dishes because I do feel the menu items are inventive. However, I would be reluctant to go back anytime soon.
Fries were hot from the oil, which is good. The burger was super-thin and lost in the bun; not very flavorful, either.  My family loves their shakes!

Wow, the service inside was awful. I felt like I was in a frat house. All the workers were hanging out, joking and laughing while food sat on the counter and people waited to order. The burger patties have really shrunk over the years. Now they are twice as much and half the size. The particular Steak and Shake was dirty, the floors were so greasy I almost slipped sitting down in the booth. The burger was really good but too small for the money.

I think this place is an great place to grab some wings and catch up with your friends. It may get busy and crowded at times but it's a great place meet new and old friends. This is the original Hooters so that's something to be proud of and most of the girls will help you no matter what. 

The food has always been good. I love the blue cheese burger, wings, raw oysters and the buckets of oysters!

Lunch buffet for $7.95? Sold!

It was a crappy Saturday afternoon & we wanted something fast but tasty, so when we passed by the restaurant, we made a u-turn & headed in.
