The buffet was simple, only six or seven main dishes, but everything was delicious. I love raita, the yogurty lemony sauce that I generously topped on everything. The curry was good, but the standout dishes were the chicken tikka and masala, plus the fragrant rice.

Other than the grumpy staff, we enjoyed the quick meal and will certainly return.

LMAO you all don't need me telling you that this place is awesome, it's a Five Guys. The burgers are no nonsense, juicy, generous and sinful. The atmosphere is that of a no frills burger temple. 

You come here because you want the nostalgia burger of your childhood. And that's exactly what you get.

I tried to get reservations several weeks in advance with only super late options available, so I expected our Friday evening @ 5:30pm slot to be crazy packed, but it wasn't! We beat the dinner crowd and are officially becoming old people. First impressions? Awesome decor. Nada is a Cincinnati transplant connected to Circle Centre mall downtown Indianapolis. It's inside boasts an explosion of cheerful color and intentional details. A little too replicated for my taste, but definitely bright and funky. The fun doesn't end there as their menu displays an exciting variety of Tex-Mex fusion options.

Husband and I started with the Guacamole. Of course. Solid, but a little bland. Their chips have a unique flavor, as well. More like chunky crisps than chips. I moved on to the Braised Chicken Enchiladas with a side of Sweet Chili Glazed Nada Fries (really just soft chunks of cooked potatoes). Pretty good stuff here, but I couldn't resist sampling Husband's Truffled Mashed Potatoes (although I did manage to avoid his Pork Belly Tacos, so success was had). I should have stopped there, but I knew it would be a while till we went out to eat again, so I stuffed my already full belly with some Warm Chocolate Torte. SO GOOD!!

All in all, Nada brought a strong showing. Attentive service, fun flavors, cool modern vibe, and slick downtown presence. And here's where I break it down to the nitty-gritty. You have to really present to impress me with your Mexican fare and I must say that the authentic offerings of nearby Adobo Grill have this place beat with a little more warmth and charm. Nada is still great, but the competition is pretty fierce. Is there room in downtown Indianapolis for multiple upscale Mexican dining rooms? I guess we'll find out.

This take out spot well off of Main Street is a tiny hole on the wall with 3-4 people working in the open kitchen, which really is just a couple stoves. The pad Thai and drunken noodles were really good. I'd recommend this place for anyone looking for a good cheap take out.

The chicken here comes in chicken tender-sized pieces. You order by number of pieces, and they weigh it and charge you by the pound. You have the option of breast or boneless dark meat. Supposedly they have drumsticks as well, but I didn't see any actual evidence of this, nor would drumsticks be cost-effective due to the bones. 

At just under $9 per pound, 7 pieces of mixed dark and white meat ended up costing about $7, plus 50 cents per sauce. We tried the green goddess ranch and chipotle lime sauces, but I wasn't really blown away by either. The chipotle was heavy on smokey flavor, but I couldn't detect much lime. The ranch was all right, but I've had better. The chicken itself was good though. The white meat wasn't dry, so I actually slightly preferred it over the dark meat, which could be a little fatty and a tiny bit tough at times (and I usually prefer dark meat). The original pretzel breading is nicely seasoned and crispy, with a nice texture. Their special flavor (Thai coconut basil something) was pretty good as well. 

It's nice to not have to go all the way to Fednuts for decent fried chicken.

Absolute heaven in a cup! When I told my friends I was going to St Louis, more than one highly encouraged me to check out Ted Drewes. Solid recommendation!

Ted Drewes has been crafting delicious frozen custard since the early 1900s and is an attraction on Route 66. The staff are super friendly and keep the line moving. I went in the early afternoon and the line wasn't terrible at all. There was also plenty of room to park. While there are not a whole lot of seating options, it's no big deal. I found a bench but most people were in their cars. I went with a sundae--vanilla custard, topped with hot fudge and raspberries. It was divine!

The other thing I noticed was that people really want to share the love of Ted Drewes frozen custard. There were lots of parents there with kids, people on dates, etc. I shared my bench with a grandfather and his granddaughter and they were so sweet and enthusiastic about their Ted Drewes! This stop is well-loved by locals and people passing through on Rte 66.

5 stars for Drago's famous charbroiled oysters. Best oysters I tried in New Orleans! (even the bread it came with was the best!) Highly recommend and must try when visiting! Can't put it into words, it's just life changing. Our uber said she doesn't even eat or like oysters, but she'll eat them here because they're really good. It's also neat with the open kitchen to see the magic happening :) 

Side note - Also tried the lobster mac and cheese - it was good, cheesy, satisfying, but not enough lobster. Would not get again. Stick to the charbroiled oysters!

The charbroiled oysters were amazing.  I can see why so many rave about this place.  The service was quite good as well.  

However, I think I need to try it again as there was just something lacking.  All would say this is 4-5 stars, so I just need to try again on my next trip.

The burger was good, but when the girl who worked the cash register while wearing gloves goes back and then prepares the food without changing gloves, this place needs to do a better job training their employees in basic sanitary practices.

The atmosphere was cool, the beer was good, the place was spacious...I don't see any problems with this place.

Getting there:
This place is down the street from downtown, near the river. However, you can't see the river from the brewery.

Experience:
This place was really cool. There was lots of room, everyone brought their dog, the staff was abiding by COVID guidelines. We did a flight of beer. They don't have a huge selection, but the beers I tried were pretty good.

This will be a short review on service and grilled oysters. I had been here about 5-6 years ago and don't remember being that good. After eating a ton of food already in the day, but my fiancé wanted to hit up one more spot before we leave. So it was about 1:30 pm in Sunday labor day weekend, but it wasn't too busy. We were quickly seated and the waiter can't by to take our order. We said just waters and the oysters. Now I don't like oysters that much but these were pretty darn good. Not too cheesy and cooked well. And hot. Food came out fast, Check too. In and out w a good snack.

I prefer CVS over other pharmacies as I can generally get in and out of their stores without a lot of hassle, or a long wait at the check-out lines.

This particular CVS is at the intersection of Gunn Highway and Anderson Road, in the same little shopping plaza as Bank of America. Even though they close at 10pm it is still a very convenient place to stop as I drive up and down Gunn on my way to Citrus Park. If I need a 24-hour drug store then I drive over to the CVS on N. Dale Mabry near my house.

The store is compact, but fully stocked of the necessities of life, and their prices are certainly reasonable. This is my go-to spot for last-minute toothpaste, mouthwash, bar soap, shaving cream, razor blades, etc. There are certainly cheaper places to visit if you need paper and plastic products, dishwashing soap, or a quart of milk, but it's tough to beat the convenience of CVS if you're in a hurry.

They do have a pharmacy in the back of the store that stays open till 10pm, and their pharmacists are super helpful and friendly. I generally get my flu shots at this store since it's quick and easy with no appointment needed.

Just OK. We came tonight on a Saturday night around 830pm. The wait time was told 25/30 mins but ended up being about 10 minutes only. Wings & curly fries are hot & GOOD! Clam chowder was thick & medium brown color. Did not taste good. The sweet tea was NOT good either. 3 star rating because food quality service was just OK. I still enjoy Hooters wings but I would rave too much. This particular location has a huge selection of novelties to bought Hooters gear. Great BIG selection of cups / clothes etc.  If you need Hooters gear come here. Food is OK

Very solid sushi BYOB. I loved the presentation of the sushi-the One Night Stand roll was served in a cute martini glass. All three rolls we had were good-One Night Stand, Crazy Sushi, and Bonsai roll. 

The decor is very hole in the wall and it was really loud on a Saturday night which made conversation tough. 

I will definitely be back.

Only problem with this restaurant is that is closes a little earlier than most of the other Chinese places in the area. This coupled with the night owl tendencies of my group I usually barely make it in the door before closing. Otherwise they have the best Chinese food in the city.  Service is best I have had at any restaurant in Chinatown. Their hot and sour soup is be best in the city as well as their salt & pepper squid.

Such an amazing Sunday brunch spot! With a great waterfront view of Tampa Bay I might add.
Its $39 for unlimited brunch buffet and bottomless mimosas & champagne. They do have a regular breakfast, lunch, dinner menu as well btw. 
The buffet includes oysters, sushi, fajitas, waffles, omelets, and a huge dessert bar! Love seafood and love desserts so it was perfect for us. 

The server was great- drinks always filled and dirty plates out of the way. and we got a table pretty quickly.
I think a lot of people host events like bridal showers and such here and there's even a gazebo outside for things like a vow renewal we witnessed. 
 I would suggest making reservations because they are pretty popular, esp for these Sunday brunch days.

The
Palette
Of flavors
And late hours
Are excellent for surviving summer.

This place is seriously awesome. I've been on a few different occasions now and am never let down. The staff is really friendly and they actually engage in conversation. The plates are beautiful and the food is great. On my last visit, I got rock shrimp, and two veggie rolls.

Typical brewpub atmosphere and menu. Loud music on the patio, loud tv's inside. Could use some better signage as it's difficult to see/find and there's no direct entrance off Racetrack.

Server was great and recommended several beers and menu items (none of which we ordered and thinking we probably should have). Instead we ordered the pretzels, french onion soup, and greek salad. All were nothing special and I would not recommend any. Broth in onion soup had a very strong rosemary/thyme flavor that overpowered it. Pretzels and cheese were exactly like those served at Hofbrauhaus (disappointing) and beer cheese was a very small portion. Side note: server recommended wings, burgers, pizzas, and calzones - will try these if I revisit which I'm not in a hurry to do.

These are good!

I've been looking for a good taco spot near me, and this definitely fit the bill. The tacos are yummy, and made fresh with each order. They're served with a variety of sides and toppings for you to customize them, your way. 

The space is clean and welcoming, and there's ample parking in the attached lot. Couple that with the friendly staff, and we have ourselves a winner!

Cajun Encounters has excellent customer service. The staff responded to my emails within an hour of sending them and answered all of my questions each time. The company is also one of the few that are open for tours on Christmas Day. However, despite the "local flavor" of this group, be prepared for much of the same touristy feel complete with crying kids and exasperated parents. Tour groups are always kind of a crap shoot, I guess, and Cajun Encounters is no exception. 

I enjoyed the Swamp Tour a lot. Our guide had the perfect mix of wry humor, interesting facts and amusing stories. Furthermore, he was clearly passionate about what he did and loved his city, so he didn't sound like he was reciting a rehearsed script. The tour itself takes you through some beautiful passages within Honey Island Swamp. Those silver, hanging Spanish moss curtains you see in pictures? They're real. In person, they are so utterly beautiful that I would actually recommend you tour the swamps in the winter than in warmer seasons. You may not see as much wildlife (although we still managed to see (and handle) a baby alligator, 2 snakes, 4 turtles, 1 magnificent blue heron, a beaver-like creature, and a mama wild boar with her 2 piglets who swam out to our boat for 20 mins feasting on the marshmallows our guide threw), but there is no foliage to mar the beauty of all that silver.

The Plantation Tour was much less impressive. Not so much for the plantations or the guides, but rather that it was very poorly planned. We were given far too much time at Laura Plantation (about 3 hours) and far too little time at Oak Alley (about 1 hour total from disembarking to re-boarding). Personally, I was completely unimpressed with our guide at Laura (who for some reason pronounces "archives" with a hard "ch" like the herb), and do not understand why people rave about the tour here. I was ready to leave halfway through. Oak Alley on the other hand is just as majestic and beautiful in person as it is in all the postcards, and the tour guides are far more captivating. Every single person in our group was disappointed with the lack of time we had at Oak Alley.

We come to M3 for the starters as they have a great selection! Our selections are always the creamy burata and charred tomatoes with grilled sourdough baguette, Fire roasted Artichokes with herb aioli, and spicy steamed Mussels with garlic bread. All of these selections are delicious and paired with a glass of wine or draft craft beer make an excellent meal. Service is always great and love the industrial-vibe atmosphere!

Photos: http://www.flickr.com/photos/karmanlee/sets/72157601624685403/
I love frozen custard! Love this place...tons of flavor to pick from...

Lines are still long when we get there after dinner....

Wish it wasn't so damn hot last night, my frozen custard melted so fast!!!!

Much like all of the Marathon locations, I liken this place to an upscale wanna-be hip version of Denny's with a liquor license.

I go because it is convenient and relatively cheap.  They specialize in perfectly acceptable executions of perfectly ordinary food.  A few items (gingerbread pancakes, and the fries when they are not soggy) stand out as being very good.  However, every now and then they manage to completely eff up something simple like a salad.  There is often a silly wait for brunch, and I have repeatedly run into the issue of the hours and menu posted on the door being irrelevant to the actual hours or menu available.

The service is extremely hit or miss.  They often apply the chaos paradigm where four different people (say the hostess, water boy, waiter and bartender) are all involved in taking orders from and bringing stuff to your table, and the likelihood of everyone in your party actually getting all of the things you ordered at remotely the same time is slim to none.  They have a generally solid beer selection and execute their cocktails well.

If you go here with middling expectations, you will not be disappointed.  The meal experiences are always inherently better than at the actual Denny's - due, in no small part, to the aforementioned liquor license.

Not sure why this place gets so many raving reviews. They're understaffed and the non lassi food they serve is like a huge jambalaya and way oversauced with spices. The mango lassi was the only positive experience from this place. Probably won't be back here, unfortunately. Would not recommend

Describe this pizza in three words... Super Yummy Delicious!

Well, that's what the menu says but I'm here to corroborate. 

Finally did the dance with Food + Drink tonight and it was fun and delicious. Ordering online is great, and with the specified pickup windows you get fast, friendly and damn near personalized service too! 

Due to Covid the dining room is closed. Hell. They aren't even letting guests set foot inside. Hallelujah! 

It comes out fresh, hot and right to your car, so all you have to do is drive away! 

The cherry picker pizza is the truth, and that's coming from a carnivore! Heirloom cherry tomatoes atop a fresh mozz and basil pie, sweet, savory, and punchy! 

But finding good toppings isn't the hard part of making pizza. It's really iall about the dough, and owner Aaron Foster learned from the masters and keeps their methods alive! It takes him 2 or 3 days to make it, so when he says there's only 20 pies available tonight, he means it. Order early and order often!

We also tried a standard pepperoni. Thats a spicy pepperoni! In a good way of course, if you like it spicy, which I do. My kiddo thought it was too hot for him, so he gave them to me and I happily added them to my cherry picker.

This pizza requires a lot of time and effort to create, and Aaron is hands on from start to finish. As a result of all that handcrafted hard work, this Za' ain't cheap, but it's totally worth it. 

To keep it in check you should know that a pie and a salad can safely serve at least 3 hungry adults, probably four, especially if you add some "magic cookies" or their housemade ice cream or margaritas!

If you haven't been, grab your phone and order NOW for tomorrow night!

NOTE: This place closes over the winter season. Go to the other Ted Drewes on Route 66 (6726 Chippewa St, Saint Louis, MO 63109).

The menu can be overwhelming especially since I wanted to try everything. With the help of the lady taking my order, I narrowed down my choices and ordered the fox treat. And it was amazing. I really enjoyed the fresh fruits in my sundae but I think I wouldn't get the fudge next time because it became a bit too sweet towards the end.

My friends and I ran into a local as we were leaving and she said that this place is amazing and she has been going here once a month for as long as she can remember! This place is definitely a must see if you are visiting STL!

After watching the popups, the name change and finally settling on a location, I made my way to Cheu Noodle Bar on a Friday evening with a buddy to see what it was all about.  What I found was a very cool, fun, fresh take on a noodle bar and I'll be returning.

The space here is a bit tight and most likely you'll have a wait on a Friday or Saturday evening.  We chose to wait it out at Varga (conveniently located down the street) while our table cleared out.  It didn't take terribly long before we were at our seats and ordering.

I was very impressed with the black garlic wings.  Heat and sweet were the tastes that hit my mouth but I did feel the dish was put together nicely.  The wings were cooked perfectly and it wasn't too sauced.  It had just enough to leave a nice impression.  The dumplings (potato, egg, cheese, chili oil) were not my favorite due to the filling combo, but I would not be opposed to trying more of their dumplings (if they change).

The star for me was the lamb neck hand torn noodle dish.  The spice on the lamb was killer, and it was falling apart while I tried to eat it.  The mustard greens and dates brought those other flavor punches that made this dish truly excellent.  I would come back and eat here just for this.

The spot is fun, the music is great (I heard mostly A Tribe Called Quest) and the kitchen worked really well together in the space they have.  I think these guys are doing a great job and I hope they will be in Philly for a while.

I love places like this....

It's an old-school hole in the wall with no table seating - only about a dozen or so seats at the counter.  The walls are whiteboards -- convenient for noting the changing daily specials.  

Here since time begin (or so it seems), there's nothing high-brow on the menu. It's classic diner food with a St. Louis twist.  I ordered breakfast and asked for the St. Louis version -- with chili.  Expecting only a small drizzling of chili, what I received was enough for a meal by itself.  If you order something here, make sure you're hungry because they don 't skimp on the food or portions.   Overall, it was a decent meal for a reasonable amount of money.

The cook worked efficiently; and everything --  the freezer, toaster, grill -- were within arms reach.  All the time she worked she kept up a running conversation with the two or three regulars.  The banter was equal parts funny and serious.

It's a cash only business, but does have an ATM squeezed into the small aisle.  If you're looking for classic diner food in a low-key atmosphere, George's will do nicely.

Yelp scores another hit!  I had the BBQ chicken and my friend had the buffalo chicken.  We also had some queso to split, not knowing that the portions were so huge.  Shame on me for not reading the reviews more carefully before ordering!  Had I done that, we would have gotten one quesadilla and shared.  As it was, I had a tasty lunch for the next day.  Can't wait to be back again, loved the late dinner discount prices!!

Located on Rocky Point off of the Southside of the Causeway bridge, I've been coming here often on throughout the years. I was here typically for professional events in the larger room and other venues. More recently, visited here with a small group in the main restaurant area. The interior decor has an old-school rustic look to it in the main restaurant area the whole eastern "wall" is actually a large glass window that overlooks the intercoastal bay water (Towards east).

On our most recent visit, our waitress has been very helpful and honest when giving us advice on any selection that's on the menu. She was awesome, but I wish I could remember her name (regrets). The visit here was during the weekend at the time. The restaurant had a few people seated and everything was nicely set and clean.

The lemon garlic shrimp risotto (had recently) was delicious, but definitely a one person serving so I would recommend at least one side dish. The cocktails are good quality here also. It's a nice stop for lunch, dinner, or personal life event celebration.

Four stars for the drinks and three for the food.  The Magazine location is where I usually end up going as it is close to my house (and Sunday they usually have happy hour all day and I like to get my double margarita for the price of a single).  I need to disclose that I'm not really  a big fan of Mexican (and I got really REALLY burned out on Mexican food and anything wrapped in a tortilla while I was exiled to Austin for a year and half due to Katrina).  They often play headbanger music (sometimes WAY too loud) so that is a bit of a strange combo of Mexican food meets goth death metal.    

This can be a great place to eat by yourself and grab a quick bite to eat or go with others and hang out for awhile.  I usually get either the tacos or enchiladas here as it is a quick and relatively cheap meal (they usually bring you the green and red sauce but you have to REQUEST the yellow habanero sauce).  They have a good rotation of different specials (as much variety as can be expected within the limited repertoire of everything has to involve a tortilla in someway Tex-Mex food).  It does get very crowded sometimes and there can be a wait.  The bar usually turns over pretty quick but some days people just linger for awhile. 

They have some very well decorated people working here (and by decorated I mean seriously tattooed up) so it can be entertaining just to watch the staff in action and they do usually provide really good service (the Mid-City location is famous for bad service and that is why I rarely go there).  They make some of the best margarita's in New Orleans and have some good cold beer so a great place to drink and decent place to eat.

This place is so cool because you can actually get half scoops. So if you want a small, one scoop of ice cream, you can get still two different flavors. I don't eat a lot of ice cream so this is new to me! The workers were very friendly and helpful. I had fun coming in here. They have flavors of the month and their top seller is Captain Butterscotch. I liked Double Fudge Brownie and Key Lime Pie but I didn't feel like they mixed well so I will have to pick one or the other next time and mix it with something else. 
 
Loved: 
- Captain Butterscotch 

Liked: 
- Double Fudge Brownie

Ok: 
- Key Lime Pie (flavor of the month)

My constant craving of Ice-cream always leads me back to Creole Creamery. I tend to go to these independent shops as I feel they really do provide a unique experience along with great tasting treats. This place has many flavors with unique names and tastes. On different occasions I may just get a scoop or sometimes I indulge in a banana split. Huge scoops here so be sure to have a big appetite. My friend had the sampler of like 5 different chocolate scoops. Each one rich and very different. I had the Lavender Honey before and it was smooth and creamy. Such an exuberant flavor to choose! I can go on and on about their extensive list of flavors, but you could check out the website to see the list. Things from Witch's Brew, Wasabi, Mojito, to Doberge. I usually always take friends here who are visiting the city or who have just never been before! Don't forget to bring cash though!

The only okay thing about this place is that you can find some good deals here. They have toiletry essentials and other goods worthy of a starving student's budget. There is a price for these reasonably priced goods and that is putting up with the stank of the store.  Is it just me or is there a really ugly stench plaguing the store? I suppose it's just the classy smell of kmart.

It definitely took a while for me to get used to life without Target.  The day Target realizes they would have a strong market in SB/Goleta is the day this place shuts down.

Oh and one more thing for my fellow videogame fanatics: videogames here are waaaay overpriced!  Your best bet is to shop online for these goodies.

Maddening. This should be a 4.5/5 star review. Nashville is at a tipping point when it comes to bars/restaurants. I have heard time and again how difficult it is to find/keep good FOH/kitchen talent but doing so is essential to the business plan. I don't want this city to fizzle out when there's so much potential yet to be tapped. The fact of the matter, though, is when you're asking the buying public to dole out significant dollars, you have to be on top of your craft every time. You do.

My first experience at Ellington's came during their first week. I was (pleasantly) stunned by how well they tapped into the '70s cool of that era's James Bond, Hart to Hart, The Rockford Files, etc. Rather than depressing, the brass, browns, wood paneling, and large plants set a mood. This was punctuated by the music/muzak. My mood was further elevated by the menu. The choices of classic and signature drinks were well-curated (here, it makes sense to go with the classics). I was happy with my feta/watermelon appetizer and the shrimp & grits were delicious. Despite not having gluten-free desserts, I enjoyed the 1970s-era cups my post-meal coffee came in. I left happy. Very happy.

Then, I came back the following week and the wheels fell off. This time around, the place was busier but not so busy that you couldn't sit. We were warmly greeted by the hostess from the previous week. Rather than being seated by the window (by the patio), we were seated by the wood paneling/mirror banquette. Fine so far. I liked having the new perspective of the dining room. I spied my waitress from the previous week and it looked like we were in her section. Nice! Hopefully she remembered my generous tip. And then we sat. And sat. And sat. We stared awkwardly at each other. My guest started to get annoyed and I got embarrassed. No one interacted with us. We weren't given so much as a glass of water. We felt extremely unwelcome. Finally, our hostess came by with water and a smile... but that was it. The waitress from the previous week who was being so gracious and charming with other tables twisted her body so as not to have to acknowledge us. Again. We sat. And sat. And sat. By this time, I am past being embarrassed. I am angry. A floor manager finally comes by to take our drink order. She says that she put too many covers in our server's section and that was the reason for the protracted delay. A few things about that: 1.) A lot of covers =/= being unable to stop by the table and say, 'Hi, folks. I'll be right with you and I'll have a runner drop some water off to you. Thanks!' 2.) There were other servers/runners in our section joking with and serving customers (who arrived before and after we did). 3.) No mention of 'Let me get you started with some drinks/apps on the house. So sorry for this mix up.' None of these things happened. Rather, after a tepid excuse for being treated like filth and watching our server - the same server I over-tipped the previous week - treat other guests with professionalism, I decided to leave. I went to the host stand, informed them that they could cancel my order and that we were leaving. In the midst of this, who should arrive? Our server. For the first time. Nope. Please continue to ignore us. You were doing that so well. The floor manager took my name and number and offered to have a manager call me. I left Ellington's and retired to the Fairlane lobby. I noticed two people from the restaurant had followed me down there but neither engaged. I used my Yelp app to find another eatery, left and have no plans on returning.

It's a shame.

This place opened up in the old Philadelphia Cheesesteak spot.  A great add to this neighborhood and they have the drive through.  They have huge portions, and the prices are great.  Each time I've been it was nice and clean, and they are friendly, and food is served fast.  I've had the nacho's twice and probably will again.  




7/21

good chinese food, not the best but it's up there.

not the biggest restaurant, but the service was wonderful.

egg drop soup: decent, could use a bit more seasoning. a big portion so def share

hot pot fish: this was probably the best dish of the night. seasoned very well and the fish was cooked well

shrimp lo mein: least favorite dish. the noodles were way over cooked.

orange chicken: i personally liked the tanginess of this dish and thought it was breaded well but the pieces of the chicken were questionable. they weren't full big pieces of chicken like i'm used to, a lot of little pieces.

overall, it'll satisfy your craving of chinese food but i'm still on the lookout for my favorite chinese in the city

Lunch was clutch here, as of now it's counter service and sit where you want. Got to try a decent amount of items here with that flexibility. I do want to try dinner here, but it can be a hard table to get as the popularity is growing and size of the restaurant isn't that large. Plan head on this one if you're aiming for dinner, otherwise lunch is a nice option.

The food during lunch time was excellent, lot of delicious flavors with each dish that made me definitely want to try more of the menu. Well platted aesthetically and well put together chef wise makes the food taste as good as it looks. Definitely recommend this restaurant and look forward to trying more from them next time I'm in town.

We had to come in when we say a sign claiming how highly rated their burger was. 
I wouldn't say it's nearly the best burger I've ever had... it was okay. 
The service was good. The tots+ cheese was AMAZING. The originally burger and the mushroom burger were the 2 we got and they were okay. Nothing like burgers I've had in Chicago!

I like that this place was really upfront and said-- hey, we're a bunch of white guys who like ramen and other asian stuff, and we're gonna make it out own. I appreciate the asian fetish being spelled out. While this place is pretty small (and therefore often has a wait) it's a pretty cool place to have a low-key delicious dinner. 
Yays: fun place to get ramen not in Chinatown with a quick and efficient staff
Nays: i miss the authenticity and didn't really like paying a higher price to sit in a not very comfy place (lots of stools and hard chairs)

If I lived closed to this noodle bar, I'd pop in more regularly because the food wasn't at all bad-- but not really worth me waiting an hour for.

The farm and fisherman and their bloody beets steak were on the top of my must-have list in Philadelphia.  It took some effort, but I was able to secure a table of 5 with my girlfriends on a Sunday night.  Please make a reservation if you decide to come because this restaurant is small.  It has about 10 tables, very minimalist with a feel of intimacy.  The only complaint I have is the lack of a hostess when my party entered.  Although they were around and about, no one took the initiative to approach us.  Our evening did get better from that point, so it's a non-issue.

We ordered two of the famous bloody beets steak to share.  This was only my second time trying beets but it made me an instant beets lover!  Now, if only I can have the recipe so I can make my beets like that every time.  That's what the dish does to people.  Even those who hate beets would change their mind.  Oh, it isn't so bad after all.  The yogurt and bulls blood (seriously?) were perfectly harmonious with the beets.  It was sweet and a bit tangy.  Just the right amount of sauce and god, the wonderfully well-cooked beets!  I can't imagine anyone would say this often.

The second course was the Stuffed Rhode Island Squid with chorizo, a special of the day my server mentioned.  It came with two, perfect to share, and the chorizo and Valencia rice were gooooood.  Chewy squid and soft interior.  It was a delicious combination.  The main course for myself was the stuffed trout.  I was worried that it would be an overkill on "stuffed" type of dishes but my server assured me that they are not the same.  I can't decide which I liked more, the stuffed squid or stuffed trout!  The stuffed trout had kale and bacon bits inside with crispy, chewy skin on the outside.  Not to mention, the farm and the fisherman makes the best sauce to compliment their dishes.

I was honestly very happy with my choice - in restaurant and the dishes.  It is currently the best overall meal I've had in Philly (and I've definitely been eating well..thank you Philadelphia and your never ending list of good eats!)

By the way,  I made the reservation on yelp!!  This is way cool :)

The only meat I get from Chipotle is Carnitas. They didn't have any ready and were just putting it on the grill raw. i dont understand why they would wait until they were out of it to start cooking some more. Instead of giving me a time, she just said they didn't have any.

Overall: An under-whelming taco experience and a mess service-wise. Good, but not great, and definitely still worth a try if you're craving tacos/Mexican.

The good: Beautiful atmosphere and fun as well. The tacos are good sized portions and the prices are reasonable. A good mix of options to choose from taco-wise. 

The bad: The food was surprisingly bland. The tacos were good but over hyped, the chips were stale and cold and salty, and the salsa and guac were underwhelming. All good, but nothing great. Slow slow service, had to wait forever for seating and throughout the meal.

Atmosphere: 9/10
Service: 6/10
Food: 6/10

I can't believe I haven't reviewed TCC yet! This is one of my long time haunts, ever since a Thai friend brought me here in high school. I love it because it's inexpensive and good with a HUGE, HUGE amount of vegetarian options! 

Yeah, the place is kind of kitschy in atmosphere, but it's big and there is rarely, if ever a wait. It's also clean. Service here is usually pretty good. We went last night with the International Supper club, and the service was lacking a bit, but there were 25 of us (they knew in advance though.. and only 1 server). I'll cut them slack because usually the service is good.

As for food, even though TCC is owned by the same people as several Thai places in the area, they just have THE BEST spring rolls - fried, of course! They are small and come with this amazing sweet and spicy sauce. YUM!! I also always get a Thai ice tea to accompany it. It is pretty sweet, but I love it. I usually order number 51, which is noodles in a brown sauce with broccoli (I don't get tofu or meat, just veggies). My most recent experience, I got #66, Masman curry, which was extremely yummy!! I got it mild (I'm a wimp) but it had a little spice to it and lots of veggies, potatoes and peanuts. The serving is more than enough.

Definitely my go to place when it comes to Thai!

I came here with my friend who had a gift card to partake in the float experience. This review is based on my feelings and my feelings alone.

Customer service was great and super friendly and considerate. He was sweet, hospitable, and super accommodating. There are no qualms about customer service and atmosphere of my visit. If anything, he is what carrying this 2 star instead of 1 star experience. 

 The float  tank itself seemed a bit disgusting. Not by any means because of the type of water it was, but inside the tank on the walls and crevices were disgusting. I have posted photos to verify this. If I am knowingly aware floating in treated water that other naked bodies are in rotation in and plus the built up grime on the interior walls, that didn't really give me a firm chance to be at ease during this experience. I feel that it is important to maintain a level of hygiene when experiencing this and though I felt hygiene was done right with the first part of the visit, being in the tank itself left me with a sickening feeling of disgust. Like I said, I am not unfamiliar to using spa treatments and things similar to this experience. It is simply a matter of cleanliness.

What I can say about this experience once you get over the disgust is that I did feel relaxed and enjoyed the chance to remove my mind from all exteriors and simply relax. It was a great environment for the right purpose, but I did feel unsettled due to the constant feeling of being in a place that hadn't been cleaned properly from my point of view. I am purely going on first impression. As someone who has never done this before, no one wants to get into a tank and see reminiscence of God knows what on the walls and around the filters or jets.

Would I give this another try? Yes, but only after I felt that the place had been properly sanitized in the tanks. I am happy to reconsider my experience and rating of Float Nashville if I better understood why it looked like this and felt like I was floating around in something unsanitary - chemicals or not.
Here for a gift I was wanting to buy for someone. But didn't get any help with the front desk. Probably they were too busy and there was a long line.

Came on the recommendation of yelp. I was worried when I pulled up because I thought the place was closed. The grass and trees hid the building. The neon open sign let me know it was in fact open. Boy, you can never tell a book by it cover. When we entered, we were taken aback by how nice the inside and decor was. We were quickly seated and given some veggies in a red pepper vinaigrette dressing and hot tea. The food was amazing. The wonton soup was the best I ever had. I had the shredded beef with hot pepper. It was fantastic and the perfect balance between spicy heat and flavorful meat. The general tsos was sweet with a great kick. Fried rice and chow fun rounded out a great meal. By the time we left the place was packed. Lost a star for the exterior. Check it out, a must go to.

I really enjoyed my souvenir shopping experience here. Fair prices!

It was a tranquil calm in the hectic city of New Orleans. The cashier was super helpful and told me about the different spices of New Orleans and we even had a brief discussion of New Orleans cuisine. 

Super helpful and friendly, and to top it off, the prices were super fair. The Cafe Du Monde chicoy coffee were the same prices as ordering it from the take-out counter at the Cafe Du Monde flagship shop across the street! The spices and hot sauce were comparable to super market prices too. Needless to say, I bought all my gifts here. What's there not to love here?!

One of the best yogurt places I have ever visited. A lot of unique flavors and toppings making it well worth a stop. Try the peanut butter, tart and fruit flavors and you won't be disappointed. Only drawback was the ridiculously long line midday visit this location in the early afternoon or evening for less foot traffic.

Super tour pour faire le bayou! (apparement, le meilleur)
Pick up à 8h ou 10h ou midi, et retour 5h après environ
1h45 sur le bateau dans le bayou, à voir tout plein d'animaux (alligators bien sûr, mais aussi oiseaux, serpents, araignées, tortues, phacochères, etc.)
Très bon service client, que ce soit le chauffeur qui nous a amené en bus au bayou et le gars du bateau
Là-bas, avant que la croisière commence, vous aurez le temps de vous restaurez au besoin et il y a une petite boutique souvenirs
54$ prix régulier; rabais si vous prenez un autre tour (demandez à votre hotel ou agence)
A faire absolument! :)

Over cooked meat is a crime for a burger joint. Not that they asked how we wanted it cooked.
Nothing blew my mind especially for how long it took.
Wiki wiki burger had a unique flavor and I liked the pineapple addition.
Grindhouse was just okay. Didn't seem special.
Meats were different but not particularly flavorful.
Onion rings were really good! Sweet potato fries were decent.
We went and ordered take out. 15-20 minutes turned into a lil over a half hour for two burgers. Shorted staffed on a Saturday? 
Friendly staff. I  will be back for beers after they get their liquor license. Maybe will give the food another try.

Joella's, I'm a fan of your quick service, fast-casual atmosphere, push-the-limits spice levels, and menu options (Which sauce? Which side?). I'm into some heat but not into torturing myself, and the "Tweener" sauce was just right when balanced with sweet, syrupy waffles. Your mac & cheese makes for a great side, but your garlic parm fries are the best, hands down. 

The only thing keeping me from returning to Joella's more often is the drive from downtown to Carmel.  If you're ever in the area, stop in for an awesome meal. Just don't expect to be very active afterwards, as this comfort food will weigh you dowwwn. Oh, and skip the nutella poppers. I love Nutella so much I would marry it and I wasn't too impressed with the texture or flavor of theirs.

Tip 1: Get a reservation! Thankfully I did so, and when I walked in at 6pm on Saturday night, I gave a slightly condescending smile as I breezed past the couple who had been told that the next available reservation was at 9:30pm. Sorry, not sorry. 
Tip 2: this is a small plates type place so plan accordingly. I didn't do much reading besides making the reservation and seeing that this place is a top pick on Eater.com. I should've read up more on the menu and portion size. Being from the Midwest, I'm a big eater, and little plate meals never fill me up. I lucked out when my tofu bowl was a sufficient dinner portion. My husband wasn't so thrilled to find a small plate sized portion for his hanger steak and had to order sliders to accompany it. That said, everything we tried was excellent. I was especially impressed that they offered a tofu bowl here, along with other vegetation options. My impression of New Orleans is that it's a big meat-eating place, so it was nice to see additional, well executed, meal options. 
Tip 3: bring cash to tip the entertainment. The singers were great and they walk around with their tip jar after their set. Don't be the ahole who doesn't have cash to give them.

Let's start with this simple fact: I love Popeyes. Rolled in 4 deep for a quick lunch during a long car ride at my suggestion (insistence involving an illegal u-turn through an unpaved stretch of gravel). 

They have dr. Pepper and orange soda and the piece de resistance, strawberry soda, at this location. Boom!

I knew exactly what I wanted. Three piece SPICY tender meal with Cajun rice and don't you dare forget my biscuit please. Oh, and can I get some packets of Cajun sparkle, thank you very much! The others hemmed and hawed and ended up with regular tenders, corn on the cob, and Mac and cheese. They also got BBQ and honey mustard dipping sauces. Amateurs. 

Allow me to take you to school on Popeyes. A. Always order the chicken spicy because they make it fresh for you AND it tastes better. B. The acceptable sides are red beans and rice, Cajun rice, Cajun fries, mashed potatoes.

My friends complained about the grease. It's  fried chicken folks, get a grip. The complained about their sides, which did look congealed and gross. They complained about the bathrooms, which were one seaters and admittedly putrid. The complained about the tables that hadn't been wiped down. They complained the next day that their stomachs still hurt from Popeyes. Oh really? It was the chicken and not the 17 cups of ronrico and diet you drank? 

Popeyes, I will be back for your steaming hot finger licking spicy chicken and the light flaky buttery biscuits, but I'm leaving my pussified friends at home.

PS... There is a super wawa right next door. If you need to use a bathroom, I highly recommend going there, as I did. Then you can pick up some laffy taffy for the ride home, too!

I had a pretty good experience overall. The service was very friendly and fast. The sushi was very tasty. We had the Hell roll, spicy tuna and another roll I can't remember the name of that was equally good. The Hell roll is always my favorite here as I really like spicy food, but don't take my word for it. Try it out.

This was my first time to stop here at this outdoor restaurant/bar with live music. The weather here end of July was nice. As you can see from my pics I stopped here for a nice bloody Mary, which I enjoyed. I bought my Bloody from the bar. I seated myself at an available black cast iron table and chair nearest to the live band. I was able to enjoy their live band's local music, while sipping my bloody. I would definitely stop here again to enjoy a cocktail and live music.

This was my first time at Caio.  My family ordered a large tomato and a large half plain half pepperoni pizza.  

The pizza, was pretty average and I don't think I'd order it again. Sauce to cheese ratio was a bit weak...I couldn't taste much sauce. The dough was too chewy for my liking. 

Now onto the tomato pie....yum!! Sauce was delicious, and I'd definitely order it again. 

As for the price, I paid $30 for 2 pies. A bit steep if you ask me.  So I ask myself, will I be back? Maybe, but only for the tomato pie!! $30 though? Maybe Caio has a bogo night, or perhaps they can price the average pizza more appropriately.

Boise Brewing is a great little brewery conveniently located in downtown Boise. 

Came in here on a weeknight for a post work brew. I ordered an imperial stout while my beer swigging partner in crime opted for the Snowboarder Porter. Both were solid. We debated on who had ordered better--but couldn't decide. Because really?  Both were equally pleasing in their own way (stout was full of flavor--porter was lovely and smooth with subtle notes of chocolate).

We ordered at the bar and took our beers to their upstairs seating area. The atmosphere downstairs is open, industrial, and a skosh on the noisy side. Upstairs it's a little quieter, a little comfier, and a bit more chill.  

Plus--foosball anyone? 

We were able to chill in relative peace, overlooking the activity below for 45 minutes.  I'm not sure the waitstaff actually serves up there (servers came upstairs and cleared away empties--but didn't address us other than that).  But, truly, the place is so small, and the service at the bar was so quick and friendly, I have no probably heading to the bar for refills.

The downstairs bar/seating area opens up to a small patio area as well.  It's not fancy, and a little no frills--but you can definitely enjoy a brew while sitting in the fresh autumnal air.

For my part, I could definitely see myself heading down to enjoy a brew and chill sesh in their upstairs loft.

Get to it!

This restaurant came very highly recommended to me, so I had to try it a short while back. These Danny Boy Fajitas were also specifically recommended, since fajitas with a combo of meats is a fave of mine. 

The food was good, but not quite to my personal liking. It was definitely missing some kind of sauce or salsa. Not sure if it usually comes with it or not. That would have gone a long way. I didn't ask for any, because the server was in the back for quite awhile and until I was almost finished. I often have a late lunch when I'm out and about, so probably catching some of these restaurants at the wrong time or something. It's unfortunate. I also read something just now about the chips and salsa being kept full. I did not get any at all. Hmmm.

It was filling and the meats, onions, and peppers were grilled to perfection. There were some other reviews complaining about the low number of tortillas. Definitely not enough tortillas for all the filling, but I couldn't eat it all in one setting anyway.  ;)  By the way, if you go with the corn tortillas, you get one more (probably smaller, though). It definitely was not an issue for me. I like to eat a lot of the goodies on their own anyway.

I can maybe see myself returning some day, but I will definitely get something else on the menu since in my opinion there are several others that do fajitas better.  I did see some other rather tasty-looking dishes come out to other tables when I first arrived.

Nice group of people. This is VERY small. Will take just a few minutes to scan around. It is in open courtyard for the most part. Taqueria El Pueblito  has excellent food at an affordable price. 
Would be very pleasant place for a lunch or snack in the courtyard on a sunny, warm day.

Quick tips: Delicious and deceivingly strong house margaritas. They have one of my favorite quesos. Veggie tacos are build your own - onions spinach and bell peppers made for a good mix, they have loads of veggies to choose from. 

Food: um i love their queso, I want to bathe in the queso. The only drawback was the queso was a little bit small, but I guess if I wanted to bathe in it, anything would be small. The combo tacos are best with the double layered corn tortillas. Don't forget the house margarita, which is so well crafted you forget you are drinking tequila until you are stumbling out the door after your second (yes I'm a lightweight!) 

Service: great service! Our waiter was super nice and funny. 

Ambiance- I wish they had a better waiting area in the front. There was a long line to eat, but we were served quickly. Have a margarita while you wait and go window shopping!

Fabulous redfish! Get it with the crabmeat atop. It is an excellent addition! I've already told y'all about the chargrilled oysters, get 'em and don't think twice! Also tasty are the fried crab claws and the apple cobbler. Heck, I've never had anything that wasn't delish!

This place is extremely overrated. First of all, it is at the heart of downtown Indy, so goodluck on finding parking. If you want to park anywhere nearby, you need to pay that notorious $20.
Secondly, this place is very snooty. Asked if I made a reservation for lunch? I don't see any Michelin stars nor do I see you being all full. In fact I find plenty of tables open and only 1 person at the bar. We were seated towards the back of the restaurant, a party of 2. We were seated at this super small table 1 end connected to the booth another with a chair. The table was wobbly. I am sorry but our table was already full with just water cups and condiments, how were we going to put plates on it? Asked if we could move to a booth, after waiting for 5 min, hostess came back and said they all other tables had reservation and this is the only table they could seat us at. Now I really have a problem with restaurants that do not give their upmost to customer service, because otherwise, what are you? The restaurant was at most 20% full on a Saturday lunch time. By the time we left, it was still around 20% full, so why couldn't we have sat somewhere else? We asked if we could put two tables together, and they agreed, thank the lord, otherwise I think I would have walked out. 

Other than this, stay away from the salsa and chips. They were no good. Though they are unlimited you won't want to get more than 1 batch. Salsa did not have any flavors and chips had a weird texture and super greasy. I looked around the restaurant and it seems like most people also did not touch their chips.

Ordered the pork belly taco and was advised to add the egg. I do agree. Probably one of the most perfectly cooked sunny side up egg I've seen. Too bad the pork belly did not taste good and the rest of the taco was meh. Other person in my party had the chicken taco, he said it was just ok. I ordered the beans and rice and seriously, I thought I was missing rice. It came out with the beans super puree and it was poured on top of the rice, it was super small portion wise and it did not have much rice in it at all. We also got their so called fries, which are not fries but wet potato wedges. They had this special house sauce which is like mayo mixed with bbq essentially. That side was kind of weird, so be careful if you are not into something too different.

The biggest thing I have to rave about this place is the decor and ambiance. Very very cute, even the bathroom. Makes me wish my apartment was decorated this way. But what is the point if their food and service was no good. Our waitress was probably over occupied. She never refilled our water, though she was courteous she tried hard to get tips, I don't blame her. She tried to strike a few awkward small talks.

The Rusty Pelican is a fusion of an upscale dining room and elegant banquet rooms with a water view. The place is normally dimly lit during the evening and brings a great atmosphere for a romantic date or just a casual rendezvous. The price is pretty decent for French and Italian style cuisine and for their specialty seafood dishes. They also have a pianist that plays classical to modern music and valet parking during the evening on the weekends. 

They give complimentary sour dough and raisin and nut bread. I love when restaurants give you something while waiting for your food. My favorite dish is Seafood Mixed Grill which includes Salmon, Balsamic & Sweet Vermouth Sauce, Crab cake, Mango Coulis, and a Skewer of Shrimp and Scallops topped with Citrus Beurre Rouge and is about $23. The salmon was grilled perfectly! Other times I've tried their specials of the week and they're pretty unique and good. On my friend's birthday she also received a free fiery creme brulee. It was pretty sweet! But considering the prices, with a party of 4, the total bill can be up to $100. That's pretty pricey for my lifestyle, but it's fun once in awhile for a nice occasion.

Overall, the service was pretty good on a busy night. The servers are warm and welcoming, and are pretty pleasing and attentive. But on a really busy night, they might be bombarded with huge parties and sometimes it's not that great and it gets pretty loud.

Be sure to call in for reservations and ask for a window table, it's worth the wait and is pretty great when you can watch random things so close by. 

The only downside is that the location is pretty hidden and kind of difficult to find the first time. Google search their location. Also, they have only one restroom in the entire building. So if you can, go before you go...

Outstanding!  Everything was outstanding!  I've been a fan of this business for a long time, but I'm even more of a fan now with this second location practically in my damn back yard.

No matter what kinda beer you drink, they've got you covered.  If they don't, ask about their seasonal options.  If they have the tripel, GET IT!  If they have the Summer Days, GET IT!  Ask questions later.

Hungry?  No problem.  From pizza to burgers and pasta entrées, again they've got you covered.  During this most recent trip, La Chica and I split the following and left STUFFED.

Ale Cheese Dip - Hands down the best beer cheese dip I've ever had.  Lacked the awkward bitterness of most beer cheese dips.  Just smooth and light, like an American lager.  Comes with what seems like a whole damn loaf of bread.

Butcher Burger - Very, very good, but very, very busy!  With 3 meats in the burger, it's a lot for my taste buds to take in.  And then with all the toppings, forget about it.  It should be called the sensory overload burger.  And with a $14 price tag, I'd suggest sticking to one of their regular burgers.

I saw someone order a calzone, and WTF?  Who is eating that thing?  It was the size of a small child.

Service was fantastic.  Bathrooms were extremely clean, and they have a system in place that catches waste water, and they use it for irrigation.  Being green makes green!

Will definitely be returning, and sooner than later.

Yah Mon was absolutely delicious, they definitely deserve their rating! It's a bit hidden and in an awkward location, but so worth it. I had the oxtails and wasn't able to finish it was so filling. I was really upset that I forgot my leftovers in my hotel fridge. Both of my friends absolutely love their dishes as well. Good ambience, good service, good food, no complaints!

Cici's is probably one of the most under-rated pizza joints. For only $5.99 it can't be beat. The employee at the register was very friendly and they even have an app now that you can use to get points per visit that you can use towards a free pizza. You can also get 1 personal pizza per visit and they have brand new boneless wings that were pretty good. 

The restaurant is definitely old and dated. The seats on the booths are ripped up and the place is showing it's age but I'd come back since the price is right.

Much to my surprise, the Tudor Glen Medicentre (that has been there my whole life) closed on August 31st and moved to McKenney.

I haven't been to a Medicentre in years, so forgive me if my complaints are just par for the course... but I was really not happy with my visit.

First of all, on a Sunday, there are 2 receptionist working, but only one doctor.  When I checked in, the lady said the wait would not be very long.  She didn't give any specifics - I should have asked.  The wait was 2 hours in the waiting room and then over 20 minutes in the exam room before the doctor came in.  I'm actually not complaining about the wait - It's good to know that the doctor takes his time with the patients.  But there was a serious issue with inconsistent messages coming from the front desk staff.

I sat down, and the next person who came in and went to check in was told the wait would be over an hour.  What?  Is that what we call "not very long"?  okay... weird but whatever, I'm already there.

The next person that came in was told the wait would be 2 hours.

The 10 - 15 people who came in after me were all quoted between 1 and two hours - very inconsistently.  

A lady came in with a UTI (I shouldn't have been able to hear that, but the chairs are set up very closely to the front desk) and when she said she couldn't wait two hours, she was told to come back tomorrow.  

Once I was in the exam room, I noticed two signs on the wall.  They each stated that 2 different doctors will not prescribe T3s, T4s or Tramadol (one will not prescribe any narcotics).  I understand the apprehension of prescribing such medication to patients that you are not familiar with, since this is purely a walk in situation.... but shouldn't those signs be placed in the waiting room?  Imagine waiting 2 plus hours to get in just to find out that the doctor won't prescribe what you're there for.

Anyway.... I'm sure I'll be back since I think this is the only Medicentre in town.  but... meh.

I can't tell you how happy I am to finally have a great Italian restaurant in the neighborhood! While I loved Fitler Dining Room, it was more of a once in a while restaurant for us. I can see Trattoria Carina popping up on the rotation far more often. 

The restaurant was buzzing on Saturday night - we lucked into one of the last open tables outside and it wasn't long before people were placed on a wait. At this time, reservations are not accepted. I kind of like it - there aren't many places that offer first come first served, so Carina is perfect for a night when you didn't plan ahead but still want a nice dinner.

There is a short list of cocktails and also red, white, rosé and sparkling wine, which you can get by the glass or bottle. The menu is broken into starters, salads, pastas, mains and sides. We wanted to try a little of everything so we ordered the meatballs, pumpkin salad, tagliatelle with bolognese, shells with crab, branzino and broccoli. 

I thought all of the food was nicely prepared and presented and tasted great. I love a good plate of pasta and neither of our pasta dishes let me down. The shells may have won out by a small margin - the tomato sauce was just spicy enough and I loved the toasted breadcrumbs for some texture. The branzino was perfectly cooked and I really enjoyed the citrusy tomato salad underneath. Also, those meatballs! If Carina ever opens for lunch, I really hope they put a meatball sandwich on the menu. 

I'm looking forward to many more meals at this neighborhood gem!

Perfect spiciness! Not too much, not too little. We suggest the lassi drink, it's a thin yogurt based drink, it calms the heat when you can't stop eating the delicious food! Our large party ordered just appetizers and we had leftovers. The service was excellent and the orders were perfect, no mistakes. We basiclly tried one of every appetizer and everyone loved every single thing. I obviously can't remember the names for everything, but it was helpful that there were a few people of Indian descent in our group to help everyone enjoy the dishes that weren't obvious to figure out. Some needed sauce on top then eaten in one bite, others needed something spread on bread. Overall I can't wait to go back with my mom because she'll love the vegetarian options available. My dad will love it too because they can make most things without any spice at all.

This was the first time I had experienced a full-size supermarket in NOLA. I'm used to the itty bitty Rouses in the French Quarter. But this Rouses...Oh this was the Stop & Shop of New Orleans.

Huge store with everything you could possibly need either during your vacation or if you live there (you lucky, bastard). Rows and rows of food items. A HUGE deli area, followed up by a Cajun deli area (yes, really). They sell Tasso, Crawfish, baked goods, etc. I was here in hopes of picking up some stuff to take on the plane ride home with me. If I could transfer this supermarket to NY, I would. Oh and the staff is really friendly, to boot.

Came in with the fam and spent quite a bit of coin here. Some of us got ice cream, milk shakes and slushies. The employees were great and helpful and also knowledgeable on the products. We ended up getting tons of chocolate.

Fabulous BYO.
Get the bloody beet steak. It blew my mind!!! AMAZING!!! Thick slab of beet. I don't know how they cooked it, but it is awesome and so is the sauce.
I also tried the Duck ravioli which was very good, but unfortunately for me, the beet steak really overpowered it. It was a lovely dish, but unmemorable and didn't really wow me.
The red snapper with tarragon, fennel grapfruit and potato gratin was wonderful. Lightly seasoned and cooked to perfection. It was a great dish and the flavors worked well together.
The duck leg dish with risotto was also very good. Earthy tone to it. A little heavy, which is expected. Very delicious.
Every dish was very well done. I would return for the beet steak in a heartbeat and also for the red snapper.
Service was very friendly and attentative. Cannot beat a BYO. Small restaurant so you typically need a reservation.
A bit pricey, but this is definitely a place where you come for the food quality. Nothing was itty bitty so it was all worth it.

Right on the edge of Center City Philadelphia is a bright and cheery Dominican restaurant called Parada Maimon.  This is def a good place to know about as it serves down-home Dominican food in addition to breakfasts and items like Philly cheesesteaks at incredibly low prices. Everyone is friendly here and the food is tasty.  Their lunch specials served all day are amazing.  I recently enjoyed the oxtail platter which came with yellow rice, salad, black beans, and sweet plantains for less than $7.  Wow!  But you def have to add one or more of their pastelitos.  The chicken one was yummy.  There Is a cool atmosphere with lots of rustic wood here and even an outdoor eating area. And did I mention free Wifi? There are a few free parking spots to the side of the building or if you come by foot you are two minutes walk from Chinatown or the Reading Terminal Market. Parada Maimon is a great and affordable addition to the Center City dining scene!

it is easy to overlook this Dierbergs ---I drove past it with no regard many times as I was focused on getting to Whole Foods and Trader Joes.....Well the last time I needed a few grocery items i was on my way to Whole Foods and I noticed Dierbergs and said to the hubby oh---just pull in there as I was feeling particularly lazy that day and just wanted to get home as quick as possible...

i am so glad I finally got a chance to check out this location.  I really enjoyed the lay out and cleanliness of this Dierbergs.......The meats all looked very fresh and I purchased a few items.....

I had to be quick because the husband was even lazier than me and decided to wait in the car so I had to shop quickly but I still managed to drop almost 100.00 in under 10 minutes....That is power shopping yall....

Forest Park has so many things to offer and all the reviews have already mentioned them. The first experience and memory I have had of Forest Park, being that I did not grow up around here or explored much when I first moved here, was the skating rink. Yes, I know... Everyone is boasting about all the fun things to do in the spring and summer and here I go ruining it with ice and cold weather.  However, I feel that this is noteworthy if you are interested in outdoor ice skating. The only problem is, you would have to make sure it's cold enough outside.

The park is also a wonderful spot for photographs whether it be an engagement, wedding or just for fun! There are so many different and beautiful view around Forest Park for such occasions.

The art museum is another wonderful place to visit while in Forest Park. I could spend a whole day there! They have some wonderful arts and artifacts to marvel at for hours at a time. The best part is, it's free. There is a paid parking garage for $15 and $5 for members. I was curious and checked out the membership fee and saw that a year's worth of membership is actually very reasonable for one or 2 people. I was pleasantly surprised!

Of course, there are scenic trails if you want to walk/run/jog and people-watch. There are so many beautiful things to do and see in Forest park. You just have to come check it out!

Haven't had Poke in a while and seen this place and had to try it. 

Food - Great fresh ingredients, fish , good portions , flavor is perfect,  sauces are on point. 

Service - Employees are nice but could cheer up a bit more . 

Prices - Paid almost $18 for a large bowl wth avocado added, a lil high but was good. 

Location  - Inside the assembly hall. 

Would probably try it again, but would venture out and try the other restaurants first.

Wow. SO much hype for this place, including some articles about it being one of the best ice cream shops in the world. REALLY? Y'all need to get out more.

Stopped here on my tour of St. Louis favorites. I LOVE custard, so I was very excited to try the famous concrete. But the ice cream was very melty and not at all thick or cold enough. A lot of pontificating about something that doesn't exist here. Maybe it used to be better and they've gotten sloppy? I also ordered the s'mores flavored concrete, which, had little to no toppings visible.

This is really nothing more than a glorified ice cream stand. There's no seating inside or out, and you know who has better ice cream? DQ. Also, there's this whole myth about Ted's that they turn your concrete upside-down to prove its worthiness. They didn't. You know who does that every time I order a Blizzard? DQ.

Just go to DQ.

Awesome barbecue. We got the platter to split. Originally ordered half chicken, ribs, and brisket. They didn't have any chicken ready, so we got pulled pork instead. That was the only disappointment. Got collard greens and cheddar bacon mashed potatoes as sides. The potatoes were phenomenal. The meat was all cooked very well, with just enough seasoning and sauce. We also got the breakfast biscuits to go with the meal, and they were a tremendous complement to the meat. All in all, we left full and very satisfied. $41 after tax and tip

Stopped by here last night for dinner. I had a bowl of hot and sour soup, and an order of vegetarian dumplings. It was very good plus they give you a lot! I couldn't finish them, so I had to take the rest of it home. Service was also very good, and fast. I was impressed.

Drago, I wanted to like you but your food was just so mediocre. We had both raw and charbroiled oysters, both of which were extremely gritty. Please clean them better, I don't like eating sand and bits of crunchy shell with the garlic/butter/cheese mess on your charbroiled oysters. We came for the oysters, and found the whole oyster experience to be somewhat unpleasant. 

As for the entrees, the duck I had was tough, rubbery, and a bit overcooked. The seared tuna was tasty enough and comes in huge slabs (on the salad or as a entree), but was not spectacular or unique, and it's pretty tough to mess up seared tuna. 

For the prices here, I expected the food to be much better than it was. The service was pleasant. However, there are way too many delicious restaurants in New Orleans to waste your time at this one.

COVID-19 indoor dining review: whenever I come back to see my parents in Jersey, this is the only restaurant I insist on coming back to, every time (I actually only recently learned the actual name, we always call it "Amy's place"). Came by for dinner on Christmas Day, and while there were a LOT of cars in the parking lot, people were mostly there waiting for takeout. Inside the restaurant, there were only three small parties (including us), and we were all spaced at opposite ends of the restaurant. The servers all wore masks and stood back when taking your order - felt very safe! 

Always get the spicy fish with silky tofu, the eggplant, the Chongqing chicken, and the beef with spicy peppers. SO much food, with enough for a full meal of leftovers. I've also had a lot of takeout from Szechuan House and the food travels/reheats very well!

Ok the Commercials got me. Just wanted to try a $6 burger.  But have ate at other Carl's Jr restaurants in the past and have not been very satisfied.   This one was clean and the counter help was very friendly.  So the burger was good and fries were fresh.... So I would try this one again.  When they deliver the food to the tables they seem like they generally concerned about your dinning experience.  She asked it I wanted any more dipping sauce or any thing else.  Good job Carl's Jr!

Was really craving Pad Thai and found this spot on Yelp so decided to give it a try.  It was about 45mins prior to their closing so we placed the order online and headed right over to pick it up.

The restaurant is off the side of a main road, and is very easy to drive right by if you're not paying attention -- so be attentive and slow down early.

There are about three parking spots in front and a few more to the left of the building.  Due to COVID they are only doing take out and delivery, with the option of eating your food on one of their outside bench tables, with an umbrella to help block the sun.

I ordered a tofu and shrimp pad thai which came out to be about $14.  The portion size here is definitely for a family as the pad thai lasted me for 4 meals!  The Thai Hot was spicy and had good flavor but I feel it completely took away from the other flavors pad thai should have; e.g. tamarind.  Nonetheless the pad thai was great here and I would definitely order it again.

The following day, because the pad thai was so good, I wanted to try something else on their menu.  So I ordered the drunken noodles with chicken in medium this time.  Same deal here with the portion size, although this one lasted me only 3 meals -- thinking it was the extra protein that allows for an extra meal.  The flavor was great, but the heat for medium was not hot enough, so thinking next time I'll try their hot (in between medium and Thai hot).

If you're in the area and craving Thai food, so far, this is the place to beat.

What a great new craft ice cream addition to the city! Yes, they are a bit pricey, but you are paying for quality and care. Coffee cream and sugar was my favorite flavor here. Perfectly creamy with a coffee kick.

This is probably the Creole Creamery location that most people think of when you mention the local chain.   It's a cute little location (McKenzie's) on Prytania.  The parking is just street parking, but I've never had a hard time finding a mostly close spot.  They're not always the quickest when there's a line, but usually if that's the case, I'll head somewhere else to get my sweet snack.

They have a great selection of ice creams, and they rotate some of the flavors depending on the season.  The service is hit or miss, but the ice cream is delicious, so you put up with the lines or lack of seating.  Taking it to go is almost always the best option, and there are other places nearby if you want to take your snack and walk around.  

They also have espresso, so if you're an affogato fan, they've got you covered.

Great fun, good food, strong drinks, hip crowd, fair prices, and good, loud live music.

Three Muses lived up to all of the great reviews.

Felt like an old speakeasy.

Even though the menu is not that big, I started to have a panic attack about what to get, partly because I was starving after waiting 45 minutes to be seated on a Friday night (and having to endure the smokey disaster that is Locust Bar for drinks with friends in the meantime) and partly because everything. looked. so. damn. good. 

I settled on the Miso Ramen (yummy!), Black Garlic Wings (ooh la la!) and the Crispy Rice Cakes (yeya!).  As a side note, Coconut Curry, Pork Belly Buns, Cold Sesame Noodles and Shaved Kale... you're on my list for next time.

The drink prices felt a little high for a noodle place to me, but I was quite pleased to see that my favorite mixer, Jin-Ja, made an appearance in a bourbon cocktail.  It did not disappoint.  Note to self: pick bourbon over vodka next time you make yourself a Jin-Ja cocktail at home.

Yes, the place is small (but there is adorable ramen on the wall!) and yes you might have to wait a bit, but the staff is great, as is the food.  

Cheu Noodle Bar, I can't wait to CHEUse you again (sorry, I can't help myself).

The gluten free pizza is great! The first time in the factory ensemble line is a little awkward but it moves quickly, respectful and wonderful nice at being able to pick all your ingredients without being overly charged. 

You pick the toppings, sauce and cheese then pay. They bake it and deliver it to your table. 

Glad we found this place so close to the hotel!!

Unique menu this is my third trip here tried something different  every time fried green tomatoes rule!  3 of us shared 4 appys for dinner. Artichoke, fried green tomatoes, spicy mussels and baked Brie. All outstanding would have any of them again. It's was a lot.Cant think of anyone having any single appy and then ordering dinner. We're going straight to dessert. Warm German  choc brownie with ice cream and a chocolate chip peanut butter ball. Expect them to be delicious too. Excellent service by Alex.  Dessert extremely rich and yummy

Blaze was represented at the NOLA Yelp Krewe de Vieuxing party on 1/23/16 and I was lucky enough to get a coupon...once the parade was over the children wanted to try it out because of the coupon...I was game so we headed on over...

Walked in and they had a number of patrons but we were able to order immediately...went with a Meat Lover's and another that was half White Top and half pepperoni and black olive...

After placing the order the pizzas came out PDQ (pretty damn quick)...I'm personally a huge fan of thin crust and found these pizza crusts to be very good...

My drawback with this place is the fact that they are real light on the toppings...The daughter loved her White Top and I tried a bite and have to tell you that was a very tasty pizza and I'm in no way a fan of white pizza...the son liked his but wasn't blown away and I agree with the son's assessment...

However it did the job for a reasonable price and I'd recommend the place to anybody craving pizza and wanting a quick sit down meal...

This location is superior to the South Street one.  Here, it's got the space that it takes to be a super market.  Baked goods are delicious for sure.  Much more varied and interesting selection of products than the standard Giant/Pathmark/Acme ::shudder:: fare.  But let's face it:  the prices here make this great food utterly unaffordable for most working people with multiple mouths to feed.  I understand that that results from factors beyond Whole Foods' management, but it's still not acceptable that the 'best' food is unreachable for so many families.  If Trader Joe's weren't a few blocks south, there wouldn't be an affordable large food retailer in the Logan area.  Here's to you, Trader, a place where I can get bags of food for $30.  Rant over.  

Whole Foods highlights: the coconut oil (which is a solid-funky!) in the body section is a sensual moisturizer.  It melts from a soft solid into a liquid with the heat of your fingertips.  If you have dry hair, introduce it to this oil.  The prepared foods make excellent quick meals.  The 365 product line is the company's stab at an affordable option; I appreciate the gesture.

We stopped in this Save on Foods as they had their cakes on sale and I am a big fan of their strawberry shortcake.  There were new staff in the bakery learning about decorating from one of the more experienced staff so I waited until another staff member came to help.  She was friendly and asked what the occasion was for the cake and we told her no occasion, as cake is good anytime :) 

The store is bright and newer, and although I sometimes have to look around to find things, I eventually do find them.  I like the produce section, and the meat selection is good too.
