There wasn't a line up when I went to pay either which was nice to be able to get in and out quickly.  The strawberry shortcake was also delicious as expected!

Came to bourbon and brand for brunch and was not disappointed! 

Ambiance - it's funky inside, and has outdoor seating as well. Plenty of tables and booths and a large bar. 

Food- the chicken and waffles with pickled jalapeño and blueberries was unreal. Such a great flavor combo that you won't find elsewhere. The Huevos rancheros are delicious, bursting with flavor. The standard eggs benny was simple and done extremely well, and the Dutch baby pancake is sweet, delicious, and has a perfect texture. Don't skip out on the Bloody Mary either- get it with bacon! 

Service- top notch. Everyone was friendly, polite, prompt, and professional. 

I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this as a new brunch spot to throw into your weekend rotation!

Can't speak for the beignets, but really enjoyed the live jazz music in the park and the refreshing Mango SoCo daiquiri slushie. I'm not a fan of the Bourbon street slushies, but this one was particularly really delicious and not overly sweet. I wish the chairs were a bit more comfortable as my husband. 

Given that there's no cover charge or drink minimum, the trio band was pretty good. I was impressed at how some of the musicians played multiple instruments (harmonica and trumpet I believe). 

The jazz band played until 11:30. I wish the cafe was open longer so I could satisfy my craving for beignets while listening to some sweet jazz music.

After recently moving to Tower Grove, my boyfriend raved about Blackthorn deep dish- which is on my top "TG to do list". We called in for a pizza pick up right when they opened at 5pm (according to my boyfriend their pizza oven is fairly small and could only hold a few pies...) We ordered a 3-topping 10" deep dish and were told that it'll take 45 mins. (Yikes! 45 minutes? Well it is a deep dish...) 

To keep this short the 45 minute wait was well worth it. Blackthorn deep dish is not a true Chicago deep dish but it's still pretty tasty and filling. I can't get over the tomato sauce they use. The sauce is savory with nice heat to it. It's very distinct in flavor. Also the crust is cooked to perfection; not too soggy and not too crispy. 

Pre-warning: Blackthorn is a dive bar. It's not your Chuck-e-cheese or Deweys joint, so I wouldn't recommend bringing your kids here. 

Overall, I'm satisfied and glad to try this hidden gem.

What is the pink sauce?!

Feeling lazy, I went and ordered take out. The ordering process was smooth, and they quickly brought out my food. There were also a few other people ordering take out.

I ordered the Ichiban roll - salmon, masago and unagi wrapped in crunchy. I didn't really know what "crunchy" was, but I decided to take my chances anyways. As I expected, they were tempura flakes, but different to those I'm used to, these were really small / smushed flakes and seemed like it was quite old. The salmon, eel and masago themselves were fresh from what I can taste. The salmon was fatty, but still had the silver lining on it (which I kind of dislike, but since it was hidden in the roll, I wasn't too bothered). Now, what really almost made me want to gag is... the pink sauce.

What is the pink sauce?! It was a bright-ish pink color and had the consistency of mayonnaise. So, think pink colored liquid soap. That's what it looked like. The adventurous side of me decided to taste it - pretty much a sweet mayonnaise sauce. But, I just couldn't get over the color and the artificial-ness of it all, and pushed the sauce, along with most of the "crunchy" to the side.

While I like traditional sushi, I also love American sushi creations drenches in house special sauces, but crazy sushi's pink sauce was a bit more than I could handle. My search for sushi creations continues.

There's one phrase that makes me weak in the knees and renders me practically speechless-- chargrilled oysters. And that's how I found myself at the French Market after seeing a sign up outside. Were were hungry? Not particularly, but I heard the call. We split a dozen plus a crabmeat au gratin. The oysters were pretty good. The prices were a little on the high side but the seafood was fresh and the location is perfect.

Most of our vacation in New Orleans this summer was rainy for some part of every day. But that was not going to stop us!!! On a day that started off like it was going to be a complete wash with dark threatening clouds rolling in, we were hoping a Swamp Tour 30 minutes outside the city would save the day. Met a vendor while walking down Canal Street near Harrah's and he suggested Cajun Encounters. He recommended we drive to the location ourselves to save money since we had our own car, so we did. 

GETTING THERE -
Questioning the intelligence of our decision as we drove through a storm while exiting the city, we were delighted to find clear skies just a few miles after hitting the road. A quick prayer for a good day seemed to be answered as those dark clouds decided not to follow us... which made for a beautiful day in Slidell, LA.

Well off the main highway you will find them near an old mechanical bridge. Once inside, you'll may find a small line to pay for your tour. You'll then receive a colored rubber bracelet indicating your tour group. We were very fortunate to have Captain Mike, a down to earth born and bred Cajun who really knew those swamps.

THE TOUR -
The first half of the tour was quite boring as Captain Mike went  over a little history of the Bayou and drove high speed thu the more open areas of the swamp. IF YOU ARE LOOKING TO SEE GATORS, this will be a hit or miss experience. We saw a few, but they were reclusive and didn't seem to be interested in the hot dogs Capt'n Mike was beating on the water to coerce their attention.

But then we turned down a narrow heavily tree'd area where you could feel branches scraping the bottom of the boat. Wife was totally paranoid we would get shipwrecked or something and Capt'n Mike didn't help as he side swiped a few large trees... lol!!! You should have seen her face.

THE BEST PART -
Well, we came to rest in a small cove and Mike pulls out Bryan, a little one foot alligator and my kids go nuts!!!! Normally well behaved children, I politely had to apologize to several people after Mike asked "who wants to hold Bryan". We were at the front of the boat you see, and Capt'n Mike and Bryan were at the rear. If any of the passengers from our tour are reading this, I sincerely hope your feet are feeling better after being trampled by our overexcited boys!

Bryan was a big hit, and the boys enthusiasm gave several more people courage to hold the little fella, including my wife. But the big prize was yet to come. Mike spotted a HUGE gator who was not shy at all. For this gator he used a stick to dangle the hot dog and what came next drew lots of Oooo's and Aaaaaahhhh's. This gator came a clean 4 feet out of the water to grab this hot dog and we were amazed. It was just what we were hoping to see!!! Saw some other stuff on the boat ride back after that encounter but didn't care. That huge gator and little Bryan were all we talked about for a few hours. Hopefully your experience will be as good.

My boyfriend and I decided to come here for dinner on a random Saturday around 6. Very risky since all the restaurants in the St Pete pier area are always crowded. We did manage to get two seats at the bar immediately, which was fine for us. Our bartender/server approached us quickly with menus, but then took a while to take our initial drink order. Once he came back I ordered the Dragon Mojito, which was very good and delivered quickly. We ordered the cheesy bread appetizer to start. It is incredibly cheesy and actually a bit greasy, but had good flavor and was perfect for someone starving like me. We placed our order, chicken taco salad and tropical salad with blackened mahi added on. I wanted to wait to finish my bread and eat some of it with my salad so I waited, waited, and waited some more. Finally our bartender returned and apologized for our salads taking a while saying it was indeed his fault for waiting too long to put them into the system. He offered to make another drink, which I was not initially going to do, but waiting longer made me want another. We then waited some more. He finally went back himself to check on the salads and they finally came. This wait time total was about 45 minutes to an hour. Luckily the salads were great, the mahi was cooked perfectly, and both were nicely dressed. The tropical salad had so many flavors and toppings and all worked well together. The chicken taco salad was also very good and was the equivalent of ordering a couple loaded tacos. The food saved this review for me. Our bartender did apologize and admitted to it being his mistake the food took so long. Not sure if I will return, at least not during a busier time.

So, this place has changed quite a bit since my first review in 2011. I thought my review deserved an update, as I've been twice this month.

There are reservations now. Per their policies, you are only allowed to stay at a dining table for 1.5 hours, no matter how much you order. I'm not sure how strictly this is policed. The pair of hostesses were not particularly welcoming or helpful, but we were able to get a reservation for about two hours after we arrived (spent our wait down the street). Originally we were told that we could possibly take the table of a group that was running late; they had 5 more minutes. Apparently they arrived while we waited outside, but we were not informed and just kept waiting without any notice that it would be another hour. Not the best customer service.

BUT otherwise this place is awesome. Both times we were there, Shotgun Jazz Band was playing. The second time, Washboard Chaz joined in spontaneously! Both times, the band was lively and entertaining. They played loudly enough that the whole restaurant could hear but not too loud that you couldn't have a conversation if you wanted. They play for tips, so don't forget your cash!

The food is delicious - I'd still recommend the fries, but also the mac and cheese, bulgogi bowl, and the steak and cake. The steak and cake was tender strips of steak with a crab cake, fried to perfection - a little crispy on the outside but warm and soft in the middle. I'd eat one right now. Get the homemade vanilla ice cream for dessert! And, their signature, gin-based cocktail The Muse is lovely and refreshing.

Also, the service from our waitress, who also is one of the managers I believe, was EXCELLENT. My friend asked if there were any warm drinks because her throat was sore. Our waitress said there wasn't, but she brought out a glass of hot water with honey. How sweet is that?! It's thoughtful touches like that that are so memorable to customers. Also, she told us about the discount for locals!

I'll be happy to continue bringing out of town guests here, and maybe showing up just for a fun weekend again soon.

I always love this place!! Of course it's always nice when the staff knows you by name. I love the salad bar selection and the pizza always has a great thin crispy crust which is how I like it. 
To nite tho I had deep fried food....yup I did.
I had half an order of the appetizer sampler.  Mushrooms, onion rings, mozzarella sticks, and zucchini......all battered and deep fried oh yeah and dipped in ranch!! Crunchy craving satisfied!!!

Excellent atmosphere, lots of parking, service with a smile and great menu options. 

There is patio and inside seating. We enjoyed the live music on a Saturday afternoon. Our server was cheerful and attentive. The beer list has many collaborations and I loved the sour options. Try the collective sour of its still on the menu. Yum! 

I ordered the smoked wings with orange marmalade marinade. They were cooked to perfection. I prefer smaller, non jumbo wings and these were big and juicy. If you like this style, give them a try. They have all homemade sauces and you can tell the care they take in the preparation. 

My husband's burger was good. We've had better but very enjoyable. 

Overall an excellent experience and I can't wait to return.

LOVED the roasted oysters!! The kids even liked them.  I ordered the seared Tuna and was given enough to feed two or three people!! Way too much food.  Hubby got the fried seafood plate and it was ok.  Go for the OYSTERS!  Definately an experience!

My favorite sushi restaurant in the city! Their sushi rolls are unique and delicious, and I really like that they're BYO. The presentation (when you dine in) is always beautiful- you almost don't want to touch it!

Cons: It can get very loud inside, especially when there are large groups of people (usually drinking liquor), and for whatever reason the staff always seems to try to rush you in and out (even when it is empty inside).

I am an avid fan of CL Deals, so when this certificate became available with an additional promotional code I snatched up two. So I waited to complete this review until after I had used both. Now after having gone two times, once for lunch and once for dinner, I am not impressed.

The reviews rave about the dim sum. Maybe my palate isn't as refined as I think but I wasn't impressed. I selected three items from the dim sum menu before deciding to just order off the menu when I went for lunch. I was disappointed cause I have had great dim sum before.  The walking menu really appealed to me but here there are only a few options which they keep on the cart, which are mostly the baked options. All of the steamed or fried options are prepared once ordered.  Fearing that I would not get full, I also ordered the lettuce wraps to accompany the dim sum.  They were actually well flavored but very oily. 

When I visited the next time, it was for a late dinner with a girl friend. We ordered the chicken teriyaki and seaweed salad. The service was slow just as it was when I visited for lunch. Once delivered the seaweed salad was still frozen. When we brought it to the attention of the server, she seemed shocked. Only after pulling out a piece with ice on it did she believe us and respond. The only thing they did was nuke the salad which we could see since the kitchen is open. This let us know that the salad is not freshly prepared in house.  The chicken teriyaki however was freshly prepared of which I am glad since it took so long for it to be delivered. The flavor was good and the portion was sufficient for one. If not for the cost, I would probably order this more often since it is much better than you will find at the Chinese choose your number restaurants.

This is a dream. I was truly living my best life as I was eating the cookies and cream cookie dough. 

Service: Friendly as can be and they will let you sample any dough that speaks to you.
Atmosphere: Clean, simple and fun.
Dough: YAS. You really can't go wrong with any flavor but my favorite of the samples I tried was the cookies and cream. What's better than OREOs in cookie dough? Try and argue with me. You won't. You order scoops similar to an ice cream shop. I was fully convinced I was going to order two scoops until I saw one of the cookie monsters (not their official name just being punny and cute) scoop a one scoop into it's cup. HOLY ONE SCOOP. It was three small scoops combined into one giant scoop! Now, no shame if you're heart's pulling you towards that double scoop. I commend you.
Price: A little steep, but I get it.

Na Baked, I shall return for by sugar coma soon!
Oh the joy of a peartini & a dozen chargrilled oysters!! Save room for the apple goblet and 2 scoops of ice-cream. Yum-o!

So many options I don't know what to choose!

I definitely thought my friends and I were the oldest people in the joint, you know following the school of 3 year old birthday parties ordering before us. The line went quickly and was worth it.

A small scoop will run you about $3 and they give you plenty! I ordered the  Black and Yellow Crunch which has chicory (that thing in Cafe du Monde coffee) which was awesome. It was really hard to not go with my gut and get a standard flavor, but I'm pleased I did.
The red velet was outstanding and I tasted the oatmeal chip cookie which was good for a bite, would probably be too much in a cone.

They have an array of Double Chocolate sweets all the way on the far left, but those are too chocolatey for me so I stayed away.

I wish this place had more outdoor seating.

It was a cold night at the end of a long and arduous year, and COVID19 precautions had made dining out (literally, in little wooden sidewalk pod enclosures) less than completely appealing. But this lady was determined to still have a nice chef-prepared dinner for her wedding anniversary, and she was going to trek out by bus and trudge through icy air to get it.

Italian pasta was the plan, and after much searching on Yelp (whereby I discovered many COVID19-related closures), I finally found Bistro La Baia. With promising reviews, we decided to try this option on the outskirts of Rittenhouse Square. Lobster ravioli for me, and penne arrabiata for the significant other. The food was ready right on time when I arrived, and came with a complimentary bundled of delicious slices of Italian bread that practically crackles when bitten into.

The entrees were quite good as well. The ravioli consisted of six pieces, two sauteed shrimp and a rich, creamy tomato sauce. That and half a piece of the Italian bread made for a perfectly portioned and delicious meal for me. The penne arrabiata was a larger portion, and while not the best ever, it still met with the S.O.'s overall approval.

The sidewalk seating wooden pods were empty when I arrived, but that was before 6PM, so maybe the restaurant was busier later in the evening. It really gave me the impression of the sort of place that would primarily be frequented by residents of the surrounding neighborhoods. The one person I interacted with there was very polite and helpful (even giving me time to put my mittens back on before handing me the food for my journey home). I probably wouldn't have thought to try Bistro La Baia under most circumstances, so it was a nice discovery. I hope that it'll be able to survive the wave of restaurant closures that Philadelphia has seen as a result of the pandemic.

I'm a fan of this teeny-tiny Kroger because I love being able to walk to the grocery store with my little reusable bags. Okay, this Kroger does not have the greatest selection, but they do have staples and some pretty nice high-end items, cheeses included. The tuna steaks I purchased are beautiful, and at a really good price.

The wine selection is awesome for such a small space!

I really wish they carried Athenos Greek yogurt, because they carry all kinds of Athenos products. I also really wish the cashiers were nicer. Some just act like it's a huge hassle to check you out and scan your coupons.

Get stoked that there's a grocery store so close to your house!

As soon as I heard about this, I had to go!  My gal pal Stacy got a group of random friends together (couples date day downtown) and we all paid her our $25/pp in advance for the 2 hour tour around the city.  Rain or shine it said and it rained ....and we still had a blast.  I didn't pedal (too short and too lazy) but it was a lot of fun to ride (on the back and the side).  We brought our own beers and blasted an Ipod full of ridiculous tunes as we pedaled through the city on a busy Saturday afternoon.  For all of those cars who got stuck behind us, we're sorry but come on!  It was fun to watch us ride, right?

It's a bar on wheels....but there are rules.  Alcohol cannot leave the bike, no serving beers to pedestrians (aka - not a "real" bar that way) and stay on time or there's a late fee.  We managed to follow the rules, have a great time and no one threw up from drinking and riding.  That's a score in my book.

We made two "pit" stops - one on Mass and one on Meridian to urinate and take a shot.  Then we continued on the ride, switching seats and making new friends along the way.

This is great for groups of any kind - you do not have to drink but it does make it a little more fun with a buzz.  This bike is ridiculous and awesome at the same time.  You don't have to be super active or in great shape (after all, there are 10 riders) but if you don't want to be outside they say to stay at home.  And there are no rainchecks for bad weather (even snow) so don't get whiny if the sun isn't out.  We rode in partial downpour and it was even more fun than I thought it would be!  

I am considering this as an option for a birthday party outing, girls' night out, the list goes on for who would enjoy this little bit of rowdy fun!  Everyone seemed to really get a kick of out it and for those of us who have lived in Indy a long time, it's nice to see something new and different enter the area with a bit of creative energy that can be enjoyed while consuming alcohol or not.
I had the Tree Hugger Benedict with a side of sausage.. Dang good. This is the place to go for a lazy Sunday breakfast, then a small walk in the park with the wife..

Julian B Lane Riverfront Park is located in Downtown Tampa, off North Blvd, just North of University of Tampa and Tampa Preparatory High School, across from the hood on the west side, and across from the Hillsborough River, the Straz Center for Performing Arts, and within eye-shot of the other Downtown Tampa waterfront park, Curtis Hixon Park on the east. Julian B Lane Riverfront Park has undergone a massive multi million dollar renovation and the results are amazing! I applaud the mayor and the city of Tampa for doing a great job with this park. I've had the pleasure of attending the Navy Band performance on the park's opening weekend and the Stella Artois event at the River center with beautiful views of the city! I love that there is plenty of free parking at this facility which is sorely missing from the Curtis Hixon Park. This park Is now a great spot to play tennis, do water sports, or a good starting point to get onto the Tampa Riverwalk. I look forward to coming here for many more special events, concerts, tennis, and Water sports! 

Julian B Lane Riverfront Park features: 
- River Center for indoor special events 
- Boat House with rowing boats, kayaks, and stand up paddle boards 
- Play Cove splash pad area for kids 2-12 
- Festvial Lawn for concerts 
- 2 dog parks for large and small dogs 
- boat docks for kayaks, water taxi, and boats 
- Bat house 
- 6 concrete tennis courts
- 2 pickle ball courts
- basketball courts
- 1 multipurpose sports field for football & soccer 
- 5 standard size shelters
- 1 large corporate/event shelter
- 1 Neos Playground system
- 2 ping pong tables
- 2 chess / checkers tables 
- Standup Paddleboard & Kayak Rentals

Wow! Talk about going above and beyond. My fiancé and I made reservations for our anniversary tonight. We were pleasantly surprised upon arriving when they seated us, they decorated our table with confetti and gave us a nice card signed by the entire staff! From start to finish, Ronnie was exceptional as well as the entire staff. They truly made tonight memorable. Okay. Now to the rest of the review. 
This is a actually the second time I've been here and each time has been phenomenal. The decor is modern with just the right lighting to set the ambiance to a more intimate setting, even with the open floor plan. 
We ordered the chilled seafood tower and let me tell you it was amazing! The King crab does not disappoint. We also shared the Bone-in 20 oz. ribeye which was cooked to our specifications. Another success for the night. The crispy Brussels sprouts with bacon would make a kid think it was candy and beg for more. 
I could keep rambling on and on about how great the whole experience was but I'm already looking forward to my next visit! Fleming's does a wonderful job making us feel like royalty for the night! Fine dining at its finest! Bravo!
amazing place! Takes you back to yesteryear! Great ice cream and its a candy shop as well...I haven't tried the candy yet though :) You'll love it!

It's a nice welcome to otherwise not very attractive part of town on a busy intersection between Bears and Nebraska, Culvers is a welcome additions. If you are into fast food restaurant like a greasy hamburger and fried chicken sandwich, you would added to your already long list of fast food restaurant along fletcher ave. For me, it is the many flavors of delicious custard that draw me into culvers, and that's what the 4 stars is about!

Another Yelp-Win for the books.

This place was awesome.  We wandered down Frenchmen Street through a few restaurants and bars, but this was the best of them all.  The drinks were good, the jazz was very good, the waitress was great, and the fries were AMAZING.  Definitely get the fries.

Special shoutout goes to the jazz band... their name was some kind of African soup, I think?  I was never a band geek, but that one guy could play a clarinet with the best of them, I'm sure.  I also give them bonus points for no cover charge on the Friday night we were there.

Prices are high but theres creative cocktails and trendy food. Lamb sliders were amazing and the feta fries were tasty although I do wish there were some sauce or another cheese on them.

I'll def be back.

I love Latin food, but I don't want to go to deep DEEP north Philly and I'm not always up to spending what they spend at the Center City spots. So Parada Maimon is a good compromise. Most of the times I've been here I've gotten the pernil with rice and black beans. I've tried the half chicken, the gizzards, and the mofongo. The chicken was good enough that I brought some home to my family. It was a hit. The price can't really be beaten. For those wondering, you can sub out rice and beans for some fries... or maybe some other side they're offering. 

What issues did I have? You can either order at the counter or you can have a seat. The counter (cafeteria style) food is ready-made while most other things are made to order. My first impression was underwhelming... as the pernil I had was dry. I didn't know to ask for gravy since I ordered from the menu. That wasn't enough to keep me away because I came back and had the mofongo and I didn't like it much. I mentioned in a review for another place that I don't fault the establishment. I just didn't know what I was getting into because it more or less tastes the same everywhere I've tried it. There was a little confusion in the portions... they should just say large and small, but instead they say lunch and dinner if I remember correctly.

So for the best dine-in experience... order at the counter, if you're not fluent in Spanish then English is fine...mostly (I got a verbal judo flip with my basic Spanish), state what sauces/gravy you want on your food and then have a seat. Also, get one of their fresh juices (Chinola for me). If you really want to EAT get the dinner (large) portion, but if you're there for the deal get the lunch (small). 

So with a large plate of pernil with a good amount of gravy, some hot sauce and oil for the rice, and some thousand island or whatever for the little salad... I'm NICE! I think they have tres leches too, but I've been too full to try it.

PRO-TIP: And ask for maduros... I don't think they're included, but I don't think they're extra. It's just like 3 or 4 and anyway.

FUN FACT: The area is desolate so there's really no best way in or out on foot. You're catching alleys, bums, and long empty stretches on all sides. Seriously, don't let that stop you from checking this place out.

A local favorite!  Blenders in the Grass is a perfect alternative for when you're sick of Jamba Juice.  The concept is similar but I think Blenders has a more creamy, smoothie taste whereas Jamba Juice has more of a tangy, fruity taste.  

All the smoothies are 24oz. and come with a free Super supplement or 2 Single supplements.  My favorite flavor by far is the Strawberry Colada which is made with pineapple juice, strawberries, coconut, pineapple sherbet and ice milk.  But really, all of the flavors are delicious.  If you manage to do the impossible and can't find something on the menu you'd like to try, that also offer a Build Your Own Blender option where you can choose any ingredients for your smoothie.  They also offer juices and Wheat grass shots.  

Something else worth mentioning is that they can make any smoothie non-dairy by substituting a soy base.  At about $5 per smoothie, it is a tad pricey, but worth it for a nice cold treat on a warm Santa Barbara day.

This is a review of the city tour through Cajun Encounters. The tour started  out in the city and we drove passed St. Louis Cemetery No. 1 (THE cemetery that I wanted to visit) Our tour guide tells us we won't be visiting it?? I was instantly upset. We head out to the area that was most effected by Hurricane Katrina. That was interesting to see. As we drive through town our guide points out random restaurant (I wasn't on a food tour?) We get to St. Louis Cemetery No. 3 and we stop. We walked around for like 5 minutes and didn/t even see half of the cemetery? Then we head out to the city park which I was actually happy about because I wanted to visit the sculpture garden. We barely had any time to be there either! A little over 1 minutes and then it started to rain. We head back into town and go through the garden district which was nice but most of the houses were on the opposite side of the bus. Overall the tour was just alright. I felt like I really didn't see much unfortunately.

Holy clamshells I was surprised by the quality of this venue. I was having a grumpy day (they don't care) having woken up with sleep paralysis (stop writing Justin this is irrelevant) and that threw me into a really weird mood (for the love of God please stop) but my dad still wanted to go get lunch with me thankfully. WAM! Suddenly we were having FANTASTIC seafood!

Everything we ordered: Clam chowder, steamed clams, fried oyster po boy, garlic bread. It was all really good! Even the presentation of my sandwich was lovely. I ordered an additional side of aioli preemptively but I really didn't need to, my meal was perfect. And I'd say the pricing is pretty good too. I've been to New Orleans several times... and such comparisons aren't really fair, but you can get a po boy twice the size for the same price there. That being said, I'm amazed by the taste and quality of the sea food considering the location of Idaho.  

The decor of the restaurant is super jazzy and fun. This would be a great place to bring a first date to kinda say, "hey let's just loosen up and have a silly goose time, it's no worries. See! Look how slap-happy and fun this place is?! It's okay if we don't get along and this keeps happening to both of us until we are assuredly going to die alone or with someone we just settled with! Let's have some seafood!"

Lastly I want to touch on the service of this place (that came out wrong). Our servers were amazing. Our waiter was great, the greeter was great, random people we talked to and asked about the restaurant were great. Two thumbs up. 

But now I have to get to the reason I took away a star... I'm sorry; we were having so much fun. One of the servers walked by us and I could smell cigarette smoke. I'm highly allergic so it's easy for me to tell. If you're a manager, please please please don't throw the baby out with the bath water, maybe just make sure the staff keeps away from that sorta ordeal until work time is over. My dad and I loved each and every person we interacted with here, and we feel they're all deserving of praise. 

So that's it that's what I got. New place to get some great food in Meridian! Hurray!

I don't really think this place deserves a five star rating unless your basing it on speed of service, price, and portion amount.  As far as taste goes, yes the wonton soup was delicious and so was the sesame chicken.  The Chicken Lo Mein was nothing to run their screaming for it was a little bland and I absolutely dislike their fried rice.  Yes it has pork in it, i know you don't get that in too many places, but it had absolutely no flavor what so ever.

The egg roll was ginormous, i mean seriously massive.  it was just okay, i would not get again, but it was big enough to almost fill me up alone.

The portions were huge! I think it could feed four easy off one plate, so beware.

They have the standard pictures you see at any eat in and takeout chinese strip mall place.  Take that picture and double the size that is what you get for $6.99, amazing deal.

i do know they say they have 25 plates for lunch for 5.99 includes soup, egg roll and a soda, if you don't want a soda its only 4.99.  I'm assuming the portion size isn't much smaller than the dinner size according to the other reviews.

All in all i don't really think i will come back here, it isn't just my go to place.  I still have yet to find that place in the metroeast, the closest i have came for chinese is House of Hunan in ofallon and Sala Thai for thai food.

As I doubt anyone is making decisions to go or not to go to Subway based on Yelp reviews, I rarely write them, but I needed to give a shout-out to this franchise for a few reasons:

- Super-friendly service
- Low prices. My 6" rotisserie chicken cost $4.69, whereas it's typically over $5.
- Generous portions. I was given three slices of cheese instead of the regular two, and my sandwich was overloaded with chicken.

Their king cake is absolutely delicious. The cake part is fresh and not dry at all and the cream cheese filling so good. Even delivered to us in Wisconsin it was delicious and probably the best king cake I have ever had. 

We stopped in this market when we were down in NOLA last spring. It's a bit cramped inside, but a good place to stop to get some water and snacks when in the area.

I would highly recommend this tour for anyone who is visiting the New Orleans area. It was one of the highlights of our trip. I especially loved our tour guide - no matter what question we threw at him, he knew the answer...we  defiantly  learned a lot!

We decided to make Zeppoli our go to destination with a couple of friends the Sunday before Christmas and I have to say, I am glad we did. Yes, we did have reservations and no we did not need to wait for a table. We arrived right on time and were immediately seated. Zeppoli's is great because it is also a BYOB, so we sat down and were given wine glasses immediately. The menu is small and precise. Our server was wonderful and before ordering we were told that this is traditional Cicillian cuisine and not standard Italian fare. 

We started out with the following apps: Panzanella Catania, Insalada Verde, and the Antipasto Siciliano. We were also given an order of Finocchi Salsiccia, Fennel Sausage, because they forgot to provide me with silverware. Both salads were good, citrusy and fresh. The anchovies that were on the Panzanella salad were ridiculously good and added a lightly salted note to the tomato and bread. The sausage was also delicious, it basically melted in your mouth and the rabe that was provided with the sausage gave it a great bitter element. But the star here was Antipasto. Good lord was that a good salad. I wish I could eat that dish every night. It was so wonderful. It has sharp provolone, marinated mushrooms, beans, salami, roasted red peppers and tomatoes and the list of awesomeness kept going. Probably the best Antipasto dish I have ever eaten.

For our Entrées the ladies each ordered the Taglietteli al Limone with prosciutto and I ordered the Taglietteli al Limone with bottarga as a small order and my buddy had the Pesto Trapanese. The Taglietteli was wonderful. It was like a flavor explosion in my mouth. Super citrusy and fresh and then you add in the bottarga and the dish just blew my mind because it went, citrusy, clean, fresh and oceany (Not sure if that is a word, but that is what it tasted like). Awesome dish! The pesto dish was ridiculous as well. My friend did let me try a bite; he was reluctant to do so. We also both had the Fisherman's Stew. It was good; the standout on this dish was the calamari. I guess that is how calamari is supposed to be cooked. It wasn't even close to rubbery, it was tender and basically melted in your mouth.

We did have room for desert and got the Zeppoli. They were wonderful, especially after you dipped them in the nutella. They came out fresh and hot. I definitely burned my mouth because I didn't want to wait to eat it.

Overall this was one of my favorite meals in 2012. I would come back to Zeppoli's every week if I could afford it, alas I cannot. However, next time we are looking for somewhere good to go near Cherry Hill, Zeppoli's will certainly be in the forefront of my mind.

Lovely meal at a quaint restaurant, but I can't give this restaurant a full 5 stars.

First off, the menu is a little limited, but that's because you're really leaving it up to the chef and whatever ingredients are freshest.  That's the concept, and the chef is very talented.

The space itself is a little small, so you can hear other people's conversations quite readily which became awkward for me near the beginning of our meal.

I harmlessly asked if I could do another vegetable instead of potatoes with my striped bass, this confused my waiter (the look on his face was priceless), but then he went back to the kitchen asked about it, and I could hear everything they were saying.  This literally took about 8-10 minutes, and I was like I don't care.  They said not a problem, but then when I received my dish it had the potatoes anyway.  If I were an internet dude I'd use the SMH acronym here.  I just did.

I don't want the newbie waiter's service to take away from the food, since that was outstanding.

Here's what we did:

Wine -- BYOB!

Bread (3/5) -- I'm not a big bread guy, but this was more like a muffin and lacked sophistication.

Leek Soup (4/5) -- Very good for a rainy evening.  A touch buttery, but not in a bad way.  There was a pea shoot garnish which I asked about to make conversation with the waiter; this turned into another "everyone-in-the-restaurant-hears" debate between the servers and the chef.  It was very good nonetheless

Kampachi (5/5) -- Easily the highlight for me.  It's seared (grilled?) on one side and raw on the other.  Sashimi-grade quality, and a good portion with just the right amount of sweet garnish with the dish

Striped Bass (4/5) -- These guys know how to cook a fish.  Tender on the inside, just a touch of crispness on the outside.  Served with purple cauliflower, regular cauliflower, and...potatoes!  Light on the sauce, so I did not feel like a blob after eating.  A goodish 7-ounce portion of fish, I'd guesstimate

I passed on dessert and did a coffee, which happened to be very good since they brewed it up fresh.

Crowd seemed local and very pleasant.  The restaurant veered from warm to a touch chilly, so I'm not sure if they were having some heating issues.

i'd definitely go again, but not banging down doors to get there.  Gut feeling is that this would be 5 stars with a more experienced waiter and during the warmer, summer months when the fruit of the earth is in full bloom.

Family owned and operated they spoil you with the best stuff ever this place is a gift  from the GOD's. I was blessed to live around the corner from this Chippewa location  and I loved every moment of it. I loved the Hawailan Delight its packed with all the good stuff that makes me need Ted Drewes Custard Anonymous ...Hi my name is Samantha and I've been addicted to Ted Drewes for 5 years Its a sad sight really. But I love the Pineapple, Banana, Coconut, & Macadamia Nuts this is nothing but a guilty pleasure for me. I eat this stuff and it feels like I'm in heaven. This is so good it will make you slap your grand ma! It don't matter what you order its gonna be lip licking brain freeze pack on the custard good. Thank you Ted Drewes! Like Ted always says it really is good guys and girls!

Four stars overall but five stars for delicious beignets:) The line was only about 10 customers long, but it took about 25 minutes. They give you a number and the beignets get delivered to you, so it wasn't like each customer was getting the beignets while ordering, not sure why the line was going so so slow. I think the cashiers are inefficient in that they also make the coffee orders so there's a lot of multitasking for one person. The customer behind me and I bonded over how slow the line was.

Love though that Cafe Beignet has a resident live band though. That was a really nice NOLA touch. My family and I all really enjoyed the band. Plenty of seating too so that's nice, considering how popular this spot is. 

The beignets were nice and fluffy. Not too oily. Lots of powdered sugar, def get a lot of napkins before sitting down! (3 beignets for $3.99) Also my family and I also went to Cafe Du Monde, and we weren't unanimous on which has better beignets so the verdict is still out. I'll go with Cafe Beignet, the beignets tasted fluffier and less oily to me here:)

I love the ambiance of this place.
Great food and great music.
We tried the Mac and cheese, the Lamb sliders and the apple pie.
Everything was very tasty.
I would like to be able to make this place a regular place to go but we don't live in Louisiana unfortunately

I agree with Scott F. This is our neighborhood Chinese spot and I have to say, the food is decent, CHEAP, and the service is great. We can order our food and have it delivered in 20 minutes. Plus, it's enough to feed the two of us for more than one meal. It's Chinese food. I have no complaints!

This a local institution and a no-frills frozen custard shop that serves delicious frozen custard.  I liked what they offered and the prices were very reasonable.  I have had my fair share of good frozen custards so this wasn't anything mind blowing or such but it was on point regardless.  In my three visits to St. Louis, the third visit recently was the first time I went to Ted Drewes.  It was worth it.  I had two concretes.

You check out the menu on the side of the shop on a blackboard or you go up to the counter see the menu posting there.  The menu post by the ordering and pick-up counters is very hard to read.  It's not printed in a neatly organized way.  First, I ordered their 'Fox Treat' concrete - "a concrete or sundae with hot fudge, raspberries and macadamia nuts."  I asked them to make it with their Abaco Mocha flavor.  It was da bomb.  I snarfed it down.  Then, I realized that I was already done with my concrete but craved more.  So I went up to the counter and ordered another concrete.  This time, I asked for their Lemon flavor with Blueberries.  It was pretty good.  On the second go, I slowed down a bit and savored it more...heheh...as I wasn't going to have it for the third time.

I enjoyed my cups of their concretes.  You could taste the freshness of their vanilla custard and the mixed in ingredients. Again, it wasn't anything extraordinary or special as I have had same quality good ones elsewhere and Greg's in Mundelein, IL (to me) is a bit better but still a solid punch of good tasting frozen custard.  One thing I didn't like about their menu is that they only offer their regular vanilla flavor in a cone (and dipped in chocolate coating, if you want that) but otherwise, any added flavor kind is not served on a cone.  That's kinda a bummer.

Anyway, I would recommend checking Ted Drewes out while in St. Louis.  They have two locations and this is their original one.

Meh.  I was expecting more.  I normally go based on reviews on Yelp/Trip Advisor and I really rarely listen to the propaganda pieces that cities put out in flyers etc, I like listening to the boots on the ground, reviews from real people.  So I went on the recommendation of people online, and my friend who loves it here, but I was sorely disappointed. 

My meal (pork with broccoli and potatoes) was good, the portion was small, the potatoes were delicious and the pork was sliced way too fine - for the price, I'd expect more.  

My brother asked for a burger, medium-well, it came out raw.  He thought it looked ok so didn't send it back and when he got in to it, it was raw. 

Hubby got the ribs and they weren't much to write home about.  He did love the grits though!

I don't think I'd go back, which is a shame, it was too much money for not a lot of food and not particularly great food at that, disappointing :(

Ambiance/Decor: 3/5
Food: 4/5
Service: 4/5
Price: $
Overall: 4/5

Almost every time I'm in town, I stop at Boulevard Pizza. The pizza is crispy and has a thin crust that is full of flavor. The wings are perhaps the best in town and they have their awards on display to prove it. Most recently I stopped by for their lunch special and it's a complete steal: I got a mini pizza for $2.49, a hero and salad for $3.79, and a foot-long garlic bread for 99 cents! If the mouth-watering pizza weren't enough, they have a full bar serving cold drafts as well as cocktails. The pizzeria has a neighborhood vibe and almost instantly takes me back to the pizzerias of my childhood. You can't visit Reno without stopping at Boulevard Pizza for some cold brew and hot slices. Check out their website for daily specials!

Five star experience at the deli, thanks to an exceptional staffer named Steven!

First time visiting this newish Publix since it opened. Its convenient location and ample parking made it an easy-breezy stop while visiting the bustling Westshore. 

After a busy day of shopping at local mall stores, my friend and I stopped by Publix to satisfy our cravings for deli meats and cheeses. 

We were helped immediately and treated exceptionally well by Steven. He went above and beyond, and enthusiastically shared his knowledge of Boars Head products, and gave us samples to ensure we'd love the new slow-smoked turkey breast. 

He also recommended a better roast beef than my go-to. Now, I'm forever hooked on Boars Head London Broil. 

Needless to say, the sammiches we made afterward absolutely slayed.

It's easy to be wary when you use something like Groupon...yeah, it's a good deal, but you just don't know if you're getting your discounted money's worth.

Lucky for us the Voodoo Bone Lady turned out to be a great deal. The only tricky part is figuring out where to meet up...we got an address, but it was for a grocery store and not any kind of office. Turns out that everyone was just meeting up at that corner, so if you get there early don't get too confused, the VBL will be meeting you up shortly.

We did the cemetary tour, and were pleasantly surprised to have a few "extras" thrown in, like a bit of history of New Orleans in general and VBL's personal experiences living there during Hurricane Katrina. She was knowledgeable and made sure everyone could hear her...well, except for the obnoxious drunk guy (in a Vikings jersey btw) with us who would barely pay attention. Oh well, can't do anything about that.

It was blistering hot, involved a lot of walking and lasted a few hours, but well worth it. Just be sure to stock up on liquids and stick close so you don't miss a drop of information.

While on my first NO trip everyone had their suggestions of where I had to have the best beignets.  This was on the list.  I can only compare this to Cafe Dumonde.  This was a much larger order and the beignets were much more dense.  Impossible to eat an entire order.  We shared with a stranger.  (:  However, very good.

One of the first things everyone suggested I do when I go to NOLA is eat oysters. Well, I have a few times before (raw) and am not a fan so that was not on the agenda but everyone swore on their lives (including many friends) to go to Drago's and eat them charbroiled. I read so many reviews and saw the pics of them and must admit they looked incredible. I'm all for trying new things so I said "What the heck!" and OMG am I ever glad I did!! 
These are some of the most delicious things I have ever put in my mouth!!! They have an incredible smokiness and are smothered in butter and parm cheese to make them out of this world!  After that I had the shrimp and grits w/ tasso ham which was also delicious. The tasso has quite a kick and along with the wonderfully tasty sauce and the dozen large shrimp, it made the grits a bit more tolerable (I found them to be bland and loose) At $22 it is a great deal for a larger portion than imagined.
My mom had the shrimp with angel hair pasta which was also a big portion w/ about the same amount of shrimp and that also was very, very good, I think it was about $19. 
We were so full we had to pass on dessert but if I had room left, I would've ordered some more of thos oysters!

I met a girlfriend for dinner. I arrived first, and was seated right away. Paul C. was our server.

I had a card for a free appetizer, but it had expired. I asked if they would still honor it. Paul said yes. Good show!

We got beef carpaccio. It was paper-thin sliced meat with capers and mustard aioli. Complemented by nicely dressed field greens. This is an appetizer to share. It was absolutely delicious. My dining partner had never had carpaccio, and she loved it.

We both opted for one of their specials: a 5-ounce fillet with a crab and lobster cake for $26. It came with garlic mashed potatoes, mixed vegetables (broccoli, carrot, red pepper strips and zucchini) and that wonderful parmesan-encrusted tomato that comes with many Brio dishes.

This was a plateful of food. And it was all fabulous. The steak was cooked perfectly (rare to medium-rare). The crab and lobster cake was rich, contained very little filler and sat in a tasty sauce of some type. The potatoes were well-peppered, so they didn't just look like a lump of white on the plate. The vegetables were well-seasoned. And I just love that tomato with its crispy outside and perfectly intact tomato.

The breadbasket at Brio is always inviting with the seeded flatbread triangles and sourdough bread, along with a plate of butter.

Paul was outstanding with his check-ins to ensure all was going well. Waters were refilled any time they got to half-full. And he brought over the dessert offerings. We had to decline.

I had hefty to-go vessels, including the remaining carpaccio, the bread and butter, and half of my meal.

This was stellar from beginning to end.

I came here with my family at around 11am, no lines and we were seated right away. It took them over 30 minutes to bring out my family's food! Even something as simple as Pho should NOT take that long to bring out. I ordered the number 41, the canh bun. It has good flavor but was very lacking in noodles. I only got like 3 balls of meat in my dish as well. The pho broth is pretty normal, nothing special. My younger brother's rice dish with grilled chicken and shrimp was pretty good though! The chicken was extremely tender and the shrimp was also cooked well. Pho Cali is good if your family have the Viet food cravings after splurging on American buffets over at Circus Circus/Silver Legacy, but don't expect to get in and out very quickly.

What's to say about Ted Drewes? It's delicious. I like the Cindermint concrete and the Johnny Rabbit concrete. On Friday  night I had the Johnny Rabbit (cherries and chocolate chips). Yum! I took my grandmother and she had the Terramizzou. She was thrilled and hadn't been there in years. Go there. It's delicious!

The food was great, but the service was horrible! Had the chargrilled oysters for my appetizer. AMAZING! I wanted to suck the shell! My Mediterranean crab salad was so-so. Just crab, lettuce, and dressing. It needed something else. The restaurant was very convenient, since it was in the hotel. I'll go back for oysters at the bar, but that's about it.

I have heard so much about Cafe Mosaics and when I finally got there I wasn't disappointed. They serve vegetarian fare and there's a sign on the door that says "Tofu Rulz!" I was sold at Tofu. They know what to do with those tasteless blocks of soy so that you don't miss meat for a millisecond. I ordered the surprise burrito, with tofu, rice, cheese, teriyaki, cilantro spicy salsa and sour cream. It was huge, and I was only going to eat half, but I couldn't ... stop ... myself. My lunch was delicious, and I'll be back to try other things on the menu. They unapologetically play rock loudly here. In fact, there's even a sign above the counter that says "we don't take music requests. We like our rock and we like it loud." The service is efficient, if lacking a bit in personality. I found the servers were a bit stand-offish, like one might expect in too-cool-to-smile-at-you Toronto. And there's no debit, which is kind of annoying. But the food was excellent, and I'll go again.

My name is Dave and I am a recovering Wrap of Kahn addict. I OW'd at Parrilla a few years ago. That's right, I Over Wrapped and had to crawl out on my hands and knees. It all started when I started working near by and it was an easy lunch option. They started renovating the place into the den of wrapture that it is now just to make us all so comfy we could lie there on our silk pillows and stuff more corn salsa in. I think what sent me over the edge was the Gorgonzola.  Why do they have to put it on everything? Is there opium in that cheese? Is that hiw they got me hooked. Well it didn't work. It sent me into rehab.

Now that I have had quite a few sobering slices at LuLu's, I can go back and have salmon wraps and buffalo wraps, but never the siren wrap of kahn.

I come here every so often. I like that its close to my apt and its on the water. 

Im here on some holidays. They have a huge buffet for them, so on big holidays I will feast out! 

Their food is good! Caesar salad amazing! Love their crabcakes! Great fish tacos! Yummy warm bread and soft butter. 

They are very pricey! Its an upscale type of restaurant so that is expected and it's on the water. However, I still come in my gym clothes and sit at the bar to eat, but honestly, I can careless about what I look like. I still pay the same price as everyone else. Still spend money! Plus I will stop in, eat at bar, and leave. So dont feel you have to be dressed up because its fine dinning. 

I give it 4 Stars because at Happy Hour time I will come in to eat food at Happy Hour prices. Well, the prices are cheaper on the crab-cakes but they are beyond small. They cut the portions way down with price too. I Still spent $40 when I just got salad, crab-cakes and 1 cocktail. And the serving sizes were small! 

Its also very different looking in there. Old and country like. I really dont know what else to call it. Just so you know, its not a hangout place at all. Just a dinner experience. Or they hold events there, think they are big for that. Its huge in there. Plenty of parking too! 

You should try them out, just as long as you go in knowing what to expect. 

Hope my review helps you!

Three Muses felt more like a cool hangout spot than anything else. The Jazz band that was playing that night played some great tunes. The lighting is mellow and just added to the vibe. I consider myself a Jazzy type of guy, so this was up my alley. 

It was made very clear during the reservation process that this was for a special occasion, a Birthday event to be more specific. Not sure that I expected anything much, but I hoped they would at least acknowledge it. The waitress must have mixed the reservation...who knows? But her acknowledgment was a "happy anniversary". smh!
When you are getting ready to spend big dough, this becomes an issue. Its all in the details. Just ask the people at Commander's Palace.

Moving on to the food. Its Tapas with the price tag of an upscale restaurant. Not sure I get all the fuss about this place. The food is not bad, but it is seriously overpriced. If you and your date want to leave on a full stomach, be ready to drop $100. It didn't make any sense.

Call me a glutton! 

Their burritos are obscene and delicious!  I always  finish every bite! 

Chipotle is my favorite Mexican franchise over Pancheros and Qdoba for sure! 

The food is fresher and not as salty. 

Decor is a bit modern and cold but oh well.  Its not like you're there for an hour. 

I had the streak on this visit. Most chunks were really good - some too tough. 

Guac is pretty good & I like their light chips.

Oh man...I keep seeing places on here that I have never reviewed yet come to all the time.  Forgive me Amber Indian!!!

On a side note, I can only rate this place for the Lunch Buffet as I have never come here for dinner.

The buffet is outstanding!  So many choices and variety from vegetarian options to some with meat.  3 different kinds of rice and all the naan you can possibly stomach without exploding....and explode you will...because you will easily over-indulge here on the choices and deliciousness of them all.


Is this the BEST Indian food I've had? no....but it sure is the best Indian Buffet I've had.


if half stars were possible, I'd give this place a 4.5 honestly.  Amazing, but not perfect

I dig Three Muses, because it's close to the touristy French Quarter, but is so totally, refreshingly Marigny.  It, like the Uptown Delachaise, which I also visited on my most recent trip to the Crescent City, is a gastropub/winebar with small plates and a decent selection of wine and draft beers.

Be advised that the plates are indeed quite small.  If you're starving, I'd say you could easily put away three of them yourself.  My friend and I had two each, plus dessert, and weren't super full when we left.  Seating is also limited and the seats by the door were absolutely freezing!  It was a warm evening in late November, but the doors were open and cold air was blowing on us.  Eventually we moved to the bar when two seats opened up there.

You order at the bar, which seems to somehow work better here than it did at Delachaise.  The food runner was sweet as pie!  There is an impressive vegetarian portion of the menu, of which we sampled the feta fries, falafel bites, housemade rigatoni, and miticana gratin, all of which were totally yum.  For dessert: chocolate heaven and banana-marscapon struedel.  I'm drooling over the memory of eating it.

The band playing was just freaking excellent.  I had a 9:00 Fringe Fest show to be at, so we missed most of their show, but what we saw / heard was super.

I'd definitely visit again, next trip down south.

Totally did not know what to expect when I first got to New Orleans. Desperate to try to find a place to grub and ended up here. To my surprise everyone was so nice at the restaurant. They do say its that southern hospitality. 

Grilled trout with sweet potato and corn grits:
This fish was Delicious!! very flavorful and cooked to perfection. The meat wasn't too tough and soft enough to my likely. 
The sweet potato was also on point. Equal amount of sweet, salt and mash. 
Usually the grits I've had don't have much flavor but these corn grits where mmm mm  good!!

Sweet Tea: it was decent, just maybe a little too sweet.

I highly recommend this place to try and promise you don't be disappointed.

This shop rite is always clean and the environment is always welcoming. The hot food stations are okay. The Chinese Buffett area is subpar however as you can notice right away the processed taste in the sweet chicken that they save. The grill however is another story. The jerk chicken which is very popular is generally good. Some hit and miss days, but I would say 90% of the time is has very good flavor. The staff are friendly and although it's generally packed, everything is organized and smooth flowing. I just say the sweet potato pie in the bakery section *not the regular one, the Eickhoffs Bakery Swet Potato pie is the BEST pie I have ever tasted. I brought it to work and all my co workers say the same thing. I kid you not, if you like sweets, try it...you won't ever regret it!

I am writing an update on this review as I came here often specifically for the sweet potato pies they sell in the bakery labeled eickoffs sweet potato pie. I had wondered why they were no longer selling them and decided to ask on of the enployees who worked there. She indicated that people complained about the pies being burned and being too sweet. WHAT! They were absolutely the best. Please if there is any management who follows these reviews, please take heed and address this issue. I knew many who bought these pies and loved them and am extremely disappointed that this has now become a seasonal produ
It's nice seafood place sushis and rolls are really good. Service is good. Comfortable and nice atmosphere. Cocktail was so so

Holy eff. 

The Southern Caviar burger. The sauces. The onion rings. 
Same bat time - same bat channel!
I'll be back.

Good food, beer, and scene. Just know that it's a happening place for big sport events so get there early if thats why you're going and I mean early otherwise youll be standing. Burritos and nachos are awesome, if you like Spicey try the stash!

I had a wonderful evening there.
Nice, fresh and well prepared tapas, friendly staff, tasty drinks and amazing atmosphere.

Gulf fish Cevice: excellent. Fish well prepared. The blend  of the sweet mango with the herbs and fish really bring this cevice to life. Too bad that dish (and that's my only complain) was way over-salted.

Pork belly: cooked to perfection. delicate (not oily) and well seasoned.

Lamb sliders: perfect patty seasoning and great tomatoes puree.
but the best of all tapas was....
The shrimps tempura. bit sour, bit sweet, crunchy, perfectly cooked.it's a modern version of the tempura where the shrimps are not deep fried but the crush is actually spread over the shrimps. EXCELLENT.
Fries are fries.

The best of this place is the jazz band that was playing that night. Amazing skilled and talented musicians while you enjoy delicate food. Everything was perfect!

Note: you must book a table with operable otherwise you'll have 1 to 2 hours wait.

I went here for lunch the other day with a buddy of mine off my recomondation via yelp of course....lol.  Anyways, it looked like it was gonna be a good find.   We pull up and it just so happens theres a parking lot about a 100 feet from the place.   So that was convenient.  We got there right at 11:30am the time they were supposed to open...There was no sign of life inside and there was 2 Asian dudes sitting at the front door waiting to get in as well.  So, I took a wild guess and asked them if they worked there, and they said YES....Lucky guess I suppose....I asked where the people were with the key and they said 5 mins away in a cab....Um okay, so 15 mins later a carload of chefs and waiters arrive and we go in....I was a little pissed, but figured no biggie, lets give this spot a try bc I saw all the great reviews and pictures on yelp.   

Well I'm glad I DID!!!!   We get inside and the place was very clean and pretty cool looking....Our waiter was very attentive especially I think bc he was 1 of the dudes outside waiting with us, lol...However, they have a GREAT menu with a lot of options...I had some eel sushi which was very good and my buddy had some assortment platter thing...Now, the best thing though was the "One night stand roll" I ordered!!!!!   IT WAS FREAKING SLAMMING!!!!!!!!!!   It had salmon and tuna wrapped around spicy, crunchy crab!!!!!    NO RICE!!!!!!   Banging!!!!!    All the food was well worth all the BS I went through up till this point.   Also, the presentation of the food when it comes out is awesome too, make sure you have ur camera!!!!  I'd definitely go back, but I'd just give them a little more time to get to work  next time.  When we left it was around 12:30pm and the place was slammed too, so that's a good sign....

This tiny BYO is worth the trek over the Walt Whit. The service is astounding and the food leaves you wanting more the minute you leave the restaurant.

The menu is divided into the traditional three courses - salad, appetizer, entree (of course, all of this is in proper Italian on the menu). While they recommend that you order one item from each section, you can do whatever pleases you. We ordered a variety of dishes and all were amazing. However, do yourself a favor and definitely order the gnocchi. It melted in my mouth and made me sad I had only ordered a half portion. 

Each course was paced nicely and the bread they give the table is to die for. I could have made a meal on that alone.

Bring a few friends, a few bottles of wine and be prepared to put this restaurant on your list of favorites. Can't wait to go back!

I thought this small grocery store was by far one of the best stocked and offering the most variety that we went to on our trip.  They had a huge pre-made area with sandwiches, cubed cheese packets, hummus, etc. to grab and go.  I also loved that they had a huge selection of coconut water to rehydrate after a long night and give you that boost before your walking tour.  The bloody mary fixing selection was off the chart with everything pickled in a jar that you could imagine.

The prices were a bit higher since they are in the French Quarter but, really not much more than anywhere else and to be able to find high quality foods and everything you want you will pay more.

I will definitely seek this place out again to do a little shopping while in the French Quarter or not!

This place has a very casual vibe and amazing views! They have a full bar and both indoor and outdoor seating. For lunch I had the grouper sandwich grilled. It is served on a fresh roll and the fish was so fresh and full of flavor! The burger was also an easy classic option. Both served with fries.

I was in the mood for a burger today & tried Five Guys.  It was a decent experience.  I ordered the "Little Burger" which was plenty big.  I love that you can add free toppings to it.  I went with lettuce, tomato, grilled onions, mushrooms, & A1 steak sauce.  In addition I ordered fries.  The burger was excellent.  The fries were plentiful but definitely greasy.  The fries even tasted unhealthy due to all the grease.  The bag the fries came in became soaked with grease.  The star of the show was thus the very good burger.

I always see this BWWs on my way home from Marsh Creek and I was starving, so I decided to stop.  I came during game day and I must say that they have so many TVs that this is the perfect place you can watch the game with a beer.  However, I got two different plates of wings and one was good, but the other one was terrible and dry.  The service here is really good.
Quick 24hr caffeine stop if you need a break from the war on I4 between Tampa and Orlando.

I travel a lot and have been to WF across the country.  This was by far the worst I've seen.   

Stayed at a nearby hotel and wanted to pick up something from the WF deli to have for a quick dinner.... The deli was horrendous.  Salad bar looked sad, "Korean" hot food section had 2 scraped at pans with hardened sauce that looked like they had sat for hours and some hard rice.  Deli line was long and did not move at all so abandoned hope.  Premade food was limited to mini salads, 2 half wraps and 1 noodle dish.  Everything else was a packaged sweet like brownies.  Other WF have much much better selection!!! 

Also a lot of items did not have prices!  This is normally not too much of a problem but at whole foods it could lead to you overpaying and buying a $30 jar of moisturizer or $25 candle ..... 

Ended up leaving hungry and with only a container of bath salts....

What more can you say one of the best sandwich places in town and it's cool because it's only in Arizona when many of my friends visit from out-of-state always make sure I bring them here so they can get themselves and Eegee!
A lot of my East Coast friends say that it reminds them of Italian ice I say it's even better than Italian ice.
With a variety of sandwiches packed full of flavor you can't go wrong with this place, not to mention their french fries especially when you dip them in ranch some of the best Rancho find around it's perfect and fries and with their salads.
And with the ever changing flavor of the month you're always good.

I really enjoy Santa Fe and their diverse menu. They have some beautiful fish dishes including a whole fish, some standard Mexican dishes such as enchiladas and tacos and some unusual items like fish and chips as a special or the steak with yucca fries or this chicken dish filled and covered with tons of flavor (not remembering the name). I've been here a dozen times and it's always good. Great margaritas too and a huge covered porch lined in fans. It's a relaxing space with a homey neighborhood feel.

I have only ever been to the brunch. You really can't complain about 6.95 brunch. Great omelet station. The french toast is awesome. Beware- you see your fare share of grease. In other words, not for the calorie counter. But, just like everything else that's unhealthy for you, its delicious!

Was told by a few locals this is the spot for beignets.... it was eh... dough was too dense for my liking and a little bland. The iced cappuccino was weak. Service was good though.  The only thing I loved about this place was the outside seating. It was a perfect day with a light breeze. So we sat for a while and listen to a few guys play some music.

Cool place next to Cigar City Cedar & Mead in Ybor. Very quiet little tasting room on the corner of 15th and 8th. I stopped by with friends on a Saturday afternoon after hearing about the opening a while back and not yet having tried it! The bartenders were very welcoming and offered us many tastings from the menu. They also have started a moonshine collection with mainly spicy selections. The main vodka menu is large and I liked pretty much all of the samples I tried. While we did not end up buying a take home bottle that day, we tipped the staff and thanked them kindly for their hospitality. I think this place has tons of potential! Give it a try!
